webTitle: Lord Alli damns white domination of Whitehall

fields.headline: Lord Alli damns white domination of Whitehall
fields.trailText: June 27 2000: Not enough ethnic minorities in the corridors of power, says Blair peer.
fields.body:
A close ally of the prime minister, Tony Blair, last night damned the civil service for its white domination.

Lord Alli said progress among senior mandarins was so slow that it would take nearly two centuries for ethnic minorities to be fairly represented at the top of the civil service .

Giving the annual Greenwich Lecture in London in memory of three murdered black students, including Stephen Lawrence, Lord Alli said senior civil servants prided themselves on being meritocratic. "But they are to a man - and woman - white," said the millionaire business man. "Put at its clearest - and bluntest - 0% of the very top civil servants are black.

"There are no black permanent secretaries. There are no black ambassadors. Is this a reflection of the world we live in?"

Lord Alli said the time had come for Britain to have its first black ambassador and called for a "step change" in the slow progress in promoting black talent.

Just 1.7% of the top 3,000 civil servants are black or Asian, compared to over 5% of the working population.

Lord Alli said: "At the current rate it will take 190 years before our communities are fairly represented in the most senior ranks of the civil ser vice. We cannot wait that long."

He added: "My challenge now to government ministers - black and white - is to take the action needed to deliver what we promised. Put the undoubted energy and intelligence of your senior civil servants into seeking out black talent.

"And if you cannot find a suitable candidate to be Britain's first black ambassador or permanent secretary, let us help you find the right people to do these jobs."

Recent Cabinet Office figures show that the proportion of black and Asian top civil servants fell between from 1.8% in 1989 to 1.7% in 1999.

The government has vowed to double the number by 2005 to 3.2% amid allegations that the "old boy network" is hampering progress.

The government figures showed that black and Asian staff were paid up to pounds 3,500 less than white colleagues, and were more likely to resign .

A Cabinet Office spokeswoman would not respond directly to Lord Alli's attack but said: "We have a strong commitment to equal opportunities and we value the diversity of our staff.

"We fully recognise that people from ethnic minorities are underepresented at senior levels, that is why a key part of the programme to modernise the civil service is to achieve a dramatic increase in diversity and to tackle under representation.

"We therefore set challenging targets to double the representation of ethnic minorities in the senior civil service by 2005."

Lord Alli also attacked the Conservative leader, William Hague, over his demands for tougher asylum and immigration policies. He suggested he was worse than Enoch Powell.

Lord Alli also called for a new "contract" between the black population in London and the Metropolitan police.

This would involve the Met giving commitments to the black community and, in return, receiving more encouragement for young blacks to join the force.

fields.headline: What the European papers say
fields.trailText:
Marca Spain
"Raul made Spain cry. There were tears in the stands; it wasn't quite what we expected from Raul. In fact, it was the last thing we expected from him. Tuesday is his 23rd birthday. It will be, without doubt, the saddest of his life."

"Raul made Spain cry. There were tears in the stands; it wasn't quite what we expected from Raul. In fact, it was the last thing we expected from him. Tuesday is his 23rd birthday. It will be, without doubt, the saddest of his life."

As Spain
"Whereas Zidane was the life and soul of his side, Raul was a shadow of himself and never really got started."

Glas Javnosti Yugoslavia
"This is a slap in the eye as Yugoslavia were completely humiliated by the rampant co-hosts. It was a debacle; an utter fiasco."

De Volkskrant Holland
"As national coach, Frank Rijkaard has unquestionably grown in his role. The uncertain steps of the preparations have been replaced with confident strides at just the right time. The lethargic and fragile team has become an aggressive collective that earns respect with every match."

De Telegraaf Holland
"In a swirling De Kuip the army of fans were served up with one of the best ever Dutch displays. Holland show-ed for the first time in this tournament that they have the faces of true champions."

Corriere dello Sport Italy
"So how much fear is it right to have? In truth, it's best that the Azzurri aren't too scared at all."

L'Equipe France
"According to Gary Lineker, football is a match between two teams of 11 men and Germany win in the end. Nowadays his famous comment appears to apply to France."

webTitle: The fall and rise of Craig White

fields.headline: The fall and rise of Craig White
fields.standfirst: David Hopps on the all-rounder back with England after mishap
fields.trailText: David Hopps on the all-rounder back with England after a mishap.
fields.body:
Only a month after Craig White lost consciousness and collapsed in a rain-soaked gutter in a Scarborough sidestreet he returns to the England squad for Thursday's Lord's Test against West Indies convinced that the terrifying experience has brought him a more relaxed perspective towards the pressures of international sport.

The blare of ambulance sirens, the prolonged fretting of his wife and family and the anxious series of heart and brain scans that followed are all memories that will scar the Yorkshire all-rounder forever. A man who knows what it is like to fear for his life should not worry unduly about the outcome of a cricket match.

Ignore the caricatures about how a Yorkshire birthplace and Australian upbringing should have left White impervious to criticism. He has tended to be the worrying kind; indeed, it has probably limited his development at international level.

But now he insists: "My attitude towards playing has changed. I'm just going out to do my best and bollocks to what anyone thinks or writes. I will do my utmost to win but it is just a game that should be enjoyed. I've realised that your health is more important than anything."

White has received no medical explanation for his collapse, only assurances that he did not suffer a heart attack and the knowledge that a series of brain scans revealed nothing untoward.

Had the weather been fine in Scarborough that Tuesday he might, as a keen biker, have donned his leathers and taken his 1,000cc Yamaha for a spin around the more deserted roads of the North Yorkshire moors. The implications of that are too horrendous to contemplate. Instead the rain came in off the east coast and he chose to get out the car and drive the short distance into town.

"I'd just driven into Scarborough to buy a few toiletries," he recalled. "I'd walked down the road for about 100 yards when I felt a sharp pain in my chest. I took a deep breath and a couple of strides and then I remember everything going dizzy and grey.

"When I woke up I was lying in a gutter down a sidestreet, about 10 yards further down the road. It was raining and blood was flowing out of my chin. I was in the recovery position and a lady was ringing an ambulance. I couldn't remember how I had got there. I must have walked the last 10 yards without even knowing."

White was left with a twisted knee - "I must have gone down with a right wallop" - that delayed his return to the Yorkshire side. He has returned much like his old self.

"You don't collapse for no reason and it is disturbing that the doctors couldn't find an explanation," he said. "But I've had the all-clear and I can't just sit around waiting for it to happen again."

The death of Wilf Slack, the former Middlesex and England batsman, still haunts cricket. He collapsed and died in The Gambia 11 years ago, after several previous blackouts at the crease. The postmortem examination concluded that he was suffering from Wolfe-Parkinson-White syndrome, an abnormal heartbeat, usually considered benign but which can be exacerbated by stressful occupations.

Lord's was Slack's home ground. There is no ground in the world which would give White a more sympathetic welcome.

fields.headline: Kluivert comes of age
fields.standfirst: Hat-trick has home fans hailing the new No9
fields.trailText: Patrick Kluivert's hat-trick has home fans hailing the new No9, writes Jon Brodkin.
fields.body:
Even as a little-known teenager at Ajax Patrick Kluivert was brilliant enough for Luis van Gaal to announce: "We have our own Ronaldo." But, when it comes to the moment his career turned from Oranje to gold, few will forget Sunday night.

The Barcelona player may have seen one of his four goals against Yugoslavia handed yesterday to Dejan Govedarica, who must be overcome with glee. And Frank Rijkaard may have stressed that the 6-1 victory was a team effort. But the way Edwin van der Sar bowed to Kluivert and shook his hand by the bench told its own tale.

At 23, Kluivert has won more honours and played in more tournaments than most could dream of. But even to him this match seemed to mark a change. He picked up his man of the match award with the grin of someone who had spent too long in Amsterdam's coffee shops. And his words yesterday were transparent: "I don't yet realise the importance of what I've achieved."

Kluivert proved beyond doubt that he belongs with the great strikers. Even before Sunday's ruthless hat-trick he had scored one more goal than Marco van Basten from 15 fewer internationals but not many in Holland placed him on a level with the hero of Euro 88. Now the gap is shrinking.

It is often one tournament or one match which alters the world's perception. Van Basten may already have been established at Milan in 1988 but that hat-trick against England and the unforgettable volley in the final against the Soviet Union remain enduring images.

What Kluivert dispelled on Sunday night were lingering doubts about his finishing. Some in Barcelona wondered why a player of such talent had failed in either of his two seasons at the Nou Camp to exceed 20 league goals.

Certainly the bad news for Italy is that Kluivert's assassination of Yugoslavia was achieved with "a slight problem in the upper leg". A precautionary withdrawal after an hour and warm bath after the match should have solved the problem. The player expects to be fit for Thursday.

Italy's defence will be less generous than Yugoslavia's. But, if Dino Zoff's players imagined from Kluivert's miserable year at Milan that he would be a soft touch, Sunday will have changed their minds.

Repeatedly Kluivert lost his man with impressive ease. And after heading over a Marc Overmars cross each subsequent chance was put away with ruthless efficiency. Even the Govedarica own-goal was down to his instinct and pressure. The man known in Barcelona as the Panther had pounced to devastating effect.

It has taken time for Holland to find their rhythm and gather momentum but the bandwagon is rolling now. Kluivert complained of feeling isolated in the first match and had too many long balls knocked to his head in the second but the balance has undoubtedly been found. With Dennis Bergkamp pulling the strings to fine effect behind him, Kluivert is in his element.

Rijkaard would point out that his No9 offers more than scoring talent. Good with his back to goal and quick with the ball at his feet on the edge of the box, Kluivert is a key man in directing and maintaining attacks.

Yet, with Kluivert's temperament, little can be taken for granted. Sent off at France 98, he saw red last season against Real Madrid for abusing the referee. And there also was an off-the-ball incident last term for which he was suspended. But gradually, on and off the field, his image is changing.

webTitle: Locked in when I should be jetting out

fields.headline: Locked in when I should be jetting out
fields.trailText: 27 June: I have been in the RAF for 11 years now and I want to leave. I have no enthusiasm anymore and I have become very bitter and twisted.
fields.body:
The problem

I have been in the RAF for 11 years now and I want to leave but I am trapped because the minimum notice period is 18 months. I have no enthusiasm anymore and I have become very bitter and twisted, something that has been noted at work. I feel that the RAF is ruining my life and as result, don't know where to turn. What can I do apart from grin and bear it?

Mark Askew

The solution

I can quite understand your feelings. Having to work for a year and a half once you have made the decision to quit must feel like a prison sentence. I don not see how it benefits your employer, either, since, as you point out, loyalty can be severely compromised by requiring such a long notice.

However, you are pretty much stuck with it (assuming you signed a contract confirming the leave period required) and my advice, other than to grin and bear it, is to start preparing for when you finally get out. Work on your CV, scan the job market, get careers advice, try and make use of training opportunities and generally try and get as much as you can out of your employer in terms of marketable skills. I would also advise you to hide your feelings at work - after all, these are the people who will be giving you references, so why ruin eleven years of building up a good name?

An alternative strategy would be not to serve your notice, but there are likely to be all sorts of penalties for going down this route. If you really feel that you cannot bear to carry on, take legal advice. Otherwise, hang on in there.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Eugene Onegin
fields.standfirst:
***
Grange Park Opera
fields.trailText: "It's very quaint but somewhat rustic," sings Onegin as he enters the Larins' house in act one of Tchaikovsky's opera. That same description could apply to Grange Park, a dilapidated mansion deep in the Hampshire countryside. Grange Park uses the Glyndebourne idea of opera as social occasion; it's probably the closest thing to a private opera company most music-lovers ever get to see.
fields.body:
"It's very quaint but somewhat rustic," sings Onegin as he enters the Larins' house in act one of Tchaikovsky's opera. That same description could apply to Grange Park, a dilapidated mansion deep in the Hampshire countryside. Grange Park uses the Glyndebourne idea of opera as social occasion; it's probably the closest thing to a private opera company most music-lovers ever get to see.

The encouraging thing, though, is that the organisers of Grange Park are artistically ambitious, giving young professionals a chance to perform major roles alongside more experienced singers. This performance of Onegin boasted a decent chorus and orchestra. David Lloyd-Jones conducted as the performers sang his own translation. Some of his tempi were a little brisk, the syncopations in the accompaniments falling over each other, but he drew some rich passages of expression out of his players. The soloists were also rather hemmed in by the small auditorium - of the principals, only Jeffrey Lloyd-Roberts's Lensky really managed to reach a convincing piano. The first aria after a dinner interval always receives enthusiastic applause; in Lloyd-Roberts's case it was at least deserved.

Majella Cullagh sang Tatyana with a nice bright tone, but without a great range of expression. Robert Poulton, singing solidly in the title role, was unlikely in that Ian Judge's staging had made his the most problematic character. Onegin should seduce Tatyana through brooding, animal attraction alone: she has read enough books to know from their first meeting that he's no knight in shining armour, and she calls him her "tempter" rather than her love. But he was made to prance on in dark glasses and then size up Tatyana and her sister like a workman calculating the cost of house repairs. The tragedy of the opera was too often undermined by such overdone attempts to lighten the atmosphere, proving that while you can't destroy the score of Onegin, you can lessen its impact.

&#149 In rep till July 14. Box office: 01420 565690.

webTitle: £56m for founder as Carphone floats at £1.6bn

fields.headline: £56m for founder as Carphone floats at £1.6bn
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest independent mobile phone retailer, yesterday set a valuation on the business of £1.6bn ahead of its long-awaited stock market flotation next month.
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse, Europe's largest independent mobile phone retailer, yesterday set a valuation on the business of £1.6bn ahead of its long-awaited stock market flotation next month.

Founder Charles Dunstone will cash in some £56m from selling shares in the offer and will be left with around 38% of the company, while the chief operating officer, David Ross, is banking £42m. A last minute change to the ratio of new to old shares being sold has reduced the amount they are both pocketing.

The directors of the company will be barred from selling any further shares for at least 12 months.

The valuation is slightly lower than previous estimates suggested by advisers which had placed a range of £1.6bn to £2bn on the business.

The price range published yesterday was 170p to 220p a share with the mid-point valuation of £1.6bn. Copies of the prospectus will be available from Carphone Warehouse stores from today with conditional trading in the shares beginning on July 14.

The change in ratio between new and existing shares being sold in the offer means the amount raised for the business will be roughly the same as previous indications at £180m.

Mr Dunstone said the company had so far met with a positive response since the announcement that the company intended to float.

"The reaction we are getting from potential investors is that they like the combination of a company with very strong sales and earnings growth but which operates in a very fast moving and fast growing sector," he said.

Around one-third of the proceeds from the flotation will be used to reduce debt and a further third will be used to fund the continued expansion of Carphone Warehouse across mainland Europe. The company has 450 stores in Britain and a further 430 or so trading under the Phone House name throughout countries including France, Germany and the Netherlands.

The remainder will be used to develop its other services including Value Telecom, which repackages One2One airtime under the Carphone-owned brand, and Mviva, the group's wireless internet portal.

"We've got the firepower now to the deals we need to do," said Mr Ross.

As of March this year there were 173m mobile phone subscribers in western Europe with the number set to grow to 220m by the end of 2004.

Mr Dunstone said the greater complexity added by wireless internet coupled with the anticipated huge demand for replacement handsets made Carphone Warhouse's independent advice a strong selling point.

The company last week announced that retail investors who agree not to sell their shares for three months would receive priority in the allocation of the offer.

The scheme was devised to stabilise the share price in the weeks after the flotation.

Copies of the prospectus will be available from Carphone Warehouse stores from today with conditional trading in the shares beginning on July 14. The change in ratio between new and existing shares being sold in the offer means the amount raised for the business will be roughly the same as previous indications at £180m. Mr Dunstone said the company had so far met with a positive response since the announcement that the company intended to float. "The reaction we are getting from potential investors is that they like the combination of a company with very strong sales and earnings growth but which operates in a very fast moving and fast growing sector," he said. Around one-third of the proceeds from the flotation will be used to reduce debt and a further third will be used to fund the continued expansion of Carphone Warehouse across mainland Europe. The company has 450 stores in Britain and a further 430 or so trading under the Phone House name throughout countries including France, Germany and the Netherlands. The remainder will be used to develop its other services including Value Telecom, which repackages One2One airtime under the Carphone-owned brand, and Mviva, the group's wireless internet portal. "We've got the firepower now to the deals we need to do," said Mr Ross. As of March this year there were 173m mobile phone subscribers in western Europe with the number set to grow to 220m by the end of 2004. Mr Dunstone said the greater complexity added by wireless internet coupled with the anticipated huge demand for replacement handsets made Carphone Warhouse's independent advice a strong selling point. The company last week announced that retail investors who agree not to sell their shares for three months would receive priority in the allocation of the offer. The scheme was devised to stabilise the share price in the weeks after the flotation.

webTitle: OECD tells 19 to close tax loopholes

fields.headline: OECD tells 19 to close tax loopholes
fields.standfirst:
Think-tank seeks to clean up its own house after havens clampdown

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, the developed nations' think-tank, yesterday accused 19 of its own members of operating tax loopholes which could enable wealthy companies and individuals to escape paying their bills to the state. Britain, however, was one of only three EU countries to escape censure from the OECD.
fields.body:
The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, the developed nations' think-tank, yesterday accused 19 of its own members of operating tax loopholes which could enable wealthy companies and individuals to escape paying their bills to the state. Britain, however, was one of only three EU countries to escape censure from the OECD.

The Paris-based body listed 47 tax loopholes allowed by its member states. They ranged from offshore banking units in Australia to foreign sales corporations in the US - already under fire from the World Trade Organisation - which it said could potentially contribute to harmful tax competition.

Yesterday's move by the OECD to clean up its own house came after it had named 35 countries, mostly small island states, which it said are operating as tax havens.

The OECD countries on its list have until 2003 to eliminate harmful tax practices; the non-OECD tax havens have until July next year to cooperate with its investigation.

Gabriel Makhlouf, a British inland revenue official who has been chairing the work of the OECD, told a news conference it was impossible to put a figure on how much annually was lost through harmful tax competition, but noted that Oxfam said tax havens drained $50bn from developing countries alone each year.

"That in itself is a pretty big number. Harmful tax competition undermines the ability of democratically elected governments to provide the services voted for by their citizens, undermines the integrity of tax systems and causes an undesired shift of part of the tax burden from geographically mobile to less mobile tax bases."

The OECD hailed yesterday's report as a landmark for international cooperation to elimi nate tax evasion. But there are signs already that its fragile consensus mode of operation might be under strain.

Luxembourg and Switzerland, two of the OECD members criticised, abstained from endorsing the original report which launched the tax loopholes investigation two years ago. While both cooperated with production of the latest list, the Luxembourg government said yesterday it was under no obligation to change any of its tax rules.

OECD sources drew encouragement from the fact that the two had agreed to have their tax loopholes included in yesterday's list.

webTitle: Investors furious as EMI deal approved

fields.headline: Investors furious as EMI deal approved
fields.standfirst: 2,000 redundancies loom
fields.trailText: EMI's chairman Eric Nicoli faced a chorus of disharmony yesterday as disgruntled private shareholders reluctantly approved the music group's £12bn merger with US rival Time Warner.
fields.body:
EMI's chairman Eric Nicoli faced a chorus of disharmony yesterday as disgruntled private shareholders reluctantly approved the music group's £12bn merger with US rival Time Warner.

A counter-bid to break up the deal has failed to materialise, and many investors expressed anger that Time Warner will have control of a proposed joint venture between the two groups.

Under pressure from questioners at an extraordinary general meeting, Mr Nicoli admitted that the terms were far from perfect: "I recognise that it is not absolutely ideal but I think it is the right thing to do."

The controversial agreement gives Time Warner six directors on the board of the joint venture, against EMI's five. Both groups will nominate co-chairmen but Time Warner has the right to veto EMI's choice.

One investor said: "This is, in broad terms, a takeover by Warner but they don't have the guts to make an offer." Another shareholder, John Farmer, said: "If you and your board are as good as you would have us believe, it is surely a mistake to relinquish that control."

Mr Nicoli defended the deal, saying it would create "the world's premier music company", with the firepower to take advantage of new distribution channels using the internet. He said the transaction was structured as a partnership for tax reasons, and he suggested the make-up of the board was unimportant because members would usually agree anyway: "It's unlikely we'll find ourselves voting very often, if ever."

The meeting was packed with several hundred investors at the Waldorf Hotel in central London. Nearly all the speakers were opposed to the deal. One said: "I just don't see why it's advantageous to shareholders and to the industry as a whole."

Mr Nicoli insisted the transaction had received "overwhelming support" from EMI's employees and from artists on the group's books - who include the Spice Girls, Robbie Williams and David Bowie.

However, he admitted 2,000 redundancies were likely when one shareholder asked: "How many of the employees who've given you overwhelming support are going to be laid off?"

EMI cannot complete the deal until it receives approval from the European Commission, which has launched an investigation expected to last up to four months. Mr Nicoli said he was "absolutely confident" any competition concerns could be addressed.

He insisted that the group had heard nothing about a bid from a rival consortium, tipped to include the US private equity firm Hicks Muse, Spanish telecoms company Telefonica, German media group Bertelsmann and Hong Kong's Pacific Century Cyberworks. Proxy votes from institutional shareholders meant the deal was approved and EMI's shares rose 15.5p to 656p.

fields.headline: A Touch of Glass
fields.standfirst:
Jarvis Cocker **

Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Jarvis Cocker
**

Smog
***

Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body:
Jarvis Cocker has all the stage presence of a garden rake. You could make your own Cocker at home, using a couple of pipecleaners and an old sock, and it would be no worse than the real thing. Yet he has no shortage of fans. At the Festival Hall, he was ostensibly supporting Smog, current darlings of the music press, but many punters had bowled up to see Cocker's ad hoc ensemble A Touch of Glass.

In classic indie-pop-goes-art mode, Cocker had assembled a bunch of louche instrumentals that wouldn't be too difficult for him to play on his dinky electronic keyboard, plus two songs for good measure. As his combo meandered through their three-chord ambient stuff, given weird colourings by a bizarre keyboard device called a "glass harmonica", it was pleasant, but scarcely compelling. A version of Cocker's song from Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased), My Baby May Die, was rendered whimsical by a chorus he introduced as the Swingle Singers. Finally, there was a perfunctory trot through Scott Walker's On Your Own Again, which seemed to end before it had started properly. "More like A Touch of Arse," grumbled the bloke behind me.

Smog ***

Then Smog did their cool and detached thing at considerable length, main man Bill Callahan growling out his barbed, quizzical lyrics in a dark brown baritone while his fellow Smog-men assembled backdrops that ranged from limpid and melancholic to fast, furious and metallic. If you were seeking comparisons, you could point to the expressionless nihilism of the Velvet Underground or the anguish of Mark Eitzel, but there's something of the echoing vastness of Jimmy Webb in there too. Quite good.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Schumann's crusade
fields.standfirst:
Genoveva
****
Garsington Festival, Oxfordshire
fields.trailText: Some 150 years to the day since its premiere in Leipzig, Schumann's only opera, Genoveva, at last received its first professional performance in Britain at this year's Garsington Festival. The opera's neglect is partly to do with its proximity to Wagner's rise: 1850 was also the year of the premiere of Lohengrin. But there are parallels between Schumann's opera and Wagner's cycle of music dramas. Both composers were trying to create a new vision of German opera, and both drew on medieval images and legends.
fields.body:
Some 150 years to the day since its premiere in Leipzig, Schumann's only opera, Genoveva, at last received its first professional performance in Britain at this year's Garsington Festival. The opera's neglect is partly to do with its proximity to Wagner's rise: 1850 was also the year of the premiere of Lohengrin. But there are parallels between Schumann's opera and Wagner's cycle of music dramas. Both composers were trying to create a new vision of German opera, and both drew on medieval images and legends.

Genoveva starts off as an apparently tragic tale of boiling lust and lurid revenge. The story is set in France during the crusades, although Aidan Lang's production confidently creates a mythological timelessness. Siegfried, Genoveva's husband and lord of the castle, leaves to fight the Moors, leaving Genoveva with his trusted friend Golo. But Golo, in league with the vengeful witchcraft of Margaretha, cannot contain his feelings for Genoveva. Genoveva rejects him, and Golo deviously and murderously manages to force Genoveva into prison. Eventually, Golo is forced into suicide and, via some divine intervention, Siegfried and Genoveva are happily re-united.

The problems with this plot come in the third and fourth acts, in the turn from character-led drama to static redemption tableau. But Lang negotiates this transformation sensitively, pairing the joy of the central couple with Margaretha's traumatic conversion to Christianity. Kathyrn Turpin's portrayal of the witch is visually stunning, as she convincingly veers from demented harpy to wronged mother. But it is only in her third-act aria that it is possible to hear her; otherwise, she has problems penetrating through Schumann's exuberant orchestrations and Elgar Howarth's equally enthusiastic conducting.

Musically, Genoveva is wonderfully rich. There are some thrilling arias - especially Genoveva's in the fourth act, superbly sung and acted by Susannah Glanville - and impressive set-pieces. Schumann's pacing is, for the most part, expertly judged, and he uses a tight collection of melodies for the opera's principal dramatic motives. Glanville's performance is outstanding, but the other main roles are equally well served. Nigel Robson fumes with conviction as Golo, while Johannes Mannov's Siegfried imbues a difficult part with vocal and dramatic strength.

The final victor of the evening is Schumann. Genoveva is not without its problems, but then how many of the warhorses of the operatic canon are completely flawless? Revealing that there is more to mid-19th century German opera than Wagner, Genoveva deserves to be seen more widely. Garsington's production is a successful first staging for British audiences; by one of those millennial coincidences, a production by Opera North will soon be the second.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: A different planet
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia Orchestra/ Leonard Slatkin and Evelyn Glennie
***
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText: Michael Daugherty's percussion concerto UFO, which was given its British premiere by Leonard Slatkin and the Philharmonia, was composed with Evelyn Glennie's extraordinary talents in mind. A vision of the American obsession with all things extraterrestrial, Glennie is cast as a silver-clad alien at the work's opening. Rigged up to some sophisticated live electronics, she processed through a darkened Royal Festival Hall, producing strange vocal utterances and weird, industrial scrapings. Four aliens-cum-percussionists appeared in the Festival Hall's boxes, and the scene was set for the visual and sonic spectacular of Daugherty's piece.
fields.body:
Michael Daugherty's percussion concerto UFO, which was given its British premiere by Leonard Slatkin and the Philharmonia, was composed with Evelyn Glennie's extraordinary talents in mind. A vision of the American obsession with all things extraterrestrial, Glennie is cast as a silver-clad alien at the work's opening. Rigged up to some sophisticated live electronics, she processed through a darkened Royal Festival Hall, producing strange vocal utterances and weird, industrial scrapings. Four aliens-cum-percussionists appeared in the Festival Hall's boxes, and the scene was set for the visual and sonic spectacular of Daugherty's piece.

As a demonstration of the percussionist's range, UFO was brazenly successful. Crashing cymbals and cascades of drums were noisily impressive, while bowed vibraphones and tinkling bell-trees showed the softer side to Glennie's art. Daugherty's music is an amalgam of stock film-music stereotypes and 20th-century cliches. In classic B-movie style, clunky chromaticism and driving rhythms represent the threat of the little green men, while ethereal metallic crashes hint at their exotic allure. It all adds up to a virtuosically immediate use of orchestral resources.

But the knowingly wafer-thin substance of the music does have its drawbacks. In a toe-curling fourth section, Glennie improvised with metal bars and handfuls of squeaking rubber sausages. As music, this was lame; as theatre, it was redundant. Thankfully, the final movement at least concentrated on Glennie's musical gifts. But the maniacal repetition of a single rhythm made its point well before the end of the piece.

There was a far greater coup de thétre in Copland's Third Symphony. The whole symphony is a vision of post-war renewal and optimism, and the last movement is even based on Copland's definitively American Fanfare for the Common Man. But in the middle of a jaunty transformation of this famous tune, a powerful dissonance seemed to suggest the paranoia and insecurity - like the rise of the UFO craze - that were soon to engulf the US. Over the whole work, Slatkin and the Philharmonia achieved a winning balance between the structural strength of Copland's symphony and its obvious melodic appeal.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Boom over as London property prices start to fall

fields.headline: Boom over as London property prices start to fall
fields.standfirst:
More about house prices
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The property boom is over and former hotspots such as London will see falls in house prices over the next three months, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said yesterday.
fields.body:
The property boom is over and former hotspots such as London will see falls in house prices over the next three months, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said yesterday.

Interest rate rises, the cutting of mortgage tax relief and greedy sellers expecting too high a price for their property are to blame for the downturn, according to its monthly housing market survey.

The number of houses up for sale has increased markedly, while buyers are in short supply as affordability limits have been reached.

Worst hit is London. In March, 87% of surveyors reported price rises. But in the latest survey, covering the three months to May, only 25% reported rises while 68% said prices were static. A tenth are already seeing price falls.

"House prices have come to a standstill in London. The market is at its weakest posi tion since price falls were reported in December 1998," the RICS said.

"Not only have sales fallen since the rush to beat the Budget stamp duty rise, but the number of new buyer inquiries have also fallen sharply. Surveyors envisage slight falls in prices during the next three months."

But prices in some northern regions are still rising. Most buoyant are Yorkshire and Humberside and the north-west, with 60% of Yorkshire surveyors reporting price increases.

Despite the rescue of Rover, worries about job losses have hit the west Midlands property market hard. The region saw the sharpest acceleration in surveyors reporting price falls, from 2% in March to 26% in May.

"New inquiries have fallen in recent months, while surveyors expect a slight reduction in both prices and sales in the coming three months," the RICS reported.

Apart from a temporary blip in house prices in late 1998, the last time the UK saw generalised price falls was in the early 1990s.

Average UK prices peaked in 1989 at £62,800, bottomed out in 1995 at £51,000 and now stand at £78,000.

In London, average prices have jumped far more, rising from £73,000 in 1995 to £140,000 today, according to Nationwide building society.

Nationwide will issue its monthly price index at the end of this week, but its chief economist, Alex Bannister, said it had no plans to revise its forecast that prices will rise by an average of 14% in the 12 months to December this year.

"London and the south-east has definitely slowed, but the rest of the country is relatively buoyant.

"We are still confident that prices are not going to fall across the board," he said.

"Affordability, while difficult in some areas, is still relatively good."

fields.headline: Melting pot magnetism
fields.standfirst:
Ozomatli ****
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
fields.trailText: Aptly taking their moniker from the Aztec monkey god of dance, the 10-piece Ozomatli have a penchant for beats per minute that makes hardcore seem like a slow jam at a youth club disco. Live, their hectic mix of dizzy drum'n'bass rhythms, salsa, jazz, ska, mariachi blues and beats is epic in grand scale.
fields.body:
Aptly taking their moniker from the Aztec monkey god of dance, the 10-piece Ozomatli have a penchant for beats per minute that makes hardcore seem like a slow jam at a youth club disco. Live, their hectic mix of dizzy drum'n'bass rhythms, salsa, jazz, ska, mariachi blues and beats is epic in grand scale.

It is this knack of producing killer party riffs and choruses that elevates the songs above the humdrum. Pieces like Come Ves, a warning about gullibility, and crowd favourite Super Bowl Sundae echo the brass funk of the JB Horns, the guitars of El Chicano and the Afro-Cuban percussion of Tito Puente. It's only when they move into mainstream territory - ie 10-minute guitar solos - that it sounds awkward and silly. But just when the night could degenerate into slapstick confusion, they kickstart their marching band fanfare and triumphantly play through the parting crowd.

webTitle: Freeserve falls 17% on failed T-Online talks

fields.headline: Freeserve falls 17% on failed T-Online talks
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
www.freeserve.com
www.t-online.de
fields.trailText: Freeserve faced an uncertain future in the fast-consolidating European net sector yesterday after confirming that takeover talks with T-Online of Germany had failed.
fields.body:
Freeserve faced an uncertain future in the fast-consolidating European net sector yesterday after confirming that takeover talks with T-Online of Germany had failed.

Shares in Britain's leading internet service provider slumped by 17% to 365p after it disappointed the market by effectively ruling out any takeover in the short term.

"While certain discussions continue we do not expect this process will lead in the near future to a bid for the whole of Freeserve", a statement from the company and majority owner Dixons said.

Even a solid but uninspiring set of full-year figures failed to arrest the decline of Freeserve shares in a market already unsettled by recent warnings over the long-term prospects of Amazon.com. On Friday shares in the online retail pioneer fell by 20% after cautious comments from leading analysts but recovered slightly yesterday closing up $9 at $33.

T-Online had been widely expected to complete a £6bn takeover of Freeserve and create a combined group with a dominant position in Europe's two largest markets and the financial firepower to make further big acquisitions. It would also have gone head to head with Terra Networks of Spain, which recently bought US search engine Lycos.

Although cable company NTL is still talking to Freeserve about possible joint ventures and Dixons appears determined to reduce its stake, analysts do not expect the ISP to be on the receiving end of a takeover bid for another four to six months.

"Over the next two or three months Freeserve is likely to strike a series of smaller deals, building content and broadband services and generally enriching its site, but we're not expecting a transformative deal for now," said Peter Bradshaw, a Merrill Lynch analyst.

The collapse of talks could inhibit any ambitions Freeserve has of driving much of the widely predicted merger activity between leading internet companies, according to Miles Saltiel at West LB Panmure. "Freeserve has missed the opportunity with T-Online and is now at risk of missing the window within which it can be at the forefront of the consolidation process," he said. "Dixons will have to commit for the long haul if it wants to do that, but it is not clear if it has the appetite to do so."

Peter Misek, a senior internet analyst at Chase H&Q, added: "Freeserve now has to decide whether it wants to be the consolidator or be consolidated itself." The ending of the takeover negotiation process is likely to be an embarrassment to the electrical retailer, which has been trying to drum up interest in its 80% stake in Freeserve by conducting a lengthy auction process. Its shares fell 20.5p to 263.5p.

"Dixons tried to play hardball and lost," said one analyst.

"It is remarkable that in an auction process with so many banks advising on the deal they could not come up with another bidder when T-Online pulled out."

France Telecom's Wanadoo is now seen as Freeserve's most likely long-term suitor if the German group fails to return to the bid.

In the year until April 29 Freeserve recorded a pre-tax loss of £19.7m on a turnover of some £19.5m.

Fourth quarter revenues increased by 41% on the previous period, although the number of new customers signing up during that period fell slightly. Total active account users now number 1.9m - slightly below analyst expectations.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 Shorts
fields.trailText: • Lothar Matthäus has received public support from the German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder after his disappointing performances in the Low Countries.
fields.body:
 Lothar Matthäus has received public support from the German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder after his disappointing performances in the Low Countries.

In an open letter published in the Welt am Sonntag newspaper, Schroeder empathised with the 39-year-old sweeper, who has a world-record 150 caps. "Of course one feels shame, as many players do, at getting knocked out in this way," he wrote. "But I also think it is a shame that individual players - and in particular you - are being held solely responsible for the defeats.

"I know from my own personal experience that success has many fathers but that, when it comes to failure, one is often left holding the baby."

 Meanwhile, German politicians have urged Bayern Munich to release their coach Ottmar Hitzfeld so that he can lead the national team out of the doldrums.

Hitzfeld has confirmed he is interested in the position vacated by Erich Ribbeck, but Bayern are insisting he honours his contract, which runs until 2003.

"Bayern should put their own interests second," said Peter Struck, parliamentary chief of the ruling Social Democrats. "I know Ottmar from his Borussia Dortmund days. He's a good choice."

"It would be of great help to Germany if Bayern let Hitzfeld go," agreed the Christian Democrat chief whip Friedrich Merz.

 The Turkey defender Alpay Ozalan has been suspended for three games after being sent off in the quarter-final against Portugal on Saturday.

The ban is in stark contrast to the accolades Alpay received in Euro 96, where he won the Uefa fair play award for resisting the temptation to bring down the Croatian striker Goran Vlaovic, who ran on to score the only goal of the game.

The Turkish national federation was also fined 12,000 Swiss francs (£4,800) because of players' and supporters' behaviour during the game in Amsterdam - three firecrackers were let off by Turkish fans during the second half - and the Portuguese and Italian FAs were fined lesser amounts for similar offences.

Romania's Gheorghe Hagi, dismissed against Italy, has been suspended for one international match.

 Uefa's doping officers have confirmed that no banned substances were detected among the 96 samples sent for analysis during the group stage. The eight officers received confirmation from the two IOC-accredited laboratories in Cologne and Ghent yesterday.

"It's one of those jobs where you hope all your hard work has been for nothing and you don't have a positive sample," said the co-ordinator of the testing programme, Professor Stewart Hillis. "So far, so good."

 Graham Poll, the only English referee officiating at the tournament, has admitted he made a mistake in the Group D game between the world champions France and the Czech Republic.

Poll, of Tring, awarded the French a penalty after Pavel Nedved upended Didier Deschamps, but now admits the challenge was made outside the area. "I have to put my hands up," he said. The Czechs lost 2-1 and were eliminated.

webTitle: Last dances leave the idols reeling

fields.headline: Last dances leave the idols reeling
fields.trailText: Jorge Valdano on ignominious ends for all-time heroes.
fields.body:
Soccer has no manners. Lothar Matthäus retires at 39 with 150 caps and in his last game Germany go down 3-0. Gica Hagi quits at 35 after 125 internationals, defeated, humiliated and exiled from the pitch by a red card. These kinds of inappropriate farewells should be prohibited.

Matthäus is a survivor, the only player taking part in Euro 2000 who was once my rival on a pitch. That was in the 1986 World Cup final in a game that summed him up as a player: in the first half he gave as good as he got from Diego Maradona; in the second half he freed up and became the intelligent multi-faceted player we all know him to be.

He had the spirit of a stoker in an engine-room and the depth of vision of an architect: this made him the most typically German player of the last 20 years.

But his flaw, like that of the German team as a whole, was to keep going beyond his time. Germany is going through a period of harsh criticism but Matthäus has a long series of great results to defend himself with.

Hagi is a national hero who means so much for Romanian football that the only thing he has not done yet is play football while mounted on a white horse. With his persistence and sense of vision he could continue playing until he was 100, but with this disadvantage: his team-mates would be overly ready to distort their game in order to give him the ball.

He was like a magnet that sucked the life out of his team's game and they actually played their best without him. He took a walk on his worst side during the game against Italy: one of his shots hit the post, he intentionally gave Conte a knock on the knee, he faked a penalty and, when a TV camera closed in on him en route to the changing rooms, he shouted at it in frustration.

It was all very shoddy but he does have an alibi: for almost 20 years he has been a marvellous player.

Both of them did something extremely normal in this ill-mannered, low-budget game: they left football by the tradesmen's entrance in order to join the history books by the front door.

Who dares
It is very difficult for Italy to get confused because their football has very few ingredients to it: a lot of players behind the ball, constant pressure and a fast counter-attack with long balls once they regain possession.

Filippo Inzaghi zooms forward (unless he is stopped by the linesman), Francesco Totti comes up from behind (doing as much as he can within some strict limits) and the attacking manoeuvre is backed up by one of Demetrio Albertini's two shield-bearers, Stefano Fiore or Antonio Conte. (If they both attack at the same time, it is potentially lethal.)

They are the ace, king and queen of the Italian game, all armed to the teeth with a murderous self-confidence.

If one considers Italy as a team, one needs only to ask oneself how they attacked and how they defended. It is irrelevant to think about how they actually played.

An Italian friend of mine says that he never gets nervous watching his side in action. He is right not to do so but the way Italy play reminds me of those mothers who prefer their kids to rot away their youth inside the family homes: outside, as everybody knows, there is a violent world full of temptations, not to mention flowerpots poised to fall off balconies on to their heads as they pass by underneath.

Portugal's game, on the other hand, has far more links in its chain, which makes it much more risky and open to attack. If they start an offensive from a long way back they can lose the ball, as happened when Fernando Couto gave the Turks a penalty. If they dribble the ball for a long way up the pitch, their playing style gets cramped, as happened when Turkey were reduced to 10 men.

If they do not play down the wings, their game ends up losing its speed and Luis Figo becomes irrelevant, something that occurs all too frequently when they get edgy because they need a quick goal.

I could go on and on about all these failings and risk-takings, the practical (and cynical) answer to all of which would be that it is regrettable but inevitable. But then I could tell a completely different story about all of Portugal's virtues, a team who love adventure for its own sake, something that makes them beguiling to watch. Italy's style is completely legitimate but Portugal's has greatness: that is the difference between them.

webTitle: Zidane silences music of the spheres

fields.headline: Zidane silences music of the spheres
fields.standfirst: Spanish dreams that the gods were with them confounded by France at their peak
fields.trailText: Spain dared to believe that celestial forces were working in their dressing room after that extraordinary recovery against Yugoslavia but were last night confounded by France at their peak, writes Roy Collins.
fields.body:
Spain dared to believe that celestial forces were working in their dressing room after that extraordinary recovery against Yugoslavia in which they scored twice in injury time to reach the quarter-finals. But their dreams ran into the hard reality of a French team that has developed more gears and range in the two years since they won the World Cup.

Despite some splendid football from the Spanish, highlighted in breathtaking breaks from deep involving Raul, Alfonso and Pedro Munitis, not yet established enough to drop his forename, the French seemed always to have an edge.

They also had most of their players performing at their peak, and when that is the case there are few sides in the world who can contain them. Some, of course, will always have a head or shoulder advantage on team mates and inevitably one of them was Zinedine Zidane.

Zidane, one of those allowed to put his twinkling feet up while the reserves contested the final group game against Holland, was in absolutely majestic form, playing like a man who had been denied a touch of a football for six months.

His first serious involvement was a weaving crossfield run which should have ended in something more spectacular than Christophe Dugarry's cross into touch and from there, he simply got better.

Thierry Henry, who in horseracing terms has improved a stone since joining Arsenal, twisted in and out of three defenders as casually as though he were dribbling round cones on the training field, even if his finishing shot was off target. And when he found himself getting little joy from Abelardo, he came deep to collect the ball and get a running start on the Spanish defence.

Working magnificently behind the scenes were Youri Djorkaeff and Didier Deschamps. The latter claims that he needs to express only 50% of his talent for Chelsea but there was no doubt here that, in managerspeak, he was giv ing 120%. Yet even his display was eclipsed by that of Djorkaeff, for whom a magnificent winner was simply an embellishment.

How different these quarter-finals have been from those at Euro 96. Then, the knockout stages produced a series of matches in which the majority of teams played dreary, cautious, almost miserly football, seemingly developing a Leicester-style fondness for penalty shoot-outs.

Four matches then were decided by shoot-outs, with even the final decided by the so-called golden goal - an inappropriate description as it normally separates teams who provide nothing but dross.

Here, the football has become even richer since the best teams claimed their places in the last eight, seemingly determined to make any artificial means of deciding the games redundant. Extra time looked a near-certainty here when Raul stepped up to take his penalty, but in this case the extra half-hour would only have been a result of both teams' rampant ambition, rather than their negativity.

Spain's last-gasp "penalty" looked generous in the extreme after Munitis went down from the tiniest of connection from Lilian Thuram.

In truth France played not only like men who are world champions but who do not believe they can be beaten here. It is a growing feeling here.

Their two goals, Djorkaeff's and the remarkable free-kick from Zidane, were as good as we have seen in the tournament. It will take an exceptional side to deny them the trophy on Sunday.

webTitle: The team Zoff has fashioned without frills

fields.headline: The team Zoff has fashioned without frills
fields.standfirst: With Totti emerging, the Azzurri look increasingly formidable
fields.trailText: With Francesco Totti emerging, the Azzurri look increasingly formidable, says Daniel Taylor.
fields.body:
When Dino Zoff was appointed Italy coach he declared that he would serve up simple peasant fare rather than the sophisticated dishes that fans had become used to. Some of his critics are still digesting the new menu, but at least it is no longer sticking in their throats.

Four successive wins, eight goals scored and only one conceded, Italy cannot be begrudged their place in the semi-finals. OK, it is hardly fantasy football but, then again, Zoff is not living in Fantasia.

The Italians may not boast the fantasy of the French, the dash of the Dutch or the imagination of the Iberians, but their foundations are clearly built from the same granite as Zoff's jaw. After throwing themselves out of Euro 96, the Azzurri will not be unseated without a hefty shove this time around.

"Maybe the Italians are not spectacular, but they are terribly effective," their former coach Arrigo Sacchi wrote in La Stampa yesterday. "Who can budge them when they play like this?"

If Sacchi is to be believed, the time is ripe to get a few billion lire on Italy winning their first European Championship since 1968.

They certainly have the pedigree and now that Francesco Totti, the golden boy of Roma but hitherto a tin man for his country, has finally earned the favour of the coach, they have a player capable of unlocking the most parsimonious defence.

Although the Italian fans had called en masse for Alessandro del Piero during Saturday's game, it was the strains of Totti's name which reverberated around the Boulevard De L'Impératrice as a clutch of diehards homed in on the team hotel that night. Italy, at last, have a ready-made successor to Roberto Baggio - even if Totti's No20 jersey is more synonymous with Paolo Rossi.

Dynamic, however, the Italians are not. Indeed, when the crowd resorts to making its own fun, as it had to do here, it smacks of a lack of entertainment being provided on the pitch.

The Mexican wave was snaking around the King Baudouin stadium after 53 minutes, although the slight sense of anticlimax was not confined to the stands: two rows up in the press box an Italian journalist spent most of the second half playing patience on his laptop. Presumably he and his colleagues will not be lacing their pencils with venom just yet, even if copious supplies are being kept close by.

Even so, there was no escaping the fact that for long spells, as in their game against Belgium, the Italians came off second best in terms of possession, even after Gheorghe Hagi had been sent off.

"We are in the semi-finals but so far I would not give us any more than 7 out of 10," the midfielder Stefano Fiore admitted. "But our timing is good. Before the championship most people would have given us three or four."

As for Hagi, all dignity was lost as he found himself thrashing about in a vat of sour grapes. The referee Vitor Manuel Pereira, he said, had been Italy's best player. How he had sent him off he would never know.

"I have never dived in my life," he blustered. "You could see it from an aeroplane. You could see it from the moon."

Funny, that, because from close up it looked for all the world as though Hagi was auditioning for a place in Fame. At least he could never be accused of going out with a whimper.
fields.bodyText: When Dino Zoff was appointed Italy coach he declared that he would serve up simple peasant fare rather than the sophisticated dishes that fans had become used to. Some of his critics are still digesting the new menu, but at least it is no longer sticking in their throats. Four successive wins, eight goals scored and only one conceded, Italy cannot be begrudged their place in the semi-finals. OK, it is hardly fantasy football but, then again, Zoff is not living in Fantasia. The Italians may not boast the fantasy of the French, the dash of the Dutch or the imagination of the Iberians, but their foundations are clearly built from the same granite as Zoff's jaw. After throwing themselves out of Euro 96, the Azzurri will not be unseated without a hefty shove this time around. "Maybe the Italians are not spectacular, but they are terribly effective," their former coach Arrigo Sacchi wrote in La Stampa yesterday. "Who can budge them when they play like this?" fields.headline: Dutch celebrate Patrick's day
fields.standfirst: Kluivert is king as Yugoslavs get masterclass in finishing
fields.trailText: Patrick Kluivert's awesome finishing yesterday suggests that June 25 might be renamed St Patrick's Day in Holland, writes Jon Brodkin.
fields.body:
When, after an hour's play, Patrick Kluivert looked up and saw the No9 illuminated on the board held up by the fourth official, he will not have worried for a moment about his place in the starting line-up for the semi-final against Italy.

Indeed, the awesome finishing the Barcelona striker provided yesterday to become the first player to score four goals in a European Championship suggests that June 25 might be renamed St Patrick's Day in Holland. What the Yugoslavs would call it is doubtless unprintable.

True, Kluivert would have found tougher defences in Rotterdam's parks yesterday morning. And yes, he admitted sheepishly that his third goal had gone in via a defender. But the fact that this match made Mike Tyson's bout look a close-fought contest should not detract from his achievement. Five chances, four goals. If he had stayed on he might have had nine.

Officially he was substituted as a precaution against injury, but no one should be surprised if replays show the Yugoslavia bench on their knees and handing over fistful of notes. With six goals this tournament and 16 in his last 15 matches for Holland, Kluivert is doing all right.

That he names Marco van Basten as his idol looks highly appropriate. It was Van Basten's goals which inspired the Dutch to their triumph in the European Championship in 1988, and Kluivert looks capable of repeating the trick a dozen years on. He may be thought of as a moody character but there is little doubt he went to sleep with a smile last night.

Not that the Holland coach Frank Rijkaard will be surprised at what he is seeing. He knows from his playing days with a young Kluivert at Ajax how dangerous his No9 can be. And he will remember well his former team-mate's capacity to pop up with big-match goals. It was from a Rijkaard pass that Kluivert scored to win the European Cup for Ajax in 1995.

None of Kluivert's goals here came from more than six yards but this was a ruthless display of the striker's art. Quick, lean and with an intuitive ability to lose his marker and be in the right place at the right time, the 23-year-old was wonderful. He may contribute little outside the area but few will complain at that.

The Italians, of course, will not grant him quite as much space here on Thursday. But Dino Zoff's team have not looked entirely convincing at the back and the way Kluivert is feeling he would probably fancy finding room if stuck in a phone box with Bernard Manning.

Naturally, Rijkaard tempered his praise with mention of the team. "Patrick did a wonderful job," the coach said, "and it's really exciting to see him play like that. But it's a team performance. He would not have scored any if the team had not played as it did."

Dennis Bergkamp, in particular, stood out behind him. The way the Arsenal forward dropped deep to find space, chipping an outstanding pass for Kluivert's first, explained why Rijkaard said he would try to persuade him not to retire from international football after this tournament. But this was Kluivert's day.

webTitle: Italy make a positive art of defence

fields.headline: Italy make a positive art of defence
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: It would be the height of irony if a European Championship which has taken as its slogan "Football without Frontiers" were to be won by a team attacking from behind an iron curtain. For Italy, glasnost would appear to be either a Dutch decongestant or a Belgian version of Tunes.
fields.body:
It would be the height of irony if a European Championship which has taken as its slogan "Football without Frontiers" were to be won by a team attacking from behind an iron curtain. For Italy, glasnost would appear to be either a Dutch decongestant or a Belgian version of Tunes.

Yet Johan Cruyff can hardly be justified in hoping Dino Zoff's team will not win Euro 2000 because they are too defensive. This is another of those statements from the former Dutch captain which, like the hums of Pooh, barely stand up to logical examination.

Cruyff has also slated a current Holland player, Edgar Davids, for arguing with referees. Yet it was Cruyff himself who in the 1974 World Cup final argued so much with Jack Taylor that he failed to lead his side to the triumph over West Germany they deserved.

But never mind Cruyff. The point is that creating scoring opportunities from a strong defensive base, as Italy did so frequently in beating Romania 2-0 on Saturday to reach the semi-finals, does not warrant the charge of being negative.

True, some supporters of the Azzurri did leave the King Baudouin stadium chanting "cat-en-accio, cat-en-accio" but the bolt system of defending, once used by Italian coaches to stifle the life out of matches, was something completely different from Zoff's tactics.

These amount to nothing more than defending deeply and working the ball out quickly through the midfield with the aim of using quick strikers to catch defenders on the turn or beat the offside trap. Zoff's three central defenders - Fabio Cannavaro, Alessandro Nesta and Mark Iuliano - do not man-mark so much as get tight on opposing attackers and there is no bolt as such, just a collective awareness of the need to cover at the back.

Apart from giving Turkey's Okan Buruk a free header in their opening match the con sistent excellence of Italy's defending, plus the exceptional goalkeeping of Francesco Toldo, has been one of Euro 2000's most pleasing features.

Romania were never going to waltz past Italy as they had past England. That was snakes and ladders, this was chess against the grandmasters of blocking moves. At full strength Emerich Ienei's team might have run the Italians close. Without the injured Gheorghe Popescu and Cosmin Contra, and with Adrian Ilie suspended, they were always likely to be caught short.

Italy's opening goal on 33 minutes followed a free-kick from Demetrio Albertini nodded back from the left by Paolo Maldini. The ball was half-cleared but lobbed back by Stefano Fiore. As Antonio Conte ran back from an offside position, but not interfering with play, and with Filippo Inzaghi in line with the last defender, Francesco Totti chested the ball down and scored smoothly.

Ten minutes later Albertini's through-pass found Iulian Filipescu keeping Inzaghi onside and another sweet finish ended the game as a contest.

Had Inzaghi not suffered his usual quota of misses Italy would have doubled their margin. A snatched shot wide after seven minutes was forgivable under pressure, another off target when he had more time, 13 minutes from the end, less so. Again Albertini was the provider, as he had been earlier when Bogdan Stelea touched Inzaghi's shot on to a post.

Romania's best chance of staying in the match came within two minutes of Italy's opener. A marvellous crossfield pass from Adrian Mutu found Gheorghe Hagi racing clear of Iuliano and Maldini with Toldo advancing. As the goalkeeper lunged, Hagi chipped the ball past him but it hit the far post.

That was almost certainly Hagi's last grand gesture before retiring from international football. In the 54th minute he put Conte out of the tournament with an over-the-top tackle which caught the Italian on the right ankle. Conte suffered a torn ligament. Hagi was lucky to es cape with a yellow card but five minutes later, feeling a light touch on the shoulder from Gianluca Zambrotta, he prostrated himself in the penalty area and was booked for the dive and sent off.

Ienei was asked if it had been Hagi's last Romania game. "Hagi will decide," he replied, "maybe now, maybe before our next match in September." With Mutu a 21-year-old of such talent, it may not matter.

For Italy, even Zoff is beginning to smile a little, knowing that, increasingly from now on, anyone seeking to break open his defence will need a crowbar and some gelignite. Yet it will be as well for Italy if Maldini, taken off for the second half, recovers swiftly from a muscle strain.

fields.headline: Figo brings Portugal to fruition
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Just as dog owners often look like their animals, football teams can resemble their fans. England's embarrassing failure to hold the ball reflects similar traits among their followers with drink. And a glance at the celebrating Portugal supporters said much about their exciting side.
fields.body:
Just as dog owners often look like their animals, football teams can resemble their fans. England's embarrassing failure to hold the ball reflects similar traits among their followers with drink. And a glance at the celebrating Portugal supporters said much about their exciting side.

Among the shirts, scarves and the "Being Portuguese is orgasmic" banner flapped a Brazil flag and an inflatable banana of the sort that dominated English terraces in the 1980s. Combine the two and you have the vibrant, winning formula that Humberto Coelho's team have found.

Balancing the South American skill and explosive bursts are traditional English virtues: strength, organisation, hard work and a fierce will to win. At the base of the midfield sit grafters who see their task as no more spectacular than to win the ball and send it on. Simple factors, perhaps, but not always there in the past.

Ever since a squad featuring Luis Figo, Rui Costa and three more of Saturday's players won the 1991 World Youth Cup, a country has watched and waited for its "golden generation" to shine. At times that must have felt like waiting for Godot. But in seeing off a 10-man Turkey to reach their first semi-final since 1984, Portugal confirmed their time has come. Finally Fyffes are being waved rather than slipped on.

The midfielder Costinha explained why. "I think the mentality has changed," said the Monaco player. "In the past we didn't have players in other countries. Now we have people at Barcelona, Lazio, in France and England and so on. That means we know how other countries play and it has brought a winning mentality.

"People always said we had a lot of skill. But we were not aggressive enough and did not have the mentality to win. Now we know if you concede two goals it is not enough to play nice football.

"Look how we were losing 2-0 to England and changed that to 3-2. Against Romania right to the last minute we believed we could win. And everybody knows his position. Before, everyone wanted to do everything. Now we know exactly what is expected of us." All of which sounds remarkably similar to the adaptation Brazil made to the modern game a few years ago. At the back Fernando Couto is happy to sacrifice style for safety. And although the centre-back felt this performance was pragmatic rather than impressive there was much to admire in the passing and movement. Rarely is there overindulgence.

Alpay Ozalan hardly helped Turkey's cause by getting himself sent off in the 29th minute for a punch on the ground at Couto, who exaggerated the incident. But Erdem Arif's missed penalty at 1-0 seconds before half-time was surely academic. Briefly the Turks had threatened to expose Portuguese indiscipline amid a flurry of cards but it was hard to see them holding out.

Figo in particular was irresistible, providing a stream of crosses and corners. Nominally assigned to the left, he drifted right to set up the header and then the tap-in from Nuno Gomes which sealed this win. "At the moment they say the best player in the world is Rivaldo," said the former Portugal great Eusebio. "But next year I believe it will be Figo."

By the end, as a dispirited Turkey wilted, Portugal might have had 10. That lack of a clinical edge may prove costly when chances are scarcer but this team, who have the unity and understanding of a group who have largely grown up together, seem to feel destiny is waiting. Figo and others are not only at the peak of their powers in their late 20s but aware time is running out.

"There is more to come," Figo promised. As Coelho said mischievously with a smile: "We are quite happy to stay for another week." Millions of neutrals will be equally delighted if they hang around.

webTitle: Bring back News at Ten, or else (er, or else what?).)

fields.headline: Bring back News at Ten, or else (er, or else what?).)
fields.trailText: Pulling on his biggest pair of Doc Martens, the independent television commission's chairman Sir Robin Biggam declared last month that he was giving ITV one last chance to come up with a plan to corral the country into watching its news.
fields.body:
Pulling on his biggest pair of Doc Martens, the independent television commission's chairman Sir Robin Biggam declared last month that he was giving ITV one last chance to come up with a plan to corral the country into watching its news. "The uncertainty cannot be allowed to continue," boomed the man who once told an industry audience that his family do jigsaws at Christmas instead of watching TV.

On Thursday, Sir Robin - his DMs buffed up for the occasion - "got tough" and insisted ITV move its Nightly News programme to an earlier time slot. Or so we were told. The thing was that, despite the headlines the next day, he did no such thing: no formal direction emerged from Foley Street, the ITC's London home.

The regulator, having stepped up to the brink last month, got vertigo. To force ITV's hand at this stage would almost certainly - as this newspaper reported last week - have resulted in the network hauling the commission before the high court to explain its actions. So instead of stepping out, it dangled a foot over the edge to test the wind. It "insisted" that ITV move the news, but didn't "direct" it to do so. In PR terms, it was a neat move, reflected in the following day's headlines; in substance, it was typical of the ITC's timidity, and has prolonged the agony at least until the ITC's next meeting, in a month.

All through this sorry saga, the ITC has bottled the key decisions. When it first agreed to the schedule change in November 1998, it failed to have the courage of its convictions and imposed four conditions (none of which explicitly mentioned ratings). It resolved to conduct a review a year later, thus prolonging the debate and opening itself up to massive political pressure. Then, halfway through the first year of the new schedule, it started to make noises that it was concerned about ratings. After the year was up, it said that ITV had failed to attract sufficient audiences for its new news programmes, and gave it a month to come up with a plan to boost news audiences - in effect saying ITV had broken a condition which had not been imposed in the first place.

Last week it accepted ITV's compromise package, which included £21m to boost programmes in the run-up to the 11pm news and the return of News at Ten for elections, provided ITV would agree to another, binding period of review. ITV refused to be backed into a corner, and turned away. So Sir Robin hawked himself around the news channels (yes, the same ones on which you can watch the news at whatever time you like) declaring he had no option but to tell ITV to bring forward its Nightly News - without mentioning that he wasn't actually exercising any formal power.

So does the ITC really think it has any power here at all? Its actions last week appear to suggest it is not quite sure. It appears to believe it can flex its muscles around the argument that the decline in news ratings shows that ITV is failing in its public service commitment, which the broadcaster resolved to maintain as one of the original four conditions imposed when News at Ten was scrapped. ITV's legal team says that's nonsense. But Sir Robin has certainly succeeded in his aim of setting the ITV chiefs' nerves on edge.

ITV now has three options. It could cave in and shift the news; face down the regulator and force a judicial review; or agree to the binding period of review that it rejected last week.

At the weekend, ITV chiefs were adamant that they would not be forced into scheduling a bulletin at 10.30pm. That, most believe, is off the agenda. But what about a radical rethink? While everyone is focusing on the Nightly News, there are serious problems in the early evening schedule. Trevor at 6.30pm is not doing well, and neither are the regional news programmes that precede him. Instead of shifting the 11pm news, why not have a continental-style bulletin at 7pm or 8pm? This option is now firmly back in play. At a stroke, it would guarantee higher ratings and give both ITV and ITC a way out of this near-farce. ITV executives will discuss the plan this week.

In the meantime, the ITC chief executive Peter Rogers is preparing to hand over the reins to ex-BBC policy head Patricia Hodgson. She is the woman (keep up at the back) who negotiated the BBC's licence-fee settlement and helped to steer the corporation's digital strategy. She takes up her post in September, charged with saving the ITC from oblivion as the government considers the future of television regulation. Sir Robin's delaying tactics may yet be his downfall: it is hard to see headmistress Hodgson having any truck with the old ways of the old boys.
