To force ITV's hand at this stage would almost certainly - as this newspaper reported last week - have resulted in the network hauling the commission before the high court to explain its actions. So instead of stepping out, it dangled a foot over the edge to test the wind. It "insisted" that ITV move the news, but didn't "direct" it to do so. In PR terms, it was a neat move, reflected in the following day's headlines; in substance, it was typical of the ITC's timidity, and has prolonged the agony at least until the ITC's next meeting, in a month. All through this sorry saga, the ITC has bottled the key decisions. When it first agreed to the schedule change in November 1998, it failed to have the courage of its convictions and imposed four conditions (none of which explicitly mentioned ratings). It resolved to conduct a review a year later, thus prolonging the debate and opening itself up to massive political pressure. Then, halfway through the first year of the new schedule, it started to make noises that it was concerned about ratings. After the year was up, it said that ITV had failed to attract sufficient audiences for its new news programmes, and gave it a month to come up with a plan to boost news audiences - in effect saying ITV had broken a condition which had not been imposed in the first place. Last week it accepted ITV's compromise package, which included £21m to boost programmes in the run-up to the 11pm news and the return of News at Ten for elections, provided ITV would agree to another, binding period of review. ITV refused to be backed into a corner, and turned away. So Sir Robin hawked himself around the news channels (yes, the same ones on which you can watch the news at whatever time you like) declaring he had no option but to tell ITV to bring forward its Nightly News - without mentioning that he wasn't actually exercising any formal power. So does the ITC really think it has any power here at all? Its actions last week appear to suggest it is not quite sure. It appears to believe it can flex its muscles around the argument that the decline in news ratings shows that ITV is failing in its public service commitment, which the broadcaster resolved to maintain as one of the original four conditions imposed when News at Ten was scrapped. ITV's legal team says that's nonsense. But Sir Robin has certainly succeeded in his aim of setting the ITV chiefs' nerves on edge. ITV now has three options. It could cave in and shift the news; face down the regulator and force a judicial review; or agree to the binding period of review that it rejected last week. At the weekend, ITV chiefs were adamant that they would not be forced into scheduling a bulletin at 10.30pm. That, most believe, is off the agenda. But what about a radical rethink? While everyone is focusing on the Nightly News, there are serious problems in the early evening schedule. Trevor at 6.30pm is not doing well, and neither are the regional news programmes that precede him. Instead of shifting the 11pm news, why not have a continental-style bulletin at 7pm or 8pm? This option is now firmly back in play. At a stroke, it would guarantee higher ratings and give both ITV and ITC a way out of this near-farce. ITV executives will discuss the plan this week. In the meantime, the ITC chief executive Peter Rogers is preparing to hand over the reins to ex-BBC policy head Patricia Hodgson. She is the woman (keep up at the back) who negotiated the BBC's licence-fee settlement and helped to steer the corporation's digital strategy. She takes up her post in September, charged with saving the ITC from oblivion as the government considers the future of television regulation. Sir Robin's delaying tactics may yet be his downfall: it is hard to see headmistress Hodgson having any truck with the old ways of the old boys.

webTitle: Abductions in south Lebanon fuel fears of retribution

fields.headline: Abductions in south Lebanon fuel fears of retribution
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Hizbullah guerrillas are believed to have abducted 20 men suspected of collaborating with the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army (SLA) amid fears that the group is engaged in a campaign of reprisals following Israel's abrupt withdrawal from the area a month ago.
fields.body:
Hizbullah guerrillas are believed to have abducted 20 men suspected of collaborating with the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army (SLA) amid fears that the group is engaged in a campaign of reprisals following Israel's abrupt withdrawal from the area a month ago.

According to US-based Human Rights Watch (HRW), people identifying themselves as Hizbullah members took the men from their homes in Aitaroun village in the former Israeli-occupied zone on the night of June 6.

Five of the men, who were blindfolded and interrogated, have since been released after being held for up to one week, but the others have not been seen since. They are the first documented cases of abductions in south Lebanon since the Israeli retreat and the collapse of the SLA. Local residents believe the men were abducted and questioned on the basis of intelligence files left behind by the SLA's security office in Aitaroun.

The abductions occurred in typical secret police tactics, in the hours just before or after midnight, when most of the victims and their families were asleep. In some cases, the interrogators focused on the personal histories of the abductees, including the nature of their relationship with specific security officials from the SLA.

"The fear is that militia groups are taking the law into their own hands," said Gini Sherry, HRW assistant director for the Middle East and North Africa division. "Although no one complained of being physically abused, it was clear the questions were those that would be normally asked by investigators and judges. The problem is the lawless nature of what is happening and it should be nipped in the bud."

Hizbullah's action against suspected collaborators mirrors the Lebanese government's own campaign of retribution. A military court on Saturday sentenced 92 people accused of working with Israel, or entering Israeli-held territory, to prison terms ranging from one week to five years and fines of up to $633.

So far, 404 people have been sentenced since the trials began after Israel's May 24th withdrawal from a zone it occupied in southern Lebanon. Most received one-year jail terms, but two were sentenced in absentia to 15 years in prison.

The speedy trials, which cannot be appealed, have courted controversy. Some regard them as unfairly harsh while others complain that the government is being too lenient with people regarded as traitors. The human rights group Amnesty International has said that because of the short time spent on each suspect, the trials "neither allow the innocent to be acquitted nor ensure that those who may be guilty of war crimes will be discovered.''

Up to 2,200 fighters or ex-members of the 2,500-strong SLA were captured or surrendered to the Lebanese authorities after the hasty Israeli retreat. The rest - many of them high-ranking militia officials - fled to Israel. Lebanon regards itself as technically at war with Israel, and former SLA members are considered collaborators.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe election results delayed
fields.standfirst: Audio: Jonathan Steele in Harare
fields.trailText: The first results from Zimbabwe's general election have been delayed amid fears that the campaign was not free and fair.
fields.body:
The first results from Zimbabwe's general election have been delayed amid fears that the campaign was not free and fair.

With an estimated turnout of more than 60%, the highest since independent Zimbabwe's first elections in 1980, officials confirmed that only one constituency had completed checking votes and had begun to count them, more than three hours after the first results were scheduled to be announced.

Election monitors checked ballot box seals before they were opened shortly after 8am today. The state elections directorate had hoped to release the first results by noon, but at 3pm (1300 GMT) there were still no results known.

Both President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party and the opposition Movement for Democratic Change party postponed media briefings until after the first results were announced.

Mariyawanda Nzuwah, head of the elections directorate, estimated the turnout to be at least 60%, the highest level of voting since the first post-independence elections of 1980. Only 29% of registered voters cast ballots in 1995 parliamentary elections.

In an interim assessment of the elections, EU observers condemned the intimidation of the electorate in the build-up to the vote, during which at least 30 people were killed and thousands beaten and threatened, mainly by ruling party militants.

"The term free and fair elections is not applicable to these elections," said Pierre Schori, head of the EU observer mission.

Leaders in President Mugabe's ruling party "seemed to sanction the use of violence and intimidation against political opponents and contributed significantly to the climate of fear so evident during the election campaign", Mr Schori told reporters early this morning.

Opposition supporters also waged attacks, but they were far fewer and their leaders comdemned the violence, he said.

But Mr Schori praised the efficiency and professionalism that marked the actual vote and emphasised that the election process was complex. He said no final assessment would be issued until July 3, after the votes had been counted and the country's reaction to the results assessed.

Meanwhile, the official Zimbabwe news agency reported that riot police were deployed in the southwestern Harare suburb of Budiriro, where tensions rose between rival party supporters as they waited for polling results.

Despite the months of threats, Zimbabweans voted in large numbers, many queueing for hours.

Both Mr Mugabe's ruling party and the MDC predicted they would win control of the parliament. But even a decisive victory may not guarantee the MDC control of the 150-member parliament. Since 30 members are directly appointed by Mr Mugabe, the party would need to win at least 76 of the 120 contested seats to have a majority.

The president has two years left on his term and will not step down unless the opposition gained a two-thirds majority in parliament and then changed the constitution to remove him. That overwhelming total, 101 of the 120 contested seats, is considered well beyond the MDC's reach.

webTitle: What women want and Britain needs

fields.headline: What women want and Britain needs
fields.standfirst:
Labour is embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In a unique experiment in British journalism, we set out the latest part of our vision for Labour's second term.
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: What do women want? It's the original vexed question and, as the gender gap returns to the sound of slow hand-clapping, one that the government cannot afford to fudge. But what is a women's issue? Women voters consistently declare themselves against any attempt to pit the needs of men and women against each other. They feel patronised by soft-focus targeting. And we know that their prime concerns are health and education.
fields.body:
What do women want? It's the original vexed question and, as the gender gap returns to the sound of slow hand-clapping, one that the government cannot afford to fudge. But what is a women's issue? Women voters consistently declare themselves against any attempt to pit the needs of men and women against each other. They feel patronised by soft-focus targeting. And we know that their prime concerns are health and education.

The challenge for Labour, given all that, is to address inequality without dividing men and women's interests - or ignoring the diversity of opinion and experience among female voters.

The women's unit The government should start by renewing its commitment to women by maintaining the unit - rather than submerging it into a broader equality unit - and keeping its seat in the cabinet. The unit, which has largely concentrated on magazine-style discussion of nebulous and politically uncontroversial topics like body image and assertiveness, must select some key areas for change and lobby on them effectively.

The unit must be fearless. There is little point in acting as though equality has been reached to avoid accusations of victimology, if that in turn limits the scope of its demands.

As illustrated in a recent London School of Economics analysis of the inequalities in the new deal, gender bias is unwittingly written into many apparently neutral policies. The immediate establishment of a gender audit select committee, to scrutinise all legislation for its impact on both sexes, is essential.

Work and pay Equal pay is also an issue of real and symbolic significance. A government-led offensive on earnings would signal, more than any other move, an acknowledgment that, while women's contribution to society is often different from men's, it is no less valuable.

While the minimum wage has had a marginal impact on the lowest paid, women continue to earn less than three-quarters of men's full-time earnings, while part-time women earn just 60%. The Equal Pay Act is now 25 years old. It requires a radical overhaul, accompanied by a genuine show of commitment from the government.

Government suppliers and the public sector must set equal pay standards, while all companies should be obliged by law to implement and publish pay audits. As an example of good practice, the government should undertake a pay audit of all public services and departments, with a promise to rectify all anomalies within a five-year period. It should publish the results, stimulating debate and fostering a spirit of openness. All companies who do likewise within the five years should be offered tax breaks.

Employment tribunals should be made faster and simpler for workers and bosses. They must be given the power to deal with group claims, to make general findings and recommendations, and to alter collective agreements. In addition, tribunals should have the power to require employers to produce an action plan for eliminating inequity in their pay system.

Pensions The pension system was modelled on a now out-dated idea of the male breadwinner who married for life. National insurance must be restructured to reflect women's lives too. Labour should offer help with pension contributions when women take time away from work to have children. An expanded concept of national insurance - so that benefits are paid to individuals, not married couples - would benefit older single or widowed women struggling in poverty.

Crime Sexual and domestic violence are crimes, not women's issues, and the government must prioritise them as such. Scandalously low conviction rates and a continuing inability to deal effectively with victims' needs must be addressed. Labour should establish specialist centres and courts to deal with all sexual assault, abuse and domestic violence cases.

One-stop shops would offer comprehensive medical, legal and welfare resources, taking the strain off individual agencies: thus, a rape victim would undergo a medical examination, meet her court chaperon and receive counselling all under the same roof. In addition, the government should fund centrally a national network of refuges.

Judges, prosecutors and court officers trained in the specific legal and social issues brought up by such cases would be monitored, to ensure that trials focus on protecting, not punishing, the victim. In legislative terms, we need restrictions on the introduction of sexual and medical history evidence that actually work.

Abortion The government should make a commitment to the pro-choice agenda by legislating for abortion on request during the first three months of pregnancy, sweeping away the current requirement for the consent of two doctors.

Childcare It is time to make a reality of the national childcare strategy, ensuring availability of high quality state provision across the board. The government should extend childcare tax credits to all families where both parents work, on a sliding scale. The concept of the "family wage" ought to be replaced by some acknowledgment that parents support many people, the young and the elderly, on one or two wages. Childcare funding should be available for those seeking work, as well as those in work. Labour should offer employers substantial incentives to implement family-friendly polices and subsidised childcare.

The ongoing maternity review should deliver recommendations that will allow all parents a range of choices following the birth of a child. The government should extend maternity pay entitlement from 14 weeks to at least 22 (the European average) on full pay, with the option to take a longer break on reduced pay (eg up to 30 weeks on 80% pay). This should not be means-tested, but should remain available to all women on the basis that, without it, they are working unpaid by looking after their baby.

Entitlements should be available to men who show that they are taking on responsibility for childcare. The government should pay the new parental leave, and require all employers to implement a part-time charter, which would include the right to return to the same job part-time after maternity leave.

A minister for children The women's minister should lobby for a separate minister to safeguard the rights and interests of children and young people up to the age of 18, as laid down in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. A minister for children could work alongside an independent children's rights commissioner, who would concentrate on accountability and whistle-blowing. As well as making child poverty a priority, the minister should investigate the broader issue of young people's participation in society, initially by introducing a statutory framework for school councils, which would give pupils a direct say.

Representation Finally, as all the evidence suggests that there will be fewer women in parliament next term, Labour should enshrine a formal policy to ensure equality of representation. The twinning system, which has proved so successful in Scotland, offers a viable alternative to the poison chalice of women-only shortlists. Labour will be credible on equality only if it can offer family-friendly working conditions in the nation's parliament. It must modernise the House of Commons as an example to other employers.

Appearing women-friendly is one thing, acting it quite another. And the acts that constitute a different style of government are not initiatives which imply women's concerns are a specialism, best administered by female ministers. We need instead a fully-integrated, forward-thinking view that befits a modern government. It's time for Labour to be brave about women.

The Pledges

1 Companies to be audited to prove they are paying men and women equally

2 Specialist courts to deal with sexual violence

3 Pension reform to benefit women

4 Extended maternity pay and leave

5 A minister for children

Have we got it right - or should more be done in the second term? Write to our letters page, marking the envelope Manifesto, or join the debate at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/manifesto

Next week: Scotland and Wales

fields.headline: Honour system 'worse than useless'
fields.standfirst:
David Hencke on why the House of Lords is a soft touch for lobbyists
Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Monday, 6pm: David Hencke on why the House of Lords is a soft touch for lobbyists
fields.body:
This week Lord Neill, the chairman of the parliamentary committee on standards in public life, turns his attention to one of the gaping holes in the British constitution - the anomaly which allows Britain's 695 peers to avoid declaring all their business interests.

Unlike MPs, peers can still be involved in paid advocacy, and go without a code of conduct - they rely on an appeal to "personal honour" to keep to the straight and narrow. Yet all government and private legislation goes through the Lords, which is essentially a revising chamber.

The need for reform is obvious. The House of Lords is basically a soft touch for lobbyists. If they can get an obscure change to the law - which would normally never be reported in the press - it could be worth anything from a few thousand to millions of pounds to particular clients.

Yet there are no sanctions against peers who might be tempted to help them: there is no parliamentary standards commissioner to police or investigate their behaviour and even the present law of bribery and corruption exempts peers from being prosecuted if they were caught taking backhanders. There is not even a disciplinary procedure, like the right to suspend an erring peer from the chamber.

Much of the present register of business interests in the Lords is voluntary - resulting in huge anomalies. Some people, like ex-MPs Lord Baker and Lord Alton, submit exemplary entries - no different to their practice when they were MPs. Others, like Lord Saatchi and Lord Rees-Mogg, are masters of vague and obscure language: nothing from their entry would give more than a passing clue to their huge interests.

There is no requirement to declare paid trips and the whole register seems to be run on the basis that peers are honourable gentlemen and therefore their word can be trusted.

The only compulsory part of the register is the declaration of business clients and lobby consultancies that relate to lobbying activities in Parliament - but even then they do not always list their clients, which are bound to be constantly changing.

All in all, the present regulatory system is little more than worse than useless.

The only compulsory part of the register is the declaration of business clients and lobby consultancies that relate to lobbying activities in Parliament - but even then they do not always list their clients, which are bound to be constantly changing. All in all, the present regulatory system is little more than worse than useless.

fields.headline: Bangladesh granted Test status
fields.trailText: Bangladesh have been granted Test status, Bangladesh Cricket Board officials announced today.
fields.body:
Bangladesh have been granted Test status, Bangladesh Cricket Board officials announced today.

"The ICC [International Cricket Council] today unanimously gave Bangladesh a full membership, making it a Test-playing nation," BCB president Saber Hossain Chowdhury told the Bangladesh news agency BSS from London where the ICC has been meeting.

Bangladesh becomes the tenth Test playing country. The others are England, Australia, New Zealand, West Indies, South Africa, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe.

The news sparked massive celebrations across the country and prompted reaction from across the political spectrum, including joyous remarks by Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.

"I am very happy and I thank the ICC for granting test status to Bangladesh," she said. "It will inspire our cricketers to strive harder towards their goals, including winning the World Cup one day."

Bangladeshis lit crackers, distributed sweets and danced and sang on the streets after hearing the news from Lords. "Yes, yes, we have made it," Sports Minister Obaidul Quader told thousands of people waiting outside the BCB office, after Chowdhury had phoned him from London.

The BCB announced plans for an official celebration on Wednesday.

Bangladesh became an associate member of the ICC in 1977 and won the ICC trophy in 1997. They made their World Cup debut in 1999 defeating Scotland and former champions Pakistan.

webTitle: Peer's idea to beat racism in police

fields.headline: Peer's idea to beat racism in police
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Police recruitment and promotion procedures need to be reformed so that candidates who display racist, sexist or anti-gay behaviour are excluded from the force, the new Labour peer, Lord Waheed Alli, is to urge tonight.
fields.body:
Police recruitment and promotion procedures need to be reformed so that candidates who display racist, sexist or anti-gay behaviour are excluded from the force, the new Labour peer, Lord Waheed Alli, is to urge tonight.

The director of Carlton Television is to use the Greenwich memorial lecture, which is to mark the lives of Rolan Adams, Rohit Duggal and Stephen Lawrence who were all victims of racial attacks, to demand that there is no slackening in the pace of change to combat racism in the Metropolitan police and other forces.

Lord Alli says that the way the Met handled the investigation into the Soho nail bomber demonstrated that it had become a model for change even if it was imperfect. He says the conduct of that investigation was in stark contrast to the catalogue of ineptitude and racism which characterised the inquiry into the murder of Stephen Lawrence.

He believes the black communities in London can do business with the new Met commissioner, Sir John Stephens. "We have a major opportunity but I think we need to be clear and disciplined about the terms of engagement. I think that there should be a contract between us as a community and him as a commissioner."

Lord Alli wants the Met to sign up to five pledges to the black community. They include ensuring that racial crime is rigorously investigated; changing recruitment procedures; performance indicators to measure local community satisfaction; learning from its own black staff; and delivering a more representative police force.

His ideas include ending the practice of conducting police training in isolation in such places as the police college at Hendon and training new officers in further education colleges where "our young people" train to be nurses and teachers.

In return, the black community should sign up to five pledes of its own. These include supporting police investigations with the best information and being confident it will be treated with sensitivity and confidentiality; working with community beat officers; giving accurate information about community feelings; taking part in consultations; and helping to identify the young people in the black communities who should be the next generation of police officers.

Lord Alli is expected to say it is vital that the black community sees things through. He says that in relations with the police community, activists should not walk out at the first failure or disagreement.

fields.headline: Republicanism's surrender by instalment
fields.standfirst:
Anthony McIntyre, editor of republican magazine Fourthwrite, analyses the impact of the today's arms inspection report on the future of republicanism in Northern Ireland
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Republican writer Anthony McIntyre analyses the impact of the today's arms inspection report on the future of republicanism in Northern Ireland
fields.body:
The report to the Independent International Commission on Decommissioning from Cyril Ramaphosa and Martti Ahtisaari - which states that IRA weapons are secure and cannot be used without their becoming aware that this has happened - is significant but not surprising.

In a sense it marks a further down payment in the process of 'surrender by instalment' which the leadership of the republican movement has been pursuing for a number of years.

The major question that historians will ask is not why the republicans surrendered, but why they fought such a long and futile war only to be brought back to accepting less than what was on offer in 1974, terms which they had then rejected outright.

It has not been an unconditional surrender. And it is infinitely better than continuing to fight a futile war for the sake of honouring Ireland's dead, only to produce more of them.

But let us not labour under any illusions that the conditions were good. From the British point of view, the strategic logic for engaging with republicans was to establish a process that would be inclusive of republicans - but exclude republicanism. The extent of British success can be gauged by the ground already conceded by republicanism. The consent principle and, by logical extension, partition has been accepted; the RUC has been modernised; the Northern Ireland legislative assembly has been re-established.

In this sense republicanism is effectively 'decommissioned'. It may live on discursively, but in substantive terms republicanism has been reduced to cannibalising the ideas of the SDLP. The latest move now opens the way to colonising the SDLP constituency. Some might yet conclude that John Hume was prepared to sacrifice the SDLP as a party to ensure the triumph of SDLP ideology.

What does the future hold? Sinn Fein as the expression of state republicanism and a party of votes - as distinct from a party of ideas - will move to straddle the middle ground. The marginalised faction that sustained it during the hard times will not experience the good times - that is the trophy of the nationalist middle class - but will remain only to be serviced or exploited by non-state republicanism.

If republicanism re-emerges let it be democratic rather than elitist. Army councils only ever lead us to despair or disaster.

 Anthony McIntyre is co-editor of the republican journal Fourthwrite. He served 18 years in prison for IRA activities, including 17 years for being found guilty of killing a Loyalist.

webTitle: Hostel fire suspect may have left suicide note

fields.headline: Hostel fire suspect may have left suicide note
fields.trailText: Australian police are today investigating a suicide note that they believe may have been left in a bar by Robert Long, the key suspect in Friday's hostel fire that killed 15 backpackers.
fields.body:
Australian police are today investigating a suicide note that they believe may have been left in a bar by Robert Long, the key suspect in Friday's hostel fire that killed 15 backpackers.

Chris Woods, the pub landlord who discovered the note, told Australian radio that the letter writer said he was sorry for any hurt he may cause as a result of the actions that he was going to take. Mr Long is wanted for questioning by police over the fire.

Superintendent Ken Benjamin of the Queensland force said the note had yet to be verified as being from Mr Long. "I have a note, but we have not had the handwriting verified at the present time, so I'm not at liberty to discuss it."

Mr Long is still thought to be at large and his parents have made an emotional plea to their son to contact the police. Sid Long urged his 37-year-old son Robert to phone him and his wife Norma so they could talk through the events of the past week.

"Robert, your mother and I are ready to listen and talk with you at any time," Mr Long told the Sydney Morning Herald.

"We need to hear that you are safe and well. Remember Robert, your mother and I love you. We are ready to help you work through the events of the last week."

On the eve of Friday's blaze, it is believed that Mr Long was drinking at the rear of the hotel with two English backpackers. Backpacker Darren Hill said Mr Long had told an English couple on the night of the fire to keep their windows open and to be near the fire escape. "They were very shaken up," he said. "They didn't believe him; they only got out because their next door neighbours got them out, otherwise they never would have made it."

Long is thought to have drifted into the town of Childers in March and got work picking fruit and vegetables, staying at the hostel. "He was a very lonely individual, desperate to have people like him," said publican Chris Woods. Police in Australia today said it was "highly unlikely" Long was among the victims.

As the bodies were being removed from the building, an English backpacker who featured on a victims list in Australia turned up alive. Nicola Morgan approached the police today after attending the memorial service for the dead yesterday.

The Foreign Office said she had never appeared on their list of missing victims, but was reported to have been a victim of the blaze in Australia. "It certainly seems that she contacted her parents soon after the fire, but we cannot be sure. We are just glad she is safe and well," spokeswoman Katy Parker said.

Six British nationals and one Irish national remain unaccounted for. "We have spoken to their families, but we are still awaiting confirmation when the bodies are recovered and identified," said Miss Parker. She said it was likely that the earliest the bodies could be formerly identified is tomorrow.

A police spokesman said that eight bodies have yet to be retrieved from the building. "This is a slow and painstaking process," he said. "The teams are working in cramped, dangerous conditions and we are finding it is taking about one and a half to two hours per body."

The cause of the blaze, which is known to have started on the ground floor of the two-storey building, is still being treated as suspicious. The 70 survivors were yesterday joined by local residents, politicians and rescuers in an emotional memorial service.

fields.headline: Clinton and Blair hail gene 'triumph'
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton today congratulated scientists on a "stunning and humbling achievement" in a joint announcement with Tony Blair called to mark the decoding of the human genome.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton today congratulated scientists on a "stunning and humbling achievement" in a joint announcement with Tony Blair called to mark the decoding of the human genome.

Speaking from the White House, Mr Clinton said: "Our children's children will only know cancer as a constellation of stars" and hailed the completion of the project after a 10-year race that cost billions.

"Today we are learning the language in which God created life," Mr Clinton said. "We are gaining ever more awe for the complexity, the beauty, the wonder of God's most divine and sacred gift."

Mr Blair, who joined the president via a satellite broadcast from Downing Street, added that it was "the first great technological triumph of the 21st century". "Every so often in the history of human endeavour there comes a breakthrough that takes mankind across the frontier and into a new era."

Mr Clinton joked that the life expectancy of the prime minister's baby son, Leo, had just risen by 25 years.

In the Commons, trade and industry minister Patricia Hewitt told MPs that Mr Blair and Mr Clinton believed that the "common property of the human genome should be used freely for the common good of the human race." Many fear that the work pioneered by US bio-technology firm Celera will allow pharmaceutical corporations to patent genes and genetic cures for diseases such as cancer.

Leading British scientists were however unanimous that mapping the human genome was one of the most significant scientific achievements of all time. Martin Bobrow, professor of medical genetics at Addenbrooke's Hospital, Cambridge, and a member of the government's Human Genetics Commission praised the research but warned that the work needed to maintain public confidence.

"It is a hugely significant milestone and there are many treasures there for health-related research. It is rather like reaching the top of a mountain pass and seeing in front of you a fertile plain, rich with new ideas, new methods, new techniques and new concepts for understanding the complexity of human biology in health and disease," he said.

Stephen Cox, executive secretary of the Royal Society, said: "What we have now is analogous to an alphabet - a prerequisite for a work of literature, but not yet the literature itself. The next step, no less challenging, is to learn how the letters can make words and the words can convey meaning."

Sceptics warned that the genetic breakthrough could usher in a sinister era of perfect people and death to the disabled. "The further science goes, the further the worst case scenario goes," said Steve Jenkins, a spokesman for the Church of England.

fields.trailText: John willis on broadcasting.
fields.byline:
John Willis
John Willis

John Willis
fields.body:
In Boston recently, I was visiting WGBH, the flagship station of the US Public Broadcasting System (PBS), where I came across the preparations for an auction to raise funds for the channel. The volunteers lining up at trestle tables appeared more akin to a church jumble sale than an important component in the economics of a major television station.

The point is that here was a group of citizens who cared as passionately about their public service television station as their local school. Pledge weeks in which viewers donate to PBS have been a a part of the funding base of the system for many years and, in case you think this is irrelevant, WGBH co-produce a huge amount of classic British drama as well as making current affairs and science programmes of high ambition.

When Newt Gingrich tried to destroy PBS funding a few years ago, it was viewers all over the country, the equivalents of those Boston volunteers, who turned the tide against "nuking Newt".

PBS, like public sector broadcasters all over the world, is wrestling with a fundamental question. Should it compete with commercial services or stay distinctive by offering viewers unique programmes? In Britain, the fierce bidding for soccer rights has highlighted that dilemma for the BBC, and Mark Thompson's radical Banff speech (which David Elstein wrote about here last week) has indicated where their intentions lie. The war over ITV's news has only served to highlight the confusion surrounding the role of public service on all channels.

On Friday, broadcasters and other interested parties handed in their evidence for the Communications Bill White Paper. Here the shape of broadcasting will be hammered out but underpinning almost every clause in the bill will be one key issue. Public service broadcasting now needs to be framed in a multi-channel landscape with internet access. And finding a new definition will be as difficult as catching blancmange.

Crucial judgments affecting all channels will be informed by the future framework as defined by public service obligations. What is the role of news on ITV when there are four 24/7-news channels? How far should the BBC's commercial partnerships stretch? What is the Channel 4 remit when it expands into more entertainment-based channels?

In the digital world the anchor points of public service broadcasting will be ever more important. In the gold rush of commercial services, impartial information, cultural access, educational opportunity and indigenous drama and entertainment should be there for all. Social exclusion is almost as relevant to information as it is to jobs or housing. Digital division is a significant obstacle in the new media world.

Andrew Graham and Gavyn Davies were right when they wrote: "Public service broadcasting is not an optional add-on but central to the health of all broadcasting." This is the same Andrew Graham who will be advising the government on this issue as White Paper submissions are assessed.

The BBC's obsession with market measurement, now imported in part into Channel 4, has meant that for too long public service broadcasting has been defined in a mechanistic way. It was as if efficiency and focus groups had replaced creativity and diversity as key elements of public service broadcasting's genetic make-up. Serving the viewer is more than audience measurement, "value" in public service broadcasting is more than value for money.

Walking with Dinosaurs, Warriors, The 1900 House, Elizabeth, The Murder of Stephen Lawrence and The Royle Family, show that good programme-making of ambition can still make commercial and cultural value indivisible.

The underlying core principle of universality of access laid down by John Reith in 1924 still applies but we should delete "broadcasting" from the phrase public service broadcasting because the concept should now be enshrined in much more than conventional television.

New technology merely offers a different delivery mechanism for public service functions. News, education, regionalism, community debate, participation and internationalism are renewed opportunities in the new world.

When access is fast, cheap and universal there is a huge potential for a more interactive, more democratic form of public service than in old media. I hope that, as the crucial debate hots up, the notion of public service broadcasting is not trapped in history but rather redefined for the future.

Without a cultural and economic framework in which to progress, some of the most valued strengths of British television are in jeopardy. Public service broadcasting needs looking after. It's like hair on a middle-aged man - by the time you've noticed it's disappeared, it's too late.

John Willis is chief executive, United Productions

fields.trailText: John willis on broadcasting.
fields.byline:
John Willis
John Willis

John Willis
fields.body:
In Boston recently, I was visiting WGBH, the flagship station of the US Public Broadcasting System (PBS), where I came across the preparations for an auction to raise funds for the channel. The volunteers lining up at trestle tables appeared more akin to a church jumble sale than an important component in the economics of a major television station.

The point is that here was a group of citizens who cared as passionately about their public service television station as their local school. Pledge weeks in which viewers donate to PBS have been a a part of the funding base of the system for many years and, in case you think this is irrelevant, WGBH co-produce a huge amount of classic British drama as well as making current affairs and science programmes of high ambition.

When Newt Gingrich tried to destroy PBS funding a few years ago, it was viewers all over the country, the equivalents of those Boston volunteers, who turned the tide against "nuking Newt".

PBS, like public sector broadcasters all over the world, is wrestling with a fundamental question. Should it compete with commercial services or stay distinctive by offering viewers unique programmes? In Britain, the fierce bidding for soccer rights has highlighted that dilemma for the BBC, and Mark Thompson's radical Banff speech (which David Elstein wrote about here last week) has indicated where their intentions lie. The war over ITV's news has only served to highlight the confusion surrounding the role of public service on all channels.

On Friday, broadcasters and other interested parties handed in their evidence for the Communications Bill White Paper. Here the shape of broadcasting will be hammered out but underpinning almost every clause in the bill will be one key issue. Public service broadcasting now needs to be framed in a multi-channel landscape with internet access. And finding a new definition will be as difficult as catching blancmange.

Crucial judgments affecting all channels will be informed by the future framework as defined by public service obligations. What is the role of news on ITV when there are four 24/7-news channels? How far should the BBC's commercial partnerships stretch? What is the Channel 4 remit when it expands into more entertainment-based channels?

In the digital world the anchor points of public service broadcasting will be ever more important. In the gold rush of commercial services, impartial information, cultural access, educational opportunity and indigenous drama and entertainment should be there for all. Social exclusion is almost as relevant to information as it is to jobs or housing. Digital division is a significant obstacle in the new media world.

Andrew Graham and Gavyn Davies were right when they wrote: "Public service broadcasting is not an optional add-on but central to the health of all broadcasting." This is the same Andrew Graham who will be advising the government on this issue as White Paper submissions are assessed.

The BBC's obsession with market measurement, now imported in part into Channel 4, has meant that for too long public service broadcasting has been defined in a mechanistic way. It was as if efficiency and focus groups had replaced creativity and diversity as key elements of public service broadcasting's genetic make-up. Serving the viewer is more than audience measurement, "value" in public service broadcasting is more than value for money.

Walking with Dinosaurs, Warriors, The 1900 House, Elizabeth, The Murder of Stephen Lawrence and The Royle Family, show that good programme-making of ambition can still make commercial and cultural value indivisible.

The underlying core principle of universality of access laid down by John Reith in 1924 still applies but we should delete "broadcasting" from the phrase public service broadcasting because the concept should now be enshrined in much more than conventional television.

New technology merely offers a different delivery mechanism for public service functions. News, education, regionalism, community debate, participation and internationalism are renewed opportunities in the new world.

When access is fast, cheap and universal there is a huge potential for a more interactive, more democratic form of public service than in old media. I hope that, as the crucial debate hots up, the notion of public service broadcasting is not trapped in history but rather redefined for the future.

Without a cultural and economic framework in which to progress, some of the most valued strengths of British television are in jeopardy. Public service broadcasting needs looking after. It's like hair on a middle-aged man - by the time you've noticed it's disappeared, it's too late.

John Willis is chief executive, United Productions

fields.headline: The key players
fields.trailText: John Sulston and Craig Venter give their opposing views on gene patenting.
fields.body:
John Sulston: altruist or moralist?

With his wild beard and leather sandals, Oxfam supporter John Sulston is seen as a model of quiet British understatement.

The son of a vicar, the brilliant scientist's upbringing has fostered an anti-capitalist ideal which is at the heart of his beliefs. While his main rival, Dr Craig Venter, travels in Lear jets and conducts business from his 84-foot yacht,The Sorcerer, Dr Sulston prefers the humbler delights of growing runner beans and driving a second hand family car.

To a man with his socialist beliefs, the idea of selling his hard-earned scientific knowledge is unthinkable. "The only thing I have retained from my upbringing - I did not retain the religious element - is the idea that you do not do things for money," says Dr Sulston, 57. "Global capitalism is raping the earth, it's raping us. If it gets hold of complete control of the human genome, that is very bad news indeed. That is something we should fight against.

"I believe our basic information, our 'software', should be free and open for everyone to play with, to compete with, to try and make products from. I do not believe it should be under the control of one person. But that is what Celera are trying to do. As far as they can. They want to establish a monopoly position on the human sequence. Craig has gone morally wrong."

His point is underlined by the fact that discoveries made by the Human Genome Project, based at the Sanger Centre in Cambridgeshire and sponsored by the massive British medical charity the Wellcome Trust, are published each night on the internet for all to see.

Dr Sulston's career began in the 1960s when he completed an undergraduate degree in organic chemistry and a PhD at Cambridge, then headed for the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California.
There he studied prebiotic chemistry, while spending his free time arguing against the Vietnam War, having babies and enjoying dinners with Nobel Prize winners.

In 1969 he returned to Cambridge and was snapped up by the MRC laboratory where the DNA structure was first identified.

He then made his name studying the cell lineage and genome of the tiny soil organism Caenorhabditis elegans, a one millimetre-long worm. Sulston described the work as "solid middle-of-the-road science", but the long tedious months paid huge scientific dividends.
Dr Sulston and his colleagues at the University of Washington published the gene map of the nematode in 1990, then started to sequence it. When the Wellcome Trust entered the race to do the same for the human in 1992, Dr Sulston was appointed director of the new Sanger Centre.

The nematode team finally completed the genome sequence, the first for a complex animal, in 1998. It was a groundbreaking discovery, resulting from three decades of studying the humble worm. And it was merely a forerunner for Dr Sulston's biggest academic pursuit - the sequencing of the human genome.

Typically, Dr Sulston is modest about his previous achievements but is a passionate believer in pushing the boundaries of science.

He says: "What is the purpose of being human and alive without doing new things?" He is also passionate in his belief that our genetic blueprint should be publicly free and available. Genome sequencing for commercial gain is, he says, "totally immoral and disgusting".
Keith Perry

Craig Venter: maverick or monopolist?

To his critics, maverick scientist Craig Venter is known as Darth Venter, the evil monopolist. As the head of the billion-dollar US company Celera Genomics - slogan "Speed matters, discovery can't wait" - he is labelled a ruthless competitor who sold his soul to US business and planned to charge the rest of the human race a fortune to read their own genetic code. In the race to map the human genome, he has become the most controversial scientist of his day.

But Dr Venter, now 54, was not always a man in a hurry. At 18 he lived the life of a surfing drop-out on the beaches of Southern California. It was only in 1967, when he was drafted in to the Vietnam War that he realised time should not be wasted. He served as an orderly in the naval field hospital at Da Nang, witnessing the carnage of wounded and slaughtered soldiers around him. "Life was so cheap in Vietnam," he says. "That is where my sense of urgency comes from."

During his medical training at the University of California he excelled in research rather than practice, and switched to studying and teaching at the State University of New York. By the 1980s, the early days of the revolution in molecular biology, he was working at the government-funded US National Institute of Health and soon realised the importance of decoding genes. But the work was agonisingly slow and tedious. So in 1987, when he read reports of an automated decoding machine, he installed one in his laboratory. It sped things up; but not enough for Venter.

His real breakthrough came when he realised he did not need to trawl the entire genome to find the active parts because cells already use those parts naturally. He switched his attention from the DNA blueprint to the messenger molecules (called RNA) that a cell makes from that blueprint. That enabled him to churn out gene sequences at unprecedented rates. Some were astonished by his success, notably the co-discoverer of DNA, James Watson, who famously dismissed the relatively crude results as work "any monkey" could do.

The criticism and lack of public research funding prompted Dr Venter to leave the NIH in 1992 and set up a private research institute, The Institute for Genomic Research (funded by Human Genomic Sciences). In 1995 he again stunned scientists by unveiling the first genome of a free-living organism Haemophilus influenzae, a major cause of childhood ear infections and meningitis.

His greatest challenge to the medical establishment came in May 1998 when he announced the formation of a commercial company, Celera Genomics, to crack the entire human genetic code in just three years. At that point the public project was three years into a 10-year programme. The public project expected to complete the human genome in 2003, but Dr Venter aimed to finish by 2001.

In the pursuit of his ambition, Dr Venter has been vilified by the scientific fraternity for allegedly filing more than 20,000 provisional patents on human genes. Equally, critics despise him for his high-flying lifestyle, complete with gold Rolex, Hollywood-style interviews and the ability to raise US$1bn on the New York Stock Market in just one day.

Dr Venter brushes such criticisms away, defending his work with the complete self confidence that has become his hallmark: "Is my science of the level consistent with other people who have gotten the Nobel? Yes."

Despite his brashness, however, few can deny that this maverick genius's efforts in the field of human genomics accelerated the entire process. Until today it was still open to question whether the main beneficiaries of Dr Venter's groundbreaking research would be mankind or Celera's shareholders.
Keith Perry

fields.headline: The human genome
fields.standfirst: Scientists will unveil the first draft of the blueprint for human life today. Simon Jeffery explores its impact and the main players in the race to decipher the entire text of human DNA
fields.trailText: Scientists will unveil the first draft of the blueprint for human life today. We explore its impact and the main players in the race to decipher the entire text of human DNA.
fields.body:
What is the genome?
The genome is the genetic information needed to build a human being. Scientifically speaking, it is the sum of the strands of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) that are carried in the 46 chromosomes of each human cell. In short, the blueprint for human life.

What have scientists done?
They have decoded the genome. Scientists in London and Washington will today announce they have mapped out a working draft of the so-called "book of life" and are to post the data freely on the internet.

What is the difference between the working draft and the finished sequence?
The working draft will be less accurate than the finished sequence (it covers 90% of the human genome) but the data is invaluable to many bio-medical scientists looking to understand the genes relevant to their own work.

How important is it?
It depends who you ask. To some it is a greater scientific effort than splitting the atom or going to the moon. Others maintain it is a cultural achievement on a par with the works of Shakespeare. Once scientists get hold of the genome they will be able to take diseases with genetic (inherited) characteristics, such as heart disease and cancer, and cure them at their root. Government scientist John Harris of the Human Genetics Commission says gene technology could allow us to effectively cheat death as we live (healthily) beyond what we now consider old age.

If it is so useful why has nobody decoded it until now?
Francis Crick and James Watson discovered the structure of DNA in 1953. When scientists first proposed decoding the genome in the 1980s the cost of the tricky chemistry required to read it was up to $10 for each bit of the 3bn-letter human alphabet. The cost has now fallen to 10 to 20 cents per item thanks to astonishing advances in robotics, computing and electrochemistry.

So who claims the prize?
The race to decode the genome was spurred on by Craig Venter, head of US biotech firm Celera Genomics, who entered the field late but soon came to dominate it with his company's motto "Speed matters". Dr Venter's private interest (as opposed to competing public-funded research in the US and Europe) led many to fear that Celera would offer the genome up for sale. Thanks to some behind-the-scenes diplomacy the announcement will be made jointly with non-Celera scientists from Britain and America.

What has Britain contributed?
Britain has undertaken one-third of the $3bn project, funded by the Wellcome Trust, the world's leading medical charity. The US share was underwritten by the taxpayer through the national institutes of health.

Is anybody getting rich?
Last week, as word of a joint or at least simultaneous statement leaked out, Celera's stock shot up by $18.50 to $138.50 before falling to $125 on Friday. The raw data is not being patented but patents are being granted on data that has been identified as a gene and for which the function is known to some extent. Celera has made 6,500 patent applications.

What next?
The information unveiled today is a mass of raw data that, were it typed on single spaced on A4 paper, would fill 750,000 pages. In the years ahead scientists will try to interpret this data, which could be used to find cures for a range of diseases such as cancer, Alzheimer's, haemophilia, cystic fibrosis and heart disease. Some forecast that we may one day be looking at a way to stop ageing. In Japan, a research group has announced it will sequence the entire genome of humankind's nearest relative, the chimpanzee, in the hope of shedding light on the origins of language, logic and thinking.

Is decoding the genome a good thing?
Critics argue that housing, prosperity, education and improved nutrition have done more to improve human health in the last 100 years than radically improved medicine. Others raise the fear that decoding the genome will lead to a form of eugenics whereby tests on unborn babies will reveal a range of diseases and lead to an increase in terminations of "defective" babies. Another fear is that genetic tests that pinpoint inherited (and maybe incurable) diseases will lead to insurance companies charging high premiums on those deemed at high risk of developing conditions such as Huntington's or cancer.

fields.headline: Nod off and die
fields.standfirst:
Fatigue has overtaken alcohol as the biggest killer on Britain's roads. Simon Hacker tries out a simulator to find out just how easy it is to fall asleep at the wheel

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Fatigue has overtaken alcohol as the biggest killer on Britain's roads.  Simon Hacker  tries out a simulator to find out just how easy it is to fall asleep at the wheel
fields.body:
It's a guilt trip that most of us have made. It's the middle of the night, you've got 200 miles to go, and you're knackered. There's a service station a couple of miles ahead; Knutsford services, however, isn't quite your idea of an enticing place to stop. Besides, the road ahead is empty, and most of the police have knocked off for the evening. Of course you can make it.

However, as is becoming increasingly apparent, your chances of success may be lower than you think. Because it is emerging that the chief cause of road deaths is not booze, drugs, excessive speed or mobile phones; it is good old-fashioned fatigue.

The seriousness of the problem is highlighted by new research carried out at Loughborough University. Using a custom-built driving simulator in the university's sleep laboratory, Professor Jim Horne and his team have been subjecting volunteers to a series of tests to discover how their road-handling skills were affected by lack of sleep.

My experience showed just how risky the game can be. The night before my test I went to bed, as instructed, at 2am. Next morning, at the sleep laboratory, after the prescribed four hours and 50 minutes' sleep, I was festooned in electronic ligaments that feed eye movement and evidence of brain activity back to the monitors. Thus wired, I got into the cabin and began my virtual motorway drive to oblivion.

Just 30 minutes in, I was starting to flag. The technical assistant would periodically shout, "Sleep check!" whereupon I would be expected to give a rating of one to 10 (10 being perky, one being zonked) supplemented by an A to E (A meaning you don't expect to fall asleep in the next five minutes, E indicating you're comatose). Within a few miles, I'd moved from the relative safety of being an 8A to the sleep-infested waters of a 7C. But when I watched the video afterwards, I could see that I was more of a 5D - head leaning back against the headrest in a pathetic attempt to disguise my desire to flop.

I was not the only one to disgrace myself. After my test, Professor Horne showed me the tape of another subject (let's call him Patient X). Head lopped over, eyes rolled back, foot to the floor, Patient X was doing a steady 70. The vibrations from the hard shoulder rumble strip were pulsing through the cabin, but still he slumbered, arms hanging loosely from the steering wheel. After 15 minutes, he stirred, lifted his leaden lids and said he was feeling better. Soon afterwards, however, he was back in a slumber, charging on, eyes wide shut.

Having professed a tendency to doze off, Patient X had been a willing guinea pig for Horne's experiments. But he was so embarrassed by the recorded footage that he insisted that his identity be protected.

Horne's full test goes on for two to three hours and participants take it four times. His "success" rate would have the makers of Mogadon and Classic FM compilations seething with resentment; in the cosy, dark confines of a sawn-off Vauxhall Cavalier, after five hours' sleep, you have only a 10% chance of staying fully awake for a lengthy journey.

The proportion of people who fall asleep is not the only surprising statistic. Forget the image of doddery old ladies nodding off at the traffic lights; the highest risk group is that of male drivers aged under 30. And no matter what your age or gender, driving between 2am and 6am puts a spanner in your body clock, because at this time our bodies are programmed to sleep. Age is more likely to be a factor in the daytime; the older you are, the more susceptible you are to the corollary of the "afternoon dip", the time when most Europeans have wisely gone back to bed. And if you're a student, journalist, nurse, sales rep, commercial driver, doctor, pilot or night-shift worker, you're even more likely to suffer from drowsiness at the wheel.

The annual report on road accidents by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions revealed that 3,500 deaths occurred on Britain's roads in the year to 1998. Of these, police believe, SRVAs, or sleep-related vehicle accidents, claimed more lives than drink-driving. The problem is becoming so familiar to emergency services working on motorways and trunk roads that nicknames have been coined. Part of the M6 is called "the Sleepy Corridor" and the M1 at Boot Hill in Northants has become the "Nod-off Zone".

As part of Professor Horne's work, researcher Diane Flatley is compiling a league table of the UK's most soporific highways, the details of which will land somewhere on a desk in the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions this autumn. Top of the list is likely to be the M180, a popular haunt of Grimsby commuters. It has recently been the setting for four fatal crashes.

The SRVA figures are a wake-up call to road designers, many of whom seem to have overlooked the fact that if you drop drivers into a closed loop of repetitive tarmac, things will go wrong. Professor Horne wouldn't disagree - indeed, highways authorities have taken his team's advice and removed many lay-bys on gradual right-hand bends because they are a magnet not just to tired drivers but also to those who have already fallen asleep.

Professor Horne's focus, however, is more on the driver than on the road. He believes the real issue is personal: "People know when they are sleepy, they know if they are reaching the point of fighting sleep. But those who survive sleep-drive accidents will often say, 'I just suddenly fell asleep.' There is no truth in this. You can say, 'There but for the grace of God go I,' but there is simply no excuse for falling asleep at the wheel. We know the signs, but we choose to ignore them."

So what can be done to reduce your chances of succumbing to sleep? "Everyone has their own pet theory," says Horne. "We try all sorts of things, from turning up the radio, opening the window, chewing lemons and taking your shoes off. But there's no escape - if you're tired, you can even fall asleep with your eyes open." With luck, these results may help the DETR to formulate a sleep-drive rule equivalent to the recommendations on drinking and driving.

One of the likely guidelines is that five hours is not enough. Anything less than 300 minutes' sleep gives you Margaret Thatcher eyes and puts you on the cusp of sleep deprivation. Later that day, drive for more than two hours and the chances are that you'll feel the onset of fatigue - as 90% of Horne's guinea pigs did. (If, by the way, you've ever felt your head dip when behind the wheel, you've satisfied the lab definition of nodding off; slack neck muscles signal an advanced stage of sleep.)

The verdict will also nail the truth about coffee. The team has explored its potential to prevent sleepiness, but found that the all-important caffeine levels vary so widely both between and within brands that the results could not be measured. Subsequent tests of coffee at motorway service stations across Britain showed that while you need a shot of 150mg of caffeine to resharpen your senses, many service-station coffees contained no more than 30mg. So you'd need at least five cups of coffee (and a jumbo bladder) before you would be safe to drive again.

Furthermore, no brand of coffee lists its caffeine content, which is why the lab tests on the effect of caffeine were conducted with the help of the makers of the energy drink Red Bull. Two of the slimline cans packs the required 150mg punch; the efficacy of these countermeasures, when combined with a brief nap (and double-blind-tested using a caffeine-free version), looked promising.

"The results are not conclusive, but are becoming more so. So much advice, like stretching your legs and getting fresh air, is a waste of time; if you're tired, the only thing worth doing is sleep - a 15-minute nap is ideal, because it stops short of deep sleep, which can leave you groggy. Take half an hour's break in all to allow time for the caffeine to take effect."

All of which is helpful, but what of the prime victims, males under 30? Why are they so vulnerable to the risk of sleeping at the wheel? There is no conclusive data here, but the team have some inkling. "Fewer women drive at the high-risk times and women are quicker to recognise that they might be sleepy in the next five minutes; men take more risks; they deny being tired and say they can get through it. If they're half an hour from home, they won't stop. Which is why some never make it."

* Plan your journey

Avoid driving for extended periods between the hours of 2am and 5am, and in the early afternoon. Build in breaks at least every two and a half hours.

* Drive refreshed

Aim for at least seven hours' sleep the night before you travel.

* Find a safe place to rest

Whenever you feel tired, get off the road altogether - park away from passing traffic.

* Keep your caffeine levels up

Anything less than 150-200mg of caffeine is unlikely to be of any benefit (energy drinks list their caffeine content; coffees do not). Wait for the caffeine to take effect before you start driving again - rest for half an hour afterwards.

* Don't overdo it

Try not to sleep for more than 15 minutes to avoid the grogginess that can result from deep sleep.

webTitle: Me and my motor:  Sara Crowe

fields.headline: Me and my motor:  Sara Crowe
fields.trailText: What do you drive? A Fiat Punto cabriolet, inky blue.
fields.body:
What do you drive? A Fiat Punto cabriolet, inky blue.

What does it say about you? I love fresh air and the colour blue.

What do you like about it? I still get very excited about putting the roof up and down, but I don't like the boot space - it's too small.

Why did you buy it? My 2CV caught fire one day so I thought I really must get a safer car. I bought the Fiat primarily because of its roof - not that I'm obsessed.

What kind of driver are you? Pretty safe, bar the odd shortsighted swerve when I'm very tired.

Any bad habits? Swerving. I was cross-eyed as a child and while this has been corrected I find judging the width of the car difficult. I've left many a hubcap on the pavement.

Any driving test tales? I had the examiner examining the examiner in the back of the car during my test, which was more nerve-wracking. I went up the kerb on my reverse round the corner but passed everything else.

Have you ever got any points on your licence? I got three for speeding, which have been cleared now as it was a while ago.

Have you ever experienced road rage? I get angry at traffic lights and catch myself giving the light a bitchy look but I avoid outbursts of aggression at other drivers. I keep my V-signs below the window.

What state is your car in? It is a bit bashed outside and a bit hairy inside because of my dog, who leaves a bit of her behind each time.

What's in the boot? Dog food.

Have you ever had any romantic encounters in a car? Only outside the UK.

What music do you listen to on the road? Country.

What would be your dream car, and why? An old BMW convertible - sky blue with white roof and white seats. I love big cars. It would be like driving the living room.

Who would be your dream passenger? Raul from the Mavericks - he could sing to me along the freeway.

Sara Crowe appears in A Busy Day at the Lyric Theatre, Shaftesbury Avenue, London. Box office: 020-7494 5045

webTitle: Straw calls for more anti-lout court orders

fields.headline: Straw calls for more anti-lout court orders
fields.standfirst: Crime: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to tell the police and councils to make much greater use of anti-social behaviour orders against young thugs as part of a new drive against alcohol-fuelled violence.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to tell the police and councils to make much greater use of anti-social behaviour orders against young thugs as part of a new drive against alcohol-fuelled violence.

Mr Straw is to tell the police they do not need to wait for local authority backing before they take out the orders against loutish behaviour. They enable the courts to threaten to jail teenagers and neighbours who indulge in persistent disorder but which falls short of full-blown criminal behaviour.

So far only 70 orders have been made, mostly against neighbours who engage in criminal behaviour. But the home secretary will tell the Local Government Association on Wednesday that they "should be used swiftly where circumstances demand it, not just against the very hard cases of unacceptable behaviour".

Mr Straw confirmed yesterday that he expects the next batch of annual recorded crime figures, to be published next month, will show a sharp rise in violent crime - possibly by up to 19% and a 3.8% rise in all recorded crime over the past year.

"We have a general problem of drink-related violence in our society, particularly amongst younger men, which we have got to deal with, and it's one of the reasons why the violent crime figures are going up," Mr Straw told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost yesterday.

"When crime goes up, it's not good news, of course ... What we have got is a particular problem in our society, which we all have to talk about and deal with, which is of drink-related violence. We have also, in some of the main cities, London, Birmingham, Manchester and so on, got problems of street crime. We have put £20m into those police forces to be able to target the robbers."

The home secretary renewed his call to the crown courts to follow the guidance of the court of appeal and pass much tougher sentences on those convicted of street robbery. He said recent figures showed that sentences for street robbery were becoming shorter on average while prison terms for every other offence were getting longer.

The Home Office is also to bring in measures to tackle the link between drink and violent crime including ending uniform closing times and cracking down hard on rogue landlords.

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe said the expected rise in the violent crime figures wasn't surprising "when police numbers have fallen sharply, when violent prisoners are being let out before their due release date, and when the automatic life sentence, which we introduced for a second serious violent offence, is accompanied by low tariffs".

Police cadet forces could be introduced in secondary schools under plans being considered by the Conservatives. The intention is to boost recruitment following several years of falling numbers. The scheme would mirror the existing army cadet programme, which operates at schools and universities. It would be open to 16- to 18-year-olds.
