webTitle: Hairy woman, Bonny lad and Defensive dyke

fields.headline: Hairy woman, Bonny lad and Defensive dyke
fields.trailText: SIR MISS-A-LOT
fields.body:
SIR MISS-A-LOT

"Curses!" This very noise echoed around the corridors of Castle Milosevic last night as the ungainly lord of the manor struggled to come to terms with events. He, Savo Milosevic, had gone into that day's quarter-final against Holland as the leading scorer at Euro 2000 with four goals - and he scored again taking his total to... hang on a second... five. But, at the same time, that Patrick Kluivert goes and scores four goals to take him to six for the tournament. The hairy oracle of Osijek said nothing about that! Graaarrr!

As night settled itself into a comfortable position, Savo travelled to see the oracle and berate her with his big bumfluff moustache. Through wind and rain he rode and over hill and crag, but never did he waver from his path and at long last he arrived in the town. Savo asked the locals where to find the oracle. None would respond and he was on the verge of giving up when a shadowy figure appeared from behind a nearby Inn, the Cow's Arse and Banjo. "I am the hairy witch woman you seek," said the voice. "But you needn't have bothered, cos Uefa have decided that Kluivert's third was an own-goal off of Dejan Govedarica - you're joint top scorer again."

Savo closed his eyes for a moment to soak in the news, and when he opened them the witch had gone. Joint top scorer, and still with a chance to claim the boot of gold, Savo was pleased with himself as his horse headed off into the buffeting rain (it was eating cheese on sticks and a slice of broccoli quiche). As the countryside rolled by, Savo counted his luck and pledged his allegiance anew to the god of tap-ins.

Tomorrow: Sinisa Mihajlovic goes in search of the missing central defender (only to find that it's him).

BOBBY ROBSON SPEAKS

Dear me. You should see the amount of work I've got on at the moment. I've enough on my plate being openly laughed at by Sideshow Bob, Terry Venables and Glenn Hoddle on ITV's Euro 2000 football show, so the last thing I needed was a big pile of jobs to be getting on with at Newcastle. I'm 67, you know.

Don't get me wrong. It's good news that 26-year-old Argentinian striker Daniel Cordone has agreed to join us from Racing Club in a one-year £500,000 deal with the option of a two-year extension. But have I got time to talk to the press about it? I have not, bonny lad. So I'll just get some spokesperson to say, "The club and the player have agreed terms and he is due to come to Newcastle this week for a medical. Subject to the medical, we believe this should go through this week." That's dealt with that.

Now look at this! I've flipping got to sell Alessandro Pistone. I don't really want to lose the big Italian defender, but Everton's £3m bid was far too good to turn down. I'll tell you this, mind - the press can whistle if they think I'm explaining this one away. That spokesperson can just say, "The clubs have agreed terms and it is now down to the player. He's due to speak to Everton this week and we'll take it from there." Done and dusted.

But there's always something else, isn't there? Little Kieron Dyer's just spent a night in hospital after being reportedly glassed in the face at a nightclub, only a day after the News of the World accused him of indulging in a spot of videotaped slap 'n' tickle. Ee, kids, eh? Tell you what, I'll just get the spokesperson to say, "Clearly, the manager will be having words with Kieron on his return to training in July." Heh, heh! That gives me a couple of weeks to play with... plenty of time for a snooze, I reckon!

QUOTES OF THE DAY

"They've got great players without a doubt but playing the way they do is a bit risky if you ask me" - Paolo Maldini is underwhelmed by Holland's sexy football.

"I would like to play a perfect match in Euro 2000. I know that it is impossible, but is to something to which I aspire" - Boudewijn Zenden gets his philosophical absolutes in a twist.

ORANJE BOON

In an unprecedented development not seen since Rinus Michels conducted a training session in a coffee shop, peace has broken out in Dutch football. Yes, not only are the players not arguing with themselves, they're not arguing with Johan Cruyff either.

At the weekend, Cruyff offered the Oranje a rather stinging appraisal of their abilities: telling Kluivert he didn't do enough, Bergkamp that he was too weak, and Davids that he was an ordinary player. But after Kluivert scored a hat-trick yesterday, while Bergkamp was man of the match and Davids ran the midfield, Johan has seen fit to change his mind. The team are now "fantastic" and they should "enjoy the future", he says. Will that be possible, the Fiver wonders, with environmental disaster seemingly inevitable?

But, for now at least, everything is cheery in the Dutch camp - and nobody suspects any gamesmanship at all on the part of Cruyff, a good pal of coach Frank Rijkaard. However, as much as the Fiver is a supporter of positive thinking, it can go too far. Here, for example, is Dutch defensive dyke (watch it) Jaap Stam speaking today: "I felt very sorry for Phil Neville." Gaah! "He's a player you can always count on and he's always there for the team. It doesn't matter where he plays, he's always backing everybody up." It's appreciation of your fellow pros gone mad!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Spurs have made a £2m bid for Belgian striker Emile Mpenza. But Mpenza's German club, Schalke 04, have responded by valuing the profligate striker at £6.5m.

Kennet Andersson's agent, Vicenzo Morabito, has confirmed that his client is interested in a £2m move to Arsenal. "Kennet thinks Arsenal is a good and interesting club," he said. "He has also got a nice offer from Fiorentina and, within ten days, we will decide where he will move."

Manchester United have denied that David Beckham will move to Barcelona. It was suggested this morning that the signing of Beckham would be used to help candidates secure Barca's vacant chairman's position. However United spokesman Ken Ramsden said: "There has been no offer at all yet - I think this is a flyer from the Spanish press."

NEWS IN BRIEF

Antonio Conte has been ruled out of Italy's remaining Euro 2000 games with ankle ligament damage. The Juventus midfielder was stretchered off in the quarter-final against Romania after being tackled by Gheorghe Hagi. Internazionale's Luigi Di Biagio is likely to take his place against Holland on Thursday.

Bruce Rioch is the new manager of Wigan. The ex-Arsenal and Norwich boss has not signed a contract yet, but Wigan chairman Dave Whelan says they have an agreement for either a three or four-year deal.

Liverpool's home games in next season's Euro-Vase will be screened live on BBC1. The BBC also announced that the Uefa Super Cup Final between Real Madrid and Galatasaray will be screened live on August 25.

Aston Villa will be without Luc Nilis when they begin their InterToto Cup campaign next month. The Belgian striker, who agreed to join Villa back in March, cannot be registered with Uefa by the competition's end-of-June deadline as his current contract with PSV Eindhoven does not expire until July 1.

Former Tottenham, Barcelona and Scotland striker Steve Archibald is poised to take over Airdrie. Archibald insists he has met the demands of provisional liquidators KPMG and would be "very surprised if the deal is not done in the near future".

Hearts striker Fabien Leclerq has signed for Cannes.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 (5pm, 8pm, 10.15pm, 11.15pm, 11.30pm, 11.45pm, 12midnight, 1am, 2am)

Not in any way milking their football rights for all their worth.

As night settled itself into a comfortable position, Savo travelled to see the oracle and berate her with his big bumfluff moustache. Through wind and rain he rode and over hill and crag, but never did he waver from his path and at long last he arrived in the town. Savo asked the locals where to find the oracle. None would respond and he was on the verge of giving up when a shadowy figure appeared from behind a nearby Inn, the Cow's Arse and Banjo. "I am the hairy witch woman you seek," said the voice. "But you needn't have bothered, cos Uefa have decided that Kluivert's third was an own-goal off of Dejan Govedarica - you're joint top scorer again." Savo closed his eyes for a moment to soak in the news, and when he opened them the witch had gone. Joint top scorer, and still with a chance to claim the boot of gold, Savo was pleased with himself as his horse headed off into the buffeting rain (it was eating cheese on sticks and a slice of broccoli quiche). As the countryside rolled by, Savo counted his luck and pledged his allegiance anew to the god of tap-ins. Tomorrow: Sinisa Mihajlovic goes in search of the missing central defender (only to find that it's him). BOBBY ROBSON SPEAKS Dear me. You should see the amount of work I've got on at the moment. I've enough on my plate being openly laughed at by Sideshow Bob, Terry Venables and Glenn Hoddle on ITV's Euro 2000 football show, so the last thing I needed was a big pile of jobs to be getting on with at Newcastle. I'm 67, you know. Don't get me wrong. It's good news that 26-year-old Argentinian striker Daniel Cordone has agreed to join us from Racing Club in a one-year £500,000 deal with the option of a two-year extension. But have I got time to talk to the press about it? I have not, bonny lad. So I'll just get some spokesperson to say, "The club and the player have agreed terms and he is due to come to Newcastle this week for a medical. Subject to the medical, we believe this should go through this week." That's dealt with that. Now look at this! I've flipping got to sell Alessandro Pistone. I don't really want to lose the big Italian defender, but Everton's £3m bid was far too good to turn down. I'll tell you this, mind - the press can whistle if they think I'm explaining this one away. That spokesperson can just say, "The clubs have agreed terms and it is now down to the player. He's due to speak to Everton this week and we'll take it from there." Done and dusted. But there's always something else, isn't there? Little Kieron Dyer's just spent a night in hospital after being reportedly glassed in the face at a nightclub, only a day after the News of the World accused him of indulging in a spot of videotaped slap 'n' tickle. Ee, kids, eh? Tell you what, I'll just get the spokesperson to say, "Clearly, the manager will be having words with Kieron on his return to training in July." Heh, heh! That gives me a couple of weeks to play with... plenty of time for a snooze, I reckon! QUOTES OF THE DAY "They've got great players without a doubt but playing the way they do is a bit risky if you ask me" - Paolo Maldini is underwhelmed by Holland's sexy football. "I would like to play a perfect match in Euro 2000. I know that it is impossible, but is to something to which I aspire" - Boudewijn Zenden gets his philosophical absolutes in a twist. ORANJE BOON In an unprecedented development not seen since Rinus Michels conducted a training session in a coffee shop, peace has broken out in Dutch football. Yes, not only are the players not arguing with themselves, they're not arguing with Johan Cruyff either. At the weekend, Cruyff offered the Oranje a rather stinging appraisal of their abilities: telling Kluivert he didn't do enough, Bergkamp that he was too weak, and Davids that he was an ordinary player. But after Kluivert scored a hat-trick yesterday, while Bergkamp was man of the match and Davids ran the midfield, Johan has seen fit to change his mind. The team are now "fantastic" and they should "enjoy the future", he says. Will that be possible, the Fiver wonders, with environmental disaster seemingly inevitable? But, for now at least, everything is cheery in the Dutch camp - and nobody suspects any gamesmanship at all on the part of Cruyff, a good pal of coach Frank Rijkaard. However, as much as the Fiver is a supporter of positive thinking, it can go too far. Here, for example, is Dutch defensive dyke (watch it) Jaap Stam speaking today: "I felt very sorry for Phil Neville." Gaah! "He's a player you can always count on and he's always there for the team. It doesn't matter where he plays, he's always backing everybody up." It's appreciation of your fellow pros gone mad! THE RUMOUR MILL Spurs have made a £2m bid for Belgian striker Emile Mpenza. But Mpenza's German club, Schalke 04, have responded by valuing the profligate striker at £6.5m. Kennet Andersson's agent, Vicenzo Morabito, has confirmed that his client is interested in a £2m move to Arsenal. "Kennet thinks Arsenal is a good and interesting club," he said. "He has also got a nice offer from Fiorentina and, within ten days, we will decide where he will move." Manchester United have denied that David Beckham will move to Barcelona. It was suggested this morning that the signing of Beckham would be used to help candidates secure Barca's vacant chairman's position. However United spokesman Ken Ramsden said: "There has been no offer at all yet - I think this is a flyer from the Spanish press." NEWS IN BRIEF Antonio Conte has been ruled out of Italy's remaining Euro 2000 games with ankle ligament damage. The Juventus midfielder was stretchered off in the quarter-final against Romania after being tackled by Gheorghe Hagi. Internazionale's Luigi Di Biagio is likely to take his place against Holland on Thursday. Bruce Rioch is the new manager of Wigan. The ex-Arsenal and Norwich boss has not signed a contract yet, but Wigan chairman Dave Whelan says they have an agreement for either a three or four-year deal. Liverpool's home games in next season's Euro-Vase will be screened live on BBC1. The BBC also announced that the Uefa Super Cup Final between Real Madrid and Galatasaray will be screened live on August 25. Aston Villa will be without Luc Nilis when they begin their InterToto Cup campaign next month. The Belgian striker, who agreed to join Villa back in March, cannot be registered with Uefa by the competition's end-of-June deadline as his current contract with PSV Eindhoven does not expire until July 1. Former Tottenham, Barcelona and Scotland striker Steve Archibald is poised to take over Airdrie. Archibald insists he has met the demands of provisional liquidators KPMG and would be "very surprised if the deal is not done in the near future". Hearts striker Fabien Leclerq has signed for Cannes. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO British Eurosport: Euro 2000 (5pm, 8pm, 10.15pm, 11.15pm, 11.30pm, 11.45pm, 12midnight, 1am, 2am) Not in any way milking their football rights for all their worth.

fields.headline: Digital channels threat to public
fields.trailText: John willis on broadcasting.
fields.body:
In Boston recently, I was visiting WGBH, the flagship station of the US Public Broadcasting System (PBS), where I came across the preparations for an auction to raise funds for the channel. The volunteers lining up at trestle tables appeared more akin to a church jumble sale than an important component in the economics of a major television station.

The point is that here was a group of citizens who cared as passionately about their public service television station as their local school. Pledge weeks in which viewers donate to PBS have been a a part of the funding base of the system for many years and, in case you think this is irrelevant, WGBH co-produce a huge amount of classic British drama as well as making current affairs and science programmes of high ambition.

When Newt Gingrich tried to destroy PBS funding a few years ago, it was viewers all over the country, the equivalents of those Boston volunteers, who turned the tide against "nuking Newt".

PBS, like public sector broadcasters all over the world, is wrestling with a fundamental question. Should it compete with commercial services or stay distinctive by offering viewers unique programmes? In Britain, the fierce bidding for soccer rights has highlighted that dilemma for the BBC, and Mark Thompson's radical Banff speech (which David Elstein wrote about here last week) has indicated where their intentions lie. The war over ITV's news has only served to highlight the confusion surrounding the role of public service on all channels.

On Friday, broadcasters and other interested parties handed in their evidence for the Communications Bill White Paper. Here the shape of broadcasting will be hammered out but underpinning almost every clause in the bill will be one key issue. Public service broadcasting now needs to be framed in a multi-channel landscape with internet access. And finding a new definition will be as difficult as catching blancmange.

Crucial judgments affecting all channels will be informed by the future framework as defined by public service obligations. What is the role of news on ITV when there are four 24/7-news channels? How far should the BBC's commercial partnerships stretch? What is the Channel 4 remit when it expands into more entertainment-based channels?

In the digital world the anchor points of public service broadcasting will be ever more important. In the gold rush of commercial services, impartial information, cultural access, educational opportunity and indigenous drama and entertainment should be there for all. Social exclusion is almost as relevant to information as it is to jobs or housing. Digital division is a significant obstacle in the new media world.

Andrew Graham and Gavyn Davies were right when they wrote: "Public service broadcasting is not an optional add-on but central to the health of all broadcasting." This is the same Andrew Graham who will be advising the government on this issue as White Paper submissions are assessed.

The BBC's obsession with market measurement, now imported in part into Channel 4, has meant that for too long public service broadcasting has been defined in a mechanistic way. It was as if efficiency and focus groups had replaced creativity and diversity as key elements of public service broadcasting's genetic make-up. Serving the viewer is more than audience measurement, "value" in public service broadcasting is more than value for money.

Walking with Dinosaurs, Warriors, The 1900 House, Elizabeth, The Murder of Stephen Lawrence and The Royle Family, show that good programme-making of ambition can still make commercial and cultural value indivisible.

The underlying core principle of universality of access laid down by John Reith in 1924 still applies but we should delete "broadcasting" from the phrase public service broadcasting because the concept should now be enshrined in much more than conventional television.

New technology merely offers a different delivery mechanism for public service functions. News, education, regionalism, community debate, participation and internationalism are renewed opportunities in the new world.

When access is fast, cheap and universal there is a huge potential for a more interactive, more democratic form of public service than in old media. I hope that, as the crucial debate hots up, the notion of public service broadcasting is not trapped in history but rather redefined for the future.

Without a cultural and economic framework in which to progress, some of the most valued strengths of British television are in jeopardy. Public service broadcasting needs looking after. It's like hair on a middle-aged man - by the time you've noticed it's disappeared, it's too late.

John Willis is chief executive, United Productions

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: • Handbags are swinging between sparring women's portals iCircle and Handbag.com. Last week Hollinger-backed Handbag complained to the ASA that its rival's recent adverts in the trades were misleading. People reading the full page ads in NMA assumed that the claim "more women visit our pages than buy Cosmo, She or Elle put together", related to iCircle and not to its parent company Freeserve, since its logo was heading-up the page, whereas "Freeserve" was tucked away at the bottom and half the size.
fields.body:
 Handbags are swinging between sparring women's portals iCircle and Handbag.com. Last week Hollinger-backed Handbag complained to the ASA that its rival's recent adverts in the trades were misleading. People reading the full page ads in NMA assumed that the claim "more women visit our pages than buy Cosmo, She or Elle put together", related to iCircle and not to its parent company Freeserve, since its logo was heading-up the page, whereas "Freeserve" was tucked away at the bottom and half the size.

Given that the channel's monthly visits have levelled out at 90,000 and the total reach of the magazines is around 900,000, the suggestion was patently ridiculous. Indeed the diary itself at the time called up the number given to register its concern, only to be put straight through to a Freeserve adsalesperson. This mild distortion of the actualité might have slipped by unnoticed had not iCircle's page impressions overtaken Handbag's in recent weeks - an indignity which the grande dame of women's portals just could not brook.

 UK-based alternative web TV channel DVTV, aka Digital Versatile Television, which aims to be "like an early Channel 4" with documentaries on everything from the dawn of white dreadlocks to ghetto rap, has already notched up 220,000 hits, just a week after launch. The mystery is that half the hits originate in South Africa.

 An amusing turnout at last week's WAP Wednesday event. Tamer Garip, the CEO of MyWAPworld.com, attempting to illustrate how the mobile internet could be fun, invited the audience to pick up their phones and collect a token from the site for a free beer afterwards at the local pub. Unfortunately, a technical hitch prevented most from doing so.

 The irreverent US investment site MotleyFool.com has dropped its print magazine, which had 15,000 subscribers, after a trial year. The money will be redirected into new interactive products and the three-hour show it already has on Cox Radio. Slate.com, the cult online journal, has also recently cut 10% of its staff.

 Hype phrase of the week is "the threat of the internet", which was used no fewer than 10 times by speakers at the Total Publishing conference at Earls Court last Wednesday. The Age of Convergence is still obviously a long way off for some.

fields.headline: Need to know: Mark Wilkinson
fields.trailText: Age? 38
fields.body:
Age? 38

Who is he?

MD and co-founder of DVTVchannel.com, an internet TV station. Ex-documentary maker.

What's the clever idea?

"A TV channel broadcast via the internet, as opposed to general TV which is delivered to you and that's the end of it. You can watch and chat to people at the same time all over the world, via an online chat page. You can email questions to the presenter on the live programmes. Interactive, versatile TV - it's not just delivered to you, you participate in it. We don't see ourselves as an alternative to TV but complementing it. We're offering similar things - live music, chat shows, documentary, dance, drama, fashion. We make 80% of it."

What's the thinking behind it?

"As a documentary maker I got the John Mayatt art fraud story, which was quite exclusive. I didn't want to give it away, so the initial idea was to broadcast just that documentary on the internet. From that came the whole channel idea - doing lots of things rather than just one thing. Streaming's been happening for a while, but because we've got a broad range of programming, we are the first real TV channel. The advantage of DVTV is that if you're watching part three of, say, the John Mayatt Story, you can go back and watch parts one and two. On telly you can't."

How does it work?

"We have a remote control that you download from our website, so it's on your computer all the time. Then you click "go live" and it opens it all up for you and starts streaming the programming. You don't have to put www.dvtvchannel.com in. Each week we have new programmes which rotate for seven days - at the moment an hour and 20 minutes' worth that people can watch. After that it goes into the archive. People only really go online for say 10 minute slots, so there's no point putting 24 hours on. At the top of the page, there's a menu. As you're watching the programme, you can click on chat and open up the chat room."

Possible shortcomings?

"People have to pay for internet access, but that's changing. Our service is free."

What's next?

"Because we're a production company, we're hoping to do co-productions with satellite, cable and terrestrial. So you're watching one part on your TV and the 'hypersodes' on DVTV - extra little episodes and information you can interact with, ie you can click on somebody's head and download a dream sequence. There'll also be a shop at the top of the page - you'll be able to buy, say, the presenters' T-shirts or sofas and, if a band is playing, their CDs and posters."

fields.headline: Music industry is caught Napstering
fields.trailText: An eight-month old web company that refuses to reveal the size of its customer list has been courted by not one but two of the world's largest internet companies in the past few months, during which it has been valued at an estimated $200m (£133m).
fields.body:
An eight-month old web company that refuses to reveal the size of its customer list has been courted by not one but two of the world's largest internet companies in the past few months, during which it has been valued at an estimated $200m (£133m).

Amid the fear and loathing stalking dot.com land, online music companies are still partying like it's 1999, or at least like it was before the dark days of April gave everyone a hangover.

In spite of a raft of lawsuits from an irate recording industry claiming billions of dollars in damages, analysts and industry executives are still talking about the internet eclipsing the radio and turning us all into broad- casters. Who needs an indie music channel or for that matter Classic FM, when you can just stream the music of your choice into your car? Or onto your phone or your Palm Pilot?

In the face of such enthusiasm, record industry executives have behaved in the same way that many media honchos did as recently as a year ago. They simply ignored the phenomenon or abused it as a passing fad for greasy-haired geeks wearing black T-shirts in college campus basements. Does anyone remember the reaction of traditional media companies at the start of the online assault on print?

The antipathy of the recording industry in general - and the five major record labels in particular - towards dedicated online rivals has been far more passionate than that of many other industries, however, because of the added problems of ownership.

The industry reaction to date has been characterised by high-profile lawsuits launched by major record companies wary of the ease with which fans could send digital sound files to each other without restrictions on copying or distribution. Witness the legal attacks by the Recording Industry Association of America on Napster, a popular music swapping service, and MyMP3.com, which offers a free music collection.

But there are signs that large companies are waking up to how attractive new technologies are, rather in the same way that media groups from Time Warner to News Corporation did last year.

This interest is partly sparked by the expected rate of growth of online music. In the US, it attracts more than the odd dweller of Wayne's World. It has become so popular among students - jocks and cheerleaders as well as the nerds - that many university campuses in the US have banned the use of sites such as Napster. A survey by Webnoize, a research group based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, found that more than 70% of all college students in the north-east of America were downloading files from Napster alone, a service which has already been described as the most rapidly adopted software in the history of the internet.

Jupiter, a New York-based internet consultancy, has forecast that sales of digitally distributed music will reach $147m by 2003 as well as helping to drive the $2.6bn music market.

Given these statistics and the history of new media to date, it is perhaps not surprising that companies such as Yahoo, one of the world's most popular portals, and America Online, the world's largest internet service provider, were the first to realise that although legal rights should be protected, they cannot be used to stop a rising tide. Both groups have talked to several online music companies as well as industry giants from Sony to Seagram about possible allegiances. They are also both interested in Myplay.com, the eight-month-old music company that is attractive largely because it claims to be doing something legal as well as popular.

The California-based Myplay offers a "virtual locker" which lets users download, manage and play music on any device, anywhere in the world. The company claims to police these compilations so that they do not fall foul of copyright laws and, more importantly, to pay royalties for the songs used.

How it makes money from doing this has to do with the usefulness of the information it compiles. Any user willing to sign up for regular emails of desirable services or new offers is a dollar sign for Myplay.

This base note of legality has attracted the likes of Yahoo and AOL. The former has talked to the company about a possible takeover while the latter signed its own alliance with Myplay earlier this year.

There are signs that the rest of the online music business is also keen to become legitimate, with the recent legal MP3.com settlement.

Controls over online music are more complicated than those of the print media: the need for the old guard to understand the importance of the new is not. Interest in upstart music companies shows that for the recording industry, the times are still a'changing.

Given these statistics and the history of new media to date, it is perhaps not surprising that companies such as Yahoo, one of the world's most popular portals, and America Online, the world's largest internet service provider, were the first to realise that although legal rights should be protected, they cannot be used to stop a rising tide. Both groups have talked to several online music companies as well as industry giants from Sony to Seagram about possible allegiances. They are also both interested in Myplay.com, the eight-month-old music company that is attractive largely because it claims to be doing something legal as well as popular. The California-based Myplay offers a "virtual locker" which lets users download, manage and play music on any device, anywhere in the world. The company claims to police these compilations so that they do not fall foul of copyright laws and, more importantly, to pay royalties for the songs used. How it makes money from doing this has to do with the usefulness of the information it compiles. Any user willing to sign up for regular emails of desirable services or new offers is a dollar sign for Myplay. This base note of legality has attracted the likes of Yahoo and AOL. The former has talked to the company about a possible takeover while the latter signed its own alliance with Myplay earlier this year. There are signs that the rest of the online music business is also keen to become legitimate, with the recent legal MP3.com settlement. Controls over online music are more complicated than those of the print media: the need for the old guard to understand the importance of the new is not. Interest in upstart music companies shows that for the recording industry, the times are still a'changing.

fields.headline: The deal was good
fields.standfirst:
Richard Scudamore, chief executive of the Premier League, hits back at last week's Media Guardian cover story

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Richard Scudamore, chief executive of the Premier League, hits back at last week's Media Guardian cover story on TV rights.
fields.body:
The great thing about being chief executive of the Premier League is that you are never short of advice. In the course of a season it comes at you from everywhere - passions are aroused, strong views expressed. The last few weeks are no exception with added opinion deflected from the sports pages in the sale of our media rights.

Most of the media speculation has been measured and well intentioned but Mathew Horsman's article in last week's Media Guardian was remarkable in its tone, bias and lack of understanding. The record needs to be put straight.

When the Premier League embarked on the process of selling its media rights in January, the inevitable press speculation talked of a £2bn price tag for a five-year deal. We did not fuel this estimate and rather expected to douse it by announcing that we were offering rights for a three-year term only. We have now realised over £1.1bn for the live 66-game package, £328m for 40 pay-per-view games and £183m for highlights - £1.645bn so far, with international rights, video on demand, mobile telephony and internet rights still to be sold.

It is perhaps just as well we did not take Mr Horsman's advice - back in November last year he was extensively quoted in the press as saying that £1bn for the subscription package was an inflated estimate: "Something like £750m over three years might be nearer the mark," he said. We are grateful for the advice of others which got us over £1.1bn. When we started the process it was our intention to adhere to key principles. The quality of broadcasting must exceed exacting thresholds; the Premier League brand must be safeguarded; access for viewers and promotion of the game enhanced. The process should be clear to all bidders and take account of the regulatory concerns being expressed by the office of fair trading and the European Commission. It should be kept confidential. It should allow our current partners and new entrants a fair chance. It should ensure long-term competition for the rights. We have upheld these principles.

The first decision was to give all bidders clear guidance on the rights on offer. This was done in an invitation to tender, agreed by the clubs and issued in early April. Bidders had to respond with qualitative descriptions of their editorial proposition and scheduling, their valuations for individual packages and the value they might place on any combinations of packages. This constituted the first round of bidding and indicated that selling different packages to different bidders would yield high values.

And with the regulators wanting to see competition in the broadcasting market the Premier League would face the serious probability of regulatory intervention if, with a totally exclusive arrangement, we ignored several qualified bidders who were prepared to buy our rights.

Once we knew there was serious competition for the packages and that we could meet regulatory concerns our course was clear. We recommended a further round of sealed bids. We also stated that if the bids were close we would go to further rounds to establish a definitive winner. The idea that we would not consider a second round is wrong and a misunderstanding of the process. It was in fact each winning bid being sufficiently clear of the runner-up that rendered further rounds obsolete. The club chairmen unanimously agreed with the process.

The winning bids in June were all significantly higher than those submitted in the first round in May, including any received for a combined or "exclusive" bid. Each and every bidder, be they winner or loser, has expressed to me that the process was fair. There has been no complaint to the regulators. I have letters from the main losers commending us on the process and the way they were treated. With the exception of Mathew Horsman there has been no adverse comment from analysts on the values achieved so far. Given the accusations levelled at our advisers, I would like to pay tribute to them. The commercial negotiations and discussions with the bidders were undertaken thoroughly and astutely by David Kogan of Reel Enterprises. The bid analysis and technical work by William Field and Dougal Scott of Spectrum were highly accurate and robust; the legal work by Polly Weitzman and Nick West of Denton Wilde Sapte was of the highest order

The clubs deserve credit for their conduct throughout and have been rewarded with good deals, the broadcasters are well satisfied and the most important thing is that fans will have more choice - 66 games on Sky, Saturday and Sunday free-to-air highlights on ITV and the chance to see more of their own team through Premium TV on a pay-per-view basis. My advice - we have plenty to share - is to wait and enjoy watching for yourself.

fields.headline: Reality bites the dust?
fields.standfirst:
As BBC1 turns against factual programmes, Maggie Brown argues that it risks squandering the innovative ideas of the past decade - and that the obits for 'pop docs' are premature

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: As BBC1 turns against factual programmes, Maggie Brown argues that it risks squandering the innovative ideas of the past decade - and that the obits for 'pop docs' are premature
fields.body:
On the face of it, the BBC's much-vaunted decision to cut the amount of lightweight, cheap, factual programming it screens should come as a relief. It's a victory for viewers sated with the spread of cooks, vets, sickly animals, makeovers and gardening shows across the main five channels - stemming from a clutch of pioneering BBC programmes in the 90s, which rivals rushed to copy.

Meanwhile, those running zoos, schools, factories, hotels, airports, and other public institutions may find themselves a little less plagued by fevered television producers, competing to point cameras at them.

And, with producers already working on 100 extra episodes of Doctors, the BBC's new cheap daytime soap, and maybe 30 more episodes of Holby City, the Casualty spin-off, in production, it is clear the drama machine is being cranked up, big time. This message has certainly been absorbed by some of the biggest suppliers of documentary soaps.

Jeremy Mills, managing director of independent producer Lion TV, whose observational "soap", Paddington Green returns this summer with 24 episodes, says it is now the only one of its kind in production among the 100 or so projects in hand. He's also set up a drama team.

But hang on. Some of the smartest brains behind the 90s factual boom are also bemused by BBC1's swift march towards a purer schedule of drama and entertainment. They all say documentary soaps can be compelling. Is the BBC in danger of becoming too black and white?

Alex Graham, chief executive of Wall to Wall Television, which is achieving international success with its breakthrough format, 1900 House for Channel 4 (putting real people into a Victorian environment), says: "It flies in the face of experience. For the past decade, the BBC has been the industry's pedagogue of factual programming. From Driving School and Animal Hospital to Changing Rooms and Ready Steady Cook, the most innovative programmes of the past decade have been factual.

"We forget how fresh they were in their time. Now American TV, which traditionally built its prime schedules on drama and entertainment, is awakening to the possibilities just as the British are switching off." Graham is negotiating to make a Frontier House series for American TV.

Jim Allen, LWT's controller of factual programmes, is also surprised. The man responsible for making stars of stroppy traffic wardens and warring neighbours heads a powerhouse department delivering more than 100 hours of programming a year for a variety of outlets, including ITV's hit Airline (a copy of the BBC's Airport) and the hedonistic Ibiza Uncovered series, which was snapped up from Sky by Channel 4. Most recently, the two-part ITV documentaries, Holiday Airport, about the goings on at Orlando and Palma, attracted a satisfactory 8m viewers and a 38% share, proving that popular factual programmes are far from bust.

"At the moment we have at least four negotiations going on for access [to various institutions]. Three will say no. But one will say yes. I think things are cyclical, television's not that different from a boom/bust economy," says Allen.

"Four years ago, if you were drawing up a programming proposition, then the words docu-soap would help it when you pitched. Now you wouldn't put it on in a month of Sundays." One problem is that the troubled institutions the cameras would really like to crack, from Wormwood Scrubs and London Underground to the boardroom of Marks & Spencer, are not prepared to allow the cameras in.

Allen says the challenge now is to be imaginative. So LWT's programme, It Shouldn't Happen to a Newsreader, mixed archive footage and interviews with the presenters with a touch of the tried and tested All Right on the Night format. "New ideas are coming through in factual. A lot is happening in what is now called 'format' factual. This an enormous area, there is lots worth doing," Allen says cheerily.

Jeremy Mills, whose compelling production of Castaway 2000 for BBC1 fits into the new style of "format" factual (as does 1900 House) says: "My view is that there is confusion between 'entertainment' and 'entertaining'. I can't imagine BBC1 with a pure diet of drama and comedy." And, as he points out, different strands feed off and fertilise each other. The BBC2 drama Cops owes a debt to documentary fly-on-the-wall soap.

Christopher Hird of Fulcrum Productions is also having success with a fresh - and what he calls "constructed" factual series - Can You Live Without . . ? So far, a family has done without television, an executive without her make-up and a man without his wife. Further programmes about doing without your secretary and your domestic staff are still to come. These are all challenges to test the resolve and reaction of real people.

The series began with a single Dispatches documentary, Can You Live Without Your Car?, and now with audiences of 1.8m, a second series is already under discussion. "We've found a way to introduce a substantial narrative interest. You want to see what happens, but at the same time it gives you an insight into bigger themes, touching news and current affairs. We all feel we watch too much television or use our car too much," adds Hird. "Documentary soaps make no effort to address an agenda bigger than themselves. The Can You Live Without . . ? programmes are constructed programmes. But the point is that you are in an everyday environment, something viewers recognise. And then there is the boldness of the challenge." All the same, Hird adds a cautionary note: "But I do hesitate about completely abandoning documentary soaps."

Next month sees yet another development in factual television. Peter Bazalgette's Bazal Productions (part of the Guardian Media Group), the company which changed the face of television in the 1990s with Changing Rooms and Ground Force, is making a British version of Big Brother, a format now sweeping Europe.

This endurance gameshow places a group in an isolated environment, then lets viewers pry on their lives together, and vote on whom to throw out. The survivor wins a prize. Big Brother is, says Bazalgette, "absolutely this year's TV format", in part because of the interactive element. "Documentaries and leisure programmes have reached a Malthusian climax," says Bazalgette, the king of leisure programming. "The audience is sated. Has there been too much? Yes, there probably has."

Some of the programmes are too similar, Bazalgette argues, but he clearly believes the BBC is partly to blame, by allowing its in-house producers to make copies (DIY SOS, Real Rooms) of his own successful formats. "I get hot under the collar about it," he adds.

Meanwhile, presenters such as Charlie Dimmock are asked to host more BBC shows, increasing the belief that everything is the same. But Bazalgette also sees a new factual gap for what he calls "lightly formatted shows", ie programmes charting real people in real situations - except for the camera crews. In three weeks' time, Channel 4 starts running Flat Mates, in which five young people looking for a room are interviewed by potential flat mates. "I call it Friends meets Shallow Grave," he says. Interestingly, neither show was offered to the BBC.

If these shows work, it will add weight to those who warn that television can't be rigid, that hits don't fall into neat categories. But equally, amid all the trendy talk, the recent ratings success of Elizabeth, a traditional history series on Channel 4, shows that straightforward factual programmes are also far from dead. That's why, while Big Brother grabs headlines, there will be much mulling over the performance of Guns and Roses, BBC1's series following the training of eight women army officers at Sandhurst, starting this Thursday at 8.30pm. It has been filmed in a entirely conventional manner.

fields.headline: Avatars 'R' us
fields.standfirst: As the PA's launch of the virtual newscaster Ananova shows, the internet is forcing once-shy news agencies into the limelight. How will they adapt, asks  Elen Lewis
fields.trailText: As the PA's launch of the virtual newscaster Ananova shows, the internet is forcing once-shy news agencies into the limelight. How will they adapt, asks Elen Lewis
fields.body:
News agencies such as Reuters have traditionally been one of the best-kept secrets of the media industry. However, the growth of the internet is set to change all that. Over the past year, driven by the digital age, both Reuters and its local UK competitor PA have been dipping their toes into the brave new world of the consumer.

The two media companies have reacted differently to the new economy. PA noisily launched a virtual newscaster, Ananova, before swiftly announcing its green-haired consumer brand was for sale and that it intended to consolidate its "B2B" (business-to-business) wholesaler role.

Reuters has taken a different tack. It announced in February that it would invest £500m in refashioning itself into a new media company and has made a paradigm shift from B2B into a "B2B4C" (business-to-business for consumers) model via the internet. This entails selling its live news feeds to a large number of websites (the B2B part), which can be accessed directly by the public (the 4C part.)

The anonymity of news agency journalists is renowned. A poignant example of this was when a Reuters journalist died while reporting on the Sierra Leone conflict in May, "although not many people knew the name of Kurt Schork, his material ended up everywhere," says Rodney Pinder, head of video news at Reuters.

Look at any daily newspaper and it is likely that a Reuters picture will be on the front or the back page. Watch international news and Reuters will probably be providing the footage. Remember the harrowing Eritrean famine pictures? The Blair baby? Reuters got there first.

PA can also boast a string of exclusives that would not have been apparent to the man on the street. PA was first with Diana's death; it was also a PA journalist who was granted an interview with Prince William on his recent 18th birthday.

But news agency journalists are coming out of the shadows and into the limelight. "We're becoming far more visible as a result of the internet," says Pinder. Not only can the public access undiluted news via 1,000 news feeds to different websites, but the transparency of the medium ensures Reuters is credited for its pictures and copy in a way that did not exist in the traditional world. In the UK, it has linked content deals with the likes of Yahoo!, WH Smith, FT.com, Excite, AOL and Altavista.

Thus, the 149-year-old company, whose roots lie in specialist financial services and as wholesaler to the media business, is crossing into the realm of retailer. "We're looking to expand our client base in the B2C [business-to-consumer] and the B2B4C range," a spokesman says. "Our competence fits neatly into the new world," says Geoffrey Wheating, Reuters' director of strategic media development.

Consumer feedback is not something a news agency is accustomed to, but the the web enables readers to respond to news-story writers. The agency says this will help it to tweak content to suit readers. But is there not a danger that Reuters could be dumbed-down through its contact with the tabloid-loving public? "Feedback is valuable because it provides pointers. However, our coverage won't change. Our ethos is that we exist to tell people what they don't know and what they need to know, and that wouldn't be driven in a popular market," says Pinder.

PA has been more receptive to the fads of a popular market. Last April saw the debut of its "world's first-ever virtual newscaster" Ananova, modelled on a cross between Posh Spice, Carol Vorderman and Kylie Minogue. But PA announced its intention to spin off and sell the android before she had made her entrance on the cyber stage. Sceptics suggest that Ananova was merely a rebranding exercise that transformed PA New Media into a consumer brand.

But Robert Simpson, PA's chief executive, insisted at the time: "This is not another dot.com story. This is about the internet becoming an integral feature of everyday life. Most of us in the future will still be technophobes who prefer to get information from a friendly face."

Besides, Ananova did not appear out of nowhere, it was a product of the five-year-old PA new media division, founded to exploit the internet. Similarly, PA already had a news site for consumers to access its news, and this boasted 10m page impressions. Ananova is a profitable business with over 100 employees and forecast revenues of £23m for 2003. Before the dot.com hype floundered, it was estimated that the sale of Ananova could raise £400m: estimates are now more conservative - £20m to £100m.

She has since been joined by the BT and C5 newsreading avatar Vandrea, modelled on real newsreader Andrea Calderwood. PA's decision to spin off Ananova, aside from being a money-making exercise, was taken because the board felt (says the annual report) that Ananova conflicted with the core B2B component of the media company. "Ananova is being sold as a consumer-facing brand so PA can go back to its roots as a wholesaler. We don't want to compete with clients - we're a B2B business. We're retreating out of the public eye," says a spokesman.

The renewed focus on B2B appears to be PA's strategy for the next few years. "PA has both the ability and the scope to develop more new media B2B ventures (particularly in sport)," wrote the chairman Robert Simpson in his annual report, "and we will also be alert for further joint ventures in the B2C market."

PA already has a joint venture with the Trinity Mirror newspaper group in sportinglife.com, which in turn launched totalbet.com through a partnership with Tote. Apart from joint ventures, once Ananova is sold, it is unlikely PA will launch another consumer-focused product, whether it be a consumer portal or an avatar.

It is unlikely that Reuters would launch a newsreading android to boost its presence in the public eye. However, as part of its commitment to delivering news in a multimedia format, it is likely that its reports will be injected with more personality.

Last week, it signed a joint venture with an independent radio production company to supply hourly audio updates across four of its online news reports. It is currently seeking (real) newsreaders for each of the four news feeds. For its quirky "And finally" news report it is targeting thirtysomething males and females in its search for "the next John Craven meets Trevor McDonald".

But, would it ever consider launching a Reuters news portal enabling readers to access its content directly rather than via its partner sites, thus becoming a pure B2C operation? The clue lies in Reuters' roots as a financial services company and in a separate department: Reuters Personal. It has announced plans to launch a personal finance portal later this year, which will tap into the consumer retail market. "As more products go online, there is an increasingly grey area between B2B and B2C, as you get more professional users at home. In due course there will be more products that we will be providing for the business retail user but they may be for the SME [small-to-medium enterprise] environment," says a spokesman.

As he adds, the separate brokerage subsidiary of Reuters, Instinet is set to launch an online retail arm, Instinet.com later this year. "It is an electronic equity broker. It will provide the individual with the ability to transact with the same competitive pricing as institutional brokers are used to."

Questions may be raised over Reuters' shift towards the consumer market, especially in the light of PA's announced return to the wholesaler business as a pure B2B operation. However, despite this insistence, PA is still operating a B2B4C operation with its news feeds to websites.

As large media players use the internet to distribute content, traditional news agencies must face the general commodification of news, eating into its core business. It therefore makes sense to expand from its core offering into creating new products and accessing new audiences.

"Reuters is in an interesting position," says Rebecca Ulph, a Forrester analyst. "It's not a traditional consumer-facing brand, but people have heard of it. It's in a strong position."

 Elen Lewis is features editor of New Media Age
fields.bodyText: News agencies such as Reuters have traditionally been one of the best-kept secrets of the media industry. However, the growth of the internet is set to change all that. Over the past year, driven by the digital age, both Reuters and its local UK competitor PA have been dipping their toes into the brave new world of the consumer. The two media companies have reacted differently to the new economy. PA noisily launched a virtual newscaster, Ananova, before swiftly announcing its green-haired consumer brand was for sale and that it intended to consolidate its "B2B" (business-to-business) wholesaler role. Reuters has taken a different tack. It announced in February that it would invest £500m in refashioning itself into a new media company and has made a paradigm shift from B2B into a "B2B4C" (business-to-business for consumers) model via the internet. This entails selling its live news feeds to a large number of websites (the B2B part), which can be accessed directly by the public (the 4C part.) The anonymity of news agency journalists is renowned. A poignant example of this was when a Reuters journalist died while reporting on the Sierra Leone conflict in May, "although not many people knew the name of Kurt Schork, his material ended up everywhere," says Rodney Pinder, head of video news at Reuters. Look at any daily newspaper and it is likely that a Reuters picture will be on the front or the back page. Watch international news and Reuters will probably be providing the footage. Remember the harrowing Eritrean famine pictures? The Blair baby? Reuters got there first. PA can also boast a string of exclusives that would not have been apparent to the man on the street. PA was first with Diana's death; it was also a PA journalist who was granted an interview with Prince William on his recent 18th birthday. But news agency journalists are coming out of the shadows and into the limelight. "We're becoming far more visible as a result of the internet," says Pinder. Not only can the public access undiluted news via 1,000 news feeds to different websites, but the transparency of the medium ensures Reuters is credited for its pictures and copy in a way that did not exist in the traditional world. In the UK, it has linked content deals with the likes of Yahoo!, WH Smith, FT.com, Excite, AOL and Altavista. Thus, the 149-year-old company, whose roots lie in specialist financial services and as wholesaler to the media business, is crossing into the realm of retailer. "We're looking to expand our client base in the B2C [business-to-consumer] and the B2B4C range," a spokesman says. "Our competence fits neatly into the new world," says Geoffrey Wheating, Reuters' director of strategic media development. Consumer feedback is not something a news agency is accustomed to, but the the web enables readers to respond to news-story writers. The agency says this will help it to tweak content to suit readers. But is there not a danger that Reuters could be dumbed-down through its contact with the tabloid-loving public? "Feedback is valuable because it provides pointers. However, our coverage won't change. Our ethos is that we exist to tell people what they don't know and what they need to know, and that wouldn't be driven in a popular market," says Pinder. PA has been more receptive to the fads of a popular market. Last April saw the debut of its "world's first-ever virtual newscaster" Ananova, modelled on a cross between Posh Spice, Carol Vorderman and Kylie Minogue. But PA announced its intention to spin off and sell the android before she had made her entrance on the cyber stage. Sceptics suggest that Ananova was merely a rebranding exercise that transformed PA New Media into a consumer brand. But Robert Simpson, PA's chief executive, insisted at the time: "This is not another dot.com story. This is about the internet becoming an integral feature of everyday life. Most of us in the future will still be technophobes who prefer to get information from a friendly face." Besides, Ananova did not appear out of nowhere, it was a product of the five-year-old PA new media division, founded to exploit the internet. Similarly, PA already had a news site for consumers to access its news, and this boasted 10m page impressions. Ananova is a profitable business with over 100 employees and forecast revenues of £23m for 2003. Before the dot.com hype floundered, it was estimated that the sale of Ananova could raise £400m: estimates are now more conservative - £20m to £100m. She has since been joined by the BT and C5 newsreading avatar Vandrea, modelled on real newsreader Andrea Calderwood. PA's decision to spin off Ananova, aside from being a money-making exercise, was taken because the board felt (says the annual report) that Ananova conflicted with the core B2B component of the media company. "Ananova is being sold as a consumer-facing brand so PA can go back to its roots as a wholesaler. We don't want to compete with clients - we're a B2B business. We're retreating out of the public eye," says a spokesman. The renewed focus on B2B appears to be PA's strategy for the next few years. "PA has both the ability and the scope to develop more new media B2B ventures (particularly in sport)," wrote the chairman Robert Simpson in his annual report, "and we will also be alert for further joint ventures in the B2C market." PA already has a joint venture with the Trinity Mirror newspaper group in sportinglife.com, which in turn launched totalbet.com through a partnership with Tote. Apart from joint ventures, once Ananova is sold, it is unlikely PA will launch another consumer-focused product, whether it be a consumer portal or an avatar. It is unlikely that Reuters would launch a newsreading android to boost its presence in the public eye. However, as part of its commitment to delivering news in a multimedia format, it is likely that its reports will be injected with more personality. Last week, it signed a joint venture with an independent radio production company to supply hourly audio updates across four of its online news reports. It is currently seeking (real) newsreaders for each of the four news feeds. For its quirky "And finally" news report it is targeting thirtysomething males and females in its search for "the next John Craven meets Trevor McDonald". But, would it ever consider launching a Reuters news portal enabling readers to access its content directly rather than via its partner sites, thus becoming a pure B2C operation? The clue lies in Reuters' roots as a financial services company and in a separate department: Reuters Personal. It has announced plans to launch a personal finance portal later this year, which will tap into the consumer retail market. "As more products go online, there is an increasingly grey area between B2B and B2C, as you get more professional users at home. In due course there will be more products that we will be providing for the business retail user but they may be for the SME [small-to-medium enterprise] environment," says a spokesman. As he adds, the separate brokerage subsidiary of Reuters, Instinet is set to launch an online retail arm, Instinet.com later this year. "It is an electronic equity broker. fields.headline: Whaaassuuup?
fields.standfirst: Farting aliens, sore-covered junkies and a cat in a Brazilian kitchen . . .  Mark Wnek  saw the lot as a judge at the Cannes advertising festival. But a word from Bud stole the show
fields.trailText: Farting aliens, sore-covered junkies and a cat in a Brazilian kitchen . . . Mark Wnek saw the lot as a judge at the Cannes advertising festival. But a word from Bud stole the show
fields.body:
I don't know why the International Advertising Festival, the World Cup finals of advertising, takes place in Cannes. Presumably it's because its cousin, the film festival, happens there. More probably it's a lure for the normally ultra-competitive if not warring adpeople of the world to agree to come and spend time together.

Some 8,000 of them from more than 70 countries descended on Cannes last week, some to attend conferences, some to look at commercials, some to catch up with colleagues oceans away, some to attend worldwide policy meetings, some just to hang out. And there is absolutely no doubt that I was one of the 21 holding the short straw, sequestered as my fellow judges and I were in the bowels of the Palais du Festival, viewing and sifting the 5,757 commercials competing.

We did this every day for a week, starting at 8.30am and ending at 7pm if we were lucky, around midnight if we were not. During this time we saw everything from farting aliens to sore-covered junkies, sometimes in the same commercial. We saw everything from selling cars to buying votes. We saw everything from selling by enormous high-budget spectacular to selling by a cat in a Brazilian kitchen.

At the end of it we awarded the coveted Gold Lions, some 20 or so, representing a tiny percentage of the 150,000 commercials made globally each year. At a time when the words dot and com are on everybody's lips, this year's jury lost patience with dot.com advertising which seemed to consist of little more than outrageous sponsored gags designed to embed the name of a site and encourage "hits".

Only two dot.com advertisers, Alta Vista and Stamps.com from the US, seemed to have any success in producing work which actually explained their difference in a compelling way. In the Alta Vista campaign, a woman avoids speeding tickets by her knowledge of the workings and inefficiencies of radar guns, always ending with the shocking question (to the bystanding cop): "Did you know radar guns cause testicular cancer?"

The Stamps.com campaign, for a service which allows you to frank all your mail through your computer, featured the marvellous deadpan veteran US comedian Bob Newhart as the boss of a company producing hilariously defective goods and thus needing to produce a lot of recall notices. This work, like all the US work which dominated Cannes this year, is brilliantly written, crafted and produced with timing and dialogue that would not be out of place alongside the best of Frasier.

The UK again performed extremely well, with Gold Lions for Saatchi and Saatchi's Army campaign, M&C Saatchi's Johnny Foreigner commercial for British Airways featuring the journalist PJ O'Rourke, BMP's "new comfortable VW Polo" commercial with the guy enjoying a traffic jam and WCRS's commercial for Land Rover, where one of the vehicles is "returned to the wild".

But the Grand Prix went to the "Whassup" campaign for Budweiser in America created by DDB, Chicago. The opening commercial, entitled True, begins with a young man sitting on his sofa drinking Bud and watching football. The phone rings and it's a fellow game-watching friend. Then another guy rings and another and another and soon they're having a conference call consisting almost exclusively of the guttural exclamation: "Whassuuuuup!" (in English: "What's up?")

This may not sound like much on paper, but never has a more infectious catchphrase gripped an industry. By the end of Cannes week, everyone was doing what the whole of America has been doing for a while now: greeting each other with a tongue-wagging "Whassuuuup?!"

The Whassup salute has already permeated US culture and is set to do the same in the UK via the internet. In the US, everyone from talk-show hosts to politicians is doing it.

The ads were inspired by a short film called True created by the director and star of the campaign, Charles Stone III. Shorthand communication between close friends is at the heart of what makes great beer advertising. As a US journalist said: "The spots are almost dialogue-free but speak volumes." The fun is all about the exaggerated inflections and the facial expressions. Other than that, nothing much happens.

It's a man thing. Girlfriends, when they appear in the ads, usually roll their eyes. In one execution, the girlfriend pounds the table in frustration at a Japanese restaurant as the boyfriend attempts to get the Japanese waiter to turn "wasabi" into "Whassuuup?!" The ads don't say much about the product (other than make you love it, which is not bad) but they say a lot about the incontrovertible power and value of advertising.

Mark Wnek is a partner in Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper.

fields.headline: ITN news at 10, 11, 12 . . .
fields.standfirst: Today Sky launches an interactive service for digital viewers and this week ITN will unveil its new 24-hour news channel. But, asks  Matt Wells, has   ITN left it too late to jump on the bandwagon?
fields.trailText: Today Sky launches an interactive service for digital viewers and this week ITN will unveil its new 24-hour news channel. But, asks Matt Wells, has ITN left it too late to jump on the bandwagon?
fields.body:
As the war of words between the dusty old men of the independent television commission and the smart suits at ITV intensifies, the broadcaster which actually provides the programmes over which they are fighting is preparing to enter a new battle of its own.

Today, ITN unveils its new 24-hour news channel, due to go on air later in the summer; also today, Sky News launches a new interactive service for digital viewers. As executives at all news organisations steel themselves for the 21st-century fight for audiences in the new-media age, the News at Ten debate begins to appear drearily parochial.

Yet however much ITN wants to be part of this brave new world, it is trapped by the past. The PR launch of the new channel had been scheduled for this morning because ITN believed that the News at Ten issue would finally have been settled by the independent television commission last Thursday. Instead, the argument is now expected to drag on through the summer and possibly into a protracted court battle later in the year. For an organisation which is already playing catch-up, it is an unappetising prospect.

Richard Tait, the editor of ITN, is bullish. He insists that the broadcaster's image has not been tarnished by the row, but believes that the organisation will suffer if it does not jump on to the digital bandwagon. "I don't think our brand has eroded. But I do think that if we are not universally available, our brand will erode. Our news channel is part of the process of ensuring this doesn't happen."

Tait says that the new channel is crucial to safeguard ITN's future. For while there will be an appetite for traditional news services for some time to come - and its contracts with ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 are secure for the next few years - the broadcasting landscape is on the verge of significant upheaval. "No one is obliged to watch news programmes any more. We want to get away from the traditional notion of news services, that viewers get everything the broadcaster thinks they need, rather than what the viewer wants," he says.

The channel goes on air later this month. Last week, Tait and launch editor Bill Dunlop were refusing to reveal the name of the venture, nor its line-up of presenters, nor its on-screen look - one wonders why they bothered talking about it in the first place. Perhaps they were a little embarrassed: one bright spark came up with the idea of calling it simply ITN, but that idea was dropped a few weeks ago.

ITN later relented and named the principal faces of the channel, who will be familiar to terrestrial viewers: John Suchet and Julia Somerville will present in the morning and evening respectively, and Carol Barnes will be on air at weekends, allowing her to continue her day job at Brighton magistrates' court. (Suchet will swap studios later in the morning to slip alongside his colleague Kirsty Young for his regular slot on the ITV Lunchtime News.)

Launching a new channel would be pointless without poaching a few names from key rivals, so there's Andrew Harvey from BBC News 24 and Leyla Day Belge from Sky News. Viewers of Sky Digital and customers of the NTL cable operator - which is a partner in the new venture - will see it from day one. Negotiations are also under way with Telewest, and ONDigital viewers will get it in the mornings.

The format of the channel will be somewhat different from the competition. While both News 24 and Sky tend to stick to the model of a 30-minute news bulletin at the top of the hour followed by a "back half-hour" of business, sport or other documentary, ITN has decided to go for a rolling news service, in 15-minute loops. A key difference is that there will be one, not two on-screen presenters even in peak times. The channel's look is expected to be straightforwardly slick, with no Channel 5-type desk-perching or Jon Snow-style studio wandering.

Material will be gathered from ITN's existing reporters and production staff, and the regular agencies, augmented by dedicated 24-hour channel staff. ITN has already set up a "core" group which will direct material to ITN's different outlets - principally ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5 and Euronews - and to the new channel. The system should ensure that reporters in the field are not called up by commissioners from competing programmes in the same office - a practice which is the bane of BBC reporters' lives.

While some would say it has left it a bit late to get into 24-hour news, ITN believes it is coming to the business at exactly the right time. Not least, says Tait, advances in technology have made it less troublesome financially. "There is no doubt that the digital technology makes it cost-effective. We have every intention of making it a commercial as well as an editorial success." And that doesn't mean doing everything on a shoestring: "I don't believe the way to commercial success is through cost-cutting. It is through investment in quality journalism." Nevertheless, Tait refuses to say how many staff are dedicated to the channel - revealing only that at any one time, about 120 people will be working for it, including those also spending time on other outlets.

Nick Pollard, the head of Sky News, believes it is a difficult challenge. Sky News made a small profit before the launch of BBC News 24, now it is understood to have slipped just below the red line once again. "I think they will find it tough, because we all find it tough. It is a very competitive market. We are all already fighting hard for a small percentage of the audience."

Nevertheless, says Pollard, it is the right decision for ITN to make. "I think everybody has to assume that they have to get into different types of media. If you start from that premise, it is not that difficult to see how to advance. I think television news is quite well suited to unpredictable things, anyway."

Clearly, the terrestrial landscape is changing forever. "Even the mighty BBC1 and BBC2 may become themed channels, and the idea of 'hammocking' worthy programmes between a couple of popular programmes is out of the window, and rightly so. In general, news is bound to be marginalised on the terrestrial channels."

Sky, too, is determined to stay ahead of the game. From today, viewers of Sky Digital will be able to take advantage of yet more gimmicks (sorry, interactive services) on Sky News. At the touch of a button, Sky News Active is launched and news junkies can access headlines, weather, business and showbiz news at any given moment. The technology - still in its early stages - is nevertheless impressive: a split screen comes into view with four panels showing the four options. At a flick of the Sky digital handset, viewers can call up whatever service they require, without having to wait for it to come around on the main Sky News service. Any of the four "play school" type windows (unfortunately for the analogy, all are square) can be replaced with a live feed, so important press conferences can be played out in full on Sky News Active while the main service continues with other stories.

Pollard believes such developments are key for broadcasters who who don't want to be left behind. In a declaration which should be plastered on the walls of every television executive, he says: "If we don't do it, somebody else will."

Bring back News at Ten, or else (er, or else what?)

Pulling on his biggest pair of Doc Martens, the independent television commission's chairman Sir Robin Biggam declared last month that he was giving ITV one last chance to come up with a plan to corral the country into watching its news. "The uncertainty cannot be allowed to continue," boomed the man who once told an industry audience that his family do jigsaws at Christmas instead of watching TV.

On Thursday, Sir Robin - his DMs buffed up for the occasion - "got tough" and insisted ITV move its Nightly News programme to an earlier time slot. Or so we were told. The thing was that, despite the headlines the next day, he did no such thing: no formal direction emerged from Foley Street, the ITC's London home.

The regulator, having stepped up to the brink last month, got vertigo. To force ITV's hand at this stage would almost certainly - as this newspaper reported last week - have resulted in the network hauling the commission before the high court to explain its actions. So instead of stepping out, it dangled a foot over the edge to test the wind. It "insisted" that ITV move the news, but didn't "direct" it to do so. In PR terms, it was a neat move, reflected in the following day's headlines; in substance, it was typical of the ITC's timidity, and has prolonged the agony at least until the ITC's next meeting, in a month.

All through this sorry saga, the ITC has bottled the key decisions. When it first agreed to the schedule change in November 1998, it failed to have the courage of its convictions and imposed four conditions (none of which explicitly mentioned ratings). It resolved to conduct a review a year later, thus prolonging the debate and opening itself up to massive political pressure. Then, halfway through the first year of the new schedule, it started to make noises that it was concerned about ratings. After the year was up, it said that ITV had failed to attract sufficient audiences for its new news programmes, and gave it a month to come up with a plan to boost news audiences - in effect saying ITV had broken a condition which had not been imposed in the first place.

Last week it accepted ITV's compromise package, which included £21m to boost programmes in the run-up to the 11pm news and the return of News at Ten for elections, provided ITV would agree to another, binding period of review. ITV refused to be backed into a corner, and turned away. So Sir Robin hawked himself around the news channels (yes, the same ones on which you can watch the news at whatever time you like) declaring he had no option but to tell ITV to bring forward its Nightly News - without mentioning that he wasn't actually exercising any formal power.

So does the ITC really think it has any power here at all? Its actions last week appear to suggest it is not quite sure. It appears to believe it can flex its muscles around the argument that the decline in news ratings shows that ITV is failing in its public service commitment, which the broadcaster resolved to maintain as one of the original four conditions imposed when News at Ten was scrapped. ITV's legal team says that's nonsense. But Sir Robin has certainly succeeded in his aim of setting the ITV chiefs' nerves on edge.

ITV now has three options. It could cave in and shift the news; face down the regulator and force a judicial review; or agree to the binding period of review that it rejected last week. At the weekend, ITV chiefs were adamant that they would not be forced into scheduling a bulletin at 10.30pm. That, most believe, is off the agenda.

But what about a radical rethink? While everyone is focusing on the Nightly News, there are serious problems in the early evening schedule. Trevor at 6.30pm is not doing well, and neither are the regional news programmes that precede him. Instead of shifting the 11pm news, why not have a continental-style bulletin at 7pm or 8pm? This option is now firmly back in play. At a stroke, it would guarantee higher ratings and give both ITV and ITC a way out of this near-farce. ITV executives will discuss the plan this week.

In the meantime, the ITC chief executive Peter Rogers is preparing to hand over the reins to ex-BBC policy head Patricia Hodgson. She is the woman (keep up at the back) who negotiated the BBC's licence-fee settlement and helped to steer the corporation's digital strategy. She takes up her post in September, charged with saving the ITC from oblivion as the government considers the future of television regulation. Sir Robin's delaying tactics may yet be his downfall: it is hard to see headmistress Hodgson having any truck with the old ways of the old boys.
