ITN has already set up a "core" group which will direct material to ITN's different outlets - principally ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5 and Euronews - and to the new channel. The system should ensure that reporters in the field are not called up by commissioners from competing programmes in the same office - a practice which is the bane of BBC reporters' lives. While some would say it has left it a bit late to get into 24-hour news, ITN believes it is coming to the business at exactly the right time. Not least, says Tait, advances in technology have made it less troublesome financially. "There is no doubt that the digital technology makes it cost-effective. We have every intention of making it a commercial as well as an editorial success." And that doesn't mean doing everything on a shoestring: "I don't believe the way to commercial success is through cost-cutting. It is through investment in quality journalism." Nevertheless, Tait refuses to say how many staff are dedicated to the channel - revealing only that at any one time, about 120 people will be working for it, including those also spending time on other outlets. Nick Pollard, the head of Sky News, believes it is a difficult challenge. Sky News made a small profit before the launch of BBC News 24, now it is understood to have slipped just below the red line once again. "I think they will find it tough, because we all find it tough. It is a very competitive market. We are all already fighting hard for a small percentage of the audience." Nevertheless, says Pollard, it is the right decision for ITN to make. "I think everybody has to assume that they have to get into different types of media. If you start from that premise, it is not that difficult to see how to advance. I think television news is quite well suited to unpredictable things, anyway." Clearly, the terrestrial landscape is changing forever. "Even the mighty BBC1 and BBC2 may become themed channels, and the idea of 'hammocking' worthy programmes between a couple of popular programmes is out of the window, and rightly so. In general, news is bound to be marginalised on the terrestrial channels." Sky, too, is determined to stay ahead of the game. From today, viewers of Sky Digital will be able to take advantage of yet more gimmicks (sorry, interactive services) on Sky News. At the touch of a button, Sky News Active is launched and news junkies can access headlines, weather, business and showbiz news at any given moment. The technology - still in its early stages - is nevertheless impressive: a split screen comes into view with four panels showing the four options. At a flick of the Sky digital handset, viewers can call up whatever service they require, without having to wait for it to come around on the main Sky News service. Any of the four "play school" type windows (unfortunately for the analogy, all are square) can be replaced with a live feed, so important press conferences can be played out in full on Sky News Active while the main service continues with other stories. Pollard believes such developments are key for broadcasters who who don't want to be left behind. In a declaration which should be plastered on the walls of every television executive, he says: "If we don't do it, somebody else will." Bring back News at Ten, or else (er, or else what?) Pulling on his biggest pair of Doc Martens, the independent television commission's chairman Sir Robin Biggam declared last month that he was giving ITV one last chance to come up with a plan to corral the country into watching its news. "The uncertainty cannot be allowed to continue," boomed the man who once told an industry audience that his family do jigsaws at Christmas instead of watching TV. On Thursday, Sir Robin - his DMs buffed up for the occasion - "got tough" and insisted ITV move its Nightly News programme to an earlier time slot. Or so we were told. The thing was that, despite the headlines the next day, he did no such thing: no formal direction emerged from Foley Street, the ITC's London home. The regulator, having stepped up to the brink last month, got vertigo. To force ITV's hand at this stage would almost certainly - as this newspaper reported last week - have resulted in the network hauling the commission before the high court to explain its actions. So instead of stepping out, it dangled a foot over the edge to test the wind. It "insisted" that ITV move the news, but didn't "direct" it to do so. In PR terms, it was a neat move, reflected in the following day's headlines; in substance, it was typical of the ITC's timidity, and has prolonged the agony at least until the ITC's next meeting, in a month. All through this sorry saga, the ITC has bottled the key decisions. When it first agreed to the schedule change in November 1998, it failed to have the courage of its convictions and imposed four conditions (none of which explicitly mentioned ratings). It resolved to conduct a review a year later, thus prolonging the debate and opening itself up to massive political pressure. Then, halfway through the first year of the new schedule, it started to make noises that it was concerned about ratings. After the year was up, it said that ITV had failed to attract sufficient audiences for its new news programmes, and gave it a month to come up with a plan to boost news audiences - in effect saying ITV had broken a condition which had not been imposed in the first place. Last week it accepted ITV's compromise package, which included £21m to boost programmes in the run-up to the 11pm news and the return of News at Ten for elections, provided ITV would agree to another, binding period of review. ITV refused to be backed into a corner, and turned away. So Sir Robin hawked himself around the news channels (yes, the same ones on which you can watch the news at whatever time you like) declaring he had no option but to tell ITV to bring forward its Nightly News - without mentioning that he wasn't actually exercising any formal power. So does the ITC really think it has any power here at all? Its actions last week appear to suggest it is not quite sure. It appears to believe it can flex its muscles around the argument that the decline in news ratings shows that ITV is failing in its public service commitment, which the broadcaster resolved to maintain as one of the original four conditions imposed when News at Ten was scrapped. ITV's legal team says that's nonsense. But Sir Robin has certainly succeeded in his aim of setting the ITV chiefs' nerves on edge. ITV now has three options. It could cave in and shift the news; face down the regulator and force a judicial review; or agree to the binding period of review that it rejected last week. At the weekend, ITV chiefs were adamant that they would not be forced into scheduling a bulletin at 10.30pm. That, most believe, is off the agenda. But what about a radical rethink? While everyone is focusing on the Nightly News, there are serious problems in the early evening schedule. Trevor at 6.30pm is not doing well, and neither are the regional news programmes that precede him. Instead of shifting the 11pm news, why not have a continental-style bulletin at 7pm or 8pm? This option is now firmly back in play. At a stroke, it would guarantee higher ratings and give both ITV and ITC a way out of this near-farce. ITV executives will discuss the plan this week. In the meantime, the ITC chief executive Peter Rogers is preparing to hand over the reins to ex-BBC policy head Patricia Hodgson. She is the woman (keep up at the back) who negotiated the BBC's licence-fee settlement and helped to steer the corporation's digital strategy. She takes up her post in September, charged with saving the ITC from oblivion as the government considers the future of television regulation. Sir Robin's delaying tactics may yet be his downfall: it is hard to see headmistress Hodgson having any truck with the old ways of the old boys.

fields.headline: One watchdog that needs teeth
fields.standfirst: As the consultation process on the white paper on communications ends,  Damian Tambini  backs a single content regulator
fields.trailText: As the consultation process on the white paper on communications ends, Damian Tambini backs a single content regulator
fields.body:
When Channel 5 transmitted Keith Chegwin naked last month, the Daily Mail saw it as "The Moment that British Television Plumbed New Depths". If, as ministers hope, digital television becomes a gateway to the internet over the next decade, the Mail may look back on Cheggers' antics as a new approach to taste and decency.

Now though, a joint effort between the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) and the Department of Culture (DCMS) has produced a white paper which it is hoped will provide some kind of regulation. The DTI hope that digital TV will provide cheap internet access and spur the knowledge economy. DCMS worries that the regulators it appoints will no longer act as arbiters of public taste. In Sweden, taste is left to responsible adults to decide for themselves. If in the UK, the internet rollout is stymied by a Victorian debate about taste and decency, consequences for the economy could be disastrous.

To what extent niche subscription channels and interactive services will erode mass family TV is debatable, but the transforming influence of the internet is already being felt. Last month, in protest at censorship, FilmFour posted scenes cut from The Idiots on its website. In the foreseeable future, accessing the internet from your TV should be as simple as switching channels, so censorship will look increasingly ineffective.

The difficulty lies in determining when we should regulate for taste and decency. Is a website public or pervasive enough to warrant restrictions of freedom of speech? In the long term, users will get into the habit of setting software to filter what their kids see, and the codes of the regulators will be displaced by codes of conduct policed from a distance. In the short term, however, the public expects regulation, at least on the most familiar TV platforms. The challenge for the communications white paper is to cope with the transition: where the public expects regulation, but existing institutions of regulation are faltering.

The political problem is that smut has a tendency to become a populist political issue. The government has to be seen to take positive action, with a genuine need for new principles.

Saucy TV sells, and is relatively cheap to make. Cheggers' bits were seen by 2m viewers - a 20% market share. Channels 5's regular shows, European Blue Review and X Certificate, achieve significant but not huge ratings (1.4m/15%) but are particularly profitable since they are provided cheap as marketing for porn. In the long term, those services subject to regulation could be at a market disadvantage.

As technologies converge it becomes more difficult to regulate TV, games, internet, phone and radio separately, and we find ourselves dealing with a bigger and more slippery category: "content". Convergence brings together the most public of media - television - with the most private. The internet is perfect for distributing content that people don't admit they like. Many ISP operators say that porn is the main use of the network. The top 15 searched words on Yahoo! UK last year were: sex, hotmail, chat, MP3, Pokémon, Playboy, Lyrics, XXX, games, porn, jokes, porno, pussy, WWF, and maps. If this is what the public really want, and they can only get it on the net, then they could leave a hole in the audience of the main regulated channels, just as Channel 5 does now.

Last month, the broadcasting standards commission, the independent television commission and the radio authority got together to discuss internet regulation. The focus of their discussion was Australia: one of the few countries that has tried to regulate internet content to TV standards, with disastrous results for its multimedia industry. Most agreed that the intervention was not necessary and that regulation should reflect the level of audience each service enjoys, and the extent to which children are exposed. Service providers and the public should be more responsible themselves.

In the case of the internet, we should not attempt the impossible and try to regulate content. But we certainly should ensure that users know when they are leaving regulated for non-regulated services.

Parents do not want their children's first experience of sex to be a virtual one, and neither do they want kids to plot terrorism on the net. Parents should know what their children find and do online, and should use passwords to monitor and control it. However, as many parents are technophobes, a high-profile filter software awareness campaign will have to be launched by the government. The internet industry will argue that this scare-mongering will hinder take-up, but it must be made clear that the digital revolution will be hindered more by botched regulation and access restrictions for children.

Communications reform should give the government an opportunity to improve the system of regulation, which will rely more on public complaints in the future. And a single content regulator would make the process of complaining and certifying content more transparent, accountable and accessible to the public.

IPPR Fellow Damian Tambini is a member of the communications white paper expert panel. He is the author of Digital Danger (IPPR, £4.95)

webTitle: Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas 'battle over marriage agreement'

fields.headline: Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas 'battle over marriage agreement'
fields.standfirst: Clare Dyer explains why prenuptial arrangements are increasingly popular
fields.trailText: Hollywood couple Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones are battling over a prenuptial agreement, it was reported today.
fields.body:
Hollywood couple Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones are battling over a prenuptial agreement, it was reported today.

Welsh actress Ms Jones, 30, who is pregnant with the couple's child, is refusing to sign the agreement because of issues over how much of Douglas's fortune she would get if they split and where she would live.

She is said to want £3m for each year they are married and a free home.

The Sun says the 54-year-old actor, who starred in Basic Instinct and Fatal attraction, is refusing.

He does, however, want to keep any wedding presents worth more than £12,000.

The couple are still expected to marry in September at Douglas's home in Majorca.

Douglas was reportedly forced to pay his former wife, Diandra, £40m when they divorced after 22 years.

webTitle: What the critics are saying about our sites

fields.headline: What the critics are saying about our sites
fields.trailText: From The Net's guide to cricket sites, July 2000
fields.body:
From The Net's guide to cricket sites, July 2000

On cricketunlimited.co.uk...
As one of the Guardian's 'Unlimited' series of sites this has an excellent news service and also a slightly irreverent way of looking at the game, offering you something a bit different from the stat-laden sites about the sport. The columns make compelling reading and offer a focus on the issues within the game - rather than a list of who's beating who and who's scoring the most runs. ****

...and on wisden.com
Strictly speaking this is an extension of Cricket Unlimited, but the bible of the game deserves its own place. The Wisden almanac (sic) has been around longer than the Queen Mum, and the Wisden records alone are enough to pass away any rained-off day.***

From ComputerActive Webguide, Summer 2000, Issue 3, £4.99, review of wisden.com

Produced in association with the Guardian, this site is exactly as you'd expect from two such venerable institutions. The best bit is the regularly updated news section, which - unlike so much else on the web - is of consistently high quality. Whether you want to wallow in the full blow-by-blow account of a match, or read a succinct summary, it's all here. As are well-written feature articles, oodles of stats and a busy bulletin board. The know-how of Wisden and the sports reporting expertise of the Guardian combine to provide a well-organised and well-written guide for the armchair cricket fan.****

From What's Online, issue 20, Sports section

The Wisdom of Wisden
Wisden, as any schoolboy worth his salt knows, is the cricketer's equivalent of the Holy Bible. Packed full of all the facts and stats you could ever need on the game, this is essential surfing for cricket fans. So if you want to know how many Test hundreds Ian Botham made or what the lowest score by a Test side is, then this is where you need to be heading. All the records are easily accessed using the pull-down menus, there's plenty of up-to-date editorial analysis on all the current events in Test cricket adn you can even email one of the team with a specific query. Just about the only thing this exhaustive resource doesn't actually tell you is how many people Geoff Boycott has bored to death.****

From the Virgin guide to the internet (out now, price £4.99), on cricketunlimited.co.uk

Combining commentary from the Guardian's team of cricket reporters with facts and reports from Wisden make this hard to beat. On a level with Cricinfo.

From The Net Magazine's guide to 500 great sports sites, April, on wisden.com

The original and still the best.

bbc.co.uk webguide on cricketunlimited.co.uk and wisden.com

A stylish, informative and ultimately indispensable Guardian/Wisden combination. The user-friendly Records section has all the trivia you need without having to trawl through several hundredweight of paperwork, and there's top-quality writing and interviews from the people that count. You also get bang up-to-date news, facts, the all-seeing Wisden Verdict and some of the neatest player profiles on the Net. In cricketing terms, this lively delivery knocks the middle stump clean out of the ground and leaves competitors wandering stonyfaced back to the cyber-pavilion.

To read this and other reviews of cricket sites by the BBC, click here

A review of wisden.com from a partwork about the internet in The Independent, Saturday 11 March 2000

The almanack is online. It's probably one of the most famous and trusted names in the game. It mixes humour in its features along with accuracy in the stats and scores department. Tasters from the print version appear online along with a cricket-lover's guide to TV, a daily column, and snippets from elsewhere on the web.

webTitle: Rivals merge to form new party to challenge ANC

fields.headline: Rivals merge to form new party to challenge ANC
fields.trailText: One of the most racist chapters in the history of 20th century South Africa came to a close at the weekend when a political party was born out of the merger of the Democratic party with the New National party.
fields.body:
One of the most racist chapters in the history of 20th century South Africa came to a close at the weekend when a political party was born out of the merger of the Democratic party with the New National party.

The former rivals over apartheid agreed on Saturday to form a new party, the Democratic Alliance, headed by the Democratic party leader Tony Leon, a white English speaker, with the New National leader Marthinus van Schalkwyk, a white Afrikaner, as his deputy.

The move is designed to strengthen opposition to the governing African National Congress, although the new party is not expected to pose a threat to the political supremacy of the ruling party which won 266 seats in the 400-seat parliament at the last general election.

South Africa's last white president FW de Klerk said on Sunday he supported the merger of his former party with the Democratic party to forge a new opposition alliance.

The National party enforced apartheid after coming to power in 1948 and then proceeded to dismantle it in the early 1990s, allowing the rise to power of the ANC with Nelson Mandela at its helm.

The first problem the merging parties face is finding enough common ground for the Nationals' right wing to co-exist comfortably with more liberal elements in the Democratic party.

The Democratics' predecessor, the Progressive party, formed in 1959 to oppose the system of racial segregation that was being put into place by the National party.

Differences could emerge on social issues such as capital punishment, abortion and affirmative action. But both parties are pro-market and take a tough line on crime in a country where it is rife.

The New National party, which added New to its name to try to shed its racist legacy, saw its support slump in last year's election, with the number of seats in the national assembly falling from 82 seats to 28.

The first test for the new party will be in the November local elections. At the last general election, the two parties gained 16% of the vote between them.

fields.headline: The x-factor
fields.standfirst: Gene therapy has been used successfully for the first time. James Meek looks at how this was achieved
fields.trailText: Gene therapy has been used successfully for the first time. James Meek looks at how this was achieved.
fields.body:
Last February, an air of euphoria seeped into the corridors of the Necker Hospital for Sick Children in the Montparnasse district of Paris. Wondrous cures, great courage and the heart-hollowing grief of parents left behind by children who could not be saved, make the Necker and its ilk emotionally charged places at any time, but this was different.

What was happening to the 11-month-old baby boy in the airtight bubble in a room in the hospital's immunology and haematology unit was an incredible transformation, and more: it was history. For the first time, doctors had used mankind's knowledge of the genes involved in a fatal disease to cure it. After over eight years of inconclusive experiments, gene therapy's promise to correct nature's flaws was being realised. Now that humans' genetic code has been cracked, more and more of those flaws will come within reach of repair.

When the little boy was admitted to hospital, he was facing death within a year from a rare inherited disorder called X-linked SCID, one of a family of diseases that cause children to be born without a working immune system. The slightest infection can be deadly.

The boy lay in his bubble, his only direct contact with mother, father and nurse through plastic gloves, for several days while doctors Alain Fischer, Marina Cavazzana-Calvo and Salima Hacein-Bey, took out a few million of his bone marrow cells and coaxed the healthy gene to enter them. Then they put them back - a single, simple infusion of 20 to 30 millilitres of fluid. It took half an hour to buy the boy what they hope will be a lifetime of normal immunity.

Doctors knew in 15 days from tests that the new gene was working. But the marvel for the parents was watching the change in their sickly, underweight boy. Before their eyes, he began to thrive. The ugly red blotches on his skin faded away, his diarrhoea disappeared, he put on weight, his breathing became easier.

Three months after the infusion, his astonished parents were told they could take him home. There he remains, a normal, healthy two-year-old boy.

"We lived three months of euphoria in the lab," said Cavazzana-Calvo. "Everyone was so happy. For three to six months we talked about nothing else except the results. Nothing else was important."

Adrian Thrasher, a consultant in child immunology at Great Ormond Street hospital, said: "This is the first time we can say unequivocally that gene therapy is effective on its own. Patients have not received any other treatment, yet have got better."

Three other children, one French, one Dutch and one American, have since been treated at the Necker Hospital with similar success. A fifth boy, Shah Rayhman from London, has done less well, because the disease had already caused serious complications, but the Necker is pressing ahead with further trials later this year, and similar gene therapy is to be carried out in London and Maryland.

First, they see that there is trouble in some of the cities: the walls are the wrong shape, say, making them vulnerable to attack from outside. Then, scientists have to work out which of the volumes in the libraries is causing this by giving out false instructions about wall-building. To make it harder, several volumes, cross-referencing each other, could be involved.

Finally, they have to work out how to transport a correct replacement book on an often treacherous journey to the gates of millions of cities, smuggle it inside, and sneak it on to the library shelves in such a way that the couriers will read it and obey.

(Girls have a spare set of x-chromosomes so are not affected by the disease.) The flaw, a tiny genetic mutation, is a tragic broken link in a vital sequence.

In every person's bone marrow is a group of cells known as stem cells, which, when they receive the right chemical signals, evolve and multiply to become red and white blood cells. The white blood cells are central to the body's daily fight against infection, identifying and killing alien organisms. In order to turn into white blood cells, the stem cells have to receive a signal from other cells in the body telling them to do so. In babies with X-linked SCID, the faulty gene fails to produce one of the proteins which enable the cells to receive the signals - so the cell does not hear, there are no white blood cells, and no immunity.

So how did Cavazzana-Calvo, Hacein-Bey and their eleven collaborators crack it? They took bone marrow from the little boy and isolated the cells most likely to be stem cells. Then they sent in mercenaries, in the form of a virus. Viruses do what the scientists cannot do themselves, break inside a cell with a set of genes and squeeze the genes into the host genome. It is possible to slip a human gene into a harmless virus and have it infect human cells, which can then be returned to the patient. That was what the Necker team did. The cells given the good gene entered the baby's body and produced the missing component.

X-linked SCID is rare, afflicting 0.002% of the population. But when it threatens the lives of 100% of your children, as it did with Ann Vincent from Tewkesbury, the rarity is no comfort. For a mother to be told her baby has the disease, the shock is threefold. First, your son could die before his second birthday. Second, you are the carrier. Third, your mind flashes back over family history; the mysterious infant deaths of brothers generations back become mysteries no longer.

"I come from a family which has a history of losing baby boys when they were six months old. They all died of different things, so we never thought they were connected. But when my son became really, really ill, he was diagnosed with X-linked SCID. It was the same hospital where my brother Richard had been treated 30 years ago, and they got out his notes.

"Suddenly, I felt so terrible for my mother. She'd been going through the same thing as me. She had three brothers who died and now we know why. I always thought there was a family curse."

Mercifully, since 1968, there has been another treatment for SCID patients: a bone marrow transplant. A donor was found for Ann's first son, Owen, and he was saved. Later, she accidentally became pregnant again, with another son, Niall, who also had the defective gene. Doctors were able to save him using his older brother's rejuvenated bone marrow.

But marrow transplants have severe limitations. Even patients with compatible donors have to endure months of chemotherapy, with all its ghastly side effects. Patients with non-compatible donors have only a 60% chance of survival, and many of those who do survive have only partially restored immune systems.

Craig Smith, from High Wycombe, who died last March aged four, was beaten by the imperfection of bone marrow transplants and the sheer obscurity of the disease. His parents Penny and Peter kept him alive for almost three years - an astonishing figure for an X-linked SCID patient - while a succession of GPs and consultants failed to see through his myriad infections to the root cause.

Craig had a transplant at Great Ormond Street. At first, things looked good, but then his body began to reject the donor marrow, his liver failed and he started to slip away. Penny Smith remembers her doctors talking about gene therapy, but had no idea it was so far advanced.

Many false hopes have been raised before, and bone marrow transplants will continue to save lives for the foreseeable future, but the signs look good that X-linked SCID, at least, can within a few years be held at bay by better means. Ultimately, children could be treated in the womb. As the human genome reveals its secrets, other inherited diseases, in children and in adults, should follow.

Penny Smith is 41. "If Craig was still here, or I did, by chance, have any more children, I would go for gene therapy," she said. "I really do wish them every success, the children and the doctors."

fields.headline: What next?
fields.standfirst: Henry Gee looks forward to the next century of evolutionary genomics
fields.trailText: Henry Gee looks forward to the next century of evolutionary genomics.
fields.body:
At the end of 2001: A Space Odyssey, David Bowman, ex-astronaut and newborn god, wonders what he'll do with his new powers. No need to hurry, he ponders, for he's sure he'll think of something. We are somewhere near that point now: so, ok, we have the human genome - but what then? Nobody has worked through the consequences of all this knowledge.

Discussion has been degraded by the short-term clutter of daily headlines: the fundamentals of genomics have been buried by the rows between the publicly funded Human Genome project and the private gene sequencing enterprise of Dr Craig Venter and his colleagues, and there has been much argument about the ethics of engineering and patenting genes.

When questioned about the utility of information about genomes (a genome is the genetic complement of a living form), researchers will tell journalists what they want to hear: about improvements to medical science; about faster, cheaper cures for disease; about shorter lead-times in drug development; about understanding cancer, and so on.

This is fair enough, but utilitarian, as such advances might be made, albeit more slowly, by tried and tested techniques. Left unspoken is that genomics will produce a qualitative shift, a phase change, in the whole of biological science, outside as well as inside medicine. By 2100, biology will have changed out of all recognition. It will have a precision close to that of physics. We will look back from that high frontier at the lab-coated, high-tech science of 2000 with the indulgence we now confer on the botanising clerics of Darwin's time.

Here's why. Geneticists have long understood that genetics is a far more subtle business than counting genetic beads along chromosome strings, and then isolating those particular beads that have some association with a trait or disease. Genes do not have a clear one-to-one correspondence with some external effect. There is no gene for blue eyes, or flat feet. No matter what you read in the papers, there is no gene for violence, homosexuality or maternal instinct. Genes do not work alone - they work in large, cooperative networks. Many, if not most genes contain instructions for proteins whose task is to interact with the DNA of other genes - to act as regulators.

This much has been suspected since the birth of genetics, perhaps even earlier. The problem is that we have had no way to get to grips with the issue in any larger, rounded way. Until genomics, we were limited by technology to studying genes laboriously, one at a time, making it impossible to grasp the big picture. Geneticists were like the suitor in Salman Rushdie's Midnight's Children, trying to picture the good looks of his bride-to-be from glimpses through a very small hole in a bedsheet.

In 1960 François Jacob and Jacques Monod found that genes in bacteria concerned with a particular metabolic pathway - digesting sugar, say - tended to cluster together into a unit that became known as an "operon". This should have been a clue, a metaphor for how genes work more generally. But until recently operons were thought to be a bacterial feature of no wider relevance. Now scientists are able to look at whole genomes and map the genes within them, they see that genes do get clustered and organised according to their function, and the proximity of the genes with which they must interact. This seems obvious in hindsight: after all, what is an organism but the product of a single, gigantic operon, the genome itself?

As scientists get to know more about genomes, the bridegroom's bedsheet will literally fall away. They will see how genes interact to produce not just metabolic pathways, but whole organisms. Increasingly, the growth and development of organisms will be described in terms of interactions of genes in complex networks. Complexity theorists have long understood that the behaviour of such networks cannot be predicted from the behaviour of any of its isolated units. This is, at root, why there is no single gene for any specified trait. Even those diseases related to defects in a single gene must be expressed only by the good grace of a whole host of other genes.

A casualty of this new understanding will be the reductionist view of evolution, as popularised by Richard Dawkins in The Selfish Gene, in which organisms are no more than carriers of genes whose aim, teleologically, is to spread themselves at the expense of their fellows. This view relies on a certain independence of genes, yet evolutionary biologists have long had trouble understanding how, if this view were universally true, genes could cooperate to create organisms. The selfish genes theory would solve this by suggesting that cooperation reaps more long-term dividends than selfishness. In other words, selfish genes act by a form of enlightened self-interest. The advent of genomics could expose this view as needlessly complicated. Genes are cooperative because they are simply cooperative: selfishness need not come into the equation. To say that cooperative behaviour is a way of furthering the selfishness of genes more effectively, is like the introduction of planetary "epicycles" to shore up the Ptolemaic earth-centred universe, when the Copernican sun-centred model is much simpler. In this way, the advent of genomics will foster a qualitative shift in the biologists' world view.

Genomics will have a seismic effect on how we understand the history of life, which is now studied through the comparison of the anatomical features of organisms, as well as the raw sequences of their genes. Genomics will add a new dimension: we will also be able to compare and contrast the modes and styles of genetic interactions between organisms. This will forge a long-desired link in biology, that of understanding how phylogeny (the relatedness of organisms) is connected with changes in their ontogeny (their individual development from egg, to embryo, to adult). In the late 19th century, Darwin's German proselyte Ernst Haeckel promoted the view that "ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny". This phrase has been endlessly argued over since then, without much hope of resolution. Genomic information will help us find the answers (because, yes, there will be more than one). This information will also force a philosophical change: biologists will increasingly think of life as a unitary entity with variations, rather than the Darwinian concept of seeking to understand life through the dazzling variety of biodiversity.

So much, however, for the consolations of philosophy. The biggest effects of genomics on everyday life, as the next century wears on, will be practical ones. Genomics will allow us to alter entire organisms out of all recognition, to suit our needs and tastes. We will be able to control the operations of entire banks of genes, or insert whole sections of custom-designed chromosomes. But why stop there? We will be able to design, create and produce whole genomes in computers. Some have claimed that the technology already exists to create simple organisms - but why stop at simple ones? The insertion of single genes into crop plants, which remain recognisable as such after the event, is a routine and rather piffling achievement. But we ain't seen nothing yet.

If we can change other organisms, we can also change ourselves. Genomic organisation will allow us to fashion the human form into any conceivable shape. We will have extra limbs, if we want them - maybe even wings to fly, accessories enough to befit a self-made angel. We will even be able to digitise and store human genomes microscopically, on a chip. When the time comes to colonise other stars, the genomes of millions of people and other organisms will be shrunk on to a chip, placed into a spacecraft the size of a golfball and accelerated out of the solar system at 98% lightspeed. This will happen by 2099.

If this seems like science fiction that has no chance of coming true in the next millennium, let alone the next century, here's a sobering statistic. The first complete genome was that of the bacterium, Haemophilus influenzae. It was published in 1995 - just five years ago. We have come far, in hardly more than one term of parliament. Genomics is moving so fast that it must form part of a sensible political strategy. This strategy must consider (and take seriously) the concerns of science, and not be overly swayed by the wilfully ill-informed ban-everything mentality of those who wish to retrieve a golden age that never was. People must be made to realise that the concerns of the anti-GM lobby, while perhaps of passing relevance, are distracting.

The fact is that we will have a power almost godlike, and we must come to terms with it in a positive, forward-looking spirit. This power will be conferred on us whether we want it or not - the damage has been done once the idea has been framed. Technical realisation is just a matter of cleaning up. What shall we do with it? Like David Bowman, we have yet to learn even to stretch our wings. But we will think of something.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature and writes its science fiction column, Futures. His book, Deep Time: Cladistics, the Revolution in Evolution, is published by Fourth Estate

When the time comes to colonise other stars, the genomes of millions of people and other organisms will be shrunk on to a chip, placed into a spacecraft the size of a golfball and accelerated out of the solar system at 98% lightspeed. This will happen by 2099. If this seems like science fiction that has no chance of coming true in the next millennium, let alone the next century, here's a sobering statistic. The first complete genome was that of the bacterium, Haemophilus influenzae. It was published in 1995 - just five years ago. We have come far, in hardly more than one term of parliament. Genomics is moving so fast that it must form part of a sensible political strategy. This strategy must consider (and take seriously) the concerns of science, and not be overly swayed by the wilfully ill-informed ban-everything mentality of those who wish to retrieve a golden age that never was. People must be made to realise that the concerns of the anti-GM lobby, while perhaps of passing relevance, are distracting. The fact is that we will have a power almost godlike, and we must come to terms with it in a positive, forward-looking spirit. This power will be conferred on us whether we want it or not - the damage has been done once the idea has been framed. Technical realisation is just a matter of cleaning up. What shall we do with it? Like David Bowman, we have yet to learn even to stretch our wings. But we will think of something.  Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature and writes its science fiction column, Futures. His book, Deep Time: Cladistics, the Revolution in Evolution, is published by Fourth Estate

fields.headline: The long and winding code
fields.standfirst: It would take decades and cost billions, they said. Tim Radford tells how it was done
fields.trailText: It would take decades and cost billions, they said. Tim Radford tells how it was done.
fields.body:
The Human Genome Project began as a leap into the dark, and ended by ushering in a new information age. Critics said it it would cost insane sums of money, take decades to complete and deliver only a stream of data encoded in an alphabet of four letters, nine-tenths of which would have no meaning at all.

When scientists proposed the idea in the 1980s, it took hours of painstaking effort using exquisitely tricky chemistry, to "read" even a few thousand bits of DNA. The cost was put at $5 to $10 for each one of the four "letters" - sometimes called nucleotides, sometimes base pairs - in the 3 billion-letter human alphabet. When, in the teeth of grumbling from fellow biologists, foot-dragging by politicians in Britain and America and explicit public concern in Germany, the project gathered momentum, the international cost was set at $3bn in total - $1 for each base pair. Right now the cost has fallen to 10 or 20 cents.

The first "rough draft" is complete, thanks to astonishing advances in robotics and computing, and subtle tricks with electrochemistry.

The challenge was to decipher the entire DNA of one representative human, selected from a group of anonymous donors. But the DNA of one human is an invisible double-stranded molecule arbitrarily chopped up by nature into 46 chromosomes - 23 inherited from the mother, 23 from the father - and folded into impenetrable tangles. It was then, and still is impossible to read in that form: impossible even to see, let alone manipulate.

So researchers took lengths of human DNA and inserted them into bacteria, and then grew the bacteria, much in the way dairymen "grow" yoghurt, allowing each bacterial specimen to "clone" the same bit of DNA indefinitely, so that it could be preserved in dishes in a human DNA "library".

But that was the equivalent of simply tearing random paragraphs out of a book, hoping to read them later.

So the first step was to try to make a "map" of the human genome: to establish recognisable genes, or telltale lengths of DNA, at points along all the chromosomes so that those given the challenge of "reading" the sequence would start with a rough idea of where, in a particular chapter, their paragraph might fall. That effort continued throughout the 90s, as individual groups in the worldwide community of biologists began to identify then locate genes associated with diseases such as muscular dystrophy and cystic fibrosis.

By this time, too, teams within the Human Genome Project, in industry, in the medical charities and in government research laboratories were getting experience with the genetic codes of complex creatures such as yeast, a little member of the mustard family called Arabidopsis, the nematode worm or the fruit fly.

Since DNA is the machinery of evolution, the genes of all creatures would show similarities, and make recognition easier.

All the researchers used a technique developed by Frederick Sanger, the Cambridge scientist who deciphered the protein structure of insulin, won a Nobel Prize for it, and then went back to his laboratory to decipher the code of DNA. A feat which earned him another Nobel prize.

The Sanger method, then done by hand (but now by specially commissioned robots) was simple. You shredded the DNA sample into a large number of lengths ending up with very short bits, medium lengths and long bits. If you did it often enough, you would end up with bits of every possible length. Then you would tag the end of each with a fluorescent dye, dribble them into a tiny, jelly-filled capillary tube the thickness of a human hair, using electricity to help them settle. The shortest would settle first, then the next shortest and so on until the fragments were in order.

When you had enough fragments, all overlapping each other, you could get a computer to match them, rather like reassembling the Bible from fragments that said "Saul" or "Psalm" or "Solomon".

But the process also has to be fast. To read a base-pair sequence of a human being out loud - at, say, five letters a second - it would take 20 sleepless years. The original Sanger method could deliver thousands of letters a day, but the project demanded millions.

So what began as a meticulous matter of test tubes and syringes and white-coated laboratory staff became rooms full of robots: St Louis, Missouri; Cambridge, England; Cambridge, Massachusetts or Rockville, Maryland. Biology, invented by gentlemen-amateurs became big science, demanding engineering skills and computing power far greater than needed for the Apollo programme. Although the researchers have blown a whistle, posted their latest results and declared a milestone passed, it isn't complete.

"There is roughly 10%we haven't sequenced," says Don Powell, a molecular biologist at the Sanger Centre in Cambridge. "The attitude in the Human Genome Project is that we are putting this data out, it is only going to be done once and it absolutely has to be done properly. Everybody is agreed you need to do everything tenfold in order to get yourself down to 99.99% accuracy. We will achieve better than that. Because the genome is only going to be sequenced once to this level of completion - no other organisation is going to do all this finishing and all the work to plug all the holes we can - it has to be done properly."

fields.headline: The gene geniuses
fields.standfirst: The four scientists who were the driving force behind the genome project
fields.trailText: The four scientists who were the driving force behind the genome project.
fields.body:
Francis Collins

Dr Collins first found fame identifying the gene that caused cystic fibrosis in 1989, then went on to discover the gene for neurofibromatosis in 1990 and a gene for Huntingdon's Disease in 1993. Now he heads the publicly funded National Human Genome Research Institute in Washington.

"Everything will be divided into the era before we had this information and the era after we had it," Collins predicts.

Dr Collins was appointed director of the NHGRI in 1993, following in the footsteps of DNA pioneer Dr James Watson. Now his laboratory is exploring the molecular genetics of breast cancer, prostate cancer and adult-onset diabetes among other diseases.

James Watson

It is nearly 50 years since James Watson and Francis Crick made what many scientists previously believed was the most important discovery of the 20th century: the structure of DNA.

At 72, the brash American who wrote a controversial bestseller, The Double Helix, about his Nobel prize-winning discovery, is still at the forefront of his field.

In 1992 internal politics pushed him from the director's seat of the US branch of the Human Genome Project. Now, Watson is president of Cold Spring Harbor laboratory in New York, where he turned to research into cancer almost 30 years ago. The first suggestion that DNA might have something to do with inheritance was made in 1944. Watson and Crick saw a pattern of evidence that others around them had missed. Watson has always said he was lucky that the others missed the vital clues.

Watson, one of whose sons was born with a severe learning disability, also believes parents have a moral responsibility to make sure their babies are born as healthy as possible.

William Haseltine

Multimillionaire socialite and brilliant scientist Dr William A Haseltine is chief executive of the private company, Human Genome Sciences, based in Rockville, Maryland, US. The pharmaceutical company uses genome data to develop new drug treatments and demands royalties from anyone who works on the gene, a move which has attracted criticism from fellow scientists. Among the genes patented by this company is that for CCR5, the receptor used by the Aids virus to enter human cells.

In 1982 Haseltine came up with the then controversial hypothesis that Aids was caused by a retrovirus. Greeted with scepticism at the time, he was later proved to be correct.

In 1992 he went into partnership with Craig Venter to sequence the human genome. Personality clashes led them to separate in 1997.

William French Anderson

Dr William French Anderson Jr, of the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, foresees a day when genetic therapy will be used to treat not only the living but those who have not yet been born. He hopes to get approval within the next few years to use gene therapy on a foetus that has been diagnosed with a deadly inherited disease.

"Gene therapy will revolutionise the practice of medicine. In 20 years, every major disease will have gene therapy as a treatment option," Anderson said.

In 1979, Anderson led a team of scientists with the National Institutes of Health in curing a genetic flaw in the cells of mice. By 1990, his laboratory had performed the first gene therapy experiment on a 4-year-old child with a rare genetic disease that prevents babies from developing their own immune systems.

Since Anderson's first experiment, more than 3,000 people have received gene therapy as part of clinical trials worldwide.

fields.headline: The breakthrough that changes everything
fields.trailText: Scientists have just finished deciphering the genome - the book of human life. Their DNA blueprint will change everything. The once undreamed-of knowledge has already begun to alter agriculture, forensic science, archaeology, biology and medicine.
fields.body:
Scientists have just finished deciphering the genome - the book of human life. Their DNA blueprint will change everything. The once undreamed-of knowledge has already begun to alter agriculture, forensic science, archaeology, biology and medicine. In the next decades it will fuel new multi-billion pound industries based on the software of life. It will begin to improve human health and prolong human life. It could even begin to dictate the future, and shape the lives of the as-yet-unborn. It will begin to alter - in the most profound fashion - the way humans think about themselves, and all life on the planet.

Using awesome computing power and sophisticated robotics, teams in Britain, Europe and the US have deciphered the three-billion letter DNA alphabet that shapes and limits human existence. Were it typed, single-spaced, on A4 paper, the blueprint for a single human would fill 750,000 pages.

But this code of the chromosomes, written in the four chemicals of DNA, will never be printed: instead, it has been posted on the internet, in daily instalments, so that researchers worldwide can continue a new revolution in the understanding of life itself. It will be used to understand and eliminate the inherited diseases that have scarred familes for generations: muscular dystrophy, Huntington's chorea, cystic fibrosis, porphyria, haemophilia, diabetes and hundreds of others. It is calculated that there could be 4,000 disorders caused by errors in a single gene, and the big killers - heart disease, stroke and cancer - are affected by combinations of genes.

By being able to "read" the software of inheritance, the argument goes, then doctors will for the first time be able to treat the disease rather than the patient. They would know exactly what biochemistry allowed the disorder to happen: they would be able to devise exactly the treatment to correct it, without harmful side effects.

But the completion of the first draft of the book of humanity - the scientists will now go over and over the script for years, filling in missing fragments and correcting misreadings - is just a beginning, not an end. Scientists have before them a book of letters, but they have to learn to read it: they have to begin to identify and decode the secrets of the genes, locked in that enigmatic code of four letters, strung over 23 chromosomes.

The work will take decades. Thousands of genes are already known, but tens of thousands still have to be deciphered. There could be 140,000 genes; there could be 40,000. In the course of numbering all the genes that affect obesity, or longevity, or the way limbs form, or the way the brain develops, scientists will change expectations about human life in profound ways, and they will raise huge questions as well as huge hopes.

The knowledge will also power a new industrial revolution, as biotech companies spring up to exploit this once-unimaginable knowledge. Britain has been a major player in the revolution, but when the project began more than a decade ago, the UK government would not support it. Britain's contribution was underwritten by the Wellcome Trust, one of the world's largest medical charities.

They backed John Sulston, who launched the Sanger Centre at Cambridge, first to sequence the DNA of a tiny worm, and then to tackle 30% of the human chromosomes. Passionate about the importance of the effort, Sulston and other Human Genome Project scientists have disclosed their data as soon as they have been sure of it, for both industry and other academics to exploit.

But commercial companies have also joined the gene hunt: one of them, Celera Genomics, under the US scientist Craig Venter, threatened to complete the human genome before the international team. Venter set up his own research institute to unravel the genomes of microbes such as the stomach ulcer bacterium, or the pathogen that spreads tuberculosis, and then, supported by billions of dollars raised on the US stock market, launched Celera to sequence the human genome for sale to industry. He also began applying for patents on genes, provoking international protest and a joint declaration from President Clinton and Prime Minister Blair that the data should be available to everyone. Scenting huge future profits, other companies began to stake out their own commercial claims on the human genome. The excitement increased, the progress towards the first draft began to accelerate.

Pharmaceutical companies and universities took another step in the knowledge revolution last year: they launched a consortium to begin looking not at the DNA of one representative human, but for all the tiny variations in genes that make humans so different from each other - and with such different life expectations. The promise is of personal "DNA chips" that will provide precise medical information for doctors, of treatments tailored to suit each different patient, and of more precise preventive medicine to forestall heart attacks in some, cancers in others. The promise is of longer lives, and better lives - but will it be for everyone, or just those who can pay for it?

fields.headline: Mortality and morality
fields.standfirst: Decoding the genome means we can control the ageing process. James Meek looks at the implications
fields.trailText: Decoding the genome means we can control the ageing process. James Meek looks at the implications.
fields.body:
When Robert Raine was born one hundred years ago, Queen Victoria was still Empress of India, 82 acres of land in Kensington was about to go under the hammer for half a million pounds and the government had just raised the minimum age of coalminers to 13.

The Essex centenarian is living witness to all the wonder, grief and fads of the last century. He is still going strong. Apart from some arthritis in his knees, he suffers from no significant illnesses. He lives by himself, in his own house, with the occasional assistance of the social services and Age Concern. He goes for a walk every afternoon.

And yet, of course, he is old. His skin has lost its youthful elasticity. His limbs respond more slowly to his will. His eyesight and hearing are less acute, and although his memory for the immense canvas of the past is still magnificent, his short-term memory is not so sharp. Today, for the first time, scientists are daring to look at that most natural and seemingly unstoppable of human processes, ageing, and ask some startling questions. Should ageing itself be seen as a disease? If so, why does everyone get it? And can it be stopped?

Of all the strange new horizons made visible by the decoding of the human genome, none is more hazy and more tantalising than this one. For our genes do not only contain the secrets of life, they also hold the secrets of death. And some researchers are looking to a future where knowledge and manipulation of our genes places the 100th year at the halfway mark in an active life spanning 200 years - or more.

"If you walk into the doctor's surgery, and you're fine, and you're 80, you're given a pat on the back and told it's great," says Gordon Lithgow, a lecturer and researcher into ageing at the University of Manchester. "If you're 20 and illness-free but have the body of an 80-year-old man, you'd be hospitalised immediately. There is something going on which we've never called a disease. I think perceptions will change."

Even before the prospect of knowing the function of all our genes came into view, biologists pondered on death. What, they wondered, was the point? Why should evolution have designed a creosote bush in the desert which would live for 11,000 years, a human being who was lucky to reach 70 and a mouse which burned out in a couple of years, when in theory cells should be able to reproduce and repair themselves indefinitely?

Some genetics researchers, particularly in the US, believe in the notion of programmed death - that there is a clock ticking away in our body which begins to kill us when we reach a certain age, and that the clock can be wound back.

The more popular theory comes from evolutionary biologists, and seems to be borne out by research. It reminds us that human beings are the products of evolution which crafted us to live successfully in the wild, not in the sheltered, well-fed, medicine-rich environment of the modern developed world. In the wild, our ancestors never had a chance to grow old: predators, accidents and disease took them in their prime. There was no point in a creature evolving which had the biochemistry necessary to live for hundreds of years if it was going to be swiftly torn apart by a sabre-toothed tiger before its 30th birthday.

"The evolutionary biologists have come up with a powerful idea," says Lithgow, "that says it wasn't worth building for the long term. In the wild, animals don't age. Something gets them first. Natural selection doesn't care what happens to us. We are disposable once we reproduce. We are not programmed to die."

Ageing research is a young field, with no more than a couple of dozen labs around the world regularly producing papers. But some of the results already achieved have been remarkable. By tinkering with the genes of a favourite lab animal, the nematode worm, scientists have been able to treble its lifespan.

Last year, by modifying the genes of mice, an Italian team was able to extend their lifespan by 30%. The mouse genome is very similar to that of humans.

Some of the causes and obstacles to ageing have been on the suspect list for a long time. Free radicals, molecules produced in cells as a by-product of the body's use of oxygen, go careering through our metabolism, jamming awkward atoms in vital molecular mechanisms and causing wear and tear. High levels of stress seem to accelerate ageing, as do toxins like alcohol and tobacco. On the other side, any animal which has its calorie intake sharply reduced seems to become healthier and live longer.

With increased knowledge of how our genes work, scientists are poised to look into what governs these processes.

"The impact of the genome sequence is going to be incredible," said Lithgow. "We can't complete our understanding of ageing without the genome. It may be another 50 years before it's turned into something useful, but you start by sequencing the DNA."

Targeting the genes involved in ageing is a hazardous business. The line between rejuvenating cells and turning them into tumours is a delicate one. The US firm Geron Corporation, one of the few companies set up to exploit ageing research for profit, has made persuasive claims for the properties of an enzyme called telomerase, which it says confers "immortality" or "mortality" upon cells, depending on whether it is present or not.

Yet Geron's commercial activity is focused more on the dangers of telomerase - its role in cancer - than on its potential use to defeat ageing.

The dual nature of telomerase is reflected in the broader challenge facing scientists as they struggle with no less a task than engineering evolution. It took millions of years for natural selection to produce our wild ancestors: are we prepared to wait millions of years for natural selection to modify the naked hunter in us to best use the world of medicines, soft furnishings and burger bars?

We think of early-onset Alzheimer's disease, which strikes people in their 40s or 50s, as the result of inherited genetic flaws. In fact, it may be a consequence of an original, ancient gene which served a useful purpose before its owner died in his or her 30s. The "normal" gene of people who don't get the disease may, in fact, be a more recent mutation.

"You could be taking something out that in evolutionary history has been very useful. It's almost like a genetic appendix. Now it's no longer useful to us and is causing us harm," says Lithgow. "We don't want to tamper with youth, growth or reproduction. But the genes doing that, making sure we reproduce and grow properly, have side effects in late life. The better we can deal with the side effects, the better we can deal with ageing."

According to Lithgow, society has no choice. For economic reasons, it must tackle the diseases of old age, not to extend lifespan but to extend "healthspan", the span of a person's active, healthy life. Yet lifespan will inevitably end up being lengthened too.

"What we are trying to do is understand ageing, which causes a hell of a lot of misery through things like Alzheimer's and arthritis. That's what we've created with 20th-century medicine - a population of aged individuals who reach the point where they get these diseases.

"The whole family eats everything in moderation," says Robert Raine's 70-year-old son, also called Robert, a former Ford worker and keen golfer. "We are not big drinkers, we are not smokers and we've always eaten normal, healthy food, rather than lots of chips and fatty things. We've had a balanced diet, I guess, all our lives.

The Essex centenarian is living witness to all the wonder, grief and fads of the last century. He is still going strong. Apart from some arthritis in his knees, he suffers from no significant illnesses. He lives by himself, in his own house, with the occasional assistance of the social services and Age Concern. He goes for a walk every afternoon. And yet, of course, he is old. His skin has lost its youthful elasticity. His limbs respond more slowly to his will. His eyesight and hearing are less acute, and although his memory for the immense canvas of the past is still magnificent, his short-term memory is not so sharp. Today, for the first time, scientists are daring to look at that most natural and seemingly unstoppable of human processes, ageing, and ask some startling questions. Should ageing itself be seen as a disease? If so, why does everyone get it? And can it be stopped? Of all the strange new horizons made visible by the decoding of the human genome, none is more hazy and more tantalising than this one. For our genes do not only contain the secrets of life, they also hold the secrets of death. And some researchers are looking to a future where knowledge and manipulation of our genes places the 100th year at the halfway mark in an active life spanning 200 years - or more. fields.headline: Patenting our genes
fields.standfirst: It's a controversial issue: James Meek finds out whether the arguments are so straightforward
fields.trailText: It's a controversial issue: James Meek finds out whether the arguments are so straightforward
fields.body:
The story of how Alexander Fleming, the Scottish bacteriologist of humble origins, stumbled across the wonder drug penicillin in a mouldy dish is the stuff of legend. Everyone remembers Fleming, the Nobel prizewinner.

Who remembers Andrew Moyer? Fleming discovered the drug. But it was Moyer, an employee of the US Department of Agriculture, who patented it. And it was big US pharmaceutical firms which pioneered its large-scale manufacture. In this scenario, you could characterise Fleming and his later British collaborators as virtuous, ethical men and women who never thought of profiting from a life-saving medicine and were outmanoeuvred by sly Americans.

Or you could ask whether, if the British had emulated the Americans, it might not have taken 13 years of underfunded experiments before penicillin started to be made in quantities large enough to be useful. Then perhaps it would have been available in time for Dunkirk, and not, as actually happened, D-Day.

The same dilemma exists today. Biotech firms say that if they couldn't patent genes it wouldnÍt be worth their while developing life-saving drugs and therapies, while many scientists, religious believers, humanists and environmental campaigners find loathsome the concept of private, for-profit corporations staking claims to what is literally a human birthright.

But claim them they do. And they aren't all private firms. Top spot for gene patent applications in the US goes to Incyte Genomics of Palo Alto, with 315 patents; number two is the University of California, with 219. In Britain, universities and medical charities are among patent holders.

Typical of the big patenters riding high on Wall Street and in the City is Human Genome Sciences, Maryland, which holds about 90 patents. Most controversially, it holds a patent on a gene called CCR5, thought to give Aids the key to enter human cells. HGS didn't prove CCR5 was responsible: other researchers did. But HGS already had the patent in the bag, as they had earlier used computer analysis of data from the publicly funded Human Genome Project to guess a likely role for the gene.

HGS was attacked over the debacle by, among others, Craig Venter, the brilliant, combative scientist who once worked for the US government genetics research programme and now heads Celera, the private-sector rival to the state and charity-funded Human Genome Project.

Venter says the existing regime allows companies to patent genes without doing any real work. Yet Celera itself is deeply embroiled in the patent controversy. Venter acknowledges that Celera could not have progressed so far and so fast in its own, private genome sequencing effort without exploiting the freely available data from the Human Genome Project.

US and European patent law differ, but both now accept that a human gene or protein can meet the criteria to be considered an 'invention': that it is novel, useful and reproduceable. The approach is being satirised by Donna MacLean, the Bristol poet who has applied to patent her entire self, arguing that she, too, is novel, useful and reproduceable: "I've come to embody in my own person a grey area in patent law. There are great possibilities for medical advances, but are they just going to be for those in the west who can afford them?"

As gene patenters are quick to point out, they are not, strictly speaking, patenting genes as they are found in nature; they are patenting the data of gene sequences, together with a use for that data. According to Professor Deryck Beyleveld, director of the Sheffield Institute of Biotechnological Law and Ethics, though, that doesnÍt mean patenters couldnÍt get a hold on your body. "Under the existing European directive, although nobody can patent my DNA, if you get a patent on a process which produces something identical to my DNA, I can infringe your patent simply by having my own DNA."

Such bizarre hypothetical Catch-22 situations are dismissed by the biotech lobby, emerging as one of the most powerful industrial sectors of the 21st century. "In philosophical terms, a patent is a social contract between an inventor and society,"says the HGS website. "In that contract, an invention is protected from commercial exploitation by others in exchange for the inventorÍs teaching of others to reproduce the invention."

The British biotech sector yields little to its US counterpart in terms of determination to win and defend patents. Politically, they have a free hand: despite the joint declaration by Bill Clinton and Tony Blair that the human genome sequence must be freely available to all scientists, the US and UK administrations support gene patenting.

London-based BTG, a buyer of intellectual property, holds a bundle of patents which gives it control over the gene producing the protein Factor IX, deficient in sufferers from the blood disease haemophilia B. For good measure, BTG has a patent on the protein as well. It earns money from licensing the firms servicing the £100m market for Factor IX.

"I think it's entirely appropriate that companies which have done the work on genes should have the rights to what they've developed," says BTG chief executive Ian Harvey. "If the state wants to get into developing drugs, investing the billions of dollars needed, with most of it wasted, that's something it can choose to do. But most countries have chosen not to go down that road."

Simon Cohen, a patent lawyer with Taylor Joynson Garrett in London, says: "Genes are complex chemicals, and a great deal of scientific research and ingenuity is often needed to turn a naturally occurring gene into a life-saving medicine. When this is done, a real contribution is made by that research, deserving of patent protection. The counterbalance always exists in patent law that if an invention is not truly inventive, patent protection will not be available. There are a number of cases before the courts and patent offices in Europe and the US where dubious biotech patent applications are being challenged."

Much of the confusion over the patenting of genes stems from the fact that the data has myriad commercial applications, not all of them involving drugs. The biotech and traditional pharmaceuticals firms like to stress the vast private resources which go towards putting drugs through clinical trials, many of which will fail. Yet other key uses of gene knowledge - to screen people for genetic disposition to disease, or gene therapy - differ from the traditional pharmaceutical route to market.

Around the world, for example, doctors have independently developed tests for mutations in two genes which make women susceptible to breast cancer. They say they use genetic information from the public domain and standard gene-sequencing techniques. Yet a single US company, Myriad Genetics of Salt Lake City, claims to have patented both genes, and seeks a monopoly on testing. Its licensee in Britain says it has no intention of forcing NHS labs to stop doing their own tests, but doctors are concerned.

webTitle: Is gene therapy suitable for other diseases?

fields.headline: Is gene therapy suitable for other diseases?
fields.standfirst: How gene therapy could affect the treatment of haemophilia, cancer and cystic fibrosis
fields.trailText: How gene therapy could affect the treatment of haemophilia, cancer and cystic fibrosis
fields.body:
Success with gene therapy for X-linked SCID may mark the conquest of one rare inherited disease, but what of the others? Most are less accessible to gene therapy. Others, like cancer and heart disease, are thought to be the result of the complex interaction of many genes with environmental factors. The importance of deciphering the human genome is that it will help researchers understand how genes work with each other, rather than in isolation. The success of existing gene therapy research varies from disease to disease, but scores of labs around the world are involved, with some successes among the disappointments.

Haemophilia

One of the most promising areas is haemophilia, an inherited disease afflicting males which forces about 10,000 people in Britain to take regular injections of a protein called Factor IX. The protein is essential to make blood clot; without it, sufferers can spontaneously bleed inside, which can lead to permanent disability. The problem is caused by a fault in the gene which should produce Factor IX.

Recently a team of US researchers announced promising results in tests. Six human patients were enrolled in a trial after haemophiliac dogs given the engineered virus were cured of the condition. The first three humans were given doses too low to affect the dogs - yet, unexpectedly, the implanted genes began producing enough of the missing protein to allow them to cut back on their injections.

Cancer

Clinical trials are under way or about to start - some in the UK - of three promising gene therapies. Phase III trials, the last step before a treatment is authorised for general clinical use, are imminent for an anti-cancer therapy which focuses on a gene called p53. This is known as a "tumour suppressing gene", one built into our bodies to halt the runaway growth of cells which marks the beginning of cancer.

In many tumour cells, the p53 gene is missing or damaged. Scientists have devised a way to engineer a virus which will only thrive in p53-deficient cells. It can be injected into a patient, and will only enter and damage the harmful cancer cells, leaving healthy cells alone.

Other trials focus on the set of so-called "oncogenes". In healthy people, they promote normal cell growth and then get switched off. In some cancers, the oncogenes get switched on when they should be dormant. Scientists hope to zoom in on the gene which turns the "on" switch and fuse it to another gene called a suicide gene, which activates an anti-tumour drug, killing the cancer cells.

A third, more radical approach is to use an engineered gene as a vaccine. In tumours, mutant genes emerge so unfamiliar to the body that its immune system would attack them if only it knew they were there. Researchers hope to identify the mutations, replicate them in the lab and inject them into patients to alert the immune system, which would then attack the cancer as "foreign".

Cystic fibrosis

Cystic fibrosis is the most common life-shortening illness in Britain linked to a single gene. There are 6,000 sufferers in the UK. Conventional treatment advances have extended their average life expectancy from five to 31, but all-out efforts here and in the US are under way to find an effective gene therapy. The problem gene's worst effect is to reduce the amount of water in the lining of the lungs, leading to a build up of infection-prone mucus. Researchers are trying, with some success, to get "good" genes through the mucus barrier.

In the US, they are using a virus to get the "good" gene to where it is needed. In Britain, scientists are focusing on another delivery system, a fine vapour of synthetic fat droplets.

Early results from spraying the gene-enhanced fat into the nose, and now the lungs, have been good, but the effects last only for a short time. The Cystic Fibrosis Trust cautions that the technique is "gene transfer" rather than gene therapy. The breakthrough has yet to be made.

fields.headline: Gene therapy and drug wars
fields.trailText: The completion of the Human Genome Project will be greeted by the humming of thousands of powerful computers, as drugs companies around the world race to analyse the final pieces of the genetic jigsaw.
fields.body:
The completion of the Human Genome Project will be greeted by the humming of thousands of powerful computers, as drugs companies around the world race to analyse the final pieces of the genetic jigsaw. The next decade will see an explosion in the rate of drug development activity and any pharmaceuticals group which lags will be left far, far behind.

Allen Roses, worldwide director of genetics at Glaxo Wellcome, says: "This is not just a once in a lifetime event for the industry. There is only one human genome and what happens in the next five to 10 years will not be repeatable."

Today's work shows the position of every gene in the body. The challenge for drug researchers is to determine their functions, and identify tiny differences which cause disease. Medicines can then be accurately tailored to correct these tiny chemical deviances.

John Keller, director of SmithKline Beecham's genomics technology group, says: "There certainly is going to be a competition but I don't think people should underestimate the magnitude of the task. This completes one area of biology. Everyone within biology will be pursuing their own interests in it."

The amount of money involved is immense. Britain's second biggest drugs group, AstraZeneca, spends $8m a day on research and development. SmithKline spends over £1bn annually, employing nearly 8,000 people worldwide.

It will take, on average, 10 years from the point of identifying a gene "target" to launching a drug. Many such projects are already well under way. Ultimately, genomics will lead to differences in the way drugs are marketed. Doctors will be able to judge more accurately which patients are likely to respond to which medicines.

Dr Roses says: "We'll be able to take people who've had adverse events in trials and look at their DNA to see what makes them different."

He reckons this will ultimately mean higher sales, because people will no longer have to be persuaded to "risk" suffering side effects.

A clutch of smaller British players are well placed to take advantage of the "gene economy". Oxford Glycosciences, a spin-out from Oxford University, has one of the world's biggest libraries linking proteins to disease. By connecting these proteins with genes, the company can trace the roots of illness further back, making it much easier to design effective drugs. Its shares have surged eight-fold in a year, to value the business at more than £600m.
