This completes one area of biology. Everyone within biology will be pursuing their own interests in it." The amount of money involved is immense. Britain's second biggest drugs group, AstraZeneca, spends $8m a day on research and development. SmithKline spends over £1bn annually, employing nearly 8,000 people worldwide. It will take, on average, 10 years from the point of identifying a gene "target" to launching a drug. Many such projects are already well under way. Ultimately, genomics will lead to differences in the way drugs are marketed. Doctors will be able to judge more accurately which patients are likely to respond to which medicines. Dr Roses says: "We'll be able to take people who've had adverse events in trials and look at their DNA to see what makes them different." He reckons this will ultimately mean higher sales, because people will no longer have to be persuaded to "risk" suffering side effects. A clutch of smaller British players are well placed to take advantage of the "gene economy". Oxford Glycosciences, a spin-out from Oxford University, has one of the world's biggest libraries linking proteins to disease. By connecting these proteins with genes, the company can trace the roots of illness further back, making it much easier to design effective drugs. Its shares have surged eight-fold in a year, to value the business at more than £600m.

fields.headline: Ethical grey areas
fields.trailText: A genetic underclass? | Insurance risks | Genetic screening | Gene prospecting
fields.body:
A genetic underclass?

In his book Remaking Eden, the Princeton University biologist Lee Silver foresees a world 350 years from now where pressure from wealthy parents has leveraged gene and cloning technology to the point where society is divided into two classes: 90% "Naturals" and 10% "Gene-enriched", the latter forming a "modern-day hereditary class of genetic aristocrats" so different from their Natural counterparts they are effectively another species.

Whatever ethical guidelines governments try to impose on industries, insurers and others who seek to benefit from the mapping of the human genome, the emergence of a "genetic underclass" may be inevitable. For some commentators, like US biologist Jeremy Rifkin, it paves the way for "the wholesale alteration of the human species and the birth of a commercially driven eugenics civilisation".

The first signs are already being seen with genetic discrimination taking place in some workplaces. It is now reaching into the areas of adoption and military service. The fear is that people with genetic flaws may be denied insurance, access to schooling or jobs.

Differential treatment may also be applied to people with different gene "qualities". Employers could hire only those people whose genes indicate they are resistant to the health hazards of the workplace, which is a cheaper alternative to making the workplace safe for all. Social or political pressure may in the future be applied to people to make childbearing decisions on the basis of genetic information. Mating between those with valued genes may be encouraged; between those with high-risk traits prohibited.

The mapping of the genome may give rise to "genetic determinism" - the belief that characteristics, such as intelligence or criminal behaviour, are mostly a function of genes. It may also encourage a fatalistic attitude toward health and disease and be used to perpetuate racial or ethnic inequalities. John Vidal

Insurance risks

Being able to identify genes which make individuals more likely to fall ill will mean painful dilemmas for anyone making long-term financial plans, be they consumers or providers - and difficult decisions for the governments which must arbitrate between them.

"As the blueprint unfolds, the feeling is it will have an impact in all sorts of areas for us, " admits John Dearing, chief underwriter at the Prudential.

The Association of British Insurers guidelines state that members should not ask applicants to take tests, but can require them to disclose the results of any taken in the past.

The Department of Health has assembled a group of academics to determine which genetic tests are sufficiently reliable to be considered by financial organisations. Among these are tests for certain forms of Alzheimer's, and breast and ovarian cancer. The most cotroversial is for Huntington's Chorea, a degenerative disease beginning in middle age.

Mr Dearing admits, "If somebody came in with that Huntington's gene and they were 30 years old, looking to cover a 20-year mortgage, we would have to put the premiums up so much that we couldn't offer anything viable."

Patients' organisations are keeping a close eye on developments. However, Alistair Kent, chairman of the Genetic Interest Group, an umbrella body for sufferers of hereditary diseases, believes fears of an "underclass" are exaggerated: "There has always been a problem for some people in terms of their family history in getting insurance. But the problem is very small - 95% of all life insurance applications are agreed at standard rates.

As yet, genetic tests remain rare. The Prudential, Britain's biggest insurer, has only ever received two applications disclosing the results of any. That is likely to change dramatically over the next 10 years. Andrew Clark

Genetic screening

As more data is fished out of the genome pool, the ability of doctors to predict the future course of a patient's life from a tiny speck of their genetic material will increase exponentially.

One of the most fraught ethical arenas in the genetics revolution is antenatal genetics screening, the use of gene tests to screen unborn children for future diseases which would be severe enough to influence a mother's decision over whether or not to have an abortion.

While some consequences of the new knowledge of our genes are remote, this one isn't. Trials have been under way for several years in the UK of screening programmes for the most common life-shortening single gene disorder, cystic fibrosis. One in 24 Britons is a carrier of the gene: if two carriers have children, the baby has a one in four chance of being born with the disease.

Screening for cystic fibrosis in newborn babies, so as to treat sufferers as early as possible, is already available in four English regions, Northern Ireland and Wales. But a report by a team of Leeds researchers published in 1999 recommended offering cystic fibrosis tests to everyone before birth, with the aim of cutting the incidence of the disease through abortion.

Explaining the economic advantages of aborting cystic fibrosis sufferers at the embryonic stage, the researchers wrote: "The cost of antenatal screening is estimated to be between £46,000 and £53,000 per CF pregnancy detected, considerably less than the lifetime cost of treatment." CF sufferers, who experience a suffocating build-up of mucus in their lungs, can currently hope to live into their 30s. Sufferers and their relatives hope gene therapy will find a cure for the condition in the coming decades. But the technology for genetic screening is up and running now. James Meek

Gene prospecting

In 1984, the Hagahai people of Papua New Guinea contacted the outside world for the first time asking for medical help. Blood samples were taken but the tribe was not told that some blood contained unique genetic characteristics which potentially offered resistance to a certain type of leukaemia. The US National Institute of Health (NIH) saw the potential and patented the line of one man. It eventually withdrew the patent after an outcry but the blood sample is still held under the Budapest Convention by the semi-private American Type Culture Collection, and can be accessed by anyone for a small fee.

Thousands of blood samples and saliva swabs have been taken from some of the remotest peoples on earth by gene "prospectors", mostly without their knowledge or permission. It is impossible to find out what has been patented and which, if any, have been developed into drugs.

Indigenous groups have reacted furiously to gene pirating, as did John Moore, a US citizen who had his spleen removed because of cancer in 1976. When analysed, Moore's cell line was found to have unique characteristics. A doctor patented the line and it was bought by a Swiss drug company which used it to make a drug worth millions of dollars. Moore sued the company, but settled out of court before a clear precedent could be set over whether he owned the rights to biological material taken from his own body.

Even when "gene prospecting" is done legally there are problems. Iceland's 270,000 people voted in a referendum two years ago to sell for $200m access to the entire population's medical records which make up a unique resource for scientists tracing the genetic journey of diseases. Opponents fear the database could make the most private details of individuals' lives public and that people with health problems could be stigmatised. John Vidal

fields.headline: Alarm bells
fields.standfirst: The applications of biotechnology have provoked debate about its ethics. Richard Holloway looks at some of the issues
fields.trailText: The applications of biotechnology have provoked debate about its ethics. Richard Holloway looks at some of the issues.
fields.body:
One way to classify people is by the tumbler test: pessimists say it is half empty, optimists half full. In most of the great debates about human nature people place themselves somewhere on the continuum between these two poles.

There is an obvious application of the tumbler test to political theory, with people like Hobbes in the pessimist camp. Because of his low estimate of human nature, he called for strong princes to control the brutal excesses of society. John Stuart Mill, on the other hand, believed that human nature was rational and capable of altruism, so he argued for liberty and democracy. Science is the dominant narrative of our day, so it is fascinating to watch this ancient debate conduct itself in a new language. Pessimists mistrust science, optimists celebrate the enormous contribution it has made to human progress, but many people are just not sure what to make of it.

Reaching a considered judgment on the complex issues that science presents is particularly difficult in Britain at the moment, because of the approach of certain newspapers. The science correspondents in the better papers play an important part in educating the public about science and its implications, but some of the other sheets present the subject as a shoot-out between ordinary decency and overweening arrogance. This may sell papers, but it hardly does justice to the importance of the subject.

There are real anxieties, of course. The biotech revolution we are now entering will make the industrial revolution look like a minor blip on the chart of human history. Change always induces anxiety, particularly among natural pessimists, of whom Britain always seems to have more than its fair share, so it's not surprising that recent advances in genetics have provoked alarm in certain quarters.

The paradox is that this country has so far managed to pilot a steady course through the scientific revolutions of our era. The paradigm is the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act of 1990. Like any human construct, it is far from perfect, but it does provide us with a model approach to the negotiation of current perplexities. Depending on which side of the pitch you stood, the 1990 Act was a masterly example of either moderate pessimism or moderate optimism, which steered a middle way through the field of reproductive science, between unfettered experimentation and the outlawing of procedures that were novel and controversial at the time. After a certain amount of ritual grandstanding on both sides of the debate, this is the approach we will almost certainly adopt to the new advances in human genetics. But we ought to keep our minds open to some of the sensitive issues that will confront us.

One of the difficulties is that the subject is inescapably linked to memories of the pseudo-science of eugenics, with its fascist echoes. The word eugenics is probably beyond rehabilitation, but behind it lies a morally complex issue. Theoretically, it will soon be possible to perform gene therapy to cure or prevent inheritable genetic disease. These therapies in themselves raise interesting ethical problems to which I'll return, but the issue I want to look at briefly now is their likely impact upon existing people with disabilities.

It is not too difficult to see why the disabled community might come to interpret these procedures as an attack upon their own value as human beings. We might argue that to try to mend a particular defect is far from saying that those who possess it are less human than the rest of us.

Even more complex will be the ethics of the reverse possibility, whereby a disabled couple, such as a profoundly deaf one, might invoke the process in order to design the birth of a disabled child who can be fully at home in its parent's culture. Is there any way in which a truly multicultural society could learn to live with intentionally produced disability? If, as the disabled community claims, disability is socially constructed, might it not be possible to deconstruct it in this way and thereby create genuinely plural communities? We are going to have to breathe deeply and keep our wits about us as we negotiate some of these possibilities.

When gene therapy is perfected, it will come in two possible forms, each with its own ethical difficulties. It could be performed using somatic cells, which make up most of the cells in the body, or germ cells from sperm or eggs. Somatic cell gene therapy would only affect the individual who was treated, whereas germ cell therapy would pass the altered genes on to the next generation. In 1989 the government set up a committee to consider the ethics of gene therapy. Its report in 1992 concluded that "somatic cell gene therapy will be a new kind of treatment, but it does not represent a major departure from established medical practice; nor does it pose new ethical challenges."

Where it is likely to become controversial, however, is when it is applied to procedures for the enhancement of physical characteristics, such as height or appearance. Though it will doubtless provoke debate, it would be hard to argue that using somatic cell gene therapy for these purposes would be more ethically problematic than getting a nose job or a breast enhancement using existing procedures. Nevertheless, we can expect the tabloids to have a field day with this therapy when it comes on-stream.

Germ cell gene therapy, if it is ever made safe, will raise a much more difficult issue. Would it be unethical to apply a technique that would affect an individual prior to conception? The philosopher John Harris argues that, if the technique is proved to be safe and efficacious, it would be unethical not to apply it, because parents have an obligation to avoid harm to their unborn children.

However, the real issue here is the moral status of the human embryo. Germ cell gene therapy will only be perfected and made safe after years of experimentation on embryos. The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act permits experiments on embryos up to 14 days, or on the appearance of the neural or primitive streak. But this is one of the most controversial aspects of the act and one which significant elements in British society still reject.

Most of us would probably apply a doctrine of incremental potentiality to human gametes, so that the moral status of the entity increases the closer it gets to term. The Roman Catholic Church, however, accords full human status to the embryo from the beginning, so it condemns experiments on embryos as the moral equivalent of the torture of human beings.

This is an example of the kind of disagreement that is inevitable in a plural society. But those of us who find these developments unproblematic ought to remember that they will be painful for intact moral communities that have a fixed perspective on the status of human gametes. If we are to avoid the culture wars that so disfigure the USA we'll have to negotiate these complexities with great care.

 Richard Holloway is bishop of Edinburgh and from 1991-97 was a member of the Human Fertilisation and Embryo Authority

fields.headline: Studio ends Griffith's 'vanity deal'
fields.trailText: Warner Bros has ended a five-year contract with the actress Melanie Griffith following poor box-office takings of her last film, Crazy in Alabama
fields.body:
Warner Bros has ended a five-year contract with the actress Melanie Griffith following poor box-office takings of her last film, Crazy in Alabama (pictured), which took only £600,000 on its US release.

Crazy in Alabama was directed by Griffith's husband, Antonio Banderas, and it was hoped it would earn Griffith an Oscar nomination - something she has long coveted since she missed out on one for Working Girl in 1988. Instead the tale of the glamorous and eccentric Lucille (Griffith), who escapes from her abusive husband and takes off for Hollywood to pursue her dreams of TV stardom received poor reviews and even poorer audiences.

Today's Express newspaper reports that although Griffith invested a lot of her own money in the project, Green Moon - the company she set up to make a series of films with Warner Bros - has been told to leave the studios offices.

Griffith's arrangement with the studio is known as a 'Vanity Deal': studios give Hollywood stars huge amounts of money - anything from £2m to £5m - to indulge their own pet projects. The days of such deals however, seem to be coming to an end.

Michelle Pfeiffer had to close down the company she set up with Sony to make The Deep End of the Ocean, which was one of last year's biggest flops. Sylvester Stallone and Demi Moore have also recently been asked to leave their offices at Universal studios.

An anonymous source at Warner Bros said: "Film costs are rising all the time and the good old days of vanity deals are starting to become something of the past."

fields.headline: 26 June: Casting news
fields.standfirst: On the casting couch today, Sharon Stone goes back to basics, Star Wars down under, Steve Buscemi in T3?, and Marisa Tomei and Ellen Barkin join Ashley Judd
fields.trailText: On the casting couch today, Sharon Stone goes back to basics, Star Wars down under, Steve Buscemi in T3?, and Marisa Tomei and Ellen Barkin join Ashley Judd
fields.body:
 Sharon Stone has signed for a reported $15m to reprise the defining role of her career, in a sequel to the 1992 hit Basic Instinct. Michael Douglas, who played a policeman who becomes sexually involved with Stone's murder suspect, will not be returning.

 More casting news from the Star Wars Episode 2 camp. As we reported last week, filming is due to start in Australia today and casting director Robin Gurland has been busy seeking out local talent. According to the film's official site, there are eight new additions to the cast, all more or less unheard of outside of their native Australia, but who - according to Gurland - represent "some of the best acting talent the country has to offer". The site has an up-to-date cast list and a short biography on each of the newcomers.

 After the news last week that there is a possibility of a Terminator 3 going into production, rumour has it that Steve Busemi has been approached to play a leading role. Buscemi, best known for his supporting roles in films such as Fargo and Con Air, is reported to be interested only if Schwarzenegger reprises his lead role.

 Tough-talking actresses Marisa Tomei and Ellen Barkin are both in negotiations to join the forthcoming Ashley Judd film, Animal Husbandry. The film, in which Judd plays a magazine writer who believes animals set a good example to humans on dating techniques, is due to begin shooting next month. Oscar-winner Tomei would portray Judd's serial-dating best friend, while Barkin is considering the role as her over-bearing boss.

Oscar-winner Tomei would portray Judd's serial-dating best friend, while Barkin is considering the role as her over-bearing boss.

fields.headline: 26 June: In brief
fields.trailText: Chicken Run breaks Stateside records, Dustin Hoffman feels neglected, and Iranian cinema gets bigger and better
fields.body:
Chicken Run has broken animation records for Dreamworks in its opening weekend in the US. The animated comedy from the British Aardman Studio, released this weekend, grossed $17.5m, topping the $17.2m 1998 debut of its nearest computer-generated rival, Antz. Meanwhile, the Farrelly Brothers' controversial split-personality movie Me, Myself and Irene has proved their biggest earner yet. It took $24.2m over its opening weekend - compared with $13.7m for There's Something About Mary.

Dustin Hoffman has parted ways with his agent following rumours that he feels he is being underused. According to insiders, Hoffman's departure from International Creative Management stemmed from a rather light work schedule of late, and was exacerbated by Hoffman's desire to begin a directing career that has so far not materialised. Hoffman's move follows a number of high-profile walk-outs from the agency, including Russell Crowe, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Meg Ryan.

Iran is to double the capacity of its cinemas in order to keep up with current demand of its film-mad population. The Deputy Culture Minister told the state-run newspaper Iran on Saturday that an extra 190,000 seats are needed to satisfy the country's needs. Film is one of Iran's best loved art forms, and the recent success of film directors Samira Makhmalbat and Hassan Yekpatanah at the Cannes Festival (see our news story, has only increased interest in Iranian film. The 1979 Islamic Revolution put the brakes on cinema construction and many cinemas were turned into government buildings, but since the 1997 election of the reforming President Mohammed, who spent 10 years as culture minister, cinema regulations have been more relaxed.

fields.headline: Tough at the top
fields.standfirst: When Janet Street-Porter became editor of the Independent on Sunday,  Roy Greenslade was sceptical about her abilities. Now he assesses her first year in the job
fields.trailText: When Janet Street-Porter became editor of the Independent on Sunday, Roy Greenslade was sceptical about her abilities. Now he assesses her first year in the job
fields.body:
A year ago, I debunked the choice of Janet Street-Porter as editor of the Independent on Sunday. I argued then that she didn't have the nous to run the paper and, worse still, might do it irreparable harm. The Sindy, I predicted, would lose senior staff, credibility and sales in that order.

Naturally enough, the man who appointed her, Simon Kelner, editor-in-chief of the Independent titles, thought both the tone of my article and many of its specific criticisms were wholly wrong. When we bumped into each other days later at the Groucho club - where else? - he held on to his temper, shrugged his shoulders, and said, in effect, time will tell, you'll see, Janet is a winner.

You may recall her own ambitions for her paper. A multicultural society, she wrote at the time, requires "a polymorphous journal . . . all-encompassing, tolerant in our sympathies, generous in our coverage". More prosaically, she told me that she aimed to make it "slightly more accessible, less austere and improve the presentation".

So, as she prepares to celebrate the first anniversary of her appointment, it's an appropriate moment to consider whether Street-Porter has accomplished what she set out to do and if my trenchant assault was wide of the mark.

First, let's admit that meltdown hasn't occurred. The paper is not in imminent danger of collapse. She hasn't done anything outrageous or eccentric enough to frighten the horses. Indeed, she has wisely chosen to make evolutionary changes rather than risking a revolution.

She weathered the storm of initial desertions by writers such as AN Wilson and Craig Brown (creator of the sadly-missed Wallace Arnold). For a long time, apart from changes of emphasis to the culture and reality sections, and the introduction of her own column on the leader page, it was difficult to divine that the former editor, Kim Fletcher, had departed.

That, in fairness, confirmed what she had originally told me: "I have ideas about what I'd like to do, but I intend to settle into the job first, talk to everyone and discover what they think." Street-Porter's first key decision was to appoint Michael Williams as her deputy. An experienced journalist, with a background as both a news and production executive, he was seen as a sensible, complementary, steadying hand.

After that, we had to wait until February for the arrival of Street-Porter's revamp. Reality became an A4-sized magazine; the Sunday Review magazine was remade; a business section emerged from its hiding place within sport and travel took its place; the culture pages were reconfigured with Will Self joining as TV critic; and the front page itself took on a new appearance.

Undoubtedly, these changes have made the paper more accessible. A rival editor thought it "much warmer" and "really quite good", though he was uncertain why the review, which had long been viewed as the Sindy's unique selling proposition, was changed unnecessarily.

I couldn't, and still can't, see the point of Reality. Its content seems to cry out for a larger format. Then again, the content is so marginal it really wouldn't matter if it wasn't there at all. It looks like an advertising supplement and is in desperate need of improved production values.

My main criticism in February was about the lack of regular, serious, heavyweight pundits. This has recently been addressed: Steve Richards, the New Statesman's ornament, is to become chief political commentator from September, and Colin Brown is to be political editor.

A raft of new appointments were also announced last week in other sections too. The business section, which was dire, has certainly improved under the energetic leadership of Jason Nisse, but there is a way to go yet.

Kelner says: "I think Janet's year has gone very well and she has put her stamp on the paper. It is developing into a strong product." How then have the public reacted to the Street-Porter Sindy? It has to be said, before we consider the paper's own circulation since her arrival, that the whole market has been hit by a slump in the past year.

Selling papers, especially on a Sunday, has been very difficult indeed. To mitigate the problem - or perhaps that should be crisis - papers have adopted a range of tactics to maintain their headline sales figures, including price-cutting, pre-paid subscriptions, bulk "freebies" and publishing in foreign lands.

The Sindy's preferred methods have been cutting the cover price and relying on bulks. In June last year, when Street-Porter took over, the paper's total sale was 242,238. Of these, some 29,000 were sold at a discount and 22,000 were given away.

Last month, the total was 250,142. But 66,000 were discounted and bulk sales had reached more than 35,000. For the past three weeks, the Sindy - which is supposed to cost £1.10 - has been selling in various regions for just 50p. It is estimated that the paper is regularly sacrificing at least £300,000 a week in revenue to boost its sale. The true cost is greater when bulks are added on.

The positive side of these figures is that the Sindy's owner, Tony O'Reilly's Independent Newspapers, is obviously still very committed to the paper. The negative side, of course, is that Street-Porter has had virtually no editorial impact. The underlying rate of sales decline is somewhat faster than it was under her predecessors. In other words, though the experiment in appointing such an unlikely editor hasn't been a disaster, it hasn't been a success either.

That is not, sadly, the end of the story. During my researches into life at the newspaper, a surprising and disturbing industrial relations picture emerged. It soon became apparent that Street-Porter's dealings with her staff are reminiscent of those at the Sun in the era of Kelvin MacKenzie.

The irony is that MacKenzie has been a savage critic of Street-Porter's since their time together on the execrable Mirror Group cable television enterprise L!ve TV. She couldn't, he said memorably and, it would appear, inaccurately, edit a bus ticket.

Despite her antipathy towards MacKenzie, she may well have picked up pointers from him about how to manage journalists. Several staff, and former staff, told me stories of her shouting at sub-editors and reporters in public.

These kinds of story are common about many editors and senior executives, usually on tabloids, and they should always be treated cautiously - hard words are often said in the heat of the battle. As Street-Porter writes of herself in this month's Aura magazine: "I admit I'm an extremely short-tempered, driven person, abrasive to a degree I'm not happy with." But the more people I spoke to, including those who say they have not personally suffered from Street-Porter's haranguing, the more a pattern did emerge which was hard to ignore. Needless to say, people refuse to go on the record, fearing for their jobs. But I was told of instances where, in the view of people I know to be sensible and experienced, she had "gone over the top".

One case mentioned several times concerned a young secretary who had suffered a number of tongue-lashings. "We began to think it was because she came from Essex," says a sympathetic Sindy journalist who added jokingly: "Obviously, mockney doesn't like cockney."

A casual reporter, Yvonne Ridley, was wrongly identified as having made an off-colour remark about Street-Porter, and even when the mistake came to light she was told she could not expect any more shifts. Jo Pugh, the former chief sub who had been with the paper for eight years, was evidently marginalised and ostracised after a disagreement with Street-Porter.

At one point, the situation got so bad that the general secretary of the National Union of Journalists, John Foster, sent a letter complaining about Street-Porter's behaviour to managing director Terry Grote. NUJ national organiser Jeremy Dear says: "There has been allegation after allegation about bullying, and this problem has been raised formally with management on several occasions."

When I put these claims to Grote he appeared genuinely shocked. He said he had written back to Foster to say that the company doesn't condone bullying and would, if claims were substantiated, deal with it through its internal procedures. He told me: "This is a very serious allegation to make and we took it seriously. We asked staff who felt aggrieved to see our managing editor, Jan Thompson. One or two did, but no one went ahead with a formal complaint. None of the allegations was confirmed."

He thought the whole thing was "a storm in a tea-cup". It had taken time for people to come to terms with Street-Porter's admittedly loud, brash style. "It's all terribly unfair on her," said Grote. "All the claims have proved totally unfounded. The situation has been hugely exaggerated."

A couple of the journalists told me they thought Street-Porter lost her temper more often with women than men. If so, and it may simply have more to do with the fact that the Sindy has a lot of women journalists, it would sit oddly with Street-Porter's moans about criticism of her being "sexist".

Some of her critics did point out that she has taken the job very seriously. Though absent more than most editors, when in the office she is dedicated to her task. "She has lots of ideas," said one, "and she has the uncanny ability to ask the maverick question. That can be the vital spark which gives the paper an edge, or makes it different from the rest." It should also be recognised that the Sindy has a small staff. The fact that it remains a lively paper with a serious heart is a tribute to her.

fields.headline: Wimbledon
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about strawberries, cheeky photographs, junk food and heroes. And some tennis
fields.trailText: All you need to know about strawberries, cheeky photographs, heroes and some tennis on the net.
fields.body:
1. It's the opening day of the All-England Lawn Tennis championships, aka Wimbledon fortnight.

2. First on Centre Court will be Pete Sampras, defending his 1999 gentlemen's title.

3. First in the hearts of many fans will be 35-year-old André Agassi, trying to turn the clock back.

4. Heading for almost certain gallant defeat will be plucky Greg Rusedski and Brit-with-grit Tim Henman.

5. Among the ladies, the almost universal tip for the top is Martina Hingis. She is young enough to be named after Martina Navratilova, who is making her bid for a 20th Wimbledon title, in the women's doubles.

6. When the inevitable rain falls, spectators can browse through the merchandise in the Wimbledon shop.

7. They may also while away the time with some expensive strawberries, but are more likely to munch something much less healthy.

8. For those who can't make it to London SW, there is always the official Wimbledon radio station. And, of course, our very own special report.

9. Among the unseeded players, there will be much tabloid slurping over Russian bombshell Anna Kournikova.

10. As a diversion from the frilly knickers, GQ magazine has a tasteful picture spread of Kylie Minogue in tennis mode, but without any knickers at all.

fields.headline: Dreary Drury spoils the party
fields.standfirst: Our goggle-eyed reporter can't believe his ears
fields.trailText: "Good news everyone, there's 45 minutes more of this," said an enthralled Peter Drury as half-time approached during Holland's landslide win over Yugoslavia. Surprisingly, he didn't add: "the bad news, you've got 45 more minutes of me to spoil it for you."
fields.body:
"Good news everyone, there's 45 minutes more of this," said an enthralled Peter Drury as half-time approached during Holland's landslide win over Yugoslavia. Surprisingly, he didn't add: "the bad news, you've got 45 more minutes of me to spoil it for you."

I don't know what Drury and Ron Atkinson have been up to since they headed for the low countries but judging by their incessant hyperbolic reaction to anything Dutch, I've got a pretty good idea. If I were their boss I'd scrutinise their expense sheets quite closely when they got back to England, looking in particular for any exorbitant coffee shop claims. And I wouldn't be entirely surprised to see an application for Dutch citizenship filed under miscellaneous extras by Drury.

"Wonderful ball, wonderful first touch, wonderful noise!" exclaimed Van Drury when Holland's first goal went in. Shortly afterwards, he told us that the stand was shaking, although he failed to notice that it was shaking with laughter as Drury's commentary had accidentally been broadcast over the stadium's loud speaker system. Even the Dutch can laugh at themselves.

"If you threw a chair in Charleori, let that prick your conscience," he preached as thousands of Dutch fans bounced around happily. Ignoring the fact that these people don't possess a conscience, I think even Neanderthal football fans would find something to smile about if their team were winning a match 6-0.

"They are an uplifting mass of humanity - I could watch the crowd all day," admitted the enthralled Drury. The scary thing is, you knew he wasn't joking.

As Holland pulled further ahead, Drury fell further apart. "Some of this football needs setting to music," was one of his more rational comments. Not a bad idea really, but only if it made Drury's role redundant.

Yesterday's other game was much more of a match. Other than the football, there was much to admire. Christophe Dugarry's topical unwashed Glastonbury look for instance. Emerging for the second half with France's entire quota of cotton wool shoved up his nose, he bore an uncanny resemblance to Jesus - unfortunately, not the Hollywood Biblical depiction, but the bloodstained Turin Shroud.

"They are an uplifting mass of humanity - I could watch the crowd all day," admitted the enthralled Drury. The scary thing is, you knew he wasn't joking. As Holland pulled further ahead, Drury fell further apart. "Some of this football needs setting to music," was one of his more rational comments. Not a bad idea really, but only if it made Drury's role redundant. Yesterday's other game was much more of a match. Other than the football, there was much to admire. Christophe Dugarry's topical unwashed Glastonbury look for instance. Emerging for the second half with France's entire quota of cotton wool shoved up his nose, he bore an uncanny resemblance to Jesus - unfortunately, not the Hollywood Biblical depiction, but the bloodstained Turin Shroud.

webTitle: Millennium Dome hosts The Bollywood Oscars

fields.headline: Millennium Dome hosts The Bollywood Oscars
fields.trailText: Some much-needed Bollywood glamour came to London's Millennium Dome on Saturday night when a star-studded audience gathered for India's equivalent of the Oscars. Over 3,000 celebrities, stars and directors packed into the venue for the first ever International Indian Film Awards
fields.body:
Some much-needed Bollywood glamour came to London's Millennium Dome on Saturday night when a star-studded audience gathered for India's equivalent of the Oscars.

Over 3,000 celebrities, stars and directors packed into the venue for the first ever International Indian Film Awards. Hundreds of film fans waited outside to catch a glimpse of their idols. Mainstream Hollywood stars Angelina Jolie and Jackie Chan were also in attendance.

"I find Indian Films have so much in them, the drama, the dancing and the singing," Chan said before he picked up a special lifetime achievement award. "I'm a big fan." Kylie Minogue also appeared, performing her number one song, Spinning Around (pictured).

The ceremony was hosted by the reigning Miss World, India's Yukta Mookhey, and legendary Bollywood star Anupam Kher. The film Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam won Best Picture, with Aishwarya Rai taking Best Actress in a Leading Role for her performance in the same movie, which also won Best Director for Sanjay Leela Bansali. Sanja Dutt won Best Actor for his performance in Vaastav. Each winner received a trophy in the shape of the rising sun.

India's film industry is the biggest in the world. It produces more movies than Hollywood - about 800 a year. It is estimated that some 20m Indians a day watch movies in 13,000 cinemas. However last night's ceremony was the first time the industry has held an awards ceremony.

Ceremony organisers Wizcraft said that they chose the venue of the Dome and the UK because Britain has become a huge market for Indian films. "London is the second biggest market outside India, so it is the perfect place for the awards", said spokeswoman Shalini Patel. "In the last couple of months, some Bollywood movies have entered the UK top 20, which shows how popular these films are here."

fields.headline: Kluivert's four becomes three
fields.trailText: Uefa have today confirmed Patrick Kluivert did not score Holland's third goal against Yugoslavia.
fields.body:
Uefa have today confirmed Patrick Kluivert did not score Holland's third goal against Yugoslavia.

The goal came from a near-post cross from Paul Bosvelt and appeared to have come off Kluivert's toe. Referee Jose Maria Garcia Aranda gave the goal to Kluivert but the Barcelona striker later admitted he hadn't touched the ball and that Yugoslav defender Dejan Govedarica had the decisive touch.

The decision was made after Uefa's technical study group studied the television footage of the goal from several angles. Instead of going down in history as the first player to score four in a European Championship finals game, Kluivert will now have to settle for becoming the fifth player to score a hat-trick.

It also means Yugoslavia's Savo Milosevic joins Kluivert as Euro 2000's leading scorer on five goals.

webTitle: Barbara Daniels on top-scoring against South Africa

fields.headline: Barbara Daniels on top-scoring against South Africa
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com goes behind the scenes to get the lowdown on one of the performances of the week. Today we talk to Barbara Daniels, the National Manager of Women's Cricket and England Women's senior bat
fields.trailText: Barbara Daniels, 35, made her international debut in the 1993 World Cup and was England's vice-captain in 1995-98. She has also been heavily involved in the development of women's cricket, and played an important role in overseeing the merger of the ECB and the Women's Cricket Association. On Sunday, in the third one-day international against South Africa at Canterbury, which England lost by one wicket, Daniels top-scored with 74.
fields.body:
Barbara Daniels, 35, made her international debut in the 1993 World Cup and was England's vice-captain in 1995-98. She has also been heavily involved in the development of women's cricket, and played an important role in overseeing the merger of the ECB and the Women's Cricket Association. On Sunday, in the third one-day international against South Africa at Canterbury, which England lost by one wicket, Daniels top-scored with 74.

"The pitch was a good batting track although the ball swung around a lot early on. Generally we are not used to such quality pitches, so it is always good for us to play on ones like this at Canterbury.

"My partnership with Arran Thompson [of 114] was very important. After a difficult period for the openers, I came in when we were 15 for 2 and knew I had to hang around. After we had settled, we were able to push the scoring rate on a little and found we were able to play through the line and get value for our shots. It was difficult to get the balance right - keeping the scoreboard ticking over was essential but at the same time we knew we couldn't afford to lose a wicket. Arran batted very well, at 18 she is still young but gaining experience and improving all the time.

"Their opening bowlers bowled too short and were slightly erratic. But there was plenty of swing. Kim Price bowled very well and was the pick of the South African bowlers. Bowling left arm over the wicket she found the right line and contained us well. She received good support from Helen Davies.

"The crowd was excellent - there were about 1,000 people there. They saw a good day's cricket that went all the way to an exciting climax at the finish. Although the result didn't go our way this will not affect our confidence and ambition to win the series. We have two more games to prove that we are very much an improving side with talented players.

"The South Africans, although not as strong as Australia or New Zealand, are a good side and yesterday put in a good performance. It is vital that we go on and win the series after recent disappointments in Australia and New Zealand [England lost all nine of their one-day internationals on that tour].

"The squad for the World Cup in New Zealand this winter is named in October so this series is an important part of our preparations for the tournament. We are all fighting for places in the final fourteen."

Barbara Daniels was talking to Robbie James. Click here for other recent My Days In The Sun: Aftab Habib (Leics), Chris Taylor(Gloucs),Richard Logan(Northants)

fields.headline: Inspectors examine IRA arms dumps
fields.standfirst:
Full text of the report
Full text of the IRA statement
fields.trailText: The IRA today announced that it had opened its arms dumps  to independent weapons inspectors in a key breakthrough for  the Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
The IRA today announced that it had opened its arms dumps to independent weapons inspectors in a key breakthrough for the Northern Ireland peace process.

The historic development was confirmed by the international inspectors Martti Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa at a meeting this morning with Tony Blair in Downing Street.

They said that they were satisfied that the guns and explosives held in the dumps were secure and could not be moved without their knowledge.

At the same time, the IRA announced in a statement that it had resumed contact with General John de Chastelain's international decommissioning body.

The day's developments were warmly welcomed by Mr Blair as a "very substantial further step" towards achieving a lasting peace in Northern Ireland.

The moves follow an IRA statement last month promising to put its weapons "verifiably beyond use", which paved the way for the restoration of power-sharing government in the Province.

Mr Blair told reporters in Downing Street: "I am very pleased that the agreement that was made a few weeks ago in Northern Ireland has been honoured. The confidence measure that we were promised has been put in place".

The inspectors "were shown a substantial quantity of IRA arms, including explosives" and "have ensured the weapons are secure and cannot be used without their becoming aware that this has happened", they said in a report to Ulster's decommissioning body.

Agreement to inspections of arms dumps broke the deadlock which threatened to unravel the peace process earlier this year.

However, Ulster Unionist MP Jeffrey Donaldson expressed caution about whether, if inspections had taken place, it represented a breakthrough.

On BBC Radio 4, Mr Donaldson said: "I think the question we need to know is that, if these arms dump inspections have taken place, whether this is the beginning of a process that will lead to the actual decommissioning of those weapons as required by the Belfast agreement, or whether this is as good as it gets?

"I think that is the key question."

The Lagan Valley MP added: "If these IRA arms dumps have now been identified - and my understanding was that it was to have been three arms dumps made available for inspection - then we want to know if General de Chastelain, the head of the independent commission, can report if the IRA have appointed their go-between again.

"And whether they have given any indication to him at this stage that they are actually going to decommission any of these weapons."

fields.headline: 'Our commitment to peace'
fields.standfirst:
The IRA today issued the following statement on the peace
process
fields.trailText:
"On 6 May the leadership of the IRA announced an
unprecedented initiative which had the effect of breaking the
impasse at that time in the peace process.
fields.body:
"On 6 May the leadership of the IRA announced an unprecedented initiative which had the effect of breaking the impasse at that time in the peace process.

In our statements we made it clear that our initiative was in the context of a series of commitments made by the two Governments, especially the British Government. We announced that we would:

 Resume contact with the IICD (Independent International Commission on Decommissioning), and

 We now wish to confirm that we have re-established contact with the IICD, and that a number of arms dumps have been examined by the two agreed parties.

These dumps contained a substantial amount of material including weapons, explosives and other equipment.

The leadership of the IRA have consistently sought to enhance the peace process. This initiative demonstrates once more our commitment to securing a just and lasting peace."

fields.headline: Warne's wickets, Swann's struggle
fields.trailText: GOOD FORM
fields.body:
GOOD FORM

Shane Warne Hampshire

Warne took just three wickets for 164 in his first two Championship games but has been unstoppable since, averaging just under four wickets per first-class innings. His resurgence began with figures of 43-13-86-5 at Leicester - his first five-wicket haul for his new county - and continued with five more in the two-run defeat by Surrey. Warne picked up four more as Hampshire were thumped by Lancashire, but then bowled them to their first Championship win of 2000 with eight cheap wickets against Durham. And he's been pretty tidy in the one-dayers too.

BAD FORM

Graeme Swann Northants

Swann began the winter tour to South Africa as England's No.2 spinner, behind Phil Tufnell. Now, after taking just one wicket (Ronnie Irani) for 260 runs in his last four first-class outings, he's even further down the pecking order. That disastrous sequence includes match figures of 0-73 against Oxford Universities (a game which Northants contrived to lose), and 0-116 on a wicket which helped Warwickshire spinners Ashley Giles and Neil Smith claim 17 victims. His one-day figures have been better - and perhaps the 4-14 he took from just five overs at Headingley on Saturday will help him turn the corner - but his overall average since May 24 (33.66) tells a rather sorry tale.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the latest transfer talk teed up and driven nearly 300 yards down the fairway
fields.trailText: Barcelona and Real Madrid are both preparing bids for David Beckham. Rumours suggest Manchester United could receive a world-record £45m for their star player.
fields.body:
Barcelona and Real Madrid are both preparing bids for David Beckham. Rumours suggest Manchester United could receive a world-record £45m for their star player.

Spurs are likely to lose out to Fiorentina for the services of Barcelona's Dutch winger Boudewijn Zenden. They have had more luck in their pursuit of Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher, who is likely to choose the White Hart Lane club over Liverpool.

Everton have told rivals Liverpool to forget making a cheeky £7.5m bid for Nick Barmby. Chelsea remain favourites to sign the player, who is also attracting interest from his former club Tottenham.

Arsenal and Chelsea are interested in Portugal's Nuno Capucho. The 28-year-old Porto midfielder has not featured much in Euro 2000, but Arsene Wenger and Gianluca Vialli are both known to be admirers of the player, who is considering a move abroad.

Tottenham boss George Graham will offer Schalke 04 £2m for Belgium striker Emile Mpenza.

Sunderland want to strengthen their defence with Aston Villa's Ugo Ehiogu, but the £6m centre-back isn't keen. "Ugo is looking for a club that can offer him European football," his agent said.

Yugoslav defender Zoran Mirkovic has been linked with a £6m move from Juventus to Leeds.

Leicester will offer Everton £2.5m for full-back Michael Ball.

Kennet Andersson is interested in a move to Arsenal. "Kennet thinks Arsenal is a good and interesting club," his agent said. "He has also got a nice offer from Fiorentina and, within ten days, we will decide where he will move."

Ipswich will make a firm £2.5m bid for Hayden Mullins. The 21-year-old Crystal Palace midfielder is also being watched by Charlton, Newcastle, Leicester and West Brom.

West Brom are interested in QPR's Paul Murray and Stoke's James O'Connor. But Gary Megson faces serious competition for Murray - Newcastle are also after the 23-year-old.

Fulham striker Geoff Horsfield is a target for new Bradford boss Chris Hutchings. Horsfield's place is under threat following the arrival of French forward Louis Saha; Hutchings will offer £3m for the 26-year-old.

Stig Inge Bjornebye will today complete a £300,000 move from Liverpool to Blackburn.

fields.headline: Spain bring out vintage French
fields.standfirst:
Minute-by-minute match report
Zidane silences music of the spheres
fields.trailText: After qualifying for the knock-out stage thanks to two goals in injury time against Yugoslavia last Wednesday, Spain last night spurned the chance to repeat the feat against the world champions, reports Richard Williams.
fields.body:
After qualifying for the knock-out stage thanks to two goals in injury time against Yugoslavia last Wednesday, Spain last night spurned the chance to repeat the feat against the world champions.

They were trailing 2-1 with one minute left when Fabien Barthez impeded Abelardo after spilling the ball near his goalline. But Raul drove the penalty kick - Spain's second of the match - over the bar, allowing the tournament favourites to proceed to a semi-final meeting with Portugal on Wednesday.

Both sides began the match as though they had just watched the Dutch putting six goals past Yugoslavia and fancied themselves capable of emulating the feat. Spain lined up with three forwards - Alfonso, Raul and Pedro Munitis - while France emphasised the resources available to Roger Lemerre by laying aside the experiment with the Thierry Henry-Nicolas Anelka twin spearhead and trying a formula involving Christophe Dugarry and Youri Djorkaeff on the wings, flanking Henry. Emmanuel Petit, kept out by a knee injury suffered in the match against the Czech Republic, was replaced alongside Didier Deschamps by his Arsenal team-mate Patrick Vieira.

Spain were confronting a back four that had not lost a match together since first appearing en bloc in the 3-1 defeat of Bulgaria in Euro 96. All seven of France's subsequent defeats had come with some disruption or other to the defensive alignment of Lilian Thuram, Laurent Blanc, Marcel Desailly and Bixente Lizarazu. That meant four years and 23 matches of invincibility for this remarkable quartet, now averaging 30 years of age and with an aggregate of 279 caps.

"Over time, we've learnt that we can trust each other," Blanc said last week. "There's a great complicity between us." "Maybe you could find better individual players," Desailly added, "but together we're very, very strong."

The size of the task facing the Spanish was illustrated when Thuram gave the ball away to Raul in a dangerous position wide on the right after 15 minutes and then, caught badly out of position, used his telescopic legs to block the cross. The assault continued when Barthez tipped Guardiola's free-kick over the bar after 18 minutes, and two minutes later Alfonso split the France defence with a ball that Raul accepted before clipping a lob that drew another fingertip save from the goalkeeper.

Just when the crowd was becoming convinced that no player of any era had ever controlled the ball with a more perfect touch than Zidane, on the half-hour the two-goal hero of the World Cup final met Dugarry's centre from the right with an astonishingly comprehensive miskick when alone in front of the unprotected Santiago Canizares.

Two minutes later Zidane put matters right when he curled a right-footed free-kick from 25 yards past Canizares's right hand, the goalkeeper's anticipation insufficient to counter the accuracy of the strike.

Within five minutes Spain had drawn level. When Thuram caught the back of Raul's legs as the Real Madrid forward ran on to another pass from Alfonso, Pierluigi Collina's reaction was immediate and Mendieta coolly converted the penalty.

But the scoring in such a free-flowing and wholehearted match did not deserve to be restricted to dead-ball kicks, and two minutes before half-time Djorkaeff ran on to Vieira's pass across the edge of the area to smash a rising drive through the gap between Canizares's left hand and the near post, the forward's second goal of the tournament.

A fiercely but cleanly contested game yielded a flurry of yellow cards in the third quarter: Alfonso for bringing down Didier Deschamps, Deschamps for fouling Munitis, Guardiola for tripping Djorkaeff and Paco for dragging Henry down. Meanwhile Mendieta had been replaced by Ismael Urzaiz, which meant that Lizarazu had won the battle of the Basques on his side of the pitch.

Spain's pressure was unrelenting but was being neutralised outside the danger zone by the efforts of the French midfield, with Vieira's tackling always prominent. But Guardiola's free-kicks were looking increasingly dangerous and Vieira needed all his height to glance one diagonal effort behind for a corner.

fields.headline: Kluivert strikes light up Holland
fields.standfirst:
Minute-by-minute match report
Dutch celebrate Patrick's day
fields.trailText: The Dutch sky glowed orange yesterday as the sun shone down on Holland's chances of winning the Henri Delaunay Trophy.
fields.body:
The Dutch sky glowed orange yesterday as the sun shone down on Holland's chances of winning the Henri Delaunay Trophy.

The brightest contribution came from Patrick Kluivert, who produced a ruthless display of finishing to become the first player in any European Championship to score four goals in a game.

Similarly the conclusive scoreline represented the biggest win in the history of the finals. But that was not the only reason that Holland's fourth victory in Euro 2000 was by far their most impressive.

A knife through butter was the only analogy one could use to describe the way they cut open the Yugoslavia defence, passing the ball around at will and carving out chance after chance.

It was a further step in their development on the road to possible overall victory here next Sunday. However, Holland need to be wary of using this one-sided victory as evidence for brushing aside Italy in Thursday's semi-final. The only similarity between the opponents will be their blue shirts.

"We've always stood beside each other as a team and paid attention to detail to try and improve ourselves," said the Dutch coach Frank Rijkaard. "The boys have made it a wonderful evening and I can only be proud of them."

While the Orange hordes basked in their emphatic victory, the ease with which the Dutch players were able to find their team-mates with the ball and the ease with which those in possession were able to shrug off their markers offered a stark condemnation of the inability of Yugoslavia to defend both individually or as a unit.

Their only success of the night was that, for the first time in this tournament, they did not have a man sent off.

"We made a big tactical mistake," admitted the crest-fallen Yugoslav coach Vujadin Boskov, who tipped the host nation to go on and win the tournament.

"We didn't play three defensive players and five midfielders in the beginning. We played 4-4-2 and it was our mistake.

"But Holland have the advantage of playing at home in front of 60,000 spectators in their next game. I think it is a big advantage to have over the other countries and it was our great problem tonight."

It was obvious from the first minute that Yugoslavia were in for an extremely tough evening when Marc Overmars set up his Arsenal team-mate Dennis Bergkamp for a shot on goal. It was blocked but the pattern of Dutch infiltration was established.

Yugoslavia were immediately back-pedalling, defending deep and conceding large chunks of possession, hoping no doubt that their luck would hold out long enough at the back for them to create something up front.

That was a thin game-plan but, for a while at least, the first part worked. When Bergkamp turned past Nisa Saveljic, his curled shot was not quite heading for the top corner and Ivica Kralj was able to push the ball away.

Minutes later Bergkamp skipped past the same beleaguered defender and Kralj was again able to deny the Dutchman. The Orange tide persisted and, soon after, Bergkamp played Edgar Davids into the area with only the goalkeeper to beat. But the busy midfielder was for once lost for words as he contrived to blast the ball over the bar.

At the other end, though, fortune refused to follow the Yugoslav script. On 16 minutes Savo Milosevic fashioned his team's best opening of the game, sprinting past a defender before pulling the ball back to Predrag Mijatovic in front of goal, but the striker hit his shot too close to Edwin van der Sar.

When chances are rare they need to be taken. For Holland they were abundant and a goal soon arrived.

On 24 minutes Bergkamp picked up the ball wide on the left and chipped in a ball so perfectly flighted that it sailed over Sinisa Mihajlovic and dropped into the path of the unmarked Kluivert. The Barcelona striker took one touch to control the ball and another to dispatch it over the line.

Boudewijn Zenden and Arthur Numan went close to extending the Dutch lead before Kluivert added his second on 38 minutes. It was a carbon copy of the first goal, Zenden this time the supplier, the Yugoslav defence once again marking space.

The third goal arrived six minutes into the second half after a couple of sighters from Bergkamp and Overmars. Bosvelt's right-wing cross to the near post appeared to be converted by Kluivert and was credited as such by the referee. However, the striker later admitted a defender did get the last touch.

In their opening game Yugoslavia had recovered from an identical 3-0 deficit. But Holland are no Slovenia and the Balkan side knew that there was no way back. The floodgates opened.

Zenden once again fed Kluivert, this time from near the dead-ball line, and the striker deftly side-footed the ball past a dazed Kralj into the roof of the net.

Holland were creating chances at will. The substitute Roy Makaay and Philip Cocu both went close before Bergkamp set up Overmars. The little winger was given time and space to tee up a 20-yard shot which the diving Kralj could only help into the net.

On 90 minutes Overmars scored his second, pouncing on a Cocu shot which cannoned off the post. Minutes later Yugoslavia scored a consolation goal as Mijatovic hit the woodwork and Milosevic stroked the ball into an unguarded net.

But the look on his face was less of joy, more of embarrassment.

webTitle: At last the Great Escape looms from prison of punditry

fields.headline: At last the Great Escape looms from prison of punditry
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner awaits blessed relief from the endless post mortems.
fields.body:
The inquest into the state of the national soccer team continued all week, but at least some measure of agreement was reached: this is the worst Germany team to take part in a major tournament.

Peter Shilton put it most colourfully, commenting yesterday on the prompt departure of the German coach Erich Ribbeck. "They don't take any prisoners, the Germans," he said, which came as a surprise to those of us who enjoyed the film The Colditz Story.

Shilton also said, "You didn't have to be a blind man to see the England performances in Euro 2000 were not good enough," but since the interview was on Talk sport it is not inconceivable that this was not the real Peter Shilton but some facsimile from a hotel bedroom in Amsterdam.

We should not, of course, be surprised a certain amount of twaddle is being talked after England's return, given that soccer punditry is now one of the biggest growth industries in Britain, just behind pornographic phone lines. Gabby Yorath suggested to Barry Venison, John Barnes and Chris Waddle that England might derive some reflected glory from Portugal's progress, in the light of our 18 minutes of success against them. "I mean, if they win it we could say we might have come second or third."

Waddle dismissed that and instead addressed the question worrying the nation. "Germany have got to restructure now," he said.

For my part I cannot get enough of Germany's problems, as they act as a handy distraction from Kevin Keegan's dilemma and some of the nonsensical solutions being proposed. The thought that Keegan, who has a cast-iron contract with the FA and has his own hand-picked staff of coaches, might want to "work alongside" an elder, more tactically astute statesman is too ridiculous to contemplate.

All the usual suspects are in the frame as a partner for Keegan: Terry Venables, Bobby Robson, Gérard Houllier (presumably because of his successful working relationship with Roy Evans). Robson and Venables gave the idea the short shrift it deserved on ITV. Robson was generous enough to remind viewers of his own unsuccessful European Championship in 1988, which was followed by a similar hue and cry but then a creditable World Cup two years later. His plea that Keegan be allowed to absorb the lessons and plan for the future had the ring of sweet reason.

As we approach the latter stages of this championship, there is just a chance, I suppose, that the endless kicking over the traces of England's departure will stop, for which I will not be altogether thankful since it has been fun in its futility. And there is no guarantee, either, that the foreign footballers who now take centre stage will be any more elegant behind the microphone than our own.

BBC's Football Focus went to all the trouble of interviewing the Italian squad, and providing subtitles for those of us whose Italian is a little rusty, only for Angelo di Livio to say: "We're just taking one game at a time." Pensiamo partita per partita, in case you are interested.

England's absence from Euro 2000 does give us space for other sports, and the BBC clearly has high hopes for Wimbledon. It is trailing the tournament heavily. There was even a mention in Saturday's weather forecast, with much sticking of little cardboard suns around the Wimbledon area.

Watch out in next week's column, then, for full analysis of what went wrong with Tim Henman, including the suggestion that for his next match he takes Virginia Wade on court with him.

webTitle: Your indispensable guide to the Italian first XI

fields.headline: Your indispensable guide to the Italian first XI
fields.trailText: A tournament free from hoop-la; a midfielder with a beard; a parlour game with Karel.
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"It's true; my presence keeps the linesmen extremely busy for the whole 90 minutes" - That's one way of putting it. Filippo Inzaghi explains his mastery of the offside law.

THE EURO-TORIAL

It must be something to do with the stars. It seems that the heavens have aligned and blessed this tournament in a way not even Filip De Wilde could fudge up. This weekend saw four games with 14 goals shared between them. Each of the victorious teams benefited from big performances by their star players: Figo for Portugal, Kluivert for the Dutch, Zidane for the French and, in a slightly less-conspicuous fashion, Alessandro Nesta for Italy. It must be fate, we reckon.

If the Gods have conspired to make this tournament one to remember, then it couldn't have come at a better time. Cynicism - dread word - has been running rampant over the last 12 months: over the over-stretched nature of European club competition, the ever-expanding wage packet of the professional footballer, and the further encroachment of TV on the domestic game (all over Europe). What we needed this summer was a tournament free from all that hoop-la, one that reminded us all what the game is really about. And it appears that we might well get it.

Of course this could all change with a pair of dull semi-finals. But the spirit in which the tournament has been played so far suggests that it won't - and for what it's worth, the Portuguese wouldn't be able to play for penalties if they tried. If the tournament is to gain the climax it deserves then the French and the Dutch should meet in Rotterdam next Sunday. And in a tournament where the best team always seems to win, it might just happen. We lucky people.

YOUR PRINT-OUT-AND-KEEP GUIDE TO DISTINGUISHING MEMBERS OF THE ITALIAN FIRST XI!

Alessandro Nesta - Tough-tackling defender with long black hair parted down the centre.

Paolo Maldini - Tough-tackling defender with long black hair parted down the centre.

Fabio Cannavaro - Tough-tackling defender with long black hair parted down the centre with blue hair band.

Demetrio Albertini - Multi-talented midfielder with long black hair parted down the centre.

Stefano Fiore - Multi-talented midfielder with long black hair parted down the centre. Has beard.

Alessandro del Piero - World-beating forward with long black hair parted down the centre. Wears tracksuit.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. Win a £200 tab behind the bar at Yates's Pubs all around the country....go to www.breathe.com, click on the Euro 2000 link and enter the draw.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

The Spanish media have taken defeat on the chin, and manfully blamed Raul for the exit of Jose Camacho's side from the competition. "It wasn't quite what we expected from Raul, it was the last thing we expected from Raul," said Marca this morning. "Raul made Spain cry." According to the paper, the star striker also pinched the nation's lunch money and flushed its head down the toilet.

A Vietnamese bookie accepting bets on Euro 2000 matches has done a runner with more than $20,000 in bets laid by more than 100 punters. "The are some people who bet hundreds of dollars and there are many places where people bet their cars and motorcycles," a Cambodian paper reported. Sounds like an afternoon at Haydock with the England lads.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hey guys, Karel Poborsky! Now I'm back in the Czech Republic chilling with my homeboys - hey, you Jan Koller! Get your big face out of my fridge! - I really don't have time for transfer rumours, so instead why don't we play a little parlour game? Come on, let's!

OK you guys, here goes. Which Yugoslav defender, who plays for Juventus, has been linked with a £6m move to Leeds? Clue, it's not Zoran Mirkovic. Damn, it is!

Anyway, let's forget that one and try another. Which top Dutch winger won't be joining Spurs this summer? That's right, it's Barcelona's Ben Thatcher who looks likely to stay at the Nou Camp. Spurs are likely to turn their attentions to rather more mediocre full-back Boudewijn Zenden of Wimbledon.

More accurately-reported gossip tomorrow, you guys! And less of that lip from you Fukal.

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Extra (10.30am, 10.15pm)
Look, there's two days off. Why don't you try to live without football for a while?

Euro 2000 Football (1pm, 3pm)
You could tidy up your front room.

Euro 2000 (5pm, 8pm)
You could go to the supermarket and buy some healthy food instead of living on takeaways.

Euro 2000 Nightclub (11.15pm)
You could go out for a long walk.

Euro 2000 Flashback (11.45pm)
You could catch up with your friends.

Euro 2000 By Night (12midnight)
You could take your girlfriend / boyfriend out to dinner.

Euro 2000 Your Match (1am)
You could visit elderly members of your family.

Euro 2000 Flashback (2am)
Actually, this looks quite good. I'll get the beers if you order a pizza.

webTitle: Full text of the decommissioning inspectors' report

fields.headline: 'A genuine effort'
fields.standfirst: Text of a report on the inspection of IRA weapons  dumps by Martti Ahtisaari and Cyril Ramaphosa
fields.trailText: "This report is being issued following our appointment as arms  inspectors on 6 May 2000 and our first inspection of IRA  weapons dumps.
fields.body:
"This report is being issued following our appointment as arms inspectors on 6 May 2000 and our first inspection of IRA weapons dumps.

We accepted our appointment on the basis of terms of reference set out in a joint statement issued by the Prime Minister and the Taoiseach and the statement by the leadership of the IRA on 6 May 2000.

In its statement of 6 May, the IRA leadership pledged to initiate a process that will completely and verifiably put IRA arms beyond use in the context of the statement made by the two Governments on 5 May, 2000.

Besides undertaking to resume contact with the Independent International Commission on Decommissioning (IICD), the IRA leadership agreed to put in place within weeks a confidence-building measure to confirm that their weapons remain secure.

We see our mandate as being the inspection of the contents of a number of IRA arms dumps, reporting to the IICD that we have done so, and re-inspecting these dumps regularly to ensure that the weapons have remained secure.

In preparing for the first inspection visit, we were briefed by the British Prime Minister, the Irish Foreign Minister, the British Secretary of State and the Commissioners of the IICD.

We also consulted most of the parties that have endorsed the Good Friday Agreement. In addition, we consulted independent specialists in the field of arms control, who had previously participated in arms inspections elsewhere and had expertise in the area of verification.

The purpose of these consultations was to help us develop credible methods for inspection and verification.

We have now carried out our first inspection. We inspected a number of arms dumps. The arms dumps held a substantial amount of military material, including explosives and related equipment, as well as weapons and other material.

We observed that the weapons and explosives were safely and adequately stored. We have ensured that the weapons and explosives can not be used without our detection.

We are satisfied with the co-operation extended to us by the IRA to ensure a credible and verifiable inspection. All our requests were satisfactorily met.

We plan to re-inspect the arms dumps on a regular basis to ensure that the weapons have remained secure.

The process that led to the first inspection visit and the way in which it was carried out makes us believe that this is a genuine effort by the IRA to advance the peace process.

Martti Ahtisaari Cyril Ramaphosa
London 25 June, 2000."

webTitle: EU mission says Zimbabwe's campaign was not free and fair

fields.headline: EU mission says Zimbabwe's campaign was not free and fair
fields.standfirst: Mugabe ignores cry for change
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's fiercely contested election cannot be considered free and fair, international observers said today.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's fiercely contested election cannot be considered free and fair, international observers said today.

The campaign has been badly tainted by campaign violence and threats. At least 30 people were killed and thousands beaten and threatened - mainly by ruling party militants - in the run up to the two-day parliamentary elections that ended yesterday.

"The term free and fair elections is not applicable to these elections," Pierre Schori, head of the European Union observer mission, said in an interim assessment of the elections.

Ruling party "leaders seemed to sanction the use of violence and intimidation against political opponents and contributed significantly to the climate of fear so evident during the election campaign," Schori said.

Opposition supporters also waged attacks, but they were far fewer and their leaders were clear in their condemnation of the violence, he said.

Schori praised the efficiency and professionalism that marked the actual vote and emphasized that the election process was complex, and he would not issue a final assessment until 3 July, after the votes have been counted and the country's reaction to the results assessed.

Vote counting began today with election monitors and party agents checking the seals of ballot boxes before they were opened this morning.

Officials at central Harare's counting center, a high school, said boxes were delivered from 11 polling stations. Monitors and police stayed with the boxes overnight and there were no complaints of tampering in central Harare.

webTitle: Scientists finish first draft of DNA blueprint

fields.headline: Scientists finish first draft of DNA blueprint
fields.standfirst: Interactive guide
fields.trailText: Scientists in London and Washington will announce today that they have completed the "first draft" of the entire blueprint of human life, described as the most important scientific effort humankind has ever mounted, including splitting the atom and going to the moon.
fields.body:
Scientists in London and Washington will announce today that they have completed the "first draft" of the entire blueprint of human life, described as the most important scientific effort humankind has ever mounted, including splitting the atom and going to the moon.

The human genome project to decipher the entire text of human DNA "will, in the fullness of time, rank as a cultural achievement on a par with the works of Shakespeare, or the pictures of Rembrandt, or the music of Wagner", Colin Blakemore, president of the Forum of European Neuroscience, said last night.

"In the end, it will inform us more reliably and fully about the human condition. But this is only the first step in a much longer process of discovery."

But today's announcement, which is likely to accelerate the new biotech gold rush, may only be about to happen because British scientists forced the pace. Until late last week, their American partners were denying knowledge of an announcement and were still trying to strike an accord with Craig Venter, head of the US biotech firm Celera Genomics, which entered the field late but threatened to finish first - and offer the human genome for sale.

This move provoked furious exchanges between human genome scientists and Dr Venter. The British scientists and their US colleagues have always insisted that the data should be available freely, immediately, and to everybody. Earlier this year President Bill Clinton and Tony Blair declared their joint support for this approach.

Britain has undertaken one-third of the $3bn project, funded by the Wellcome Trust, the world's leading medical charity. The US share was underwritten by the taxpayer through the national institutes of health.

Today's announcement, in London and Washington, is likely to be made jointly with Celera. That both sides are prepared to declare a draw is because of weeks of behind-the-scenes diplomacy in the scientific networks.

"All of us in the scientific community have been a little bit appalled by all of the negative press that's surrounding what we view as a real pivotal event in the history of mankind," said Roy Whitfield, chief of Incyte, a biotech firm in California. "So it would be lovely if people would get back to how this builds for the future."

Last week, as word of a joint or at least simultaneous statement leaked out, Celera's stock shot up by $18.50 to $138.50 before falling to $125 on Friday. The betting in Washington is that the announcement will be made without reference to the bitter exchanges of recent months, and that both teams will later publish their papers simultaneously, in the same journal, Science.

"I think this is a great time in biology. I would describe it as the beginning of thousands of races," said Dr Whitfield. "If you have colon cancer, the race is about curing colon cancer. If you have arthritis, it's a race to cure arthritis. It's the start of a really long race to have a tremendous impact on human health."

The "first draft" is a milestone rather than a winning post, a beginning rather than an end. But the new data will trigger a flurry of new kinds of research. A Japanese group has just announced that it will sequence the entire genome of humankind's nearest relative, the chimpanzee - in the hope of shedding light on the origins of intelligence, such as language, logic and thinking, which only human beings possess. Other teams have begun to apply genetics to the problems of ageing, of neurodegenerative diseases, and of cancer.

Francis Collins of the US national institutes of health said: "It is probably the most important scientific effort mankind has ever mounted, and that includes splitting the atom and going to the moon."

Roland Wolf of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund said: "The sequencing of the human genome represents one of the great achievements in human science. It really will be a landmark in the evolution of man."
