webTitle: Joining euro 'would double growth and bring in US-style affluence'

fields.headline: Joining euro 'would double growth and bring in US-style affluence'
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Membership of the European single currency would transform the British economy and lead to American levels of affluence, according to a report which will strengthen the hand of the cabinet's pro-euro wing.
fields.body:
Membership of the European single currency would transform the British economy and lead to American levels of affluence, according to a report which will strengthen the hand of the cabinet's pro-euro wing.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, who want the government to step up preparations for the euro, will seize on the report which says that the economy would grow by 20% if Britain signed up to the single currency.

The two ministers are engaged in a battle with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who wants to kick the issue of the euro into the long grass to allow him to concentrate on his management of the economy in the run-up to the election.

But today's report shows that the growth of recent years could be virtually doubled if Britain joined the single currency. The report, written by the leading US economist Professor Andrew Rose, is based on a model of the economy which uses tens of thousands of pieces of data about British trade dating back decades.

It predicts that joining the single currency would lead to:

 A tripling of British trade with the rest of euroland, which already accounts for more than half of Britain's exports.

 A 20% growth in GDP over two decades, which represents a significant increase over normal growth forecasts.

 A growth in average British incomes from the present level of £13,125 to the US average of £18,750.

Britain in Europe, the cross-party pressure group which commissioned the report, welcomed its findings. Kitty Ussher, the group's chief econ omist, said: "One of the main benefits of joining the euro is that it will make us all richer. Whatever we do, we will all start to feel the benefits."

The report will be used by the cabinet's pro-euro wing whose members believe that ministers must do more to sell the euro if the government is to stand any chance of winning a referendum on the single currency. Campaigners have concentrated until now on the dangers of remaining outside the euro, but today's report is the first concrete evidence of the huge benefits of joining the currency.

In his report Prof Rose, of the University of California, Berkeley, argues that countries which sign up to common currencies enjoy a dramatic increase in trade. "Countries that share a common currency engage in substantially more trade and more trade results in higher income."

He writes: "The monetary barriers are now falling across Europe. The UK should seriously consider whether it wishes to forgo this historic opportunity for an enormously beneficial expansion of its European trade."

Opponents of the single currency will dismiss Prof Rose's report as a simplified prediction of what could happen to the British economy.

The Treasury will also argue that his conclusions will have no impact on the government's policy, which is to assess the chancellor's five economic tests after the next election before deciding whether to hold a referendum.

The report will influence the cabinet debate over the euro. Downing Street insists there are no divisions among ministers, but the pro-euro wing makes no secret of its anger with the chancellor for attempting to stifle debate.

fields.headline: Glastonbury's 30th anniversary
fields.trailText: With the country's biggest live draws, Oasis and Radiohead, booked elsewhere, it was left to the less sexy Chemical Brothers, Travis, and David Bowie to headline Glastonbury's 30th anniversary. Less sexy, that is, in terms of whipping up excitement, for however festival friendly Chemicals and company may be, they lack what Travis's Fran Healy called "that 'wooargh' thing".
fields.body:
With the country's biggest live draws, Oasis and Radiohead, booked elsewhere, it was left to the less sexy Chemical Brothers, Travis, and David Bowie to headline Glastonbury's 30th anniversary. Less sexy, that is, in terms of whipping up excitement, for however festival friendly Chemicals and company may be, they lack what Travis's Fran Healy called "that 'wooargh' thing".

In headlining the main stage the Chemicals represented dance music's in creasing importance at Glastonbury. Moby showed how it should be done, stealing the weekend with a set that combined live and recorded music, and that oft-neglected human element. The New Yorker charmed Glastofarians by singing and playing congas.

Friday's surprise special guest, Macy Gray, contributed the night's other bit of sass. Her male-baiting songs and blue haired backing singers were uplifting as the sun went down.

Travis made a bit of Glastonbury history last year when they played Why Does It Always Rain On Me? on a sunny afternoon and the heavens obligingly opened. The fact that such an unexceptional band were headlining at all could be taken as proof of a deal with a higher power. Fran Healy was a sweet frontman, but he was right - they haven't got the "wooargh" thing.

Nor did Leftfield, headlining the second stage with arid breakbeats, nor the DJ, Fatboy Slim, who had them crammed into the 12,000 capacity dance tent to listen to him play some records.

The weekend produced some surprising delights however, including festival first-timers the Pet Shop Boys, who came dressed for cocktails but played a greatest-hits set that struck just the right incongruous note.

There were thrills out there if you looked for them: Ben Christophers' delicate torch songs, Terry Callier's wild-hearted soul, Rolf Harris's wobbleboard. It may not have been a vintage Glastonbury, but the sight of the crowd singing happy 70th birthday to Rolf will linger for years.

webTitle: Quick! You've only got seven years

fields.headline: Quick! You've only got seven years
fields.standfirst:
Topsy-turvy salaries

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's the season of what is called "graduation" in Britain and "commencement" in the US (Americans, typically, look forward, not backward). That is: the moment when the year's crop of mature students leave academe for the real world.
fields.body:
It's the season of what is called "graduation" in Britain and "commencement" in the US (Americans, typically, look forward, not backward). That is: the moment when the year's crop of mature students leave academe for the real world.

Commencement ceremonies tend to be glitzier affairs in the US, with music and star speakers (Maya Angelou and Bill Cosby are the most sought after) who pull in $10,000-plus for the required valedictory platitudes before a rousing chorus of Land of Hope and Glory, the throwing of mortarboards in the air and the last monster party. I'll offer my platitude for summer 2000 (no charge): "The world is your oyster, but the pearl isn't where it used to be."

For most university teachers, graduation is fire-and-forget time. They have done their job. Education is done; let the employers take over. But thoughtful professors will be conscious that the young people into whom they have put their best efforts are entering a strangely changed employment world. The nature of that change is summed up in two terms that are creeping into general use: salary inversion and salary compression.

The first, inversion, is relevant mainly to Miss Brodie's crème de la crème - students graduating with high honours, particularly in computer science and business studies. This year I shook the hand of a such a student, Eric, as he bade farewell to the California Institute of Technology. A humorous fellow with a country-boy grin and the de rigueur reversed red baseball cap, Eric shone in the computer lab and had good-naturedly done his bit on my English course (a "requisite").

What was he going to do after graduation? He'd had an offer from Bill Gross's IdeaLab (Gross, a 40-year-old Caltech graduate, made his multi-millions by setting himself up as e-commerce's equivalent of a literary agent). That would pull in a salary of $70,000 or so, he thought. Tempting. But, in fact, he would probably join a friend in New York, set up a lab in a garage, go public, and make his own multi-millions. What then? Well, he gave himself about seven years before his skill base eroded, and younger Erics ran him out of town. Then he'd come back to the west coast and try his hand at scriptwriting. Or just hang out.

The best and brightest, unlike their predecessors, expect their highest-earning years to be at the beginning, not the end, of their 40-year career. Realistically, there is no such thing as a career any more - that escalator carrying you from apprenticeship to gold watch and pension. There are just good years in which to strike it rich. Early years, probably, and very rich, perhaps.

Salary compression is what the majority of lower-flying graduates will confront. It goes like this. You enter a profession and get modest annual increments. Meanwhile, the market is roaring ahead. The boom never ends. To get someone as good as you were five years ago, your employer must offer considerably more than you were offered.

The new recruit gets the going price for their skills. Your salary is meanwhile "compressed" into an earlier pay frame. The result? Disparity, festering discontent and disloyalty.

Tony Blair and both of the current American presidential candidates have made education their big idea. Neither government will make progress unless they find some way round the compression problem afflicting that profession.

There is, everyone agrees, a shortage of good teachers in the areas where they are most needed: maths, sciences and - most urgently - computer studies. But anyone with even a smattering of such skills can earn more working in Radio Shack than in a classroom. The only solution is to pay the incoming 23-year-old science teacher £40,000, while the 40-year-old English teacher is stuck at £23,000. And the fact is, to recruit today's best English teachers, you'll need to offer a substantially higher salary than you did 10 years ago.

This is a bullet that no goverment will bite. Instead, they fiddle with pittance-sized "golden handshakes", or "performance-related" bonuses of £2,000 as a prelude to decompression by stealth ("new pay scales") in a doomed attempt to square "incentives" with "fairness". In America, the latest wheeze is a five-year tax amnesty for teachers.

In their hearts, both British and American governments know that schools won't work until teachers are paid not the rate, but the rates for the job. Until then, it will be bad education, bad education, bad education. And lots of spin, to stop us noticing.

That is: the moment when the year's crop of mature students leave academe for the real world. Commencement ceremonies tend to be glitzier affairs in the US, with music and star speakers (Maya Angelou and Bill Cosby are the most sought after) who pull in $10,000-plus for the required valedictory platitudes before a rousing chorus of Land of Hope and Glory, the throwing of mortarboards in the air and the last monster party. The nature of that change is summed up in two terms that are creeping into general use: salary inversion and salary compression. The first, inversion, is relevant mainly to Miss Brodie's crème de la crème - students graduating with high honours, particularly in computer science and business studies. webTitle: Tyne plans for Ikea-type ship kits in the navy

fields.headline: Tyne plans for Ikea-type ship kits in the navy
fields.trailText: The Royal Navy could set out to sea in a maritime version of Ikea furniture, if a novel plan to build DIY ship kits succeeds on the Tyne.
fields.body:
The Royal Navy could set out to sea in a maritime version of Ikea furniture, if a novel plan to build DIY ship kits succeeds on the Tyne.

A £6m steel-cutting plant is set to test the new system of making boxed and numbered parts, which can then be sent like flat-pack cupboards for assembly anywhere in the world.

Modelled on a Dutch experiment, the computer-aided process aims to bring shipbuilding back to Swan Hunter, one of the industry's most famous names, which has survived on offshore rig work since bankruptcy and partial rescue in 1994.

The grand old days of champagne launches are less likely to return, however, with most of the expected orders leaving the Tyne in flat-pack containers on cargo ships.

The ship kit steel plant has the potential to bring 350 jobs to Swan's Tyneside yard, according to the company, more than doubling the 300-strong workforce in an area with 13% unemployment. The site will specialise in robot-controlled steel-cutting.

"This will be our industry's equivalent of Ikea," said Jaap Kroese, the Dutch businessman who resurrected Swan's name when the company closed in 1994.

"It may not be like the old days when people lined the riverbanks to see the ships sailing out but, nonetheless, Swan Hunter will be building ships and, more importantly, there will be a future for workers."

Two troop landing ships for the Ministry of Defence could be the first kit-built vessels in Britain if Swan wins a £140m tender in competition with two other British yards.

webTitle: Poll was not fair says EU team

fields.headline: Poll was not fair says EU team
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The EU observers' team last night issued a strong condemnation of the Zimbabwean government's conduct during the election, as well as that of President Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party.
fields.body:
The EU observers' team last night issued a strong condemnation of the Zimbabwean government's conduct during the election, as well as that of President Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party.

"Zanu-PF's leaders seemed to sanction the use of violence intimidation against political opponents and contributed significantly to the climate of fear so evident during the campaign," it said.

Pierre Schori of Sweden, who led a team of some 190 observers, by far the largest foreign contingent, pointedly refused to characterise the election in soundbite terms.

Asked if it had been free and fair, he said: "This is not a term which is applicable to these elections."

Instead he divided the team's interim report into three phases: the preparations and campaign, the voting and the count, and the post-election period.

The report attacked the conduct of the registrar general, who is appointed by Mr Mugabe, saying his office did not operate "in an open and transparent manner" and had obstructed local independent Zimbabwean monitors as well as the international observers.

"The EU mission reached the conclusion that this was not due to administrative incompetence but to a deliberate attempt to reduce the effectiveness of independent monitoring," the report said.

It criticised the high level of violence and intimidation, and condemned the government for failing to uphold the rule of law. It said the government's efforts to restrain Zanu-PF's supporters "were often ambiguous".

Zanu-PF was responsible for the bulk of the political violence, it said. Supporters of the MDC were also engaged in violence, but to a much lesser extent and MDC leaders were clearer in their condemnation of it. Without quantifying what proportion of the rural areas were affected, the report said that in "many" of them, Zanu-PF's intimidation was so intense as to make it virtually impossible for the opposition to campaign.

Finally, the report strongly criticised the government-controlled Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation and the state-owned newspapers for failing to provide equal access to the parties and for being "used as publicity vehicles for Zanu-PF".

The EU concluded its assessment with the cryptic comment: "With high authority comes high responsibility. The president of Zimbabwe will have to play a crucial role in the post-election phase".

Mr Schori refused to be drawn on what exactly he meant, except to say: "Mr Mugabe will be there regardless of the result. We believe in reconciliation and conflict prevention."

Some observers last night privately criticised the EU's rush to judgment, but Mr Schori made it clear that the team as a whole did not want to wait for the result of election for fear its report might seem to have been affected by knowing which party had won.

The EU plans to present its final report on July 3.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Ridley Jacobs ensured that West Indies warmed up for next month's triangular one-day series with a narrow victory over Hampshire in Southampton. The wicketkeeper hooked the second ball of the last over from the Hampshire pace bowler Simon Francis for four to guide the tourists home by four wickets in a low-scoring match.
fields.body:
Ridley Jacobs ensured that West Indies warmed up for next month's triangular one-day series with a narrow victory over Hampshire in Southampton. The wicketkeeper hooked the second ball of the last over from the Hampshire pace bowler Simon Francis for four to guide the tourists home by four wickets in a low-scoring match.

Chasing 189, West Indies were 180 for six with one over to go but Jacobs and Mahendra Nagamootoo kept their nerve to steer them home. Dimitri Mascarenhas was Hampshire's top scorer with 52 from 71 balls.

Gloucestershire want last week's NatWest Trophy first-round match with Worcestershire to be replayed because an ineligible bowler was used last Wednesday. New rules this season state no player can be used in one-day matches at two levels. The pace bowler Kabir Ali has played for both Worcestershire's Board XI and the county side in this season's Benson & Hedges Cup. In the tie at New Road, Ali took two wickets as Worcestershire won the match by 21 runs to set up an away tie with Leicestershire on Wednesday week.

Arran Thompson, an 18-year-old sitting a science A-level back home in Colne today, scored 33 runs for England Women against South Africa in Canterbury yesterday but it was not enough to stop England losing by one wicket with two balls remaining, writes Steve Whiting . Western Province's 33-year-old all-rounder Helen Davies took three for 47 in England's 203 for six and hit 47 in the run chase.

fields.headline: England rue loss of Hussain
fields.standfirst: Cork recalled but daunting task lies ahead, writes  Mike Selvey
fields.trailText: Dominic Cork is recalled but a daunting task lies ahead, writes Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
England's chances of squaring the series against West Indies were dealt a severe blow yesterday when it was revealed that the captain Nasser Hussain will miss this week's second test at Lord's after fracturing his left thumb and could be out of action for up to four weeks. Alec Stewart will take over the captaincy.

It means that the selectors' plan to keep faith with the batsmen who failed in the first test has been foiled, giving Michael Vaughan a chance to re-establish himself after losing his place through injury.

Another player looking to kick-start his international career again will be Dominic Cork, missing since the Perth test two winters ago. Craig White has also been added to the squad after his recent ill health and the muscular Yorkshire pace bowler Matthew Hoggard comes in for the injured Steve Harmison, though he is unlikely to play.

Hussain injured his thumb while fielding during Essex's National League match against Nottinghamshire on Saturday and an x-ray yesterday revealed the fracture.

"He will see a specialist over the next 48 hours to assess the extent of the injury," said the England physiotherapist Dean Conway. "The prognosis is that he may need three to four weeks' rest."

That would also rule Hussain out of next month's triangular one-day tournament featuring West Indies and Zimbabwe. A replacement will be announced once the specialist report is completed.

In restoring Cork the selectors are hoping to raise the spectre that haunted West Indies five years ago when he took seven for 43 in the second innings of his debut at Lord's. Two tests later he took a hat-trick to set up victory at Old Trafford.

Cork finished that series with 197 runs at 28.14, 26 wickets at 25.42 and the burden of being the latest next Ian Botham. It could not and did not last and twice - after the New Zealand tour three years ago and the 1998-99 Ashes series - his career has hit the buffers, not helped by personal problems, a surly rebellious disposition and technical flaws.

His test career figures of 634 runs at 17.61 and 98 wickets at 31.81 have put him back in the pack of the might-have-been all-rounders. Controlled aggression, however, is the key to his reinstatement.

It is said that the captaincy of Derbyshire has matured him, making him more team and less Cork-oriented. But England are hoping that the fire still burns, for the flaccid response of the bowlers to the West Indies lower order was largely responsible for costing them any chance of forcing their way back into the first test.

Particularly disappointing was Ed Giddins, whose performance against Zimbabwe at Lord's flattered to deceive. When asked to produce genuine aggression at Edgbaston he was unable to do so, either because he could not, was wary of doing so or, most worryingly, was mindful that his action - unusually wristy at best - might come under closer scrutiny.

Cork would augment the opening partnership of Darren Gough and Andy Caddick (who also needs a hurry-up) and could form part of an all-seam attack that would include Andy Flintoff, who bowled creditably at Edgbaston, and probably White in place of Robert Croft.

Hovering in the background, though, is Hoggard, called up because of Harmison's injury and a desire to see more consistency from Alex Tudor. The 23-year-old paceman from Pudsey has been in the mind of David Graveney, the chairman of selectors, since the early part of the season. There are no frills: he is shaven-headed, bulky and has the sort of action where little can go wrong.

Graveney was particularly impressed by the way he broke into the South African provincial side Orange Free State last winter, where he came under the tutelage of Allan Donald. "He swings it at a lively pace," is the maestro's assessment, "and has a good shape to it."

He could also eat for England apparently, finding his way into the heart of the Afrikaners by devouring lumps of red meat by the kilogram. Best keep him away from Flintoff.

Last summer Hoggard suffered a torn knee cartilage and missed half the season. So, even with his natural solidity, he has gone down the injury path of so many young bowlers. But there is no evidence of a suspect temperament, which is regarded as yeoman-solid.

"Give him the ball and he gets on with it, no fuss," is the general observation. He may not get the chance just yet but clearly he is one for the future.

fields.bodyText: England's chances of squaring the series against West Indies were dealt a severe blow yesterday when it was revealed that the captain Nasser Hussain will miss this week's second test at Lord's after fracturing his left thumb and could be out of action for up to four weeks. Alec Stewart will take over the captaincy. It means that the selectors' plan to keep faith with the batsmen who failed in the first test has been foiled, giving Michael Vaughan a chance to re-establish himself after losing his place through injury. Another player looking to kick-start his international career again will be Dominic Cork, missing since the Perth test two winters ago. Craig White has also been added to the squad after his recent ill health and the muscular Yorkshire pace bowler Matthew Hoggard comes in for the injured Steve Harmison, though he is unlikely to play. Hussain injured his thumb while fielding during Essex's National League match against Nottinghamshire on Saturday and an x-ray yesterday revealed the fracture. "He will see a specialist over the next 48 hours to assess the extent of the injury," said the England physiotherapist Dean Conway. "The prognosis is that he may need three to four weeks' rest." That would also rule Hussain out of next month's triangular one-day tournament featuring West Indies and Zimbabwe. A replacement will be announced once the specialist report is completed. In restoring Cork the selectors are hoping to raise the spectre that haunted West Indies five years ago when he took seven for 43 in the second innings of his debut at Lord's. Two tests later he took a hat-trick to set up victory at Old Trafford. Cork finished that series with 197 runs at 28.14, 26 wickets at 25.42 and the burden of being the latest next Ian Botham. It could not and did not last and twice - after the New Zealand tour three years ago and the 1998-99 Ashes series - his career has hit the buffers, not helped by personal problems, a surly rebellious disposition and technical flaws. His test career figures of 634 runs at 17.61 and 98 wickets at 31.81 have put him back in the pack of the might-have-been all-rounders. Controlled aggression, however, is the key to his reinstatement. It is said that the captaincy of Derbyshire has matured him, making him more team and less Cork-oriented. But England are hoping that the fire still burns, for the flaccid response of the bowlers to the West Indies lower order was largely responsible for costing them any chance of forcing their way back into the first test. Particularly disappointing was Ed Giddins, whose performance against Zimbabwe at Lord's flattered to deceive. When asked to produce genuine aggression at Edgbaston he was unable to do so, either because he could not, was wary of doing so or, most worryingly, was mindful that his action - unusually wristy at best - might come under closer scrutiny. Cork would augment the opening partnership of Darren Gough and Andy Caddick (who also needs a hurry-up) and could form part of an all-seam attack that would include Andy Flintoff, who bowled creditably at Edgbaston, and probably White in place of Robert Croft. Hovering in the background, though, is Hoggard, called up because of Harmison's injury and a desire to see more consistency from Alex Tudor. The 23-year-old paceman from Pudsey has been in the mind of David Graveney, the chairman of selectors, since the early part of the season. There are no frills: he is shaven-headed, bulky and has the sort of action where little can go wrong. Graveney was particularly impressed by the way he broke into the South African provincial side Orange Free State last winter, where he came under the tutelage of Allan Donald. "He swings it at a lively pace," is the maestro's assessment, "and has a good shape to it." He could also eat for England apparently, finding his way into the heart of the Afrikaners by devouring lumps of red meat by the kilogram. Best keep him away from Flintoff. Last summer Hoggard suffered a torn knee cartilage and missed half the season. So, even with his natural solidity, he has gone down the injury path of so many young bowlers. But there is no evidence of a suspect temperament, which is regarded as yeoman-solid. "Give him the ball and he gets on with it, no fuss," is the general observation. He may not get the chance just yet but clearly he is one for the future. fields.headline: Byas records a sorry double
fields.standfirst:
Northamptonshire 189-7
Yorkshire 129
Northamptonshire win by 60 runs
fields.trailText:
Northamptonshire 189-7
Yorkshire 129
Northamptonshire win by 60 runs.
fields.body:
Yorkshire, the championship leaders, entered the weekend in buoyant mood but have come out of it in disarray after suffering two humbling defeats, which have plunged them close to relegation from the National League First Division.

After their 51-run defeat by Gloucestershire on Saturday, Yorkshire yesterday failed to come to terms with good swing bowling by Devon Malcolm and tight, well-flighted off-spin from Jason Brown before being put out of their misery by Graeme Swann.

Malcolm had England's Michael Vaughan caught behind the wicket for eight and Brown lured Gary Fellows into a false drive before trapping the Yorkshire captain David Byas lbw on the sweep in a match-swinging spell of nine overs for 28 runs.

In among these mishaps they also lost their top batsman, Darren Lehmann, who drove a boundary before being bowled off a pad when Michael Strong pitched the ball up and swung it in sharply to the Australian left-hander.

This rewarded a thoughtful piece of captaincy by Matthew Hayden, who had brought back Strong for one over with two left-handers at the crease.

Byas, who after his team's heavy defeat at Bristol on Saturday felt compelled to omit Craig White and Chris Silverwood, gained a mixed response from his reshaped attack as Northamptonshire reached 189 for seven on the back of a superb unbeaten 71 by David Sales.

Sales took a particular liking to the slow bowling of James Middlebrook, lifting him four times for six in the narrow arc between straight and mid-on. His 96-ball innings was one of style and belligerence in which he figured in stands of 70 with left-hander Jeff Cook, who was badly missed by Middlebrook when one, and 60 with Penberthy.

Yorkshire's reply was pathetic - 129 all out in 39 overs. Their top-scorer was Anthony McGrath, making his first senior appearance of the season in any form of cricket. He made 32 but it took him 72 balls to get them and he failed to reach the boundary.

McGrath at least managed to delay the inevitable, but Swann ripped through the late order to finish with four for 14 from five overs, his best return of the season.

fields.headline: Twisted vision
fields.standfirst:
It was a small fight, some chairs were overturned and a big water pistol was used. Charlie Whelan says television reporting of the football 'riots' in Brussels and Charleroi was staggeringly inaccurate

Football violence: special report
fields.trailText:
It was a small fight, some chairs were overturned and a big water pistol was used. Charlie Whelan says television reporting of the football 'riots' in Brussels and Charleroi was staggeringly inaccurate

Football violence: special report
fields.body:
I bumped into a familiar face in the Grand Place, Brussels, last week; he was an ITN cameraman. "We've got some brilliant pictures of Turks and Belgians kicking shit out of each other, Charlie," he told me. "That should help to balance the coverage," I naively replied. "Nah, we've been told they only want pics of the English causing trouble."

For 10 days I followed England's football fortunes with the BBC Radio 5 Live news team and the realisation that TV news was actually conniving with the buffoons from Uefa to get England kicked out of Euro 2000 made me even more angry with them than I was with the hooligans.

My experience in dealing with the media has taught me that television news can easily distort events, but never have I seen such distortion as I witnessed in Holland and Belgian last week. It is of course not all the fault of some TV editor who wants pictures to fit his story - the very fact that the Belgium police decided to try out their new toy, which they call water cannon, meant that there would only be one image left on our minds. No amount of explanation of what really happened on the radio by the 5 Live team could alter that.

The media had come to the Low Countries prepared for trouble from the England fans. Some were more prepared than others. Having learned from their experience in France in 1998, the 5 Live team had spent months preparing "safe" venues for reporters and presenters to send their stories back to England. Talksport covered events from a hotel room in Amsterdam and ITN and BBC TV news used Bill Neely and Jon Sopel - reporters with whom I enjoyed battling in my past life as a government press officer, but who are more used to covering diplomatic summits than football thugs. No one, however, had a better view of what was happening in Eindhoven and Charleroi than 5 Live. All the papers of course had their "hoolie watch" teams ready to report on "England's shame". The problem for them was that as we approached the first game in Eindhoven there were very few hoolies to report on.

The Dutch police had done their homework and ensured that the few were not going to wreck the party for the many. For the first time since I began following England I actually enjoyed the pre-match festivities and was not ashamed to be English. I spent my first England away trip in a campsite in Turin in 1980 and ended up being tear-gassed by the Italian police. This was my sixth campaign away with England and I began to believe that although we had no chance of winning the championship, or even getting past the first stage, at least the fans were behaving themselves. This did not suit everyone, however.

Following the police press conference where we were told that all was peaceful and that there had been three arrests for ticket touting and one for a fan getting up to "hanky-panky" with a flag pole, Jon Sopel for BBC TV news had to file his report. He could have done what every other foreign TV reporter had done and filmed his piece in the main square where everyone was having a party. Instead he found a spot miles away where the backdrop was a line of police vehicles and police horses. The image was clear for viewers back home to see, but it was a false one. Why let the facts get in the way of good pictures?

Once inside the stadium it was clear that thousands of genuine England fans had procured most of the tickets. There were hundreds of them at the Portugal end but not a hint of trouble, and for the first time ever they all sat in silence during the opposition's anthem and actually applauded it. Even though we lost the game we set off for Charleroi happy that for once the England fans had behaved and that there seemed to be a new mood amongst them.

The long break before the next game against Germany meant that we had time to visit the England training camp. The English media centre in Spa was bigger than for a European political summit, and the control of the press even more blatant than by Alastair Campbell. Before my colleague Victoria Derbyshire was allowed to interview Sol Campbell she had to agree not to ask him anything about Spurs, even though this was the day that they had agreed to sell David Ginola. The players had been so well briefed not to say anything interesting that the interviews were hardly worth broadcasting.

Following a quick spin from the FA that the BBC was the "people's choice" for their live games, we returned to Charleroi and the most unforgettable night of the tournament as thousands of Italians celebrated their victory over Belgium. We broadcast the celebration into Up All Night on 5 Live, believing that Chaleroi would be one long party.

We reported all next day about the England fans arriving and enjoying themselves and the brief altercation with a French fan chasing some English people with an cosh, and later the stabbing of an English fan (in the back) by a local Turkish youth. When we were told that his life was in danger we held back from reporting it. Five Live was being broadcast in Charleroi on an FM frequency twice daily for the fans, and such a report would undoubtedly have inflamed the situation. Actually, the fan was OK but the incident showed how important it was to have experienced producers around.

Meanwhile, back in Brussels, the Belgian police and the TV news got what they wanted. Violence. Once the telly had the pictures of the Belgian police firing teargas into pubs and arresting everyone inside, they had their story. The real story of the fans just having a quiet drink, being held for 10 hours and sent home without their luggage would have to wait for the inside pages of the posh papers a few days later or the Nicky Campbell show on 5 Live.

The police in Charleroi just could not wait for their turn. Also waiting in the main square were the world's media. I counted at least 50 TV cameras ready to witness the inevitable. On the radio, our team reported the events from 6am. No chairs had been cleared, strong beer was readily available and the police let gangs of Germans into the square. They obligingly tipped off the TV crews that they were going in to arrest some Germans and the rest is history. Gordon Farquhar, the experienced 5 Live sports news reporter, scored the level of violence as three out of 10, but who cared about the radio? The incident with the water cannon that the TV reported actually lasted no more than 10 minutes, while 15,000 England fans enjoying themselves with Germans in the hundreds of bars around the square received no coverage. ITN reported the water cannon scenes as effective policing, so effective that Bill Neely got hit in the face by a fan. Those nutters in the square loved every minute of it and even cheered when the water cannon returned.

These great TV pictures enabled those not there, and some who were, to talk rubbish. The Independent leader talked about the fans' "rampage through the Low Countries". What rampage? Charles Bremner of the Times, who normally covers the bureaucrats in Brussels, told us that "the battered Charleroi residents were happy to see England fans go home". I was in Charleroi for seven days and that is simply not true.

The tabloids, as you would expect, were even worse. Jeff Powell for the Mail, allegedly writing from Charleroi but probably from his five-star hotel in Spa, said that the rest of the tournament has been relieved of the "rioting fans". Powell had obviously not read the local paper in Charleroi which was actually very complimentary about the English, and reported "Riot, what riot?". Ian Wooldridge, writing from the safety of a bar in South Africa after "a couple of whiskies", said: "This mindless minority nonsense won't wash any more." He complains about academic pontificating on Radio 5 Live and being patronising about football writers. How can anyone take seriously someone who in the same rant tells us that the only man who ever got it right was [ex-sports minister] Colin Moynihan?

No one has criticised the racist scum, plankton and pond life that follows England more than me, but Jack Straw also failed to act decisively and gave Uefa the opportunity to threaten our expulsion. Their hypocrisy is staggering. Turkish fans can murder Leeds fans and that is "nothing to do with football". If so, then neither were the English nutters anything to do with football. The lowest point of our coverage of Euro 2000, however, was arriving back at our hotel following our exit to see the Panorama film on the "hoolies". They would have loved it and Panorama has just made them heroes amongst their peers, just as they did the Millwall F Troop in the 70s.

The Guardian's "fan in a van" is relieved it is all over. He took his life in his hands by driving through parts of Belgium in a British van, but maybe he should take a video camera with him next time and record the fans' view for TV. The pen may be mightier than the sword but it's not as powerful as television. How else could you explain someone as intelligent as Martin Kelner telling us in the Guardian that he thought it was "a shame the Belgium riot police were not equipped with real bullets"?

webTitle: Never mind the money, do you fit the media profile?

fields.headline: Never mind the money, do you fit the media profile?
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: We have approached a prominent public figure to take a place on our board as a non-executive director.
fields.body:
One colleague who insists on wearing suits all the time was convinced he would catch each of us in one before long. Last week he did, proving two things: that we are not against wearing of suits per se and that we have the good sense to dress for the occasion. This particular occasion was a trip to the Houses of Parliament.

We have approached a prominent public figure to take a place on our board as a non-executive director. The questions he asked are a measure of how the e-commerce environment has changed.

Almost immediately, he rattled off questions such as: "what are your revenue streams?" and: "how many customers do you need to move into profit?"

Six months ago, profit was almost considered a dirty word in the world of e-commerce. Now it is one of the first things people ask about. We impressed on him that Rools is a sustainable business and will eventually generate profits.

The atmosphere relaxed a little and our host gave us a quick summary of his involvement in internet businesses and went into what motivated him. To his credit, it seemed that he was getting involved because they are of interest to him, not based on the simple economics and who pays the most.

A brief interruption in the form of the division bell for a vote and we wrapped up the conversation.

The final point he made was that although the personal incentive to get involved would not be the deciding factor, there had to be enough of an incentive to make the devotion of time and energy worthwhile.

Trying to get celebrity endorsement has so far been only a marginally less exacting experience. Since William Shatner made a well-publicised second fortune through his involvement with US dot.com Priceline, celebrities have become very switched on to the potential upside of getting involved in the new economy.

A few days ago it was announced that David Beckham and Britney Spears were each going to be heavily involved in separate online ventures. We have been to see a couple of celebrity agents, in settings that are not quite as imposing as the House. These agents have been at least as commercially clued-up as any of our partners and in each case they wanted to gain a thorough understanding of the business. Their celebrity clients have very clear strategies and have put far more thought into the next five years and how they want to position themselves than either of us ever did for our careers. They have a further requirement, beyond enthusiasm for the business and the incentives it can offer. The business has to fit the professional and media profile they have built and are going to develop in the future.

For instance we know of one celebrity who plans to move from children's television to mainstream programming next year and is looking to get involved with e-commerce companies that will help support such a move.

All these meetings last week seemed to go well. Whatever comes out of them, they were certainly a colourful and welcome addition to the wide range of positive, negative and downright unusual experiences that we have had since we started this business.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com, a service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card.

fields.headline: GPs urge advice on acupuncture
fields.standfirst:
Interesting point: profession turns to alternative medicine
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Half of Britain's GPs arranged acupuncture treatment for their patients last year, the British Medical Association reported yesterday in a study recognising the growing influence of complementary and alternative medicine.
fields.body:
Half of Britain's GPs arranged acupuncture treatment for their patients last year, the British Medical Association reported yesterday in a study recognising the growing influence of complementary and alternative medicine.

The association's scientific board concluded that acu-puncture is an effective treatment for nausea, vomiting, back pain, dental pain and migraine.

It was uncertain about the benefits in cases of osteoarthritis or neck pain and sceptical about claims that acupuncture could help people stop smoking or lose weight.

Vivienne Nathanson, the association's head of health policy, said doctors did not have to accept traditional Chinese theory about the use of acupuncture needles to influence energy flows within the body. The western approach to acupuncture was based on modern concepts of neuroanatomy and physiology.

"We don't have to say how it works, but the evidence is there that it works for some conditions," she said.

Among GPs arranging acupuncture for their patients, 15% provided it themselves, 57% used another doctor, 24% a physiotherapist and only 5% a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner.

Among all GPs, 79% wanted to see acupuncture available on the NHS and nearly half wanted training so that they could use this method for treating patients in future.

The BMA said that up to 5m people may have consulted a therapist specialising in complementary and alternative medicine over the last year, including acupuncturists, osteopaths, homeopaths and aromatherapists.

The poll showed 58% of GPs arranged complementary treatments for patients, with the most popular therapies being acupuncture (47%), osteopathy (30%) and homeopathy (25%).

The BMA called on the body charged with assessing drugs and treatments, the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice), to issue guidance on how acupuncture should be used within the health service.

Practitioners of the traditional Chinese version of the treatment believe there are 365 acupuncture points on the human body, arranged in lines or "meridians".

There are 12 main meridians along which "Qi" - or energy - flows in an ordered manner. If the flow is interrupted, a person becomes ill.

Practitioners of the traditional Chinese way believe inserting needles into different acupuncture points can balance out the energy and allow it to flow freely again, curing the person.

fields.headline: For peat's sake
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Thorpe Hamlet, Norfolk
fields.body:
Thorpe Hamlet, Norfolk

With the onset of summer it's time for us to get into the garden, plant some flowers and, it appears, help destroy one of the rarest, most atmospheric landscapes in the country. Yet few of us seem to realise that with each bag of compost we take home from the garden centre, we're probably carrying away some fragment of a lowland raised peatbog.

It doesn't sound very exciting, but raised bogs comprise a complex community of sphagnum mosses that grow at a rate of 10 millimetres a year. When these die back they lay down a fresh peat layer just a single millimetre thick. Each metre of peat thus represents 1,000 years of growth and some of the richest, most heavily exploited raised bogs, such as Thorne and Hatfield Moors in Yorkshire, were 10 metres deep in parts.

These moors are, in essence, living organisms with an uninterrupted history of growth that stretches back to the last ice age. Already nine-tenths of Britain's raised bogs have been destroyed and to dig up these national treasures so that we can pot out our pansies is nothing short of a scandal. Could you imagine anyone giving a contractor permission to dismantle Norwich cathedral to sell it off a few bricks at a time?

Gardeners now account for 70% of peat used in the UK. In the last four years for which there are full government data 2m cubic metres were being used per annum. This is the equivalent of a peat pathway two metres wide and a metre deep stretching from Land's End to John o' Groats.

The main problem is public ignorance of the existence of equally effective commercial alternatives. The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds is calling for a total ban on peat extraction and use by 2005. Their peatland policy officer, Oliver Watts, points out that "there's absolutely no justification for ruining these precious sites, when perfectly good compost alternatives exist. In effect, when gardeners sprinkle peat on their own little patch, they are sacrificing a greater natural paradise which belongs to us all".

fields.headline: Ministry of funny walks
fields.trailText: How pathetic that there was "amusement in Whitehall" at the proposal in the government's draft health strategy that GPs should prescribe regular walks to tackle ill-health (NHS action plan targets smoking, June 23). There is overwhelming evidence that regular exercise, and walking in particular, is one of the most effective and cheapest ways of reducing early deaths from obesity and heart disease.
fields.body:
How pathetic that there was "amusement in Whitehall" at the proposal in the government's draft health strategy that GPs should prescribe regular walks to tackle ill-health (NHS action plan targets smoking, June 23). There is overwhelming evidence that regular exercise, and walking in particular, is one of the most effective and cheapest ways of reducing early deaths from obesity and heart disease.

The real irony is that one of the seminal studies into the health benefits of exercise was based on a survey of British civil servants. No doubt the hilarity in Whitehall provoked by this far-sighted proposal will be tempered by shortness of breath and pains in the chest. Let's hope the policy on health walks makes it into the published strategy.

Ben Plowden
Director, The Pedestrians' Association

fields.headline: No votes for Thursday
fields.trailText: Norman Shepherd (Letters, June 24) is mistaken, as are so many commentators on low turn-outs. If elections were held at the weekend: if the polling stations were open all day: if we could vote at the supermarket, garden centre, pub, workplace, via the internet, phone, or fax: if personal polling clerks visited non- voting households, the end result would be little better.
fields.body:
Norman Shepherd (Letters, June 24) is mistaken, as are so many commentators on low turn-outs. If elections were held at the weekend: if the polling stations were open all day: if we could vote at the supermarket, garden centre, pub, workplace, via the internet, phone, or fax: if personal polling clerks visited non- voting households, the end result would be little better.

The turn-out reflects the respect in which the candidates or their backing organisations are held, and the level of interest in the issues. In this village, with about 1,300 electors, a turn-out of less than 60%, even for parish council elections, would be considered poor.

Why? Because the candidates all live in the community, stand without political tags or backing, and the council has no political grouping. The formula is simple: respect plus interest equals response.

CG Hind
Gotham, Notts

Thursday elections are a quaint British tradition dating from 1935. It has no logic and has been preserved by the inertia of successive home secretaries and their fear of Sabbatarian objections to weekend voting.

Thursday voting robs thousands of children of a day's education, when their schools are taken over for use as polling stations. Many parents face the inconvenience and expense of organising an extra day's child care. In a small way, Thursday voting reinforces class distinctions in education, since private schools stay open.

Through referendums and developed elections, the present government has made the British people vote more often than ever before. Every local or national election during its term has taken place on a school day - a poor advertisement for a government supposedly committed to education and families.

Richard Heller
London

fields.headline: Fiji rebels free women hostages
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: The rebels holding Fiji's deposed government at gunpoint released four women yesterday before talks to free the remaining male hostages again broke down in acrimony.
fields.body:
The rebels holding Fiji's deposed government at gunpoint released four women yesterday before talks to free the remaining male hostages again broke down in acrimony.

The ousted prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and 26 MPs remain inside the parliament building where they have been held since May 19, when the businessman George Speight led an armed raid.

A deal to free the hostages announced on Friday fell through on Saturday, apparently because their release would have left the rebels without bargaining power.

The military authorities, who have taken control of the country, have been negotiating with the rebels on the makeup of an interim civilian government to lead Fiji until elections are held. The latest impasse appears to be over the naming of a president. The rebels insist that they must appoint the president, who in turn would probably name rebel representatives to the interim government.

Mr Chaudhry was Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, and the rebels say they staged their coup because he was trampling on the rights of the indigenous majority. Mr Speight's occupation of parliament was followed by attacks on ethnic Indians.

Talks on political crisis in the Solomon Islands were held on an Australian navy ship yesterday, but without representatives of the Malaita Eagles Force, which attempted a coup three weeks ago.

The premiers of the provinces of Malaita and Guadalcanal agreed to consult their respective militant groups on a date for and the issues to be discussed at ceasefire talks.

The MEF is fighting the Isatabu Freedom Movement for dominance on the main island, Guadalcanal, where the capital, Honiara, is located. Reuters

webTitle: Something rotten in the state of Texas

fields.headline: Something rotten in the state of Texas
fields.trailText: I fear that it is too much to hope that Gary Graham's execution (EU angered by execution, June 24) will at last expose the transparent fraud (transparent on this side of the Atlantic at least) of George W Bush's "compassionate conservatism".
fields.body:
I fear that it is too much to hope that Gary Graham's execution (EU angered by execution, June 24) will at last expose the transparent fraud (transparent on this side of the Atlantic at least) of George W Bush's "compassionate conservatism".

Bush's inexplicably widening poll lead seems to demonstrate that no candidate since Goldwater has lost for being too rightwing - so determined seem the US electorate to vote with their reactionary instincts turned on, and their frontal lobes turned off. This race depressingly evokes memories of 1980 and Reagan's successful "there you go again" anti- intellectualism

Keith MC O'Sullivan
Oxford
keith.osullivan@history.oxford.ac.uk

 Can the world trust as US president a man who shows such disregard for fundamental principles like truth, morality and the burden of evidence? Civilised society generally only convicts where a man is guilty beyond reasonable doubt. In the case of Gary Graham there was some amount of doubt. Texas now sits alongside the likes of China, where state authorised, politically motivated homicide is commonplace.

How can the US dictate human rights issues overseas when it so monstrously disregards them in its own back yard ?

I find the prospect of George W Bush as US president nothing short of horrifying. A man who has himself a questionable past, one who appears to have little grasp of global politics or domestic reality, and now someone exposed as happy to sacrifice the life of a man rather than leave a mark on his populist policy machine.

Richard Callis
London
Richard.Callis@msdw.com

 The execution of Gary Graham should serve to underline the unjust and barbaric nature of capital punishment. The doubts surrounding Mr Graham's guilt and the nature of his trial give this awful case the appearance of a lynching. The fact that the death penalty is used so widely in America and attracts such a large degree of public support is a shameful stain on an otherwise proud civilisation.

Neil Baird
Weston-super-Mare, Somerset

fields.headline: Parsnips on a pension
fields.trailText: Your sanctimonious reader, M Davis from Paisley (Letters, June 24), states that with Sainsbury's parsnips at £1.05 for two an OAP couldn't buy them with their 75p rise in the pension. Perhaps so, but they could certainly buy a great deal more warmth with their generous increase in winter fuel allowance. Even pensioners don't burn parsnips! By the way, parsnips are cheaper at Tesco.

fields.headline: University challenge
fields.trailText: John Dunford and Alan Smithers (Should entry grades for university be lowered for less privileged students? Saturday Review, June 24) rehearsed the issues associated with trying to give disadvantaged groups greater opportunity to access university education in the UK.
fields.body:
John Dunford and Alan Smithers (Should entry grades for university be lowered for less privileged students? Saturday Review, June 24) rehearsed the issues associated with trying to give disadvantaged groups greater opportunity to access university education in the UK.

But one critical area was ignored. If the "new" universities (that happen to provide more opportunities for these disadvantaged groups) were given the same financial support per student as the "old" universities, significant progress could be relatively quickly made to resolve the issues of access - especially if the same principle was applied to the schools system.

Disadvantaged students tend to come from disadvantaged areas, go to disadvantaged schools and then disadvantaged universities. The fact that so many succeed so well is of enormous credit to the individuals concerned, as well as reflecting the fact that, of course, money isn't everything. But the real question that should have been the focus of the discussion is: "How can we do more to try to break out of this circle of privilege and disadvantage?"

Dr Bruce Lloyd
South Bank University, London
101645.1441@compuserve.com

 Robin Milner-Gulland (Letters, June 24) has a point. A few years ago, as a headmaster, I attended an admissions conference at the invitation of a group of Oxford colleges. A headmaster asked: "You seem to regard Cambridge as your only competitor. Should you not be looking at the 'new' universities like York, Warwick, Lancaster etc?" The chairman's response: "Are there any other questions?"

Fred Tye
Thirsk, North Yorkshire
ftye@clara.net

 Peter Lampl (£20m price tag to end bias by top universities, June 20) correctly identifies the conditional offer system operated by universities as a source of bias against states school pupils that needs to be removed. It does not require a PhD to realise that a pupil predicted by their head teacher to obtain three D's but obtaining 3 B's is better than one predicted to get 3 B's but only obtaining three C's, yet the former is less likely to receive an offer. In contrast Lampl's second solution, the introduction of scholastic aptitude tests, a glorified 11-plus, is suspect as performance in such multiple choice tests can be raised through coaching. Evidence of this is the proliferation of private tuition and preparatory schools in areas of the country with the 11-plus, with the primary purpose of getting pupils into grammar schools.

Chris Roberts
Manchester
roberts.chris@tesco.net

fields.headline: Move over, Darling
fields.trailText: Alistair Darling (Letters, June 24) seeks to justify the proposed withdrawal of benefits to people in breach of community service orders by proclaiming that "Society is built on a contract."
fields.body:
Alistair Darling (Letters, June 24) seeks to justify the proposed withdrawal of benefits to people in breach of community service orders by proclaiming that "Society is built on a contract." It is indeed, Mr Darling, and society has a contractual obligation to every newborn citizen: it is obliged to ensure that mortality in its infants is not five times greater among the poor than the rich, that every young child has an equal chance to a decent education and is not disadvantaged by poverty, that higher education should not become the preserve of the better off, that speedy access to health care is not restricted to those who can afford to clamber over their poorer brethren to the front of the queue, that everyone should have a chance to work and, when they grow old, that 40,000 of them do not die every year from the cold.

Society is in serious breach of its contract with millions of its members, and those such as Mr Darling, who are responsible for the continuation of that breach have no right to lecture to the rest of us.

Colin Burke
Manchester
colintburke@netscapeonline.co.uk

 Alistair Darling implies that offenders consent to be made subject to community service orders. He says that if they enter into an agreement they should stick to it. However, in reality the courts that make such orders do not require consent. It is therefore reasonable to expect that the same courts should deal with any breach of the orders.

The responsibility for completing the order lies properly with the offender, responsibility for dealing with any failure to do so lies with the court - not the secretary of state for social security

D O'Sullivan
Derby

 Full Marks to Hugo Young (Comment, June 22) for his razor-sharp exposé of a shabby piece of legislation that would see the withdrawal of benefit from those accused - not convicted - of breaking community service orders. No marks at all to Alistair Darling for his weaselly protestations that a contract has been entered into and should be kept to.

In actuality the contract is that if you break your order by missing two appointments you are returned to court for resentence. Hard enough for many whose lives are shambolic, disorganised and distressed. It is not patronising, as Darling says, to state this, it is a reality, of which he and the home secretary seem supremely unaware.

I too entered into a contract when I joined the probation service, to advise, assist and befriend. No one told me it was going to be rewritten to beat, berate and incarcerate.

John Dessauer
London
john.dessauer@tesco.net

 Any Millbank protege researching public scepticism about Labour should read Alistair Darling's cold reply to Hugo Young's criticism of benefit cuts for young offenders. New Labour, hard labour?

Kevin Donnelly
Manchester
kevin@kevdon.demon.co.uk

 I always thought Alistair Darling preferred to pickpocket the poor (single parents, disabled people, asylum seekers etc) but in the case of criminals it seems daylight robbery will do.

But why stop at offenders who fail to fulfil community service orders? What about Jack Straw's contract with the electorate when he promised not to introduce private prisons or vouchers systems for asylum seekers. Shouldn't he have his pay docked for breaking those promises? Or is it a question of one contract for the rich, and one for the poor?

Jim King
Birmingham
fields.bodyText: Alistair Darling (Letters, June 24) seeks to justify the proposed withdrawal of benefits to people in breach of community service orders by proclaiming that "Society is built on a contract." It is indeed, Mr Darling, and society has a contractual obligation to every newborn citizen: it is obliged to ensure that mortality in its infants is not five times greater among the poor than the rich, that every young child has an equal chance to a decent education and is not disadvantaged by poverty, that higher education should not become the preserve of the better off, that speedy access to health care is not restricted to those who can afford to clamber over their poorer brethren to the front of the queue, that everyone should have a chance to work and, when they grow old, that 40,000 of them do not die every year from the cold. Society is in serious breach of its contract with millions of its members, and those such as Mr Darling, who are responsible for the continuation of that breach have no right to lecture to the rest of us. He says that if they enter into an agreement they should stick to it. However, in reality the courts that make such orders do not require consent. It is therefore reasonable to expect that the same courts should deal with any breach of the orders. The responsibility for completing the order lies properly with the offender, responsibility for dealing with any failure to do so lies with the court - not the secretary of state for social security D O'Sullivan Derby  Full Marks to Hugo Young (Comment, June 22) for his razor-sharp exposé of a shabby piece of legislation that would see the withdrawal of benefit from those accused - not convicted - of breaking community service orders. No marks at all to Alistair Darling for his weaselly protestations that a contract has been entered into and should be kept to. In actuality the contract is that if you break your order by missing two appointments you are returned to court for resentence. It is not patronising, as Darling says, to state this, it is a reality, of which he and the home secretary seem supremely unaware. I too entered into a contract when I joined the probation service, to advise, assist and befriend. No one told me it was going to be rewritten to beat, berate and incarcerate. fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: • Danger at work
fields.body:
 Danger at work

For many British employees, the workplace is a potentially dangerous environment. Each year more than 1m workers are injured, and 400 people are killed in work-related activities, at an annual cost to the country of around £18bn. To combat the risks, the government has joined the Health and Safety Commission to set targets to reduce work-related deaths and injury. They have introduced a 10-point strategy and an action plan, to help employers improve conditions.

 Hot stuff

If you sit by a sunny window at work, you'll be almost as hot as if you were sitting outside, because glass lets through 90% of the sun's heat. So says Durable Berkeley, the UK's largest distributor of 3M Scotchtint Solar Control Window Film, which filters out 80% of the sun's rays. For more information, visit the firm's website: www.hotatwork.co.uk, or call 0118 948 3500.

 Test your skills

Do you know where your skills lie? A new series of books from the Institute of Management aims to help people assess their strengths and abilities. Each book looks at one particular skill and gives tests and guidelines so readers can gauge how they measure up. The five "Test Your . . ." books assess leadership skills, management skills, management style, personality, and aptitude and ability. The last two titles give guidance on the much-feared psychometric test, and show what it may reveal about potential employees. Available at £6.99 each from bookshops, or from Lavis Marketing (0845 7023736).

Data without distress

We all know that sense of horror when a computer crashes and valuable documents vanish. But a new report has found that human error - accidentally deleting or overwriting a file, or saving it in the wrong place - accounts for a third of data loss in organisations. The survey from DataSafe Services found that 57,000 small businesses in the UK could face collapse if they lost all their computer data. For advice on storing information securely, check out the website at www.telesafe.co.uk

 Overworked over here

Office Staff Overloaded Shocker! In the least surprising piece of news for some time, it was widely reported last week that British workers are being overwhelmed by information. We hardly needed a study by business communication specialists Pitney Bowes to tell us about the increasing time taken up by voicemail, email and snail mail. But the volume of communication may surprise some - the company says the average British worker sends and receives 191 messages each day, only five fewer than American workers.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: A risky business
fields.standfirst:
There's life in the dot.com yet. A few high-profile failures may highlight the need for caution, but they don't mean the death of the industry. Claire Phipps reports

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: There's life in the dot.com yet. A few high-profile failures may highlight the need for caution, but they don't mean the death of the industry.
fields.body:
The language of job ads can make any role, no matter how mundane, sound like a nine-to-five day full of non-stop excitement. But for those looking for a position outside the normal routine, ads promising to "redefine job roles", offering a chance to "build a young, dynamic team", assuring you that "enthusiasm and the ability to work under pressure" could land you in the thick of a new company launch, could hardly be more tempting.

And it is the new dot.com companies that often seem to promise the most. Small company, big prospects is the subtext, and plenty of workers have been persuaded to take the risk of working for an internet start-up. And it can be risky. Only those marooned on a desert island could have missed coverage of the collapse of boo.com, and reports this week on dot.com funding have also cast a shadow over the industry. Venture capitalists, once so eager to toss money into the dot.com well, have retreated with their bags of cash, stung by the death of boo and the plummeting prices of internet shares. Now that every twentysomething with half an idea dreams of e-millions, investors have twigged that some ventures are more upstart than start-up.

So is it time to get out? Not so fast. The dot.com industry is still young, and reports of its death are rather premature. Job losses do happen - just last week 226 staff were laid off when Somerfield's online shopping site 24-7 closed its virtual doors - but in the same week, clothing giant C&A announced the end of its stores and 4,800 jobs. When boo.com finally shut up shop, there were headhunters waiting in the pub to console the newly unemployed with champagne and career opportunities.

Lucy Simmons, 24, has been working in customer support for a business-to-business (B2B) financial site for six months and is unperturbed by the scare stories: "I don't think job security exists in any sector any more, so it's no more risky to go into this than any other job. I don't know if it's a good long-term career choice, but it suits me fine at the moment."

While the rate of investment in internet start-ups may be slowing, there's still an awful lot of money sloshing around out there. A report from accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers last week confirmed that investment in European internet companies rose last year by an astonishing 70%, of which the UK won a third. Over three-quarters of these investments went on younger start-up companies. But Robert Conway, PwC's global technology industry group leader, cautioned at the time that "venture capitalists will become far more selective. Start-ups will find it difficult to raise finance without good ideas and great management."

Working for a dot.com, especially one that's barely up and running, requires a certain amount of trust. Yes, the boss has a great idea and a whole lot of enthusiasm, but he or she might be new to management and could have less experience than those they are now employing to make the coffee.

Share options in the firm might make you a fortune if the company soars, but you could just as easily end up with nothing if it goes under before any profits materialise (as boo.com's unlucky employees discovered - some did not even receive their wages). Salaries and perks could well be at the skimpier end of the scale: Anders Bergtoft, managing director of ShopSmart.com, which took over boo's Stockholm offices, recently warned employees to expect "buses, beer and burgers", rather than the Concorde, champagne and caviar their predecessors reputedly enjoyed.

Simmons confirms this: "Pay is probably less good than in other sectors. Depending on when you join the company, you might not get shares or options, so the idea that everyone who works for dot.com companies will become millionaires is a bit of a myth. And people do seem to think that the work is more glamorous than it actually is. I work long hours just like my friends."

The first flurry of excitement about internet shares has died down, and workers should approach a job at an internet start-up with a degree of scepticism. One estimate from Merrill Lynch predicted that three-quarters of European internet companies would disappear in the next few years. For the wary, a job with a B2B site, rather than the riskier retail sites, is probably a safer bet, relying less on the whims of the consumer.

But who really wants a job with a lifetime guarantee? Simmons, for the moment, is enjoying the uncertainty: "I wasn't actually looking for a job at a dot.com, but when I was offered it I was tempted because it was something new and different. And I'm still young enough to get a different job if it doesn't work out."

fields.headline: The low down
fields.trailText: These days it seems there are more American banks in London than in New York.
fields.body:
The allure of the City

These days it seems there are more American banks in London than in New York. While many British businesses have relocated away from the capital, or scaled down operations there, a survey from the London Chamber of Commerce & Industry (LCC&I) has found that the City is highly rated by foreign financiers.

Why is London so attractive? According to the LCC&I, foreign banks are attracted to London by the "depths" of its financial markets and its tradition as an international finance centre.

The other big attraction is the quality of staff, and a third of the companies polled expect to expand their labour forces this year - "an unusually high proportion," says the LCC&I. But demand is outstripping supply, with only a quarter of the banks finding it easy to recruit compared to more than half in 1997. Competition for staff is increasing labour costs and so, it must be said, is the recent flood of labour regulations introduced to bring this country in line with European regulations. Taking other factors into account, however, London is still considered to be less bureaucratic than either New York or Tokyo.

There are other criticisms, not least the overheated property market. But as far as transport goes, foreign businesses are more concerned about air than the Tube. They feel that London could do with more aviation links, a depressing thought for Londoners living under flight paths. And sometimes praise can be more startling than criticism - Britain's telecommunications system is highly rated.

The majority of the banks, 83%, expect London to remain the pre-eminent international financial centre over the next decade. It may be Londoners' favourite hobby to knock their home town, but international business, especially foreign exchange, can't get enough of it.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: Summer's arrival may mean lunchtime picnics in the park to break up the working day, but it also has its disadvantages, not least a thinning out of the office as colleagues jaunt off to the sunshine on their annual summer hols. And while working with a depleted staff team may be difficult enough, co-ordinating holidays to ensure that everyone doesn't head for Ibiza at the same time can be even more stressful.
fields.body:
Summer's arrival may mean lunchtime picnics in the park to break up the working day, but it also has its disadvantages, not least a thinning out of the office as colleagues jaunt off to the sunshine on their annual summer hols. And while working with a depleted staff team may be difficult enough, co-ordinating holidays to ensure that everyone doesn't head for Ibiza at the same time can be even more stressful.

Alan Witt knows more about holidays than most, as branch manager for a Thomas Cook outlet in Plymouth. But his 16 years' experience in selling holidays is little help when it comes to planning and negotiating time off for his staff team.

Witt gets 30 days holiday each year. "The longer you are with the company the more holiday you accrue - all new joiners start at 23 days and the maximum is 30 days, which is a healthy allowance compared to some companies," he says. Although staff book holidays for customers all year round they are not allowed the same privileges when it comes to their own time off. "We do have periods where it is difficult to grant leave, January is the heaviest booking period," he says.

There's a lot to take into account when juggling holiday schedules. "You have to look at the skills of the staff. You have to have staff that can step into the shoes of others. This means making sure that some of them are dual-skilled - so sales staff should be able to do foreign exchange or sales staff should also be able to cover administration. It just takes a bit of planning, and making sure you have a multiskilled workforce so that you are not suddenly left under-resourced. Also make sure that when members of staff are on holiday you allow for any sudden absences through sickness - otherwise you'll be left high and dry."

Everyone in Witt's team works five out of six days with Sunday off, and most work Saturdays so everyone is allowed a roster day off during the week. This means that there is a certain amount of juggling all year round. "For holidays, I find it best to use a year planner so that you can see everyone's holiday clearly marked. I'm a firm believer in flexibility and there's certainly no pecking order. Often we work on a first-come first-served basis, but we also give priority to people who have actually booked a holiday rather than those taking time off to stay at home. If something urgent does come up I'll sit down and try to figure something out with the member of staff. Nothing is impossible and I believe in give and take.

"You do sometimes find that if there's something going around, like the flu, then staff might be off at the same time and there's nothing that you can do to avoid that. However, we are quite lucky in that we have another branch in Plymouth so we can draw on their staff if we need to. We have a general staff shortage in this region so it always helps to be accommodating since you never know when the shoe might be on the other foot."
