fields.headline: Desktop icons No 25: The highlighter
fields.trailText: By their highlighters shall ye know them. For unparalleled access to your colleagues' innermost natures, the full, unexpurgated dirt on their deepest hopes and fears, check out their preferred shade of nausea-inducing fluorescent marker.
fields.body:
By their highlighters shall ye know them. For unparalleled access to your colleagues' innermost natures, the full, unexpurgated dirt on their deepest hopes and fears, check out their preferred shade of nausea-inducing fluorescent marker.

Yellow, of course, is the colour of conformity, the favoured hue of middle-managers patiently waiting for their shot at the top. Orange and green signify something a little more rebellious - the remnants of a primeval artistic streak among office workers who have somehow convinced themselves that colouring in memos and reports is an acceptable substitute for actually reading them. Pink represents repression (don't ask why, it just does). And the use of blue highlighter pens is clearly a perversion emanating directly from the most depraved sewers of Gomorrah, still punishable by death in some less enlightened regimes.

All this psychological data is of the greatest interest to the Powers That Be, who are, as we speak, monitoring our highlighter choices and using them to reach deep into our souls and seize control of our brains in preparation for the establishment of an Orwellian superstate.

The perpetrators of this dastardly plan masquerade under the name Schwan-Stabilo, purportedly a "company" with "headquarters" in the "picturesque market town" of Heroldsberg, Germany. It was in 1971, they say, that they invented the world's first highlighter, the Stabilo Boss - and 20 years later, in 1991, that they perfected the world's first refillable one. They also claim the credit for inventing the first ever overhead projector pens. Most think this is the full extent of their ingenuity, but we know better.

Some may dismiss this as paranoid nonsense. They will tell you that the real purpose of a highlighter pen is for picking out important passages in workplace documents - for highlighting, you might say. Fools! Don't they realise? That's exactly what they want you to think . . .

fields.headline: Mugabe ignores cry for change
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's ruling Zanu-PF party yesterday warned that President Robert Mugabe would defy all calls for his immediate resignation even if the results of the weekend elections swung decisively against him. Three quarters of the votes are likely to be counted by the end of today.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele in Harare and Andrew Meldrum  in Mberengwa
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's ruling Zanu-PF party yesterday warned that President Robert Mugabe would defy all calls for his immediate resignation even if the results of the weekend elections swung decisively against him. Three quarters of the votes are likely to be counted by the end of today.

As it became increasingly apparent yesterday that the opposition Movement for Democratic Change had garnered massive support, the government moved to dampen expectations that Mr Mugabe would bow to popular pressure. There would be no change in the composition of his cabinet.

"Zanu-PF will form the government whatever the results," John Nkomo, the party's national chairman, said. "Mugabe can have a cabinet of just five if he wants. Mugabe is an institution."

Saviour Kasukuwere, a Zanu-PF candidate, pointed to the constitutions of the US and France, where presidents continue to govern even when they lose control of their respective elected chambers. "There is nothing different here," he said.

Up to 5m Zimbabweans were eligible to vote this weekend in a poll which represents the biggest challenge to Mr Mugabe's rule since independence in 1980. Never before has there been an opposition party able to field candidates in all 120 seats.

The MDC ran its campaign using the buzzword "Change". Dozens of voters interviewed randomly outside the polling stations cited high prices, unemployment, and government corruption as reasons for wanting just such a change.

Constitutionally Mr Mugabe, whose term runs until 2002, is not required to step down but the MDC still hopes that if the results show an overwhelming vote against him he will face pressure to go. They also hope the army will back them.

After a violent election campaign in which around 40 people died, the level of intimidation fell dramatically during the two days of voting.

fields.headline: Japan's damaged PM scrapes home
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democratic party, which has ruled Japan for all but two of the past 45 years, was returned to power last night despite the unpopularity of its prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, and a government that has overseen four years of record unemployment, bankruptcy and suicide.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democratic party, which has ruled Japan for all but two of the past 45 years, was returned to power last night despite the unpopularity of its prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, and a government that has overseen four years of record unemployment, bankruptcy and suicide.

With 95% of the votes counted, the LDP was certain of victory with the help of its coalition allies.

In effect, Japan opted for the devil it knows - a decision which will mean business as usual for the world's second biggest economy.

But strong gains by the opposition and a low turnout will ensure that the heat remains on Mr Mori, whose verbal slips have driven his approval rating below 20% and prompted some LDP leaders to plot his replacement.

Opinion polls last week suggested an easy win, but the LDP had to wait until the final dozen results before it reached the modest 229-vote target it had set itself in the 480-seat lower house of parliament.

A tense Mr Mori said on television that it was too early to make a judgment on whether he should stand down, although the victory will probably ensure that he can stay in place at least long enough to host next month's G8 summit in Okinawa.

"If there is criticism from within the party about this result, I will accept that and make a final decision about my future," he said.

The prime minister has looked shaky since he took over the reins of power from Keizo Obuchi, who suffered a fatal stroke on April 2.

His verbal gaffes have undermined much of the sympathy vote that the LDP expected to attract from Mr Obuchi's death.

Mr Mori kicked off his campaign in the worst possible way by declaring that "Japan is a divine nation with the emperor at its core", a comment that critics said was an echo of the emperor-worship ping Shinto creed of the pre-war military regime.

Last week he attracted fresh criticism by admitting that he had played a key role at the wedding of a former mobster's family.

He then sparked off a furore by suggesting that floating voters - estimated to be about half the electorate - should stay in bed on polling day.

Such comments have distracted attention from a long-awaited improvement in the economy.

The government confirmed this month that Japan had finally emerged from its worst recession since the second world war, albeit with a tiny growth rate of 0.5% and one of the biggest public debts in its history.

During the election campaign Mr Mori promised to keep spending taxpayers' money until the growth rate passed 2%, which is not expected for at least a year.

The government has already pumped billions of yen into the economy to lift Japan out of the two-year slump.

Much of this has gone on public works in rural areas, ensuring the support yesterday of the LDP's two biggest sources of votes: the construction industry and farmers.

The opposition DPJ promised to raise taxes and cut spending. Despite this prudent, but politically damaging, platform, the party made gains, mainly in urban areas

It was expected to win about 130 seats, a solid improvement on its pre-election strength of 95.

"We have won the trust of voters because we were honest in our campaign. We are prescribing bitter medicine, not sweet talk," its leader, Yukio Hatoyama, said.

Only 63% of the 101m eligible voters bothered to go to the polls, the second lowest turnout, after the 1996 general election.

This apathy reflected the dreary weather - most voters had to brave downpours - and the even drearier state of national politics. Almost 50 years of virtually continuous one-party rule and the perception that the prime minister is a figurehead rather than a leader disillusioned many.

Mr Mori's two coalition partners also suffered a setback.

New Komei, which is backed by the Soka Gakkai lay Buddhist group, lost about a quarter of its 42 seats yesterday and the number of New Conservative party MPs fell from 20 to single figures.

Foot in his mouth

Yoshiro Mori's spate of slip-ups during the campaign sent his approval rating below 20%.

'Japan is a divine nation with the emperor at its core'

Critics said this expression, used during a speech to a Shinto group, harked back to the pre-war belief that the emperor was a god.

'We must protect the national polity from the communists'

'Kokutai' (national polity) is another pre-war expression. It referred to Japan's unique emperor-centred political system.

'Undecided voters should stay in bed on polling day'

Mori's democratic credentials were called into question after this gaffe - a sign of his fear that non-aligned voters could cause an upset.

'Yes, I was a go-between, but I didn't know the man's background'

Mori admits playing a key role at the wedding of a former gangster's son.

'My condolences to the souls of dead soldiers'

In a ceremony to mark the 55th anniversary of the Battle of Okinawa, Mori upset his hosts by mentioning only the military sacrifices and forgetting the 120,000 civilians who died in the fighting.

fields.headline: Lord Levy's tiny tax bill
fields.standfirst: Politics and patronage: The question of party funding raises its head on both sides of the Atlantic
fields.trailText: Lord Levy must have had a horrible weekend. No doubt, he is wondering why he didn't stick with making stars out of people such as Chris Rea - and avoid ever getting mixed up in this brutal business of politics. His claims of no wrong-doing are falling on deaf ears because that's not the point. He may be technically, legally, entirely in the clear but London mansions, Bentleys - and a £5,000 tax bill - just doesn't look good. And since politics has become largely about image, then how something looks is critical. And this looks like a glimpse into that cosy world in which wealth, privilege and power work the system to their own and each other's benefit.
fields.body:
Lord Levy must have had a horrible weekend. No doubt, he is wondering why he didn't stick with making stars out of people such as Chris Rea - and avoid ever getting mixed up in this brutal business of politics. His claims of no wrong-doing are falling on deaf ears because that's not the point. He may be technically, legally, entirely in the clear but London mansions, Bentleys - and a £5,000 tax bill - just doesn't look good. And since politics has become largely about image, then how something looks is critical. And this looks like a glimpse into that cosy world in which wealth, privilege and power work the system to their own and each other's benefit.

The problem is Lord Levy's tiny tax bill falls neatly into a narrative which is gaining an obsessive grip on the chattering classes: a crisis of political legitimacy. David Lammy's "victory" in Tottenham's byelection last week, when only 25% of voters bothered to turn out, is one more example to add to the mounting pile of evidence. If people don't vote, what kind of legitimacy does the winning MP, or government have? Even worse, when a local council organises an innovative idea like a referendum on GM crops, a subject believed to arouse great passions in consumers, and only 14% voted, the whole exercise is rendered meaningless.

Lots of books have been published, and more are due, agonising over this ebbing of trust in political institutions, and what kind of democracy we will be left with in a couple of decades. Disaffected Democracies: What's Troubling the Trilateral Countries? edited by Susan Pharr and Robert Putnam, is one such study. It charts the nosedive between the mid-60s and mid-90s in public respect and faith in politics in almost all western democracies (only countries such as the Netherlands and Iceland manage to buck the trend).

The editors sensibly point out that this does not mark the death of democracy, because faith in it as the best form of government remains high. It is just that we don't have very high expectations of it any more - either in the honesty of its participants, or its capacity to promote our interests. We all now agree with Winston Churchill's adage: democracy is the worst form of government, except for all the others.

But there are lots of people who for different reasons don't think passive support is good enough. The government for a start. Mo Mowlam is commissioning research into dozy citizenship - why don't the Royles get off their butts and vote? There is a wonderful irony here; the wheel has turned full circle in the past 25 years. In the mid-70s, the governing classes (including the Labour government) were seriously worried that the country was becoming ungovernable; they couldn't control trade unions, students were a pain and the task of government was fire-fighting those chippy citizens.

Anyone at university in the early 70s had a great time devoting all their ingenuity and intelligence into organising sit-ins and demos. (Rest assured that those finely honed organisational skills are now being deployed by a host of corporations.) Denis Healey's acceptance of International Monetary Fund-imposed cuts in public expenditure in 1976 was the turning point. What followed was Thatcher's use of mass unemployment and flexible labour laws to strike fear into worker and student alike, plus a deliberate decoupling of government from grassroots autonomous political activity.

Mrs T particularly relished demonstrating the pointlessness of political participation - delivering missiles at Greenham Common without a thought to the popular protest movement. She achieved a docile, apathetic electorate - and now, there are plenty of people in all political parties scratching their heads about how to get the public interested again.

In fact, the roots of the current crisis of disillusionment with politics go all the way back to 1968. The failure of those protests was the beginning of the end of a postwar dream of social transformation through political means. The answer for the failed '68 radicals was to forget politics and go New Age. You can't change the world, so change yourself instead, was the thinking. One of the slogans was "There's a policeman inside your head and you must kill him". Class warfare wasn't on the streets but in your head. From this, developed the "me generation" - an intensifying process of disengagement with the public sphere and a retreat into the personal.

The million dollar conundrum is a) can you re-engage people in a public sphere, and b) how? There is no shortage of players offering answers. Take three examples. First, the professional politicians are trying to reconnect with their electorate by moving the primary battleground from the economy to values. They have given up on the former as beyond their control, but they have yet to learn that the latter is equally so. As if William Hague and Tony Blair's warm words about marriage and the family will make one jot of difference. Second, there are those who advocate global democratic institutions to exert political control over the global economic trends which have undermined the nation state; but how will a global parliament avoid the problems - magnified a thousand times - of relevance, connection and corruption which bedevil national politics?

And third, the most interesting protest movement in years has been Reclaim the Streets; this group consciously revived 60s ideas of radical protest, using wit to subvert in a form of political street theatre. They have challenged (with some success over the road programme) many capitalist presumptions, but before they had begun to mature and develop some coherent alternatives, RTS appears to have been hijacked by a violent militancy, as Jay Griffiths points out in this week's issue of the London Review of Books, which will probably kill it off in Britain. (Although interestingly its export to the US is gaining strength.)

That leaves us, for the time being, with the pessimists triumphant. Their analysis is: get real, the high electoral turn-outs and mass political parties of the postwar period were an aberration. In fact, mass political participation is historically very rare, either through choice or lack of opportunity. Postwar politics made extravagant claims for its own power and unsurprisingly failed to deliver. Now we are simply returning to a normal politics, like that of the 18th and 19th centuries, which is characterised by cynicism, apathy and varying degrees of corruption. This politics never inspires or attempts to involve the majority of people, who prefer to get on with their own lives anyway. The pessimists could be right, but what's worrying is that what stands to benefit most from such disengagement is the intimate coupling of business and political power.

Which brings us all the way back to where we began, with Lord Levy's nasty weekend. And thus, we are neatly shown how we seem caught in a spiral of political disillusion and apathy which generates its own deep confusion about what change politics can and can't achieve.

fields.trailText: In our review of summer books, page 24, Friday Review, June 23, we identified Jenny Fabian as the sole author of Groupie (published by Omnibus). The book is by Jenny Fabian and Johnny Byrne. Apologies to both.
fields.body:
In our review of summer books, page 24, Friday Review, June 23, we identified Jenny Fabian as the sole author of Groupie (published by Omnibus). The book is by Jenny Fabian and Johnny Byrne. Apologies to both.

In a report about MI6 and the Zinoviev letter, page 5, June 23, we referred to the Comintern as the "internal" communist organisation. We should have said "international".

In our report headed The weird and wonderful return to get stoned at Stonehenge, page 7, June 27, we referred to "the bizarre Barking Balleria - a collection of up to 100 salsa players..." The band is the Barking Bateria. It plays samba, not salsa.

Homophone corner, from page 6, Euro 2000, June 23, "[He] would no doubt have pounced on that goal as vindication of all his hair-brained theories..." We go with Fowler, "harebrained [or hare-brained], not hair-". Collins allows hairbrained as an alternative, but we do not.

webTitle: Rich? Don't want to pay tax? Here's how

fields.headline: Rich? Don't want to pay tax? Here's how
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: For anyone with real money the first tax-planning decision is whether to avoid or evade payment.
fields.body:
For anyone with real money the first tax-planning decision is whether to avoid or evade payment.

Tax evasion is a criminal matter. It involves hiding money where the authorities are unlikely to find it, such as in safe deposit boxes or overseas bank accounts. Across Europe billions of pounds in tax is evaded each year through the use of accounts in places where the authorities refuse to pass on information about customers to investigators.

Last week, at the EU summit in Portugal, Gordon Brown won the backing of 14 of the 15 EU member states to introduce a framework for the sharing of information on suspect accounts but the plan faces huge hurdles. Austria, for example, refuses to relax its code of secrecy for any foreigner stashing money there.

Taking the legal route, avoiding tax, is a complex and expensive business. Tax planners often charge upwards of £400 an hour for advice.

There are two broad categories of tax to avoid: tax on capital gains and tax on income - through regular employment, for example, or the earnings from an investment. Other than through rudimentary planning, such as using a partner's allowances, tax on income is quite difficult to avoid. Capital gains are another matter. A range of tax breaks, such as investing in young high-risk companies, allow an individual to roll capital gains liabilities forward almost indefinitely.

Avoiding tax on both capital and income invariably requires the setting up of a trust or a move offshore, and often both at the same time.

Trusts come in all shapes and sizes. But the mechanism usually involves transferring beneficial ownership of an asset to someone else, such as a family member. Sophisticated tax avoidance structures can be constructed through the use of trusts, but they often prove expensive to set up and administer.

For those with big money who cannot bring themselves to hand over a portion to the British government the most effective course of action is to leave the country for all but 90 days a year.

fields.headline: Charmer who woos Labour donors
fields.standfirst:
Fundraising peer at the centre of tax row is a Middle East emissary for his friend Tony Blair
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The invitation to dinner at Lord Levy's north London mansion was irresistible to one wealthy businessman when he discovered that the guests of honour were Tony and Cherie Blair. He suspected he was not on the guest list to offer his views on business regulations but rather for the size of the cheque he might make out to Labour.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Ewen MacAskill and Michael White
fields.body:
The invitation to dinner at Lord Levy's north London mansion was irresistible to one wealthy businessman when he discovered that the guests of honour were Tony and Cherie Blair. He suspected he was not on the guest list to offer his views on business regulations but rather for the size of the cheque he might make out to Labour.

"Most people only get invited to those things if it is thought they will give a donation," admitted a Labour business adviser. "It's all very subtle and it's not so subtle, if you know what I mean."

The crunch call follows the intimate and genial evening, when Millbank moves in for its money and Lord Levy is already after his next target.

"He can be very charming when he is trying to get money out of people - but equally he can be quite vicious," said the adviser. "I would not want to cross him."

With his even tan, mane of silver hair, firm handshake and fixed smile, and the ear of the prime minister, Lord Levy is prominent among "Tony's cronies".

The prime minister's millionaire tennis partner is a spectacularly successful fundraiser and personal peace envoy to the Middle East. Ennobled in 1997 by a grateful Mr Blair, his address book has helped raise an estimated £7m for Labour's election victory.

Much of the cash was channelled through the then leader of the opposition's blind trust. Lord Levy remains an active fundraiser for the people's party.

A secretive sort who normally shuns the spotlight, Lord Levy will hate the embarrassing publicity triggered by yesterday's disclosure that he paid only £5,000 in taxes for 1998/99.

The 55-year-old music industry impresario drives a Bentley, and the grounds of his large north London home boast a pool, palm trees and tennis court.

He collected £4.25m last year by selling an eight-bedroom house in Tel Aviv, buying a more modest second home after scrapping plans to emigrate to Israel.

Lord Levy yesterday denied allegations that he had salted cash away in an offshore trust to beat the taxman, admitting only an overseas Israeli bank account (declaring the £150 interest on his tax return) to pay bills in that country.

During the 1998/99 financial year, the peer emphasised, he devoted himself to voluntary work, living off the capital from selling a music business.

Shouter

But how did he get by on around £20,000? "He does not live a five-star lifestyle," said a senior Labour figure.

Known as a "bit of a shouter" who can be abrasive with his staff, legend also has it that while he persuades others to finance Labour he keeps his own hand in his pocket.

Lord Levy was a key figure in persuading Bernie Ecclestone to hand over the ill-starred £1m returned by Labour after the motor racing mogul's No 10 talks with Mr Blair were disclosed shortly after the election. Along with the three trustees of Mr Blair's blind trust - one of whom, Lady Jay, yesterday mounted a staunch defence of Lord Levy - he knows where Labour's financial bodies are buried.

As controversial as his low taxes has been Lord Levy's unusual role as Mr Blair's US-style emissary to the Middle East. Since April last year the unelected peer, who has no formal Foreign Office role, has visited eight states: Bahrain, Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Oman, Qatar, Syria and Israel.

When an RAF plane landed at Damascus airport just before midnight earlier this month for the funeral of Syria's president Hafez al-Assad, it carried two representatives of the British government. One was Robin Cook, the foreign secretary; the other was Lord Levy.

Mr Cook is Britain's official representative for foreign affairs, Lord Levy the unofficial go-between. While Mr Cook acts solely for Britain, the peer also works for Ehud Barak, the Israeli prime minister. Questions are being asked about whether it is right that someone can in effect buy their way into international diplomacy.

Sources in Whitehall and Damascus maintain he plays a useful role, his shuttle diplomacy helping bring Syria and Israel together in January for peace talks in Shepherdstown, West Virginia. Yet Lord Levy remains sensitive about domestic criticism of his role. A friend of the peer maintains that his value to Mr Blair is because the prime minister sees him as "someone he could confide in, an objective voice" rather than a fundraiser.

Making his way to the top from a relatively poor background in Hackney, east London, Lord Levy is proud of his title, although he rarely attends debates in the second chamber.

Asked yesterday how one so rich could pay so little in tax, he pointed out that his family's flat did not have a bathroom until he was nine.

Leaving school at 16, Lord Levy qualified as an accountant before moving into the music industry to give us Alvin Stardust, Chris Rea and Bad Manners. He made around £10m when he sold Magnet Records in 1983 and set up M&G Records, sold in 1997 for another considerable sum.

Hostile

He is one of the country's most prominent Jews, giving up the record business to devote himself to raising money for Jewish charities.He is patron or a post holder with 21 charities and trusts, and his support benefits cancer, community and music organisations.

The Foreign Office was initially hostile to Lord Levy's freelance activities, unhappy to see Downing Street pursuing an independent line. Some ambassadors were rash enough to be dismissive of him when he turned up at their embassies. None makes that mistake now: they all know that he is Downing Street's man.

There are repeated reports that Mr Cook and Lord Levy have a poor relationship, so much so that when the two turned up together in a limousine a diplomat asked: "Are they talking?"

Those who know the duo best, however, insist that the relationship is good. Lord Levy and his wife, Gilda, are frequently entertained at Chevening by Mr Cook and his wife, Gaynor.

Peter Hain, a Foreign Office minister, defended the peer. "He is giving up a lot of his energy and personal resources to help the peace process," said Mr Cook's deputy. "That deserves plaudits, not criticism."

webTitle: Tories press for tax check on Robinson

fields.headline: Tories press for tax check on Robinson
fields.standfirst:
Blair faces Commons challenge on legal orders to seize French flats
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives are to demand a full-scale inland revenue investigation into the clouded financial affairs of Geoffrey Robinson in the wake of the Guardian's disclosure that French tax authorities claim he owes them up to £3.6m in tax.
fields.body:
The Conservatives are to demand a full-scale inland revenue investigation into the clouded financial affairs of Geoffrey Robinson in the wake of the Guardian's disclosure that French tax authorities claim he owes them up to £3.6m in tax.

Tony Blair is also expected to face renewed challenges in the Commons over the news that legal orders have been obtained in France to seize two flats in Cannes inherited by the former paymaster general from his Belgian patron, the late Joska Bourgeois.

As the sole beneficiary to the £35m Bourgeois fortune, Mr Robinson has also been held liable for her debts, albeit six years after her death, a detail which puzzles Tory MPs and tax analysts, as well as some Liberal Democrats.

As controversy broke out yesterday over Lord Levy' s tax affairs, Mr Robinson was not available for comment. He left the government two years ago over his private £373,000 home loan to Peter Mandelson, and is expected to publish his memoirs this autumn, probably in technical rather than lurid terms.

But two accountants, David Heathcoat-Amory, the junior Tory Treasury spokesman, and David Shaw, the former MP who advises the shadow trade and industry secretary, Angela Browning, are demanding more detailed answers over his tax affairs, convinced that the long-running story has thrown up more questions than answers.

Taunting Mr Blair with the fact that he, Cherie Booth, Gordon Brown and other leading Labour figures have stayed at the disputed flats, Mr Heathcoat-Amory said last night: "We now know why the prime minister refused to investigate the source of Geoffrey Robinson's money and his tax affairs when he was a Treasury minister."

Mr Shaw, MP for Dover until 1997 and now Tory candidate in Kingston and Surbiton, said last night: "Geoffrey Robinson is very sophisticated in accountancy terms.

"You can see by the way the money moves around the companies he has been involved in."

That is an oblique reference to his days running Jaguar cars, to his complex dealings with Robert Maxwell and to his Guernsey-based trust.

The Tories are not even convinced that Mrs Bourgeois was the prime mover in her own business fortune, which is said to be rooted in the Nissan car franchise in Belgium.

They intend to press the inland revenue to find out what Mr Robinson's capital assets and his income are, where exactly they are located, and who exactly controls the income they generate.

Mr Robinson got into hot water as a minister when it was revealed that he had managed to indicate to the managers of his supposedly blind trust that he wanted it to invest in Coventry football club, his constituency team. It proved to be a wise investment.

With the government on the back foot in recent weeks, questions are also being asked about financial consultants and other firms, many of them household names, being granted lucrative government contracts after seconding staff into Whitehall ministries.

What is known as "revolving door" tactics in Washington DC may be yielding a "staff for favours" system, warned the chairman of the House of Commons public administration committee, Labour's Tony Wright.

fields.headline: Judge: 'strong public interest'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The first Lord Levy knew that his tax affairs were to be splashed all over the Sunday papers was when a fax detailing the allegations arrived at his home from the Sunday Times reporting team at 4.30pm on Friday.
fields.body:
The first Lord Levy knew that his tax affairs were to be splashed all over the Sunday papers was when a fax detailing the allegations arrived at his home from the Sunday Times reporting team at 4.30pm on Friday.

A hard copy was delivered by hand soon after and the Labour peer's lawyers contacted the newspaper at 7pm. Within three hours, they had applied for an injunction at the high court to prevent publication of the claims contained in the article and to gag any reference to the injunction.

The duty judge on call, Mr Justice Toulson, was by chance an expert on confidentiality law and he returned home from a dinner engagement for an 11pm hearing over the telephone between lawyers for both sides, including Lord Grabiner QC, a fellow Labour peer, who acted for Lord Levy.

After an hour of arguments, the judge ruled just before midnight that, although the information about Lord Levy's tax affairs was confidential and private, there was an overriding public interest for it to be made public. He did, however, give Lord Levy permission both to appeal against his ruling and to apply again for an injunction on different grounds if he believed the newspaper article contained a "distortion" of the facts.

The Labour peer took no further action.

The judge said: "My starting point is that an individual's tax affairs are confidential and that he is entitled to have them protected by law unless there is an overriding public consideration to the contrary effect. The way in which it is put on behalf of the Sunday Times is not primarily that there is something objectionable about what Lord Levy is said to have done, though that is part of it."

But he concluded that the newspaper's "principal target" was the government. "The Sunday Times say here is a government which in opposition deplored the current state of affairs and, for example, named Asil Nadir as a beneficiary of that state of affairs and, now that it is in government, it is a taking a different position inferentially because they do not want to upset the people who are the big funders of the Labour party.

"There is a strong public interest in a newspaper being able to advance that, if there is a proper factual foundation for it, and a case like this needs particulars; it cannot be done in generalities. They need to name names and to identify the individuals who are benefiting. It does seem there is a legitimate interest in the public knowing.

"If the individual had nothing to do with the Labour party, I would have inclined to the view that the right to confidentiality should prevail. But if the individual has allied himself to the party to the extent of taking a peerage and taking the Labour whip, then I do see force in the point that his own conduct is a matter of legitimate public reporting.

"In terms of comment on the government's stance, it is relevant and proper to put this before the public. He who actively involves himself in public life, as Lord Levy has, cannot altogether complain if he is caught by the heat.

"I incline to the view on these facts that the Sunday Times ought to be allowed to publish."

webTitle: Making globalisation work for world's poor

fields.headline: Making globalisation work for world's poor
fields.trailText: It takes the death of 58 men and women in an airtight trailer in Dover to bring home the reality of what it is to be an asylum seeker in the 21st century. Far from "sponging off the state", the life of an economic migrant is fraught with risk and can end in a container that becomes a tomb.
fields.body:
It takes the death of 58 men and women in an airtight trailer in Dover to bring home the reality of what it is to be an asylum seeker in the 21st century. Far from "sponging off the state", the life of an economic migrant is fraught with risk and can end in a container that becomes a tomb.

Treating this tragedy as a law and order matter misses the point, because it fails to distinguish between symptom and cause. The conventional wisdom is that governments need to take tougher action against criminal gangs who, for a fee of £10,000 per head, promise that they can smuggle people into the west.

Actually, this case says more about the perils of globalisation than it does about the failings of governments to stamp out crime, highlighting that the liberalisation of capital markets has been accompanied by ever tighter controls on free movement of labour.

Until the debacle in Seattle last December, it was assumed that what was good for Bill Gates and Monsanto was good for everyone. Governments are no longer quite so confident that they are carrying their electorates with them and have been forced to reassess not just what globalisation is, but how it can be shaped to maximise economic welfare.

No virgin territory

Britain's contribution to the debate will be a white paper being prepared by international development secretary Clare Short and due to be published this autumn. A gathering last week discussed how globalisation compared with the previous epoch of economic liberalism in the two decades before the Great War, and what could be done to make globalisation work for the world's poor.

One big difference between now and 100 years ago is that economic migrants from Europe were encouraged to start new lives in the US, southern Africa, Australasia and Latin America. The dislocation and the misery of mass migration should not be minimised, but labour mobility was a shock absorber that gave the international system stability. Today, there is no virgin territory left and governments are wary about granting rights to citizenship now that welfare states are far more wide-ranging than before 1900.

In years to come this approach will look increasingly short-sighted as falling birth rates and the ageing of the baby boomer generation leads to a shortage of prime-age workers in the west. Had they settled in Britain, the 54 men and four women would almost certainly have added to the economy by finding work and paying taxes. As far as the government is concerned, there are lessons to be learned from what went before. The first, which perhaps has to be emphasised after Seattle, is that there really is not any alternative to a market-based economic system.

Lots of the hardline, anti-globalisation protesters are good at saying what they don't like, not so adept at what they envisage once capitalism has been smashed and the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the World Trade Organisation have been reduced to rubble. What it would actually mean is lives that would be - as Hobbes put it - nasty, brutish and short. However, letting markets rip is equally daft. The story of the period 1850 to 1950 is of governments exploring ways of shaping, managing, directing and controlling markets to spread the benefits of growth and to ensure that the risks of economic failure did not all fall on the poorest and weakest.

Progressive taxation, welfare states, health and safety regulations, anti-trust laws, state ownership of key industries were all born out of the sense that wider democracy and ever-greater inequality of income were incompatible. With the gap between rich and poor today widening all the time, the challenges that faced reformers from Shaftesbury to Keynes now face policymakers.

How can a market system - which operates globally as well as nationally - be governed to maximise economic and social welfare? As was said at Ms Short's seminar, the task is much harder than a century ago because nation states exercised more control over their own markets than they now do over global ones.

That is one reason why the good side of internationalism - the spread of ideas, technology transfer, lower costs to consumers - has been accompanied by a dark side - money laundering, drug smuggling, trafficking in prostitution, financial instability. So unless some action is taken to shape globalisation the world will become an even more dangerous and volatile place.

So the third and final lesson for the government is to ignore those who say that the discredited policies of the 1980s and 1990s can do the trick, and that a system of global trickledown will work for rich and poor. This is like people in mid-Victorian Britain trying to pretend that a limited franchise, the defence of property rights and regular crackdowns by the militia would keep the industrial proletariat under control. In fact, it soon became obvious that the alternative to reform was revolution.

Pitifully slow progress

Likewise, it may be tempting for governments in rich, western nations to believe that all will be well - provided the global marketplace is only lightly regulated and poor countries fast-track liberalisation policies. But this would be a mistake. Today the United Nations meets in Geneva to assess progress towards meeting the 2015 development targets set in Copenhagen five years ago.

On each of the three main counts - income poverty, child mortality and universal primary education - results have been pitifully slow and targets will not be met unless governments take more decisive action. There is less unanimity, however, on what should be done. World Bank economists David Dollar and Aart Kraay argue that the main driving force for eliminating poverty is growth, and that there is no real evidence that redistribution has much of an impact. Growth is neutral in its distributional effects, with a 5% increase leading to a 5% increase in incomes for the poor. The trickledown brigade cite this as evidence that those who support managed markets and redistribution are utterly misguided.

But if growth is all you need, and the invisible hand of the market will do the rest, why did poverty in Britain soar in the 1980s and 1990s when liberalisation was all the rage? Why have the past 10 years seen so many financial crises, resulting in governments pursuing anti-growth policies - higher interest rates and fiscal retrenchment - to prevent hot money leaving their shores?

Of course, growth is necessary to lift people out of poverty, but strategies that fail to recognise the need to tackle inequality are actually anti-growth, resulting in the waste of productive potential. As Oxfam's Kevin Watkins puts it: "Highly unequal countries are bad at converting growth into poverty reduction because they have to grow faster than more equal countries to achieve the same level of income gain for the poor." East Asia, where policymakers have pursued egalitarian economic policies, has been far more successful in eradicating poverty than Latin America, where there has been less emphasis on equity.

The events since the devaluation of the Thai baht three years ago this week should act as a wake-up call for governments. We have been living through the first crisis of globalisation, and there is a need for policies to increase the flow of aid, reduce developing country debt, open up protected markets to goods from poor countries and manage capital flows to minimise financial disruption.

Governments should ask not whether they can risk trying to shape and manage global markets, but whether they can risk not doing so.

fields.bodyText: It takes the death of 58 men and women in an airtight trailer in Dover to bring home the reality of what it is to be an asylum seeker in the 21st century. Far from "sponging off the state", the life of an economic migrant is fraught with risk and can end in a container that becomes a tomb. Treating this tragedy as a law and order matter misses the point, because it fails to distinguish between symptom and cause. The conventional wisdom is that governments need to take tougher action against criminal gangs who, for a fee of £10,000 per head, promise that they can smuggle people into the west. Actually, this case says more about the perils of globalisation than it does about the failings of governments to stamp out crime, highlighting that the liberalisation of capital markets has been accompanied by ever tighter controls on free movement of labour. Until the debacle in Seattle last December, it was assumed that what was good for Bill Gates and Monsanto was good for everyone. Governments are no longer quite so confident that they are carrying their electorates with them and have been forced to reassess not just what globalisation is, but how it can be shaped to maximise economic welfare. No virgin territory Britain's contribution to the debate will be a white paper being prepared by international development secretary Clare Short and due to be published this autumn. A gathering last week discussed how globalisation compared with the previous epoch of economic liberalism in the two decades before the Great War, and what could be done to make globalisation work for the world's poor. One big difference between now and 100 years ago is that economic migrants from Europe were encouraged to start new lives in the US, southern Africa, Australasia and Latin America. The dislocation and the misery of mass migration should not be minimised, but labour mobility was a shock absorber that gave the international system stability. Today, there is no virgin territory left and governments are wary about granting rights to citizenship now that welfare states are far more wide-ranging than before 1900. In years to come this approach will look increasingly short-sighted as falling birth rates and the ageing of the baby boomer generation leads to a shortage of prime-age workers in the west. Had they settled in Britain, the 54 men and four women would almost certainly have added to the economy by finding work and paying taxes. As far as the government is concerned, there are lessons to be learned from what went before. The first, which perhaps has to be emphasised after Seattle, is that there really is not any alternative to a market-based economic system. Lots of the hardline, anti-globalisation protesters are good at saying what they don't like, not so adept at what they envisage once capitalism has been smashed and the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the World Trade Organisation have been reduced to rubble. What it would actually mean is lives that would be - as Hobbes put it - nasty, brutish and short. However, letting markets rip is equally daft. The story of the period 1850 to 1950 is of governments exploring ways of shaping, managing, directing and controlling markets to spread the benefits of growth and to ensure that the risks of economic failure did not all fall on the poorest and weakest. Progressive taxation, welfare states, health and safety regulations, anti-trust laws, state ownership of key industries were all born out of the sense that wider democracy and ever-greater inequality of income were incompatible. With the gap between rich and poor today widening all the time, the challenges that faced reformers from Shaftesbury to Keynes now face policymakers. How can a market system - which operates globally as well as nationally - be governed to maximise economic and social welfare? As was said at Ms Short's seminar, the task is much harder than a century ago because nation states exercised more control over their own markets than they now do over global ones. That is one reason why the good side of internationalism - the spread of ideas, technology transfer, lower costs to consumers - has been accompanied by a dark side - money laundering, drug smuggling, trafficking in prostitution, financial instability. So unless some action is taken to shape globalisation the world will become an even more dangerous and volatile place. So the third and final lesson for the government is to ignore those who say that the discredited policies of the 1980s and 1990s can do the trick, and that a system of global trickledown will work for rich and poor. This is like people in mid-Victorian Britain trying to pretend that a limited franchise, the defence of property rights and regular crackdowns by the militia would keep the industrial proletariat under control. In fact, it soon became obvious that the alternative to reform was revolution. Pitifully slow progress Likewise, it may be tempting for governments in rich, western nations to believe that all will be well - provided the global marketplace is only lightly regulated and poor countries fast-track liberalisation policies. But this would be a mistake. Today the United Nations meets in Geneva to assess progress towards meeting the 2015 development targets set in Copenhagen five years ago. On each of the three main counts - income poverty, child mortality and universal primary education - results have been pitifully slow and targets will not be met unless governments take more decisive action. There is less unanimity, however, on what should be done. World Bank economists David Dollar and Aart Kraay argue that the main driving force for eliminating poverty is growth, and that there is no real evidence that redistribution has much of an impact. Growth is neutral in its distributional effects, with a 5% increase leading to a 5% increase in incomes for the poor. The trickledown brigade cite this as evidence that those who support managed markets and redistribution are utterly misguided. But if growth is all you need, and the invisible hand of the market will do the rest, why did poverty in Britain soar in the 1980s and 1990s when liberalisation was all the rage? Why have the past 10 years seen so many financial crises, resulting in governments pursuing anti-growth policies - higher interest rates and fiscal retrenchment - to prevent hot money leaving their shores? webTitle: Blair stays loyal to tax row peer

fields.headline: Blair stays loyal to tax row peer
fields.standfirst:
Lord Levy denies Tory sleaze allegations
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Levy, the multi-millionaire fundraiser for the Labour Party, yesterday vigorously denied any wrongdoing after it was disclosed that last year he paid only £5,000 in tax.
fields.body:
Lord Levy, the multi-millionaire fundraiser for the Labour Party, yesterday vigorously denied any wrongdoing after it was disclosed that last year he paid only £5,000 in tax.

"I have absolutely nothing to hide," said the former music industry tycoon, as Tory MPs piled on the pressure over his modest tax bill and Tony Blair threw a protective arm around him.

The peer broke with his long-standing dislike of personal publicity and toured radio and TV studios to insist that he has always paid his fair share of taxes - and that during 1998/1999, the year in dispute, he lived off post-tax capital.

"As far as I'm concerned, if you've paid your taxes over years and then in a year you choose to live off of a small amount of capital to pay your living expenses, and your money is invested in homes which do not yield income, and you've paid your taxes, what is wrong in that?" he told BBC Radio 4's The World this Weekend.

The Sunday Times had disclosed that Lord Levy's £5,000 basic rate tax bill represented an annual income of about £21,000. Lord Levy sought a high court injunction to prevent the newspaper publishing its findings, but Mr Justice Toulson declared that there was an overriding public interest in the information being made public.

The newspaper did not suggest that the peer had acted unlawfully, but claimed the amount of the tax bill placed a question mark over how much of the 55-year-old peer's considerable wealth, if any, was shielded in the sort of offshore tax avoidance schemes that Labour colleagues criticised so vehemently in opposition.

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, said she thought the public would be bemused by the size of Lord Levy's tax bill.

"Most people on modest incomes who are paying something very similar in tax will look at a man with those sorts of resources and scratch their heads," she said.

Yesterday Lord Levy said he had paid £2.5m in tax when he sold his recording business, Magnet Records, in 1988.

"I paid the tax, I did not take a year out, I did not leave the country like others, I paid the tax and that £2.5 million in 1988 is worth many, many more millions today," said Lord Levy.

Furious that the press had obtained private tax details, Downing Street officials went on the offensive, telling reporters "the prime minister has a high regard for Lord Levy and nothing the Sunday Times has ever produced has caused him to doubt that."

Lord Levy, a friend of the late John Smith and more recently Mr Blair's tennis partner, raised an estimated £7m for Labour - including Bernie Ecclestone's £1m, sent back during the Formula 1 tobacco advertising row - in the run up to the last election to help neutralise the Tory war chest.

Amid rumours that his tax details were obtained by private investigators acting for Arab interests dismayed by Lord Levy's "partisan" role as Mr Blair's personal envoy to the Middle East, the peer said he intended to complain to the Press Complaints Commission.

"I don't think the price one should pay [for being a public figure] is the total invasion of one's privacy," he said. Rounding off a formidable defence of his rags-to-riches CV and his role as a fundraiser for charities like Jewish Care as well as for Labour on Channel 4 News last night Lord Levy declared:"I am very proud of who I am and what I am."

That did not satisfy senior Conservatives, still stung by Labour's sleaze campaign before 1997, or some Labour MPs who demanded greater transparency in the financial affairs of both Lords and Commons.

Led by the shadow chief secretary, David Heathcoat-Amory, and the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, they insisted that Lord Levy's explanation is hard to reconcile with his known wealth or with his lifestyle.

In effect, the Tories argue, it would take very sophisticated tax management to reduce a rich man's income to the point where he only earns £20,000 in a single year. "I think a lot of people will have raised eyebrows, a lot of people on modest incomes who have seen their tax bills (rise) under the Labour party," Mr Maude told GMTV's Sunday programme.

Another senior Tory, racking his brains for an explanation, said: "There must be income from a trust fund somewhere here."

Another Tory accountant volunteered the device known as A and B trusts, one for capital, the other to take the income which the capital generates. At the end of each year the B trust for income is closed and converted into a capital trust - thus avoiding tax. Money is then drawn down as capital.

Lord Levy insisted that 1999 was a unique year in his 35 year business career because he had lived off capital on which tax had already been paid. Working for Labour and his chosen charities had left him little time for business. This year's tax will offer "a very different picture."

"I have most of my capital invested in two very, very nice residences, which don't bring me any income. I have always earned other fees, directors' fees, under PAYE. I started a second business, I sold that in 1997 and then for the next two years I basically lived off capital ."

The capital came from the sale of his summer home in Israel. His other main asset is his pension fund. Over the years he said last night he has paid between £250,000 and £300,000 in an average tax year.

Decrying speculation about elaborate tax shelters he added: "I have never been involved in any way in tax avoidance. I am against it. I am fully behind the chancellor in his attempts to close loopholes" - a current battle in the finance bill at Westminster.

webTitle: TUC gets its due for rise in recruits

fields.headline: TUC gets its due for rise in recruits
fields.trailText: Which country is seeing its trade union movement grow, its workers enjoy better wages, union officials consulted by government and employers, and is getting more citizens off tax-costly welfare rolls and into tax-paying jobs? Great Britain.
fields.body:
Which country is seeing its trade union movement grow, its workers enjoy better wages, union officials consulted by government and employers, and is getting more citizens off tax-costly welfare rolls and into tax-paying jobs? Great Britain.

Which union leader in Europe is preaching flexibility and arguing there is nothing wrong with employees putting in a 50-hour week? Germany.

The TUC is the only movement in the leading European economies recruiting rather than losing members. With 8m, it represents the single biggest group in civil society in Britain.

Yet, according to much of the union movement, this should not be happening. Britain is regularly denounced by the European left as a Trojan horse for US "wild-west" capitalism.

Many UK union leaders share that view, arguing that information and consultation rights or trade unionists on the supervisory boards of companies offer a better model of industrial relations.

However, although France has more nominal employee rights than any other EU nation, this has not stopped Renault from brutally shutting its Vilvoorde plant or Michelin laying off 10,000 workers.

The number of French workers paying dues to a union has declined in inverse proportion to the state substituting itself for worker organisation by legislating rights instead of encouraging workplace organisation. There are now fewer than 1m French workers paying dues to trade unions.

There is an alternative model to the lawyer-driven, rights-based agenda. This is to throw everything at policies which drive towards full employment.

Only full employment provides the social power for working people and their unions to exercise influence instead of lobbying for an ever-growing list of paper rights which look good but are rendered meaningless in a Europe without work for millions.

The founding father of the employment-based drive to labour power remains Wim Kok, the John Monks of Dutch trade unionism in the 1980s.

He unified quarrelsome unions, agreed a wage pact with employers, and encouraged workplace flexibility to get people into work.

The result? By most left indices - low unemployment, good industrial relations, quality public services and health care plus bicycle lanes - the Netherlands is a benchmark nation for Britain's Labour Party and trade unions.

Now Dieter Schulte, leader of the DGB union confederation, the TUC's German equivalent, has signed up for the Kok approach. In an interview in the Bild Zeitung, he said: "The only chance for German unions is to embrace flexibility and discuss annualised working hours and different workplace-based pay systems without letting ideology get in the way."

After two decades in which the main demand of German unions has been for a shorter working week, Schulte told his 8m members: "Perhaps we also have to allow a 50-hour-week when it is necessary." The DGB, once Europe's most numerous trade union federation, has sunk to represent little more than a quarter of the German workforce.

After 20 years of hoping that globalisation might go away there are signs that unions in Europe are beginning to work with the trend of real, existing labour markets. Flexibility is the key to a successful economy based on today's consumer-driven demand.

EU social rule-makers have to understand the lesson that unions do best when everyone is at work.

One size fits all regulation will not help the unemployed into work, nor help unions grow again and regain influence to promote members' real not theoretical interests. Europe's new challenge is not to draw up endless charters of rights but to organise working people into unions.

 Denis MacShane is Labour MP for Rotherham and co-author with Professor Chris Brewster of Making Flexibility Work (Fabian Society, 11 Dartmouth Street, London SW1; £10). He is a former international trade union official

webTitle: Citibank makes e-business operations one unit

fields.headline: Citibank makes e-business operations one unit
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Citigroup, the US financial conglomerate, is to unite all its corporate and investment banking e-commerce operations into a new e-business unit.
fields.body:
Citigroup, the US financial conglomerate, is to unite all its corporate and investment banking e-commerce operations into a new e-business unit.

While an announcement about the operation, which could boost the group's share price, is not expected for several weeks, it is being put together by one of the bank's vice presidents, Jorge Bermudez.

The unit is being known internally as e-Business and early details suggest the operation will also include Citigroup's worldwide e-commerce businesses.

The news follows a flurry of announcements from the group about internet-style deals. Among the recent initiatives was the creation of a global corporate smart card programme using Sun's Java Card technology.

The idea behind this plan is to irradicate the need for multiple credit and payment cards and authentication of customers' identity over the internet. Other projects have also involved tie-ups with other technology firms, such as SAP in a deal which will allow Citibank's payment systems for its business customers to be accessed via the on-line ordering service - known as business to business procurement - included in SAP's software.

The decision to group all e-commerce business into one unit is designed to make it easier for Citigroup's corporate and institutional clients to access all its e-business technology and applications.

Citigroup last night confirmed the plan. "It is evolving," a spokesperson said.

webTitle: Rival bid rumours overshadow EMI investors' meeting

fields.headline: Rival bid rumours overshadow EMI investors' meeting
fields.trailText: A shareholders' meeting at music publisher EMI today to approve the company's merger with Warner Music of the US will be overshadowed by continued speculation that a rival bidder may attempt to spoil the deal.
fields.body:
A shareholders' meeting at music publisher EMI today to approve the company's merger with Warner Music of the US will be overshadowed by continued speculation that a rival bidder may attempt to spoil the deal.

EMI insiders yesterday remained puzzled by the rumours, which have identified an international consortium as the source of a potential bid.

Reports have named US private equity firm Hicks Muse, Spanish telecoms business Telefonica, German media group Bertelsmann and Hong Kong's Pacific Century Cyberworks. An EMI statement on Friday said it had received no approach and sought clarification on the source from the takeover panel.

If approved, the £12bn merger of Warner EMI will create the world's largest music publisher, with a roster of artists including Madonna, the Spice Girls, Robbie Williams and Janet Jackson.

The deal also unites EMI's content with the internet distribution of AOL, which announced its merger with Time Warner, owner of Warner Music, at the start of the year.

The agreement between Warner and EMI met with initial disquiet when announced. Some investors expressed concerns about the structure of the deal, which will see EMI continue as a separately listed holding company for its 50% interest in the merged business.

EMI shareholders will receive a 100p special dividend on completion of the deal.

But Merrill Lynch Investment Management, EMI's largest shareholder, was among those lending the company its support at the end of last week, and it has indicated that it will vote its 7% in favour of the deal at the extraordinary general meeting in London.

The deal has already been shaken by the start of competition inquiries by US and European regulators concerned about the control the merged entity would have in the music publishing market.

fields.headline: Vodafone under pressure
fields.standfirst: Plea to settle row with Brown as details of tax avoidance plan emerge
fields.trailText: Vodafone Airtouch, Europe's biggest company, hatched an intricate tax avoidance plan, involving a Luxembourg holding company with a financing arm based in Switzerland, to deny the British and German governments hundreds of millions of pounds in tax each year, according to sources with a close knowledge of the mobile phone group's finances.
fields.body:
Vodafone Airtouch, Europe's biggest company, hatched an intricate tax avoidance plan, involving a Luxembourg holding company with a financing arm based in Switzerland, to deny the British and German governments hundreds of millions of pounds in tax each year, according to sources with a close knowledge of the mobile phone group's finances.

New details of the tax scheme, first exposed by the Guardian earlier this month, have emerged as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is due to publish a report today slamming the activities of 35 off- shore financial centres around the world and at the same time identifying the precise Swiss-Luxembourg tax dodge planned by Vodafone as a prime example of unacceptable avoidance.

Vodafone is believed to have been ready to transfer Mannesmann, which it acquired for £90bn this year in the world's largest hostile takeover bid, into the Luxembourg vehicle and then finance its operations through Switzerland. The bulk of the division's profits would then have avoided regular German and British corporate tax.

But the move was scuppered by chancellor Gordon Brown, who used the budget to crack down on the misuse of so- called controlled foreign companies. A furious Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, subsequently threatened to move the company to a more lax fiscal jurisdiction, such as Ireland, unless the measure was repealed.

Debate over the validity of Vodafone's complaint has been clouded by a parallel budget measure affecting multinational companies, involving a clampdown on the misuse of so-called mixer companies. These have been used in the past to smooth profits flowing from various high and low tax jurisdictions before they entered Britain to be taxed at a uniform rate.

In fact, it has now become clear Vodafone was simply exploiting a loophole that potentially could have cut billions of pounds from its tax bill.

One of Vodafone's institutional investors said at the weekend: "We are concerned at the way this whole issue is still festering. What looked at first like a regular, if robust lobbying effort, has become personalised and overly aggressive."

The fund management industry has always been suspicious of companies enjoying what look like artificially low tax charges and in the past this showed through in the ratings of companies like Hanson and BTR.

"We will be urging Mr Gent to settle this matter with some urgency," said the investor.

Vodafone itself declined to comment, other than stating that discussions with the gov ernment were continuing. Luxembourg is seen as one financial centre which will have to reform its secretive banking regime if the EU's plan to crack down on tax dodging by individuals across the continent, agreed at last week's summit in Portugal as an alternative to an EU withholding tax, is to stand any chance of success.

For many years, Germany has struggled to stem the flow of money over the border to Luxembourg, eroding the government's tax yield there.

Tax investigators have always met a wall of silence in Luxembourg when trying to trace funds, although the authorities have now promised to support a new continent-wide framework for sharing information .

webTitle: Crackdown on dodgers puts havens on probation

fields.headline: Crackdown on dodgers puts havens on probation
fields.trailText: The Isle of Man, Gibraltar and the Channel Islands are among 35 offshore financial centres which are today put on probation by rich industrialised nations under suspicion of harbouring of tax dodgers. Unless they show willingness to reform, they will face the threat of sanctions which could undermine their business.
fields.body:
The Isle of Man, Gibraltar and the Channel Islands are among 35 offshore financial centres which are today put on probation by rich industrialised nations under suspicion of harbouring of tax dodgers. Unless they show willingness to reform, they will face the threat of sanctions which could undermine their business.

The move marks the latest stage of a clampdown by the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development, which is leading the fight to tackle tax evasion by rich individuals and corporations.

At the start of the OECD's annual ministerial meeting in Paris, member governments will publish a list of 35 offshore locations which meet the technical criteria of being a tax haven, defined as places that offer zero or low tax rates but lack legal and administrative transparency.

To avoid the charge of double standards, the OECD will also identify 47 potentially harmful tax regimes and practices within its membership, including Luxembourg holding companies.

The Guardian has learnt that the list of offshore centres will include a number of British dependencies, namely the Channel Is lands, Isle of Man, Gibraltar, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat, the Turks and Caicos islands and Anguilla. Also on it will be the US Virgin Islands, Somoa, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Antigua and the Dutch Antilles.

A source said inclusion on the list represented an invitation to the governments concerned to engage in a constructive dialogue with the OECD. If, by next July, an offshore centre has refused to cooperate, it will be placed on blacklist and face the threat of sanctions.The UK government has been encouraged by the willingness shown by some of its dependencies to make their financial systems more open and transparent. Bermuda and the Cayman Islands are among six offshore centres which will escape inclusion on today's list by pledging to reform and the Isle of Man has also made steps in the right di rection, according to a UK source. But, in theory, the fiscal independence of UK territories means that they could be be subjected to punitive action by the British government.

One of the main concerns is that many offshore centres lack agreements to exchange information about suspected tax dodgers to allow other countries to investigate their own nationals.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Passenger hits head on tunnel
fields.body:
Passenger hits head on tunnel

A father of two was back home yesterday after he survived smashing his head against the Balcombe tunnel when he leaned out the window of the 11pm London Victoria to Brighton train travelling at 60mph.

Dave Carter was found unconscious in the carriage by a guard and taken to the Princess Royal hospital in West Sussex.

His wife, Laura, said she picked up the phone at home to find herself connected to an open line on his mobile. In the background she heard people talking about how he was lying in a pool of blood.

Foot power drives mobiles

Jim Gilbert, a lecturer from Hull University, has designed shoes that power a mobile phone as you walk. They will also power personal stereos, computers, and navigation systems.

Dr Gilbert came up with the electric shoes in answer to a challenge from Trevor Bayliss - whose inventions include the clockwork radio. Next week the shoes undergo testing before going into production by Mr Bayliss's firm - the Electric Shoe Company.

Elderly women impaled

Two women aged 78 and 82 were fighting for their lives in the Coventry and Warwickshire hospital yesterday after being impaled on railings when struck by an out-of-control car.

The couple were hurled on to the garden wall railings by the impact of the collision. Firefighters and paramedics battled for 45 minutes to free them. They were conscious throughout.

One winner scoops jackpot

One ticket holder won Saturday night's £7,033,499 National Lottery jackpot for matching numbers 6, 9, 32, 34, 42 and 48. The bonus number was 4.

fields.headline: The weighting game
fields.standfirst:
Germany has the same number of votes in the council of ministers as France and the UK, with their smaller populations. Is this fair?

The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The capacity of the Germans to strongarm Tony Blair into deeper and faster European integration is directly proportional to the strength of the axis across the Rhine between Germany and France. But that key relationship is, as the French assume the presidency of the European Union, in quite a state.
fields.body:
The capacity of the Germans to strongarm Tony Blair into deeper and faster European integration is directly proportional to the strength of the axis across the Rhine between Germany and France. But that key relationship is, as the French assume the presidency of the European Union, in quite a state.

It is partly a matter of linguistic pride. French politicians have been falling over themselves to respond to the vision of Europe's future set out by Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, in a "private" (ie unofficial) colloquy a month ago. For the French the problem is that Fischer talks their language all too well - grand, historical, utopian. We need a revolution "against the ancien regime of Brussels", says Mr Fischer, replacing it with a president and fully representative parliament. There is an alternative to centralism within the EU and it is a version of the division of powers exhibited in Germany's postwar settlement: the subordinate jurisdictions (formerly nation states) have their position entrenched by a formal constitution which we must start writing now.

The French have been both stirred and horrified. Mr Fischer is only saying what is close to official doctrine in Paris - his recipe bears a marked resemblance to the "Manifesto for Europe" written by Jerome Monod and Ali Magoudi, the first of these a close adviser of President Jacques Chirac. But Jean-Pierre Chevènement, interior minister in Lionel Jospin's socialist-led coalition, says the German love affair with European federalism is a paradoxical sign they are still political juveniles. Unless they come to terms with nation statehood (adopting a post-Nazi nationalism) they may be unreliable.

Beneath the rhetoric there are some large practical reasons why Franco-German unity is not quite what it would need to be to make Tony Blair fear being pushed into a federalist corner by Gerhard Schröder (whose own relationship with Mr Fischer is far from clear).

The first of these is a straightforward question of primacy within the EU.

Between now and year's end the French are obliged to try to get the governance of Europe into a shape fit for enlargement and write a treaty of Nice. Günter Verheugen, EU commissioner responsible for expansion, is talking about giving the Poles, Czechs and other front-rank candidates "concrete proposals on dates". What that implies is that by, say, 2004 institutions will exist to make an EU with 20 members viable. They don't yet.

The council of ministers - the EU's ultimate decision-maker - works on the basis of 87 virtual votes. If existing rules persisted, the Poles would get eight of them, the Czechs and Hungarians five each, the Slovenians three, and so on. So the arithmetic would alter for what constitutes a blocking minority and a qualified majority. And that would throw into relief the peculiar link between votes and population. When it had six members, a valid majority in the European Economic Community represented 68% of its population; in the EU the majority is only 58%. Needless to say these figures are going to become more controversial as the volume of business transacted under majority voting increases - as it must if enlargement takes place. There is a subsidiary but teasing question of voting for policies that will be considered for "enhanced cooperation" (allowing groups of countries to go ahead on their own).

The rules are odd. Germany has 82m people but enjoys the same number of votes as the UK, France and Italy with their considerably smaller populations. Sweden has a 10th of Germany's people but nearly half its votes. At accession the Polish population would be about half Germany's but the Poles would be entitled to four-fifths of Germany's vote.

Here the Fischer rhetoric breaks on the rocks of power mongering. The Schröder government wants more fairness, as well it might. Germany qualifies for the largest representation in the European parliament (99 members) on the basis of its size, so why not in the council of ministers? The reweighting of votes in the council of ministers suddenly becomes a necessary condition of movement. And that is still to leave on the shelf the vexed question of how many commissioners there should be and what sort of relationship there should be between their national identity and national size. There are now 28; big members have a right to two; the commission is already unwieldy.

France - this was said recently by Europe minister Pierre Moscovici - will not accept fewer votes than Germany in the council of ministers "because France is also a big country". His colleague, foreign minister Hubert Védrine rightly says the voting question is fundamental: without agreement what is the point in speculating how Europe would look in a decade or 20 years' time?

These voting weights are not private matters for anoraks in Brussels seminars. These are precisely what the exercise in constitution writing envisaged by Joschka Fischer would have to address in detail - especially the relationship between demography and democracy. As for the UK, there are officials, perhaps Blairite ministers, too, who are none too keen on re-weighting. Keeping Germany "small" is, after all, a long term ambition of many in the establishment.

Existing rules make it more likely that the UK could combine with the Scandinavians or the Iberians to secure a veto. Such negativism, as ever, typifies UK thinking about Europe's future.
