fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Japanese investment bank Nomura has set its sights on a bid for the defence sector's second-largest group, BAE Systems , a deal that would rank among the most controversial in recent City history.

New laws should be passed to protect the Co-op from hostile bids such as the raid launched by entrepreneur Andrew Regan three years ago, according to the TUC . The unions also argue that a two-tier board should be set up and that the Co-op should move into into housing, care provision and financial services.

Sunday Telegraph

The price of oil will collapse in the next five years and the "oil age" come to an end, according to former Saudi oil minister Sheikh Yamani . He predicts that advances in technology and new oil field discoveries will lead to "a future crash in the price of oil".

Rover has warned suppliers that it is planning to halve car production at its Longbridge plant later this year to less than 52,000. John Towers, the former Rover boss who lead the Phoenix bid, has said that he would preserve volume output at Longbridge.

Greg Hutchings is preparing to split his roles as chairman and chief executive of Tomkins , the industrial group, and allow the company to appoint a non- executive chairman to silence recent attempts by institutional shareholders to unseat him.

Sunday Business

NM Rothschild's Internationational Biotechnology Trust director Jeremy Curnock Cook is facing allegations of a conflict of interest in his personal holdings in its investments. Sunday Business said it obtained a confidential document sent by shareholder Millennium Partners to other investors alleging that Mr Curnock Cook may have derived personal benefit from his directorships in companies in which IBT invested. The paper cited the document as saying the potential profit to Mr Curnock Cook was at least £145,000. An IBT official denied there was a conflict of interest.

Ford has discovered losses of up to £60m at Land Rover , which it bought last month from BMW for £1.9bn. Ford found evidence of "unbelievable commercial neglect" during the final years of ownership by BMW, which was "very poor at managing costs", the paper cited a Ford source as saying.

Sunday Times

Bill Clinton is about to wage a US legal assault on Airbus , the European aircraft group, which on Friday heralded the launch of a super jumbo that will break Boeing 's historic monopoly in the jumbo jet market. The launch of the A3XX triggered an offensive by Mr Clinton at the US summit with EU leaders this month. Mr Clinton is understood to have told the Europeans the US government would not stand idly by and allow them to subsidise the A3XX inappropriately.

Carphone Warehouse is set to strengthen its board with the appointment of two outside directors as it prepares to float this week. Des Wilson , retiring as director of corporate and public affairs for BAA, is becoming a non-executive, as is John Gildersleeve , the Tesco director who heads the grocery chain's non-food operations.

IoS

Labour peer Lord Simpson of Dunkeld has earned more than £14m in his four years running Marconi - but the company has decided that this is not enough. The former Rover boss is to benefit from a review of Marconi's share option policy, launched because the group fears it is underpaying its staff.

Mail on Sunday

Drinks group Diageo has admitted it has to start planning the sale of its US foods business Pillsbury after years of resisting pressure to break it up, say insiders.

Sunday Express

Coca Cola and Pepsi are going head to head to pluck the £60m sponsorship deal of the Premiership from Bass Brewer's Carling.

fields.headline: Hooray for Lord Levy
fields.standfirst:
Or at least for the judge who exposed him
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: One might imagine that there is little cause for celebration in the weekend travails of Michael Levy. Surely only the Tories could draw pleasure from the case of a millionaire Labour peer exposed for having paid just £5,000 in taxes to the inland revenue last year.
fields.body:
One might imagine that there is little cause for celebration in the weekend travails of Michael Levy. Surely only the Tories could draw pleasure from the case of a millionaire Labour peer exposed for having paid just £5,000 in taxes to the inland revenue last year. For them the delight is obvious: they have already begun to use Lord Levy the way they used the tangled business affairs of the former Treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson - as evidence of Labour hypocrisy. This is the government, cry the Conservatives, which is happy to slap taxes on all of us - only to keep their own money to themselves. In the time-honoured, crowd-pleasing slogan: "It's one rule for us, another rule for them."

The specifics are even more prickly for Labour. The party condemned tax avoidance schemes in opposition, yet now it faces the charge that its richest supporters have somehow found ways to keep their own tax bills down to the bare minimum. For that reason, there will be no smiles on Labour faces at this twist of events. The party did so well by identifying the last government with sleaze that it has created an extra-high standard for itself to be judged by: Labour has to be whiter than white. Luckily, not even Lord Levy's accusers suggest he did anything illegal or even improper to get his tax bill down to pocket change levels. We should be clear: this is not sleaze in the Tory sense of the word. But any financial question mark over Labour is damaging, including this one.

The millionaire himself is bound to be the most cheerless of all this morning. He will be embarrassed to have had his financial arrangements laid out for all to see, humiliated to have to go on the radio to protest that he grew up in a flat with no inside WC. As it turns out, he defended himself quite ably yesterday: he said that he paid such low taxes because he didn't earn any money last year. He'd invested all his cash in property, which pays no interest. Lord Levy may also be helped by speculation that his tax returns were somehow eased into public view by those hostile to his efforts at mediation in the Middle East: they may be hoping that a tainted Lord Levy will be less effective as the prime minister's personal envoy to the region. In a perverse way, that is a compliment to his efforts.

Still, despite all the aggravation this expose will have brought Lord Levy and the government, all friends of democracy and an open society have cause for celebration in this episode. It is not the conduct of the Labour peer we should applaud - but rather the actions of the High Court judge who brought it to light. At midnight on Friday, Mr Justice Coulson issued what could well be a ground-breaking ruling. Lord Levy had sought to gag the Sunday Times, which had obtained his tax records, but the judge found in favour of the paper. "He who actively involves himself in public life, as Lord Levy has, cannot altogether complain if he is caught by the heat," he said.

Let those words be emblazoned in bold type in every newsroom in the land. For they amount to a statement of a concept that British law so sorely lacks: a public interest defence. Ever since the landmark Sullivan ruling of 1964, the US has been clear that a free press has a right and even a duty to report on matters of public import. No such right has existed in British law. Yet Mr Justice Toulson effectively bowed to that concept in his judgment. He said that if Lord Levy had been a purely private citizen, his right to confidentiality would have been paramount. But as a Labour eminence, his conduct was "a matter of legitimate public reporting".

That view is precisely our own. We have long advocated a proper respect for the privacy of individuals where there is no public interest - to be balanced by a legally enshrined right to report on the publicly-relevant conduct of public figures. This is just such a case and we applaud Mr Justice Toulson for seeing it.

webTitle: Undercover reporter a hit with viewers and executives

fields.headline: Undercover reporter a hit with viewers and executives
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC's annual report last week singled out MacIntyre Undercover for fulsome praise: it "bore the hallmarks of British innovation and quality at the heart of the BBC1 schedule", wrote the corporation's chairman, Sir Christopher Bland.
fields.body:
The BBC's annual report last week singled out MacIntyre Undercover for fulsome praise: it "bore the hallmarks of British innovation and quality at the heart of the BBC1 schedule", wrote the corporation's chairman, Sir Christopher Bland.

Under the heading "editorial standards", the programme was hailed as a demonstration of how investigative journalism can "use careful editorial judgment to produce bold and controversial programming".

But while the programme may have been a hit with BBC executives and viewers, senior BBC journalists have been expressing disquiet about MacIntyre's methods.

The show's investigations each cost around £300,000 - roughly three editions of Panorama - and enjoyed the full backing of the BBC's publicity machine. MacIntyre was held up as the future of popular current affairs, even though the programme was made by the BBC's documentaries section.

Now, of the four which have been broadcast - a fifth was never shown - three appear not to have lived up to the hype which surrounded their broadcast.

Mr MacIntyre's pedigree on ITV's World in Action impressed the BBC, which signed him to pep up its factual output. His methods were cutting edge: he made covert filming his modus operandi.

The first programme to be broadcast was billed as a expose of football hooliganism, with MacIntyre immersing himself in the violent world of the Chelsea Headhunters, one of Britain's most notorious hooligan gangs. It was a dream start for the team: two of the men featured in the programme were subsequently arrested and charged with conspiracy to commit violent disorder.

The production team's next target was the seedier side of the modelling industry, with MacIntyre posing as a photographer to infiltrate a world of underage sex and hard drugs. Gerald Marie, European president of the world's top model agency, Elite, was shown offering an undercover model £300 for sex, while Xavier Moreau, president of the Elite model look contest, was heard to make a racist remark. Both executives resigned and two other employees were suspended.

But it was not long before the accusers became the accused. After first holding up its hands, Elite claimed the programme, while embarrassing, was "biased and flawed". The two executives were reinstated.

The third programme centred on the Gillingham care home, while for the final edition MacIntyre turned his attention to criminals making a fortune out of advanced fee fraud, where victims are persuaded to part with their cash on the promise of spectacular financial returns. Inevitably it transpires the unwitting victims lose their cash.

The weekend's allegations surrounding MacIntyre's methods have sent shockwaves through the BBC which, from Greg Dyke down, had hailed him as the saviour of investigative journalism.

Questions have been raised about how the BBC is regulated: the ITV company Carlton was fined £2m by the independent television commission when it was found to have faked scenes in a documentary about the drugs trade. Although the BBC has not been accused of faking scenes, it is not subject to such strict external regulation.

fields.headline: Farce work
fields.standfirst:
Glasgow counts cost of controversy after Tyson ends fight in 38 seconds
Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: It was a swift left uppercut that finally brought Glasgow to its senses.
fields.body:
It was a swift left uppercut that finally brought Glasgow to its senses.

Fourteen seconds after the first bell, Mike Tyson swung and Lou Savarese hit the floor, taking with him any hope that the most hyped fight in Scottish boxing history might have been worthy of the farce and fallout that preceded it. Political uproar; a legal challenge; an unpaid jewellery bill; an alleged assault; and rows of empty seats at Hampden Park.

Those who had kept faith through the controversy said they felt cheated. Some fans had not had the chance to sit down before the fight ended after 38 seconds.

"It was a complete farce," said Stuart Burns, 28, from Irvine, as he left Hampden Park on Saturday night. "Frank Warren should be ashamed of himself."

"I'm absolutely gutted," said Jabed Mahmood, 24, of Leeds. "I paid £500 for my ticket."

Yesterday, as the Tyson bandwagon rolled out of town, trailing fresh controversy over Tyson's verbal abuse of Lennox Lewis, Glasgow was left counting the cost of the show that wasn't.

Promoters had predicted a £30m bonanza for the city, but commercial analysts say the figure is likely to be closer to £3m. Hoteliers reported a string of cancellations as the expected hordes of fight fans failed to materialise. Only around 15,000 people attended the fight on the night, less than half the number predicted.

The Scottish National party leader, Alex Salmond, said the government should be ashamed of its decision to allow Tyson in for the fight.

"The so-called economic benefits - on which Jack Straw based his disgraceful decision to let convicted rapist Tyson into Scotland - proved to be totally illusory," he said. "The attempt to bribe people in Scotland was fool's gold.

"The fight was a total farce, a complete mismatch which brought no credit to anyone involved. Women's groups and the Scottish parliament were absolutely right to oppose it. It would have been far better all round if it had never taken place."

The Glasgow Rape Crisis Centre, which was unsuccessful in its legal attempt to block Tyson's entry to Britain, staged a protest outside the contest. Representatives said they were pleased that the crowds had stayed away.

The centre still faces a legal fight with the promoter, Frank Warren, over the costs of its action. Mr Warren had indicated that he might try to recoup costs after the centre lost its case.

Mr Warren, meanwhile, said he was very concerned at reports that Tyson had promised to rip out Lennox Lewis's heart and "eat his children".

Still refusing to be drawn on allegations that Tyson had attacked him over an unpaid bill for some diamond jewellery, Mr Warren said he felt the boxer's performance in the ring had been "devastating".

"When Tyson hits you, you go, it doesn't matter who you are," he said.

But Mr Warren told reporters that he would have to think about whether he would promote Tyson again.

"Contrary to what people think, money isn't everything," he said.

webTitle: BBC in the dock over care home inquiry

fields.headline: BBC in the dock over care home inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Police threaten to claw back £50,000 spent investigating allegations made by MacIntyre Undercover
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The credibility of BBC journalism was on the line last night after police threatened to claw back £50,000 spent on a largely fruitless criminal inquiry into allegations made by the MacIntyre Undercover investigations programme.
fields.body:
The credibility of BBC journalism was on the line last night after police threatened to claw back £50,000 spent on a largely fruitless criminal inquiry into allegations made by the MacIntyre Undercover investigations programme.

Donal MacIntyre mounted a strong defence of his investigation into practices at a care home, threatening to sue the newspaper which revealed the police concerns. The home at the centre of the row joined police in pledging legal action against the corporation.

Last November's programme claimed that there was a "culture of neglect" at the Kent care home, which was forced to close with the loss of 80 jobs amid the ensuing public outcry. But after a protracted investigation costing at least £50,000, detectives found no evidence to press charges. Kent police accused the BBC of being "out of touch and arrogant" for refusing to consider it may have misled viewers.

Questions have also been raised about the conduct of Medway social services, which moved to close the Brompton Home in Gillingham the day after the programme was broadcast. The Guardian understands that investigators gave the home, which cared for people with serious psychological problems, a clean bill of health just before the documentary went out.

For his investigation, Mr MacIntyre posed as a care worker at the home, and used a hidden camera to film the way patients were being treated.

His programme accused staff of routine neglect, and showed incidents in which patients appeared to be mistreated. Police launched an investigation: a team of eight detectives worked full-time for several months, at a cost of more than £50,000.

Editing row

Officers, who viewed 41 hours and 20 minutes of video tape provided by the BBC, claimed that unused footage often gave a different perspective to events described on screen. According to the Sunday Telegraph, acting detective inspector Mick Costello accused programme makers of misrepresentation: critical footage had been cut, while sequences shot several hours apart were spliced together in misleading ways, he alleged.

Claims by the programme that staff employed restraint methods which could result in death, and allegations that carers physically threatened patients, were not substantiated by the footage, police said. By the time their investigation was com plete, two people had been cautioned for minor assaults.

A Kent police spokesman described its attempt to recover its costs was serious and unprecedented. He said that it had felt duty-bound to launch an investigation, and detectives initially regarded the programme as credible. "If an organisation with the reputation of the BBC makes allegations like these we have to take them very seriously," he added.

The force had put its concerns to the BBC, but met with an unsatisfactory response. "Their attitude has verged on disdain and contempt," the spokesman said. "They seem to regard themselves as unaccountable to anyone. They should be accountable to the 80 people who have lost their jobs, the people who have been moved and the distress it has caused to their families, and to us, for having spent time, money and effort on something where none of the allegations were substantiated. This must at least raise questions about the BBC's commitment to accuracy and fairness."

Jill Dargan, who was matron at the home when Mr MacIntyre worked there, said that staff had been devastated by the "vicious editing" of the programme "There were incidents of isolated abuse, and of course one incident of abuse is too many. But it was an extremely good home, the vast majority of the clients were happy and settled and made huge progress while they were there."

Ron Neal, chairman of the Brompton Home, said last night that its parent company had decided to take legal advice with a view to suing the BBC, and would lodge a complaint this week with the broadcasting standards commission.

Mr MacIntyre, speaking to the Guardian, defended the programme. "We robustly defend the work in the strongest possible terms and we have nothing to reprimand ourselves over. I will stand by this programme, which I am personally very proud of, to my grave."

Police responsibility

The BBC added last night: "The article in the Sunday Telegraph contains damaging inaccuracies which, had they taken the time to check with us properly, we could have refuted. Those concerned are considering issuing legal proceedings for defamation against the Sunday Telegraph."

Earlier, the corporation pointed out that MacIntyre Undercover had never sought to prove criminality. "The culture of neglect and insensitivity in the Brompton care home was there to be seen on the screen," a spokeswoman said. The decision to launch a criminal investigation was taken by Kent police: "They were seeking to establish whether criminal assaults had been committed. We set out to highlight a social care issue."

The director of Medway social services, Anne Windiate, was reported as saying she would not have closed the home so quickly if she had been aware of the circumstances surrounding the film.

Yesterday, a spokesman for Medway council declined to comment about the documentary and its own investigation.

fields.headline: £2m bonus for dome staff
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: Management and staff at the Millennium Dome are to receive more than £2m in bonus payments despite the attraction's financial crisis.
fields.body:
Management and staff at the Millennium Dome are to receive more than £2m in bonus payments despite the attraction's financial crisis.

The revelation that dome staff are to receive performance-related bonus payments - with the four board directors, including the ousted chief executive Jennie Page, eligible to share up to £500,000 - came as ministers announced that the future of the dome is to be decided in a fortnight.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, will chair a meeting on July 10, also attended by Lord Falconer, min ister with responsibility for the dome, to decide which of the two shortlisted buyers, Legacy plc and Dome Europe, will take over the site with an estimated price tag of £100m.

The government is under pressure to cut the dome losses - now £110m - after a barrage of criticism over the decision to grant a further £29m to the attraction.

A spokesman for the dome - which is expecting its three millionth visitor this week - yesterday dismissed reports that almost £6m had been set aside for bonus payments to staff, but confirmed the figure came to more than £2m.

The spokesman said the payouts were retention bonuses to ensure staff would stay to the end of their fixed-term contracts and would be made despite a round of cutbacks, including the axing of "land trains" for elderly and disabled people, and a decision to abandon late opening during the summer.

The dome's four board directors, including Ms Page, are eligible to share a maximum of £500,000 in performance-related bonuses, while 350 managers will receive payments based on length of service.

The 900 dome "hosts" will receive less, around 10% of their salaries, with under £1.25m set aside for them.

The spokesman added: "The figures that have been quoted are ridiculously over-hyped. Everyone who has worked on this project has worked between two and three times the hours they are paid for."

The Greenwich attraction has been dogged by financial problems. Despite receiving £449m of national lottery money, the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, was granted an extra £60m, and another £29m last month.

Among the options to be considered by ministers will be an early sale, perhaps as soon as September, allowing the new owners to take over the dome before the closing ceremony on January 1 next year.

webTitle: Chaos fear over French air strike

fields.headline: Chaos fear over French air strike
fields.trailText: Travellers are today facing transport chaos as French air traffic controllers are due to start a 24-hour strike.
fields.body:
Travellers are today facing transport chaos as French air traffic controllers are due to start a 24-hour strike.

The action was to have begun at 5am, bringing virtually all British flights to and from France to a standstill.

British Airways, British Midland, and buzz have already announced cancellations, with Ryanair saying that cancellations are likely.

They also warn that delays may occur to other routes which fly into French airspace and that disruptions could continue tomorrow.

Last week thousands of passengers were stranded when the computer at the flight control centre at Heathrow failed. It was the second breakdown of the computer in eight days.

The latest hitch in travel plans has been caused by controllers protesting at European Union plans, which they claim will lead to the privatisation of their jobs.

BA predicts that about 50% of its services flying over France today may be delayed. All airlines have made contin gency plans and set up helplines for customers who need to travel to France.

A BA spokesman said: "Our advice is that if customers can avoid flying, they should do so, and we will issue alternative tickets."

He said that the company was hoping to get some customers transferred to Eurostar, and to get larger aircraft to fly to destinations near France, then transfer people overland.

He added: "On Tuesday, we plan to send larger aircraft to France to bring back anybody who is stranded."

Routes to Bordeaux, Lyons, Marseilles and Paris by buzz have been cancelled.

A spokesman said: "Buzz is in the process of contacting all flyers booked on their affected routes to advise them of cancellations.

"The airline is providing all flyers, regardless of fare type, with the option to re-book."

A Ryanair spokesman advised passengers to contact them about possible cancellation and the chances of making alternative travel arrangements to Europe.

webTitle: Straw plea to China on migrants

fields.headline: Straw plea to China on migrants
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has opened talks with the Chinese government on sending back more than 400 Chinese asylum seekers who arrive in Britain each month.
fields.body:
Jack Straw has opened talks with the Chinese government on sending back more than 400 Chinese asylum seekers who arrive in Britain each month.

The number of Chinese asylum seekers coming to Britain is second only to those from Sri Lanka. But the refusal of the Beijing government to take back Chinese nationals who have destroyed their documents has blocked attempts by the immigration authorities to remove hundreds of failed Chinese asylum seekers from Britain.

The home secretary revealed yesterday that he was negotiating with officials in Beijing to ensure that they could be sent back. His comments came less than a week after 58 Chinese people attempting to enter Britain illegally were found dead in a Dutch lorry in Dover.

"We are doing a lot of work with the Chinese government to encourage them to work with us much more constructively, so that once people are refused asylum in this country who have come from China we can get them back," he told the BBC's Breakfast With Frost.

"I know there is some argument about human rights in China but 99% of the Chinese who come here have suffered no human rights abuses whatever. They are simply economic migrants who are brought here by criminal gangs and they need to go back as quickly as possible."

More than 900 asylum seekers from China arrived in Britain in March and April. A Home Office spokesman said yesterday that the talks were being held to overcome the problem that China was reluctant to provide identity documents to those who had destroyed their own papers.

Mr Straw revealed his plans for a tougher regime for Chi nese asylum seekers as senior police officers were preparing for an Interpol meeting in the Hague today where it is expected that MI6 and Britain's national crime squad will agree to play a leading role in a new international elite force to combat the growing criminal trade of people trafficking.

"The tragic incident at Dover further concentrates all our minds on the danger and misery caused by those who traffic people for profit," Roy Penrose, head of the national crime squad, said yesterday.

Mr Straw repeated his criticism of the Belgian government for failing to enforce the Schengen agreement's policy on illegal migrants.

He also made clear that most of the 1,900 Kosovan Albanians who came to Britain a year ago under the United Nations temporary protection programme are unlikely to be allowed to stay much longer.

So far about two-thirds have asked to stay longer on compassionate grounds and the rest have applied for asylum, saying their fear persecution if they are sent back to Kosovo.

"Overwhelmingly these people have no basis whatsoever for asylum and they need to go back," he said, adding that exceptions would be made only for those who, for example, faced serious medical problems. People would be physically removed from the country if that was ultimately necessary, he warned.

The home secretary said the Kosovan Albanians had come to Britain on the understanding that if political rights were restored to them in Kosovo they would have to go back. "Now we have kept to our side of the bargain, and we look to the Kosovo Albanians here to stick to their side of the bargain."

webTitle: Blair won't bother to reshuffle this pack of barking dogs

fields.headline: Blair won't bother to reshuffle this pack of barking dogs
fields.standfirst:
Welcome to July in limbo. Refettling the cabinet is too hot to handle
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: All the classic ingredients are there. A government fearing for its popularity as June heads into July: ministers rowing semi-publicly: anxious backbenchers growing fractious and fundraisers flailing: an election looming ever closer. You'd know - 19 times out of 20 - what comes next: a cabinet reshuffle. Yet, no - this old dog is neither barking nor biting. Why on earth not?
fields.body:
All the classic ingredients are there. A government fearing for its popularity as June heads into July: ministers rowing semi-publicly: anxious backbenchers growing fractious and fundraisers flailing: an election looming ever closer. You'd know - 19 times out of 20 - what comes next: a cabinet reshuffle. Yet, no - this old dog is neither barking nor biting. Why on earth not?

One easy answer. Both Mr Blair and Mr Campbell have let it be known that there will be no ministerial movements this summer. Perhaps you can't take that wholly on trust, since the last time they said there would be a shuffle, there wasn't: but even the gossipmongers believe them and the surface of that Westminster lake is millpond calm. Such odd tranquillity, though, is a condition described, not an explanation offered.

The real reasons come in two stages. First, some piecemeal changes - the departing of Dobbo, the resurrection of O'Mandy - have shifted cabinet chairs pretty regularly of late. Hoon takes the Treasury 2 slot as Byers heads Defence and Smith claims Industry? You can hear Dr Gallup's pollsters snoring already. It would be a zero sum game yielding zero benefits.

The plain fact - especially now that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland only employ ministers to polish their nails - is that the number of jobs which matter, which impinge on public consciousness, has contracted into immobility. David Blunkett is well dug in, Alan Milburn is still digging. Immediately we're into the second stage. Any pre-election shuffle worth a headline would have to involve Messrs Prescott, Cook, Straw and Brown G. Therefore there can be nothing doing. It is deeply instructive to examine why that should be so.

Mr Prescott hasn't flourished in the mega-department where local government, ozone layers and train timetables meet. An impossibly stretched brief - and he'd surely do better in the defined area where his enthusiasm still runs high: transport alone. But restructuring now would be too public a u-turn, particularly if it involved the deputy prime minister. Silence falls.

Jack Straw, too, after a start of charmed competence, is beginning to find his house blowing down. You can be a good home secretary for three years or so, but then your luck - in the unluckiest, most impossible office - starts to run out. It would be an act of mercy to rescue him - and such freedom of information as remains. But now the moment of truth approaches.

Any proper refettling of this government - either ahead of an election or, much more probably, in victory after it - has to include the chancellor of the exchequer. Unless that piece is in play, the process itself is hobbled. Chancellors - like economic booms - don't last for ever. The Stafford Cripps memorial lecture as delivered by Nigel Lawson. Any chancellor with ambitions of higher office needs, like Jim Callaghan, to keep himself busy in other great departments of state until Downing Street does (or doesn't) fall vacant.

But pause for a moment and latch this bit of basic political wisdom into the present tumult which begins to afflict Mr Blair's fortunes. Who's in charge of euro policy? Is it Mr Cook and Mr Byers (with Number 10 egging them on sotto voce) or is it the dominant Brown with his five sacred tests? Tests to be applied when the time is right - which can only be after the election and, on current form, maybe a year or two beyond that? Let's schedule, for the sake of argument, a referendum in 2003, so that the impact of abolishing the franc, mark and peseta in 2002 can be duly assessed.

Logical hiatus time. For the current squabbling to make any sort of sense, you have to believe that the chancellor of decision, three years' hence, will be the chancellor we've had for the past three years. In short, to see Gordon Brown as the great unshiftable. The tests, as we know, are really political, not economic. A Chancellor Cook or a Chancellor Byers would surely interpret them differently. Indeed, any new chancellor - say Alistair Darling - would be much more under Downing Street's thumb, since he would only have been appointed in the first place if he'd signed up to Mr Blair's inner strategy. Who knows? Foreign Secretary Brown might have turned turtle inside the FO, too.

Which, on examination, is what makes Labour's euro debate so bizarre. It is an exercise in time travel down a narrow tube which shuts out the rest of the political world. It assumes only a once and future Brown, immutable in his hegemony.

There are added scenarios, of course: there are always scenarios. One - beloved of Brown supporters - is the sporting retirement of Tony Blair half way through the next parliament to spend more time with his family. But what prime minister, pray, will be able to walk away from the helm in the midst - the very midst - of euro transition turbulence, abdication at a moment of national crisis? You don't cement your place in history thus. Mr Blair will never think that time can be right.

And anyway - a proliferation of much more imminent scenarios - there is a general election to win, and win well. A poor result and much reduced majority, for instance, would spread blame far beyond No 10. No recriminations for the chancellor? Hardly. It will be open season for Mr Brown's enemies. Why did he rock the boat so openly? Why did he leave the government stuck in a muddle of euro mumbling which William Hague was able to exploit so ripely? Anyone (attention Mr Cook and Mr Byers) could see that coming. Why were the pensioners alienated in parsimony? Why did the NHS cash come too late to make a difference? What price all the micro-fiddling the voters did not understand? Who needed wobbly interventions on elite this or public school that which merely got the Daily Mail excited?

Some of that, to be sure, may be unfair: but fairness has nothing to do with politics. Either Gordon Brown will be an associated villain of the piece - or, in triumph, he'll be so strong as to harden the arteries of the next administration and actively sabotage its coherence and chances of overall success. The first Westminster cry of the day will be: who's in charge?

Welcome, then, to July in limbo. The frontbench team you see is the team you'll get. The ructions that ripple just below the icy surface are doomed to go on. The two sides of the debate are frozen in personnel permafrost. But inside cabinet, people matter just as much as policies - and the threat of reshuffling is the boss's only real sanction for order. No shuffles, no sanctions, no possibility - as we see all too plainly - of clear leadership.

The dogs who aren't barking this summer will be dogs of war in the end.

webTitle: The nuclear scientist who loved me

fields.headline: The nuclear scientist who loved me
fields.trailText: The American visitor must have thought his charm and erudition were finally being appreciated against the exotic backdrop of a foreign land. He had hardly unpacked his suitcase when he began to experience what he described as "extensive sexual contact".
fields.body:
The American visitor must have thought his charm and erudition were finally being appreciated against the exotic backdrop of a foreign land. He had hardly unpacked his suitcase when he began to experience what he described as "extensive sexual contact".

These close encounters were with a string of women from the host country: a waitress, two women at the organisation he was visiting, and a prostitute. It was only later that it struck him that his new-found popularity might have something to do with the fact that he was a US nuclear scientist travelling in a hostile country.

According to a congressional report, he was only one of 75 nuclear scientists travelling abroad who found themselves in the midst of strange goings-on. They have been watched, bugged but most of all propositioned. Another travelling scientist found himself the object of risque suggestions every night of his stay.

The report, due to be published this week and leaked to the Washington Post, takes aim at the beleaguered energy department for failing to warn and protect its nuclear experts when they travel. The scientist with "extensive sexual contact" was in an unnamed country classified by the security people as "sensitive", but the report, by the general accounting office of Congress, warns that US nuclear scientists can be targets for spies even in friendly nations such as Britain and France.

Some of the congressional report reads more like Austin Powers than James Bond. One of the travelling nuclear experts telephoned his wife from his hotel room and they chatted about her plans to go out for an evening of bingo.

"A short time later in the hotel lounge someone mentioned to the traveller the bingo trip that his wife had talked about," the report says. "The next day, another person asked, 'What is bingo?'" Another scientist visiting a "sensitive" country reported a light flashing in her hotel room every time she undressed. She concluded pictures were being taken from a smoke detector on the ceiling.

fields.headline: England, this England
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: It's usually around this time of year, when England have been crushed in some major sporting tournament, that we are subjected to lengthy and pointless analyses of what it is to be English/British. Anyone inclined to such navel-gazing should have parked themselves in front of the telly over the weekend, for there were some drastically differing (and just plain drastic) interpretations of British identity on parade.
fields.body:
It's usually around this time of year, when England have been crushed in some major sporting tournament, that we are subjected to lengthy and pointless analyses of what it is to be English/British. Anyone inclined to such navel-gazing should have parked themselves in front of the telly over the weekend, for there were some drastically differing (and just plain drastic) interpretations of British identity on parade.

Julian Cope took his hit tome The Modern Antiquarian (Saturday BBC2) out on tour in what was described as "a megalithic road trip". In-between Cope's in-car musings, peppered with excruciating hipster vocabulary (he's one of the few people left who say "freaked out" and "far out" with no sense of irony), we saw him prancing around a selection of stone circles from Lands End to Orkney.

The monuments themselves were never less than breathtaking, but Cope's enthusiastic commentary somehow took the fun out of it. "Everything I do is from a rock 'n' roll angle," he announced, to show that archaeology is dangerous and exciting, a belief that possibly explained, but never excused, his wardrobe. "The ancients were the first glam rockers," he said with authority, claiming them as kindred spirits.

Along the way we met Margaret and Ron, two fellow enthusiasts with facial hair and knitwear, and a psychotherapist who takes people into a hole in the ground for "ceremonies".

It's impossible for anyone of a certain age not to have warm feelings towards Cope, but after about ten minutes his studied wackiness began to grate. With his flying helmet, shades and hi-vis anorak, he was like one of those teachers who try too hard to be the kids' friend - there would be revolution at the back of the class long before the dinner bell. In its printed form, The Modern Antiquarian is not only a joy but a useful field guide; on screen, however, Cope's neo-hippy mannerisms swamped his subject.

Far, far away, in a very different Britain, dwell the inhabitants of ITV's new Sunday sitcom contender, Up Rising . This was England in microcosm, with all social types cosying up around the village green. Anton Rodgers played old fart Ronald Kegworthy, a man filling the void of early retirement by setting up pointless committees. Kevin McNally and Michelle Collins were likeable nouveaux-riches, who would have been more at home in an 80s Mike Leigh film.

The niceties of village life have produced some of the best comedy in the English language, viz EF Benson's Lucia novels, but Up Rising was dogged by a fatal uncertainty of tone. One minute it was The Archers, with an irritating young woman banging on about her pig; the next it was lurching into League Of Gentlemen territory ("It's a village pub! For the village!" said the fat, stinking drunk). There were some funny lines, mostly for Michelle Collins, and some awful ones, mostly for Anton Rodgers. Let's face it, any comedy that relies on jokes about a barrister's briefs is in trouble. There was a touching moment at the end when said barrister fell for the animal charms of topless handyman Dominic Matham, who was fixing her Aga, but whether that's enough to keep Up Rising going for the next four weeks remains to be seen.

Witness (Sunday C4) gave a heartbreaking account of life in Caleb House, a men-only community in Wichita, Kansas, run by the Freedom At Last Church. As part of Exodus International, it is their mission to "rescue" men from homosexuality. Strict rules applied in the house: no visitors, no contact with "friends", no sex, no unsupervised outings, constant prayer and self-laceration. Nobody was finding it easy. Brad, as handsome as a Marlboro man, had been kicked out for tricking with his housemates. He tried desperately to save his marriage as his wife, Susan, turned into an embittered fury before our eyes; finally they had the sense to call it a day. Greg was trying to extract himself from the sinks and stews of New Orleans where he ran a gay bar for seven years, until a man in a coffee shop held his hand and it was all over.

The theological basis for Exodus International is a highly selective reading of 1 Corinthians chapter 6 verse 9. A little more Christ and a little less Paul might have spared everyone a whole heap of misery.

Anton Rodgers played old fart Ronald Kegworthy, a man filling the void of early retirement by setting up pointless committees. Kevin McNally and Michelle Collins were likeable nouveaux-riches, who would have been more at home in an 80s Mike Leigh film. The niceties of village life have produced some of the best comedy in the English language, viz EF Benson's Lucia novels, but Up Rising was dogged by a fatal uncertainty of tone. One minute it was The Archers, with an irritating young woman banging on about her pig; the next it was lurching into League Of Gentlemen territory ("It's a village pub! For the village!" said the fat, stinking drunk). There were some funny lines, mostly for Michelle Collins, and some awful ones, mostly for Anton Rodgers. Let's face it, any comedy that relies on jokes about a barrister's briefs is in trouble. There was a touching moment at the end when said barrister fell for the animal charms of topless handyman Dominic Matham, who was fixing her Aga, but whether that's enough to keep Up Rising going for the next four weeks remains to be seen. Witness (Sunday C4) gave a heartbreaking account of life in Caleb House, a men-only community in Wichita, Kansas, run by the Freedom At Last Church. As part of Exodus International, it is their mission to "rescue" men from homosexuality. Strict rules applied in the house: no visitors, no contact with "friends", no sex, no unsupervised outings, constant prayer and self-laceration. Nobody was finding it easy. Brad, as handsome as a Marlboro man, had been kicked out for tricking with his housemates. He tried desperately to save his marriage as his wife, Susan, turned into an embittered fury before our eyes; finally they had the sense to call it a day. Greg was trying to extract himself from the sinks and stews of New Orleans where he ran a gay bar for seven years, until a man in a coffee shop held his hand and it was all over. The theological basis for Exodus International is a highly selective reading of 1 Corinthians chapter 6 verse 9. A little more Christ and a little less Paul might have spared everyone a whole heap of misery.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Little Buddha
fields.body:
Little Buddha

(Bernardo Bertolucci, 1993)

6pm, FilmFour

Extraordinary to see Keanu Reeves in Bertolucci's epic, elegiac study of Buddhism; but then there are elements of The Matrix in Reeves's portrayal of Siddhartha and his quest for enlightenment. The film's other main strand has Seattle schoolboy Jesse (Alex Wiesendanger) travelling with his father (Chris Isaak) to Bhutan to determine whether he is, as suspected, the reincarnation of a revered Tibetan lama; and for him to learn about Siddhartha. The structure creaks, but it's a visually stunning, magical journey.

The Jackal

(Michael Caton-Jones, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

Big-bucks updating of Zinnemann's 1973 version of Frederick Forsythe's novel: Bruce Willis v Richard Gere. Willis operates with cold efficiency as the Jackal, an assassin-cum-master of disguise hired by the Russian mafia; Gere almost sinks the movie as an IRA man: he just stops short of dancing a merry Oirish jig. Still, Caton-Jones is a dab hand with the action.

Slums Of Beverly Hills

(Tamara Jenkins, 1998)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

Natasha Lyonne is Vivian, the only member of her family with any hint of sanity. Her down-at-heel dad, Alan Arkin, drags the family around the cheaper outskirts of early 70s Beverly Hills while taking handouts from his richer brother to look after his promiscuous pill-popping daughter, Marisa Tomei. All of this means little to Vivian who has to deal with her impending large breasts, and the boys they attract. Pleasantly diverting.

Trespass

(Walter Hill, 1992)

10.15pm, Sky Cinema

Hill's violent thriller - a more comfortable production than his new Supernova by all accounts - is ablaze with action. Firefighting buddies Bill Paxton and William Sadler stumble on a map marking treasure buried in a factory inhabited by Ice T and Ice Cube's drug-hustling killers: easy enough to get in, much harder getting out with the loot. A sharp Robert Zemeckis script and Ry Cooder's soundtrack pump up the combustible atmospherics.

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Chris Penn in The Wild Life
fields.body:
Chris Penn in The Wild Life

(Art Linson, 1984)

Who? Mostly known for being Sean's fatter, younger and less talented sibling, Christopher started as he meant to go on - by doing a sorry impression of his big brother. Sean's role in Fast Times At Ridgemont High was basically rejigged for Chris by writer Cameron Crowe for this less interesting high school picture. He branched out a bit by appearing in martial arts flick Best Of The Best, then finally got critical acclaim as Nice Guy Eddie in Reservoir Dogs. The tough-guy image stuck, but also spread into his private life - he was recently pictured in the National Enquirer smoking crack in an alley (after which Sean came to the rescue, and Chris entered rehab). He's now working with notorious director Abel Ferrara. Is that a good idea, Chris?

The role: Tom Drake, knuckleheaded high school wrestler who works in a bowling alley with the preppy Bill (Eric Stoltz). When the two start sharing an apartment, it all goes very, very wrong.

Best line: His catch-phrase, which can be applied to any situation, from not being served alcohol to being turned down by a girl: "It's casual." Cringe factor: He probably looks back with regret, but only because he was so much thinner then.

Other wannabes: A pre-Ghostbusters Rick Moranis, and a very pre-Twin Peaks Sherilyn Fenn.

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin deemed it an "unfunny youth comedy," and a "meagre attempt to clone Fast Times At Ridgemont High, with Christopher Penn trying to ape brother Sean's flaky character - unsuccessfully."

Also not starring in: Teen classic Rumblefish and alongside Tom Cruise in All The Right Moves, both in 1983.

The Wild Life, Sky Cinema, Thursday June 29, 10pm & 3.05am.

fields.trailText: Sad experience makes me cautious about recommending any comedy series on the basis of its first episode. But you might care to sample Michelle Read's Romantic Friction (11.30am, Radio 4), starring Samantha Bond. The heroine, Anna, churns out bodice-ripper novels. Now she has writer's block and a looming deadline. Fortunately, characters from her earlier romances materialise to help.

No such light relief for Sheila Hill and her team in Jenny Cuffe's report for An Inspector Calls (8.0pm, Radio 4). It's their responsibility to secure vacant beds for the elderly and ill, arrange the formal detention of someone with a serious mental ailment, or track down funds to put a vulnerable teenager somewhere safe. No one seems to believe in personal initiative any longer: they always call in Social Services.

fields.headline: Ask a silly question
fields.standfirst: Tonight, the BBC unveils The Syndicate, its answer to Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? It's a risky move, says  Mark Lawson  , but if they get the formula right, they'll have a ratings jackpot on their hands
fields.trailText: A career as a senior television executive is rather like being a contestant in the genre which increasingly obsesses people in such jobs: the quiz show.
fields.body:
A career as a senior television executive is rather like being a contestant in the genre which increasingly obsesses people in such jobs: the quiz show.

A succession of dilemmas is thrown at the big players. Their responses decide whether they go on to the next stage of the power game - with its really big money prizes - or are eliminated. And the person playing for the highest stakes at the moment is Peter Salmon, the Controller of BBC1.

A few days after the BBC governors criticised your channel's performance, what ideally would be your next big show?

A) A prestigious adaptation of Dickens or Austen

B) A major season on under-age sex

C) An imitation of ITV's biggest ratings hit

D) Sir Christopher Bland - Hero Of Our Age

Well, Chris, you'd ideally want to go for "D", but there's just never a hagiographic documentary about the BBC Chairman around when you want one. It would be really embarassing if it were "B", but luckily the highbrow minority channel has got in with that one (Generation Sex, all week, Channel 4). In an ideal world it would be "A", but the audience is telling me that isn't on. I'm afraid the answer is "C".

To be precise, it's The Syndicate, a new quiz show which is the BBC's attempt to counter the ratings power of ITV's Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? With Nick Ross as a non-ham Chris Tarrant, teams of four answer questions.

The key factor in the success of a TV quiz show is:

A) The size of the prize money

B) The difficulty of the questions

C) What's showing on the other side.

D) The format

Although "A" is generally the first question a producer faces, it is the one which decides whether the series will achieve fame and fortune. A majority of the audience might say "A" but this is a complicated matter. The fact that no guest has taken home the biggest cheque has not affected the success of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? But the size of the potential prize clearly adds to the tension. From the preview tape available, The Syndicate doesn't seem to have a prize other than the right to compete in a final.

The question of "B", the extent to which the questions should be what Ron Atkinson calls a "big ask" - is always a tough poser for quiz shows. Ideally, viewers should be able to shadow-answer from their sofas, at least in the early stages. Part of the trick of WWTBAM? is that the multiple-choice format encourages educated and un-educated guessing at home. The Syndicate's questioning seems more off-the-top-of-the-head.

In terms of "C" - rival scheduling - Peter Salmon looks lucky. Channel 4 has a repeat documentary about whether the Royals are congenitally bonkers. ITV has Carol Vorderman's Better Homes. But, finally, the answer has to be "D" - format. The Syndicate will work if its set, questioning and tension match WWTBAM? On the early evidence, this looks like a big ask.

You can tell a TV show has really worked when it produces

A) Very high ratings

B) Good reviews in the press

C) High advertising revenue

D) Playground/workplace catch-phrases

We can throw out "B" straight away. In peak-time television, reviews are nice for the producer's ego but don't matter. The doomed soap-opera Eldorado got better opening episode notices than the channel-saving EastEnders.

For Peter Salmon, "C" doesn't apply - he's attempting the paradox of a commercial-type show on a channel without ads - while "A" is not what the governors are currently perceived to want.

So we go for "D" again. And the catch-phrase test is a useful one. The true impact of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? became clear when people under pressure in buses and in offices were suddenly asked ironically if they wanted to phone a friend or ask the audience. Every comedian on television - from Rory Bremner through Jim Davidson to Ali G - has done a WWTBAM? spoof. The only obvious catch-phrase potential in The Syndicate is the aspect of the format which requires teams to add or subtract members of their team in lieu of points. If "we'll reinstate Sheila" and "we'll lose Muriel" are part of office humour by August, then The Syndicate will have been a hit.

After The Syndicate, should the Controller of BBC1...

A) Tell the BBC governors: "See! See!"

B) Commission a Jane Austen adaptation

C) Give bookies 50-50 odds on his survival

D) Phone a friend at ITV for a job

This is tricky. It definitely isn't D - or not yet. It couldn't be A. So we're stuck between the other two. I'd go for B although C is a very strong possibility. Certainly - from the evidence available - The Syndicate seems unlikely to have the answers. But it should in fairness be said that the question of how to run BBC1 when caught between an expanding marketplace and the governors' nostalgia for old standards is harder than even the seven-figure posers on the Chris Tarrant series which was the beginning of Peter Salmon's problems.

The Syndicate, tonight, 8.30pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Al Gore's free tea
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: How many Buddhist monks does it take to make a banana split? Or, if you find that hard, how many banana splits does it take to make a Buddhist monk? The questions are no more nonsensical than the questions put to Vice-President Al Gore in the latest campaign finance furore drummed up by the Republicans and their covert allies.
fields.body:
How many Buddhist monks does it take to make a banana split? Or, if you find that hard, how many banana splits does it take to make a Buddhist monk? The questions are no more nonsensical than the questions put to Vice-President Al Gore in the latest campaign finance furore drummed up by the Republicans and their covert allies. They are out to get Gore, if they can, for his part in raising money for the 1996 election.

It is understandable that the Republicans feel sore about 1996. Clinton, Gore and the Democratic National Committee (DNC) stole a march on Bob Dole and the Republicans by doubling the DNC 1992 advertising budget, then launching an ad blitz early and by stealth. They kept it off the air in New York, Washington and Los Angeles, so that the press did not pick up on it, and the Republicans did not know what had hit them until it was too late. Now the Republicans would like to win the White House in 2000 by indicting the vice-president as an illicit fund-raiser who lied. Last week, they were assisted by a Justice Department counsel who suggested an independent prosecutor should look into some questions about 1996.

When Gore took tea at a Buddhist temple did he know that the monks and nuns were giving dollars to his party? Did he attend coffee mornings for groups of citizens at the White House whose purpose was to raise money for the DNC? Did he dial for dollars from his White House office? If you feel inclined to say so what if he did, you will be in the company of millions of Americans who can't fathom the intricacies of campaign finance laws, of "soft" and "hard" money, of political action committees, and "issue" advertising. All they know is that American elections have become corrupted by big money and secret donations, and they are right.

Gore did not, he says, know that the monks had been asked for money (illegal because they are a tax exempt religious institution). He did make phone calls for money, which is perfectly legal, but doing it sitting in his office instead of going to a pay phone was possibly a breach of the Pendleton Act of 1883. Devised before telephones were in common use, it was intended to stop patronage (political bosses walking the halls to wring money from staff) not to stop the solicitation of outside private individuals, which is what Gore's calls were about. As for the coffee mornings, Gore insists he was not aware of anyone elbowing the coffee drinkers for money. It was an inadequate response. His answer should have been a raspberry.

GW Bush bills himself as a reformer with results, but recoils from this most fundamental of reforms. With backing from big oil, the banks, and a secret group of Pioneers (political power brokers coughing up $100,000 each), he has spent $90m so far against Gore's $35m. Inequitable? Yes. Illegal? No. Federal law, introduced after Watergate, limits "hard" money to candidates and insists on disclosure. The idea was to take the White House off the auction block. But a 1979 amendment and a 1996 Supreme Court ruling put it back there by sanctioning unlimited "soft" money for parties: corporations, wealthy individuals and labour unions can give anything they like to parties to spend on campaign advertising masquerading as "issue" advertising, and bombarding voters by telephone.

More scandals are certainly hatching in the tax exempt committees which can give money but keep secret the identities of their donors. Two of Bush's own party, Republican presidential contenders, John McCain and Steve Forbes, have protested to the Federal Election Commission about the Bush campaign use of such money against them. McCain still seethes about what was done to him.

Gore, on the other hand, has been in favour of reform since 1978, long before McCain made it a hot issue. In an email to Bush on March 14, when their nominations were secure, Gore suggested to Bush that they forswear soft money advertising in favour of debates. All he got was a jeer and a $1.5m savaging in advertising paid for by a "Shape the Debate" group in California.

Gore has pledged that his first bill will be the McCain-Feingold campaign finance bill to ban soft money. Bush would water it down to nothing. And Gore's party will back him; it is the Republicans in Congress who for years have blocked every effort at reform. Their call for an independent prosecutor to investigate the coffee mornings and tea at the temple simply prompts another teaser: how many hypocrites does it take to sustain a political party?

fields.headline: Patenting our genes
fields.standfirst: It's a controversial issue: James Meek finds out whether the arguments are so straightforward
fields.trailText: It's a controversial issue: James Meek finds out whether the arguments are so straightforward.
fields.body:
The story of how Alexander Fleming, the Scottish bacteriologist of humble origins, stumbled across the wonder drug penicillin in a mouldy dish is the stuff of legend. Everyone remembers Fleming, the Nobel prizewinner.

Who remembers Andrew Moyer? Fleming discovered the drug. But it was Moyer, an employee of the US Department of Agriculture, who patented it. And it was big US pharmaceutical firms which pioneered its large-scale manufacture. In this scenario, you could characterise Fleming and his later British collaborators as virtuous, ethical men and women who never thought of profiting from a life-saving medicine and were outmanoeuvred by sly Americans.

Or you could ask whether, if the British had emulated the Americans, it might not have taken 13 years of underfunded experiments before penicillin started to be made in quantities large enough to be useful. Then perhaps it would have been available in time for Dunkirk, and not, as actually happened, D-Day.

The same dilemma exists today. Biotech firms say that if they couldn't patent genes it wouldn't be worth their while developing life-saving drugs and therapies, while many scientists, religious believers, humanists and environmental campaigners find loathsome the concept of private, for-profit corporations staking claims to what is literally a human birthright.

But claim them they do. And they aren't all private firms. Top spot for gene patent applications in the US goes to Incyte Genomics of Palo Alto, with 315 patents; number two is the University of California, with 219. In Britain, universities and medical charities are among patent holders.
Typical of the big patenters riding high on Wall Street and in the City is Human Genome Sciences, Maryland, which holds about 90 patents. Most controversially, it holds a patent on a gene called CCR5, thought to give Aids the key to enter human cells. HGS didn't prove CCR5 was responsible: other researchers did. But HGS already had the patent in the bag, as they had earlier used computer analysis of data from the publicly funded Human Genome Project to guess a likely role for the gene.

HGS was attacked over the debacle by, among others, Craig Venter - the brilliant, combative scientist who once worked for the US government genetics research programme and now heads Celera, the private-sector rival to the state and charity-funded Human Genome Project.
Venter says the existing regime allows companies to patent genes without doing any real work. Yet Celera itself is deeply embroiled in the patent controversy. Venter acknowledges that Celera could not have progressed so far and so fast in its own, private genome sequencing effort without exploiting the freely available data from the Human Genome Project.

US and European patent law differ, but both now accept that a human gene or protein can meet the criteria to be considered an "invention": that it is novel, useful and reproduceable. The approach is being satirised by Donna MacLean, the Bristol poet who has applied to patent her entire self, arguing that she, too, is novel, useful and reproduceable: "I've come to embody in my own person a grey area in patent law. There are great possibilities for medical advances, but are they just going to be for those in the west who can afford them?"

As gene patenters are quick to point out, they are not, strictly speaking, patenting genes as they are found in nature; they are patenting the data of gene sequences, together with a use for that data. According to Professor Deryck Beyleveld, director of the Sheffield Institute of Biotechnological Law and Ethics, though, that doesn't mean patenters couldn't get a hold on your body. "Under the existing European directive, although nobody can patent my DNA, if you get a patent on a process which produces something identical to my DNA, I can infringe your patent simply by having my own DNA."

Such bizarre hypothetical Catch-22 situations are dismissed by the biotech lobby - emerging as one of the most powerful industrial sectors of the 21st century. "In philosophical terms, a patent is a social contract between an inventor and society," says the HGS website. "In that contract, an invention is protected from commercial exploitation by others in exchange for the inventor's teaching of others to reproduce the invention."

The British biotech sector yields little to its US counterpart in terms of determination to win and defend patents. Politically, they have a free hand: despite the joint declaration by Bill Clinton and Tony Blair that the human genome sequence must be freely available to all scientists, the US and UK administrations support gene patenting.

London-based BTG, a buyer of intellectual property, holds a bundle of patents which gives it control over the gene producing the protein Factor IX, deficient in sufferers from the blood disease haemophilia B. For good measure, BTG has a patent on the protein as well. It earns money from licensing the firms servicing the £100m market for Factor IX.

"I think it's entirely appropriate that companies which have done the work on genes should have the rights to what they've developed," says BTG chief executive Ian Harvey. "If the state wants to get into developing drugs, investing the billions of dollars needed - with most of it wasted - that's something it can choose to do. But most countries have chosen not to go down that road."

Simon Cohen, a patent lawyer with Taylor Joynson Garrett in London, says: "Genes are complex chemicals, and a great deal of scientific research and ingenuity is often needed to turn a naturally occurring gene into a life-saving medicine. When this is done, a real contribution is made by that research, deserving of patent protection. The counterbalance always exists in patent law that if an invention is not truly inventive, patent protection will not be available. There are a number of cases before the courts and patent offices in Europe and the US where dubious biotech patent applications are being challenged."

Much of the confusion over the patenting of genes stems from the fact that the data has myriad commercial applications, not all of them involving drugs. The biotech and traditional pharmaceuticals firms like to stress the vast private resources which go towards putting drugs through clinical trials, many of which will fail. Yet other key uses of gene knowledge - to screen people for genetic disposition to disease, or gene therapy - differ from the traditional pharmaceutical route to market.

Around the world, for example, doctors have independently developed tests for mutations in two genes which make women susceptible to breast cancer. They say they use genetic information from the public domain and standard gene-sequencing techniques. Yet a single US company, Myriad Genetics of Salt Lake City, claims to have patented both genes, and seeks a monopoly on testing. Its licensee in Britain says it has no intention of forcing NHS labs to stop doing their own tests, but doctors are concerned.

fields.headline: The secret of life
fields.standfirst: The human genome brings hope - and fear
fields.trailText: As the first draft of the human genome is unveiled later today, there is rightly huge interest and excitement. This is a milestone in the western scientific quest to understand the workings of our own bodies.
fields.body:
As the first draft of the human genome is unveiled later today, there is rightly huge interest and excitement. This is a milestone in the western scientific quest to understand the workings of our own bodies. We are told that this moment is so significant, it will revolutionise medicine and the treatment of disease - making our efforts until now appear medievally clumsy and crude. But there is also a need to step back from the hyperbole: this may be a crucial development, but its full impact will take a long time to unfold. For a start, although the full map of the human genome will be published on the internet, it will, as one scientist has quipped already, read like Hungarian to most of us. For no one knows the language and no one has the dictionary. It will be many, many years before we have begun to understand what our genes do or the complex way in which they interact to create a living organism - let alone use that knowledge to develop treatments. The promised cures to such illnesses as cystic fibrosis and haemophilia are still some time away.

The promise of the human genome project is that it begins to untangle how almost all diseases have some genetic origins. The explanation for why some people develop cancer or malaria while others do not, why some die when some recover, lies partly in our genes. Already we can now glimpse an era of medicine in which all of us have our genome printed on a swipe-card; we will know which diseases we are vulnerable to, and how treatment can be customised to meet exactly our requirements. It opens up the possibility of eliminating certain inherited, genetic diseases, bringing relief to the suffering of families whose lives have been scarred for generations.

But we also have to be clear about what the human genome will not tell us. A string of news stories in recent years claiming the "gene for homosexuality" or for criminality have conjured up fanciful myths. People have imagined a straight genetic determinism, in which the secrets of human nature are directly foretold by our genes. In this imagining, the human genome is little more than a kind of software programme which explains everything about our personality and our bodies. Such a fantasy is misleading, to say the least. Lest we forget, personality is the product of the complex interaction of our genes and our environment.

Along with the hope for medical breakthroughs, the human genome triggers a number of legitimate anxieties, starting with two existing concerns. The first fear is of a kind of eugenics, in which certain forms of disability can be eliminated. The second relates to the response of the life- and medical insurance industry: might they deny or charge extra for cover to those born with "dodgy" genes? The former is highly charged with religious belief and emotion; just as we struggle now over the morality of aborting a foetus with Down's Syndrome, so in time we will struggle over a much wider range of inheritable diseases identifiable in foetuses. The second question is one for politicians, whose task it will be to stop the insurance industry and employers engaging in genetic discrimination.

A more immediate concern is the danger that a monumental scientific advance could be commercialised. The US geneticist Craig Venter is often cast as the villain of the piece, a flamboyant maverick intent on being the first bio-tech billionaire. To give Mr Venter his due, he has dramatically brought forward this first draft of the human genome by turning the publicly-funded effort into a competitive race. But what irks scientists around the world is that his research remains on a subscription-only basis, supplying rich pharmaceutical and bio-technology companies with the headstart to apply for patents, thus staking out territory to deter other scientists. Of course, patenting is a necessary protection for the financial and intellectual investment made by inventors and scientists. But there are some areas of the law in both the US and Europe which have shown themselves to be dangerously unclear when it comes to this brave new world of genetic information.

Beyond these concerns lie much broader questions about who will benefit from this scientific endeavour. A central fear is that the great discoveries we expect the human genome to yield will only exacerbate the (already grotesque) inequalities in health-care across the world. Billions will have been poured into the human genome project. Billions more will be invested in using its results to fight western maladies like heart disease and cancer. All the while, the health of most people on the planet will continue to suffer from a lack of the simplest necessities - like clean water. Even on a great day like today, that is a sobering thought.

fields.headline: All too visible
fields.trailText: Actors accused of over-exposure often complain that they do two pieces of work in year A which, infuriatingly, are screened in the same week in year B, thus creating the impression of a flooded market which results in them being unemployed in Year C.
fields.body:
Actors accused of over-exposure often complain that they do two pieces of work in year A which, infuriatingly, are screened in the same week in year B, thus creating the impression of a flooded market which results in them being unemployed in Year C.

Certainly you feel that the comedian Alan Davies - offered numerous opportunities by the success of the detective comedy Jonathan Creek - could have done without two of his new series being transmitted on consecutive nights on the same channel. But Stand Up With Alan Davies (Monday, 10.40pm, BBC1) - which puts a fly on the dressing-room walls of his 1999 tour - is now joined by A Many Splintered Thing (Tuesday, 10.20pm, BBC1), a new sit-com in which the comedian plays an adulterous husband. With a repeat of an earlier stand-up show - Alan Davies: Urban Trauma (Thursday, 10.20pm, UK Gold) - available two days later and Davies's Abbey National ads showing on ITV, it may soon be time for Jonathan Creek to investigate the mystery of the man who was on four TVs simultaneously.

In his latest performance - unsurprisingly given he isn't a trained actor - he uses the same baffled amiability he used for Jonathan Creek. It establishes that his main asset is likeability.

This must be so because he remains charming and unchallenging despite playing a man who is unusually controversial for a sit-com. An adulterer has been the central character in a BBC1 comedy before - in the Marks & Gran series Goodnight Sweetheart with Nicholas Lyndhurst - but that was time-slip infidelity, his two women living in the 90s and the 40s. In this comedy - written by Geoff Deane - the two women are contemporaries and the physical peaks and mental troughs of divided love - the source of painful drama in shows such as Hearts And Bones - are played for laughs.

One of Russel's traits is that he can maintain the same face in two homes. They chose the right star. Because this mini-festival of Davies suggests that - for all his charm - what you see is what you always get.
