fields.headline: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.standfirst: 'Ere we go, 'ere we go...
fields.trailText: I remember being struck, when I first studied the law, by the slogan: "It's better for 100 guilty criminals to go free than for one innocent man to be convicted". What nonsense, I thought. I suspect that most people would be content with a criminal justice system which quite often got the wrong person, provided it managed to catch most of the real perpetrators. That's why the civil liberties argument opposing a law that would allow confiscation of passports of alleged football hooligans is getting precious little sympathy, even in normally libertarian circles.
fields.body:
I remember being struck, when I first studied the law, by the slogan: "It's better for 100 guilty criminals to go free than for one innocent man to be convicted". What nonsense, I thought. I suspect that most people would be content with a criminal justice system which quite often got the wrong person, provided it managed to catch most of the real perpetrators. That's why the civil liberties argument opposing a law that would allow confiscation of passports of alleged football hooligans is getting precious little sympathy, even in normally libertarian circles.

Yes, in principle, it shouldn't be possible to stop people travelling abroad unless they have been convicted of a criminal offence. That you can be punished on mere suspicion, or on the untested (in the courts) say-so of some football official, seems wildly against English principles of justice. And there would inevitably be a lot of total innocents caught in the net.

But - and this is what I've been picking up - so what? Never mind individual justice, it's okay for 100 non-hooligans to be wrongly banned from going abroad provided that 100 real hooligans are also stopped. And never mind principles of justice. Anyway, I don't think it will come to legislation. The European Convention on Human Rights will surely prevent it. I can see several of the convention's guaranteed rights and freedoms being interpreted to include the right not to be restricted to your own country without a fair process of law. Why, then, are the Germans allowed to get away with having anti-hooligan laws? After all, they're also subject to the European Convention. Because, compared to lawyers here, those of most other European countries are not nearly as keen on, and alert to, human rights implications. Anyway our lawyers wouldn't be swayed by the knowledge that most of the country is against them.

In the House of Lords last week, Lord Bingham, the newly apointed senior law lord, firmly defended the anomalous position of the law lords as part of both the judiciary and the legislature. He reiterated that although the law lords were entitled to speak and vote just like any other peers , they would in practice not do so on matters which were politically controversial; and they would not sit as judges in cases where they had expressed an opinion on the floor of the house.

I don't doubt Lord Bingham and his colleagues' undertakings, but, first, it's not always easy to know what is potentially controversial. Secondly, as the Lord Hoffmann episode proved, it's not reality that matters but perception, and it's now the public perception that, however careful the law lords may be, there is an incompatibility in being both judge and legislator. It's a perception that isn't going to wear off.

Those who decide these things should take the initiative, before action is forced upon them. Make the law lords a supreme court and divorce them from the politicial lawmaking.

I 'm often criticised for not telling you enough about the glittering whirl of glamorous events I'm constantly attending as a prominent legal diarist. OK. A few evenings ago my frenetic social activities included the launch party of the ultra-cool Matrix Chambers, the most famous set of barristers rooms in history. (On reflection, that actually seems to be true). Blessed by the absence of Prince Charles and Mrs Parker Bowles, the party was nevertheless full of the kind of celebrities you would have expected. There was a 100% attendance by current British prime ministers with spousal attachments to Matrix QCs. I noticed from the elegant green Prada badges worn by members that the word Matrix was very large indeed, while Chambers needed a magnifying glass to decipher. This, I can exclusively reveal, is part of a deliberate attempt to get rid of the word chambers, redolent as it is of 19th century employment practices. "People might think we're just a bunch of lawyers for hire," a Matrixian told me privately, "whereas, of course, we're a wholly new concept in the delivery of what, in olden times, used to be called advocacy and legal advice."

fields.headline: A shield for some
fields.standfirst: Until now a man accused in a rape case has been able to drag up the woman's past sex life in court. A new law will make that more difficult.  Clare Dyer reports
fields.trailText: Until now a man accused in a rape case has been able to drag up the woman's past sex life in court. A new law will make that more difficult.
fields.body:
Which representative of the legal profession might you expect to hold the following views? "There are lots of women who make complaints of rape who would sleep with the local donkey and the defendant says 'Well, how can she possibly say I raped her when she goes with everybody in sight? I want that brought up.' To an extent, I suppose, they're entitled to have that done because a jury must consider that if she sleeps with nine out of 10 men why is it that she wouldn't sleep with this one?"

No, these are not the words of some crusty Rumpole but of a woman barrister who regularly prosecutes and defends in rape trials at the Old Bailey. Her attitude holds sway in courtrooms today, even though a committee under High Court judge Dame Rose Heilbron concluded 25 years ago that evidence of the alleged victim's sexual history was not only largely irrelevant in a rape trial but "inimical to the fair trial of the essential issues".

If a woman agreed to sex with A, B and C, how does that help to prove that she agreed to sex with D? What such evidence will almost certainly do, as studies in the US and Canada have shown, is prejudice the jury - in cases where jurors hear evidence about the woman's sex life, defendants are more likely to be acquitted or convicted of a lesser offence than rape.

In the 19th century, evidence that a woman had had other sexual partners was considered highly relevant. But by 1975, the Heilbron committee argued, "sexual relationships outside marriage, both steady and of a more casual character, are fairly widespread, and it seems now to be agreed that a woman's sexual experiences with partners of her own choice are neither indicative of untruthfulness nor of a general willingness to consent." Recognising that such evidence is usually irrelevant and highly prejudicial, Canada and many US states have passed "rape shield" laws designed to spare women the ordeal of having their sex lives laid bare in the courtroom. Within a few weeks a similar law, little noticed as it passed through Parliament last year, will come into force in England and Wales.

The law, part of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999, will replace sections of the Sexual Offences (Amendment) Act 1976, passed in the wake of the Heilbron committee's report. This laid down that evidence of a woman's sexual history would be admissible only with permission from the trial judge, who would allow it if he believed excluding it would be unfair to the defendant. But like earlier versions of rape shield laws in the US and Canada, this failed to achieve its aim precisely because it was left to the trial judge's discretion.

Lawyers defending men accused of rape see evidence about the woman's sex life as an important weapon in their armoury. And more often than not, trial judges have agreed. When the 1999 act was going through Parliament, MPs were told that permission is sought in roughly half of all cases, and granted three times out of four.

In a revealing study by Jennifer Temkin, professor of law at Sussex University, in this month's Journal of Law and Society, 10 barristers with long experience of rape trials outline the tricks of their trade. One is discrediting the complainant -"undermining her personality" as a male barrister put it. This includes suggesting that she "asked for it" by wearing provocative clothes or putting herself in a compromising position, for instance, by asking the man in for coffee.

That barrister, who also sits at the Old Bailey as a part-time judge, said he invariably asked the judge to allow evidence of the woman's sexual history because if she could be portrayed as a "slut" the man was highly likely to be acquitted. He also saw the woman's lifestyle as a factor influencing juries. "If you live in a squat or are a single mother it does have an impact. I think they think you are more likely to have got what you deserved."

In one case he was defending a man accused of raping a black woman who had jumped out of a first-floor window to escape him and broken her ankle. He showed the jury a video of her on another occasion "dancing in a club in a very flamboyant and suggestive Afro-Caribbean way.". The man was acquitted.

The new law is much more complex than the old, but it will greatly restrict judges' current discretion to allow evidence of the alleged victim's sexual behaviour. This will be allowed only in strictly defined circumstances.

One is to rebut evidence of sexual behaviour introduced by the prosecution. For example, if the prosecution says the woman was a virgin, the defendant may be allowed to bring in evidence that she was sexually experienced. But there will be no more trawling about in the woman's past. Where the issue is consent, evidence will be limited to behaviour at or about the time of the alleged rape, or with such close similarity to behaviour around the time of the incident that it could not be coincidental.

However, one avenue will remain wide open. Judges will still have a discretion to let in evidence of the woman's sexual behaviour if the issue is not whether she consented but whether the defendant thought she was consenting. Honest but mistaken belief that the woman agreed to sex is still a defence to a charge of rape, and if the accused can convince the jury that, however stupid his belief, he genuinely thought the woman was consenting, he is entitled to be acquitted.

One woman MP remarked during the debates on the bill that when she discovered that the so-called "Morgan" defence was possible, she "felt rather like Alice slipping through the looking glass and moving into a world of make-believe". Morgan had invited three strangers to have sex with his wife, telling them (or so they claimed, though he denied it) that she was "kinky" and would struggle so as to get "turned on". The three claimed they thought she was consenting, although she testified that they had dragged her from her bed, covered her face and held her down while they gang-raped her.

They were convicted after the trial judge directed the jury that their belief would be a defence only if it was based on reasonable grounds. But the House of Lords held by 3-2 that there can be no conviction for rape where a man honestly believed the woman was consenting, even if the belief was unreasonable.

Defence lawyers often run alternative defences - arguing that the woman actually consented or that the accused honestly but mistakenly believed she did. In those cases women will still be wide open to a possible grilling on their sexual history.

This would not reverse the burden of proof: if the accused claimed he thought the woman had consented and said he had taken reasonable steps, the burden would remain on the prosecution to disprove his claims. This, along with the new restrictions on sexual history evidence, would bring our law broadly into line with that in Canada, where rape shield laws are reckoned to have struck a fair balance between victims' right not to be traumatised and humiliated, and defendants' right to a fair trial. And at a time when rape convictions are at an all-time low, it could mean that fewer go free to strike again.

fields.headline: And for my next trick...
fields.standfirst: At a time of life when most musicians would be tempted to take things easy, Alfred Brendel is setting himself new challenges.  Alan Rusbridger  meets the great pianist
fields.trailText: At a time of life when most musicians would be tempted to take things easy, Alfred Brendel is setting himself new challenges. Alan Rusbridger meets the great pianist
fields.body:
At the age of 69, Alfred Brendel has discovered Mozart. Which is, to borrow a phrase once used by Brendel himself, "a statement that looks round for applause". And one that is only partly true. The pianist has always played the concertos and is especially pleased with his recent recordings with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra.

Nevertheless, Brendel is full of the excitement of discovering Mozart's sonatas, which have eluded him for the best part of 60 years. "This is my Mozart period," he says. He pauses. "There is a very good remark by Artur Schnabel about Mozart's sonatas: 'Too easy for children. Too difficult for artists.' " He beams an Eric Morecambe beam.

We are talking in the library of Brendel's home in Hampstead, directly above the room in which he practises, with its brace of Steinways and collection of Lisztiana, including a death mask that hovers just above his left hand as he plays. He is on a flying visit home. The previous night he was playing in Vienna; that afternoon he is setting off for Stuttgart. It would have been easier to fly direct, but his daughter is sitting her A-levels and he has been persuaded to spend one night in London. I must not come too early - he is practising. And he must be out of the house by three o'clock sharp to make the plane. There is just time to talk.

Some soloists relax a little as they approach old age. Brendel is hardly easing up, though it cannot be for want of laurels on which to rest. He still plays around 90 concerts a year - 90 repetitions of the experience he once described as "the sudden burst of sweat in a spasm of anxiety". Last year saw him performing in 53 towns and cities from Tokyo to Minnesota, from New York to Plush, Dorset.

Eight years ago we could not have had this conversation. It was then that he suffered what he simply refers to as "a sort of crisis". "I had to stop playing because I had pains in my arms and I was not at all sure whether I could continue," he recalls in tones that still have a touch of Austrian formality. "I went to see several doctors, physiotherapists, chiropractors and got more and more desperate because they did not seem to know what they were talking about, until about a year later I found a doctor in Munich who specialises in sports injuries.

"He seems to have helped me. I probably owe him the fact that I am still active and do not feel impeded in what I am doing. But of course I also regulated some of it by changing my repertoire, taking out a few particularly athletic pieces, like the Brahms concertos or the Liszt sonata - pieces I had lived with for a long time.

"I am also playing fewer programmes than before. In my 30s, I think there was one year when I played 13 completely different recital programmes within about 12 months. I am not dreaming of doing that sort of thing again."

Maybe not 13 recital programmes. But in 1999/2000 he played four different recital programmes, three different Mozart concertos, one Beethoven concerto and Schubert's Winterreise with the young German singer Matthias Goerne. The Hamburg doctor does seem to have done the trick. And if giving up Liszt is partly responsible for leading Brendel to Mozart, who would complain?

He explains why he remained aloof from Mozart for so long. "Mozart's sonatas do not have such a good reputation. People think that, beside the piano concertos and Beethoven's sonatas, they are no great shakes, and I must confess that I myself did underestimate some of them before. Well, I take everything back.

"They are in a way the most difficult pieces to play - quite contrary to what people think. Everything is completely exposed. You are all by yourself. You have very few lines to play. It should be poised and seemingly casual at the same time. This is one of the reasons you'll hear Mozart's sonatas so rarely in recital programmes.

"So I told myself, 'If I don't do it now, then it may be too late.' There is still - at least in some of my recitals - the control that I want to be there, and at least I give it a try. It's never good enough."

On Wednesday Brendel plays the C minor sonata K457 at London's Royal Festival Hall. That leads him to talk about his perception that Mozart's sonatas are "not piano works in the narrow sense".

Meaning? "Most great piano pieces are not conceived precisely in terms of the piano sound. They are put on the piano because one player can master a whole piece without the interference of other players. That is the main reason piano literature is so incomparably rich.

"So for me the C minor sonata is much more an orchestral piece than anything else; within 20 years of Mozart's death there were at least three orchestrations. That doesn't show that it needs the orchestra, but it shows how big in scale it is, and what it contains. The point for me is to make some of these latent possibilities manifest on the piano."

Even allowing for self-deprecation, a Mozart sonata surely does not present Brendel with great technical problems? "No," he counters. "People are very wrong when they think that technical difficulties in Mozart are secondary. They are not. They are intimately linked to the psychological under standing of what happens in every single second."

At this stage of Brendel's life, one senses, he invests more energy in working out every piece second by second - certainly more than he did during his 13-programmes-a-year life. And after the preparation comes the culmination of all that effort. This is Brendel's description of what happens once he is up there on stage - white tie, tails, sweat, anxiety: "The piece is first, then there is me who tries to transmit it and the public where it should arrive.

"That means that, sitting in the middle, I have to be in contact with both sides and also with myself as I do contradictory things at the same time, like controlling and losing myself. Like anticipating what I should do next and at the same time taking in what I have played and reacting to it. Like overlooking the whole piece in the way you overlook a landscape and at the same time unfolding it, giving birth to it, starting from the first note like a new experience. Then there is the contradiction of pleasing yourself as much as possible but also thinking of the person in the 30th row and a way of transmitting something into the distance. This is particularly extreme in the American summer festivals when you play for 5,000 or 10,000 people. You are hardly seen by some of these people, and still something has to come across, if possible."

Does it become more or less difficult with age?

"I think I can do certain things better, in terms of control of, let us say 'ornaments'. But this is also tied to the mind. One gets more experienced. One knows more precisely what one should do. One has a wider reach of characterisation of pieces. So it becomes at the same time freer and more accurate. Music-making is full of contradictions. This is one of them."

The state he describes - at the intersection of control and abandon, freedom and accuracy - encourages speculation about the performer's relation to his own conscious and unconscious. Brendel says he has never been tempted to delve too deeply into his own unconscious but does not share the recent tendency to debunk Freud.

"There are three Freudian notions without which I cannot be. One is the unconscious; the second is neurosis; and the third is - what is the English word? Depression. They seem so natural and so important to explain certain things. I also admire Freud as a stylist, but in German. He is one of the finest writers of aesthetic prose, if not scientific prose."

He has half an hour before leaving for Stuttgart. Long enough to digress wistfully about only rarely having performed Chopin: "In my next life - in this life my vertebrae will no longer allow it." And about the young pianists he admires: "Till Fellner and Paul Lewis here in England. Both, I feel, have the potential to go very far."

And he talks about Plush, the Dorset village where he and his wife Rene have a house and where they recently bought the neighbouring redundant church for £10. His son Adrian has turned it into a centre for music-making and concert-giving - a sort of West Country Snape Maltings. It is also a much-valued retreat for Brendel from the never-ending demands on his time and gifts.

Next year he turns 70. The anniversary programme includes residencies in Vienna, Cologne, Brussels, Amsterdam, Paris, Berlin, Frankfurt and Tokyo, as well as a series of concerts at the South Bank in London. Highlights for next year will also include the complete Beethoven concerto cycle with the Boston Phil and Seiji Ozawa, and another Beethoven cycle with the Vienna Philharmonic and Simon Rattle. There is much sweat, anxiety and wonderful music-making to come.

Alfred Brendel plays the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Moving stories
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: Rosemary's situation is far from perfect. Auntie, in whose house she now lives, has been temporarily anxious and muddled. Last Thursday, at 6am, Auntie staggered upstairs, smartly got-up in her lipstick and best handbag, and jerked Rosemary from a lovely sleep.
fields.body:
Rosemary's situation is far from perfect. Auntie, in whose house she now lives, has been temporarily anxious and muddled. Last Thursday, at 6am, Auntie staggered upstairs, smartly got-up in her lipstick and best handbag, and jerked Rosemary from a lovely sleep.

"Is it time to go yet?" Auntie said. She had a 2.30pm dental appointment. "No!" snapped Rosemary rather crabbily. "It's six o'clock in the morning. Go back to bed!" Stressed by dental problems, Auntie was having trouble with the time of day. She looked at her clock but didn't believe it. Rosemary had explained carefully and repeatedly that if it's dark outside and the clock says 10, it's night-time, but it made no difference. "Thank you for my lovely breakfast," Auntie had said, straight after supper.

Auntie recovered, but Rosemary has worse problems. She is sick to death of having her possessions in storage. Last week she arranged to meet her daughter at the dread storage depot to collect a cordless phone that Daughter suddenly absolutely couldn't do without. I find that when a daughter wants something, she usually wants it immediately. So there was Rosemary with half an hour to search this fearful labyrinth of a place before the metered light went out.

Daughter was late. The minutes were ticking by, so Rosemary decided to clamber to the top of her pile of furniture and look for the phone. But when she was nearly at the top, she had a nasty attack of vertigo and clung dizzily to the pile, sweating and nauseous, her forehead clammy, her hands limp, praying for Daughter to turn up before she was plunged into darkness.

In the nick of time, Daughter appeared, but only laughed mockingly at her dangling mother. Then another difficulty. How was she to help Rosemary down? Neither of them is keen on physical contact. "There's nothing for it," cried Rosemary, "you're going to have to hold my hand." So they both gritted their teeth and clung to each other, and Rosemary at last reached the ground. Without the phone.

Last Thursday, at 6am, Auntie staggered upstairs, smartly got-up in her lipstick and best handbag, and jerked Rosemary from a lovely sleep. "Is it time to go yet?" Auntie said. She had a 2.30pm dental appointment. "No!" snapped Rosemary rather crabbily. "It's six o'clock in the morning. Go back to bed!" Rosemary had explained carefully and repeatedly that if it's dark outside and the clock says 10, it's night-time, but it made no difference. "Thank you for my lovely breakfast," Auntie had said, straight after supper. Auntie recovered, but Rosemary has worse problems. She is sick to death of having her possessions in storage. I find that when a daughter wants something, she usually wants it immediately. So there was Rosemary with half an hour to search this fearful labyrinth of a place before the metered light went out. Daughter was late. The minutes were ticking by, so Rosemary decided to clamber to the top of her pile of furniture and look for the phone. fields.headline: Thrill by mouth
fields.standfirst: Sexual is out, sensual is in, if ice cream ads are to be believed.  Libby Brooks splits the difference
fields.trailText: Sexual is out, sensual is in, if ice cream ads are to be believed.  Libby Brooks splits the difference
fields.body:
Is it proof of some universal but unpalatable erotic truth that something chill, sticky and additive heavy should acquire such lofty status in the pantheon of sexually resonant foodstuffs? Strawberries, of course. Oysters, no argument. But ice cream? A childhood of dribbly raspberry ripples consumed on a variety of windswept Scottish beaches leads me to contend otherwise.

Not so, say the advertisers. Witness the annual early summer onslaught of lascivious lollies, with their promises of sex on a stick. The latest travesty is the most everywhere ad for Magnum ice creams, featuring a kittenish lovely teasingly unzipping her ice cream wrapper. All that's missing is the catchline: buy this lolly, you may find it reminds you of giving head. As with those who describe chocolate desserts as "orgasmic", one can only wonder at the sort of sorry individual who buys into that whole eating something sugary/actually having sex continuum.

But the prime offender in the something-cold-on-something-hot stakes has always been Häagen-Dazs. Until now. Gratuitous raunch has been declared so last millennium by the purveyors of the luxury pots. Once famed for its hardcore approach to consumer-baiting, the company last week launched a new advertising campaign reflecting a more modest attitude.

"It's a soft, sensual campaign, not a hard one with naked bodies everywhere," explains Jim Moseley, managing director of Pillsbury, owner of the Häagen-Dazs brand. "In the advert, there is a lot of chemistry between the couple. They are lost in each other. It is subtly and romantically done. It isn't sex."

But why not? Are sexuality and sensuality necessarily in opposition? Does romantic love preclude hedonistic physical pleasure?

The realm of the sensual has been historically conceived of as a female preserve; as a rosy confluence of intimacy and instinct at odds with the mechanical, finite imperatives of the male. The potency of man completes woman's receptive, alluring (sometimes dangerously so) sensuality. It results in that vexatious opposition of nice and nasty as two mutually exclusive sides of the sexual coin. Yet the sating of the senses is as greedy and animal a desire as any other. The brain is an organ of aggression and throughout our lives we tirelessly pursue that which our brain aggressively desires: love, attachment, sensual pleasure. We are hormonally hard-wired thus. Research has found that nursing mothers stroking their infants consistently fall into a rhythm of around 40 strokes per minute. Mammals licking their pups do likewise, while the orgasm, another rhythmic sensation, averages 40-50 throbs per minute.

Our need to be touched is innate. It demands reception and response. "Kissing is probably one of the most basic sensual messages we convey to another person," writes Sarah Bartlett in her book The Sensual Woman, "the most suggestive and the most intentional message of desire. Our mouths are sensory temples, our tongues, lips, inner cheeks and salivary glands evoke pleasure. Babies use suckling to survive, we eat, smile, suck, taste with our mouth. We convey more messages than just spoken language."

Although touch is the sense we most readily associate with sex, it is not our only means of sensual connection, nor should sensuality be considered only through the prism of sexuality. It brings other fulfilments.

Our culture elevates middle-class misery to an art form. We define ourselves through what we suffer, as though authenticity can be found only in pain. Happiness is a competition and we devalue small joys, so often provided by the simple pleasuring of the senses. But still, animal as we are, we can't help but stretch out on the grass on sunny days.

Meanwhile, if sexual pleasure escapes you, there's always that tub of choc chip (one spoon) to look forward to. Enjoy ... just don't confuse the two.

fields.headline: Do architects have a future?
fields.standfirst: Yes, says  Jonathan Glancey  - but only if they start using their creative skills on Britain's mass-produced buildings
fields.trailText: Yes, says Jonathan Glancey - but only if they start using their creative skills on Britain's mass-produced buildings
fields.body:
"Architects are doomed to extinction within 15 years." So says Ron German, a director of Stanhope plc, a major property development company. It is tempting to dismiss the remark as the barking of some no-nonsense chap with a dislike for the bow-tie-and-funny-glasses brigade after a few G&Ts. But German is no fool. He has been part of a decades-long process in which buildings are increasingly assembled from mass-produced components, much like cars. In the future, he says, the architect's role could be confined to "tweaking" components. "Making things special may be important to architects, but it does not make much difference to occupiers. Standardisation will be vital."

German was speaking at the annual British Council for Offices conference two weeks ago. Also on the bill was Michael Aukett of Michael Aukett Architects Ltd, who pointed out that his firm's standardised design system for Tesco supermarkets means that the company no longer needs to consult an architect each time it wants a new store. As a result, costs have come down by 32%.

German and Aukett's comments should come as no surprise. Just check out all those mass-produced supermarkets fronting Britain's A roads, that prefab litany of warehouses, distribution depots, shopping malls, business parks, sports stadia and executive hotels: an amorphous, anodyne, anonymous collection of sheds. The architectural input seems to be less than zero. Occasionally you'll drive past a shed - it could be Toys "R" Us, or Iceland, or Tesco - with some notional architectural input: it amounts to a fancy, tented porch, a split postmodern pediment and a lick of Jim Stirling-style lime green or mauve paint. And yet Britain has something like 30,000 architects. What do they do? Few seem to be involved at any great depth in the design of what really matters, such as new housing, even though Britain is being smothered in a feverish rash of the red-brick, three-bedroom stuff.

German's boss is the newly knighted Stuart Lipton, who is also chairman of the commission for architecture and the built environment, sponsored by the department for culture, media and sport. As a devotee of the most highly industrialised North American building processes, Lipton is part of the process which is sending architects sliding down the hierarchy of the construction team. He believes everyday buildings should be thought of as well designed, well made, efficient and profitable products, not arty-crafty artefacts.

The process that German and Lipton admire began in the US. The mass production of war machinery and agricultural equipment, the construction of continental railroads, the stratospheric rise of the aircraft industry, Henry Ford and his Model T, all encouraged architects to think in terms of component-based, mass-produced buildings. In the hands of young postwar Californian architects such as Pierre Koenig, Ezra Ehrenkrantz, Charles Eames and Craig Ellwood, and Mies van der Rohe in Chicago, industrial-style architecture became a new artform. This, in turn, was a major influence on the work of Norman Foster, Richard Rogers and other British architects.

In Britain today, a fundamental lack of respect for architects has seen the profession downgraded. It is not that this country lacks talent. But instead of getting someone as brilliant as Zaha Hadid to design a new opera house (which was on the cards once in Cardiff) or a museum for contemporary art (she is working on two at the moment, in Rome and Cincinatti), we have got her to design a temporary tent in front of a tiny public art gallery in a London park. Don't get me wrong. It was great that the Serpentine Gallery commissioned this delightful tent, which will stay up for the next two months, but why isn't Hadid designing a major art gallery or opera house, a factory or hotel?

It seems absurd that the huge sums pumped into millennium projects has produced virtually no worthwhile new buildings. There have been superb conversions of old buildings, like Tate Modern; there have been intriguing novelties, like the London Eye and the elegant Millennium Bridge. But aside from Caruso St John's intelligent new Walsall Art Gallery, it is hard to think of a single new building of real quality.

Meanwhile, Marco Goldschmied, president of the Royal Institute of British Architects and a partner in the Richard Rogers Partnership, is engaged in a battle of words with the government over the way public buildings are procured. Nick Raynsford, the construction minister, believes the procurement process that has given us the magnificent but hugely expensive stations of the Jubilee line extension, Portcullis House (the monstrous new office block for MPs opposite the Palace of Westminster), and the British Library has been inefficient. He wants architects to work to businesslike schedules and for buildings to be whizzed up more along the lines of German's Motown approach. Goldschmied, in Churchillian mode, calls for a "more mature understanding in the public sector of the blood, sweat, tears and sheer persistence that is needed to deliver quality buildings".

British architects are caught between the proverbial rock and a hard place. Many of the most inventive British architects of the past 25 years - including the Richard Rogers Partnership - have celebrated hi-tech industrial structures. They have been in love with the muscular US culture that has given us the modern skyscraper and the peerless system built Californian buildings of Koenig, Ehrenkrantz, Eames and Ellwood. But they have seen the system that produces such buildings shoulder their own more genteel profession out of the way. Of course there is a case to be made for more efficiently procured and constructed buildings. But in Britain, a country in which cultural philistines have long hidden behind arguments turning on efficiency, the aesthetic dimension is all too often pushed to one side.

The one thing the architects will be able to offer after German's 15 years is the power of imagination, which might yet lift trashy fast-track buildings into the realm of art. Again, architects were once their own worst enemy when they delighted in buildings conceived as purely functional machines. But one of those functions must be to provide beauty.

British architects appear to believe that marketing and PR gimmicks are their best hopes for survival. But, however much they might like to believe that "architecture is the new rock'n'roll" (it isn't) and that theirs is a "sexy" profession (ditto), the world of nationwide construction has no time for such conceits. Fifteen more years of ignoring the rules of a world they once worshipped and they really will be left "tweaking" components and dialling in the details. They need to get out a bit more and tour Britain's A roads to see where their future may lie.

fields.headline: Post Graduate
fields.standfirst: Charles Webb and Fred: He wrote an American classic. She's an aristocratic feminist who shaves her head every day. So what are they doing on the south coast of England in a rented, furniture-free flat that smells of guinea pigs?
fields.trailText: Charles Webb and Fred: He wrote an American classic. She's an aristocratic feminist who shaves her head every day. So what are they doing on the south coast of England in a rented, furniture-free flat that smells of guinea pigs?
fields.body:
"Don't look at us. Oh no. She's seen us. Go away. Don't look. Go away." Charles Webb, the author of The Graduate, and his ex-wife Fred, the feminist artist, were standing on the corner of a shopping precinct in a backwater on the south coast, scowling at me. "You can't miss them," the woman in the pet shop downstairs had said. "Couple of oddbods," her assistant had added, giggling. Then hissed: "She wears a scarf."

It had been intended that I should pick up the key to their flat from under the mat, let myself in, look around a bit, and then meet them an hour later. But I hadn't been able to find their door and then . . . well, there they were.

"Hello!" I called.

"What kind of a stalker are you?" growled Webb, a shambling creature in dark glasses and a ponytail. Fred, a dainty figurine in shades of grey, looked like she wanted to cry. "It's ruined," she said. "It's all ruined."

They still wanted me to go into their flat. They waited outside while I let myself in. There was a bed in one room, a yoga mat, but no furniture, no television, no food. There were handwritten Post-It notes saying: "Wash back", "Shave", "Put drawings away". The windows were boarded up with corrugated paper. There were animal smells drifting up from downstairs. When I left, Fred said hopefully: "Did you leave anything behind? A sign that you'd been there? Stalkers usually do."

They had wanted to know what it felt like to be stalked. They're working on something on the subject. There's a woman in Paris who comes, like Webb, from Pasadena, California, and thinks she knows the real Mrs Robinson. She's got the number of their mobile phone somehow and keeps calling them. She's an osteopath and is coming to an osteopaths convention in Maidstone soon, and wants to meet them there. "Maid Stone? Do you know Maid Stone?" asked Webb, for a disconcerting moment The American Tourist. The moment passed. "We've got very interested in what's behind this mentality," he went on. "It seems sexuality might be the common denominator."

It is fair to say that Webb and Fred (no surname) are not conventional people. They've been on the run most of their lives. Ever since The Graduate was published in 1963, in fact. The book became a classic, a movie, a soundtrack, and now a play; Benjamin Braddock, its rebellious protagonist, caught forever as icon of dissent, a "set" text. Its author, though, has just kept on moving, continuing to shun success, conformity, materialism. There's Benjamin Braddock in the West End taking off Kathleen Turner's clothes. There's the man who created him, in his 60s now, living with no furniture in a rented flat smelling of guinea pigs. "Nomads, I suppose," said Fred.

They've lived in England for 12 months now. Before that, they lived all over America, in nudist colonies and campsites and, for five years, in one room in a motel. They taught their children, two boys, at home - "unschooling" it's called in the US, even when it was illegal and involved going into hiding. They have few possessions, and give most of their money away. They rejected some inheritances: Webb's father was a wealthy heart surgeon in California; Fred's family used to run Connecticut. Her mother cried when she wouldn't come out at the debutantes ball at the Plaza Hotel in New York.

And they got divorced one day, too. "Irreconcilable differences with the institution of marriage," it says on their form. "My mother was gay," said Webb. "She couldn't be married to the kind of person she would have liked to marry, and it was a sort of protest for that reason. Although," he added, "it was sort of lost on her since she didn't know she was gay." Fred, who has also been called Sasha and Anxiety, shaves her head daily. "It's part of a ritual, sort of, to disengage from material things. I just don't like hair. It is such a bore, you know."

Their arrival in England a year ago marked the end of their retirement, which they decided to take in the middle of their lives instead of at the end. "It seemed like another way to approach something that was fairly conventional," explained Webb. He was 23 when he wrote The Graduate, and spent the ensuing 38 years trying to escape it. "Everything he wrote was always compared to it," said Fred. So he stopped. Until now. He has just sold his first novel for 25 years, New Cardiff. Illustrated by Fred, who describes herself as a satirical artist, it is about an English painter who takes refuge from a ruined love affair in a small Vermont town. The movie rights are under negotiation. A huge deal is due to be announced.

"You know what?" said Fred. "Talk to our agent about that. We've kind of distanced ourselves from the whole selling process." She added that, whatever the figure is, they'll give it all away. "No I don't think so," said Webb. "I don't think we would." "We would," she said. "I would. We have. We always have." Later, when we were talking about something else, she turned to him and said: "I don't know why you say you won't give it all away." "Because we don't plan ahead, that's why," he said softly. "That's true," she said, softer still.

We had repaired, for the sake of anonymity, to a Harvester's on the nearby ring road for an early lunch. They don't want the locals to know who they are; and they made me promise not to name their town. They did seem a bit hungry. Fred even ate the orange peel that came with her salad. Hungry for conversation, too. It must be lonely being a nomad. They both talked slowly and wonderingly as if the world was still a surprise to them. Fred took the lead, though usually stopped when Webb spoke, smiled at him when he did so.

They couldn't believe, they said, when they saw in the paper shortly after they arrived here that The Graduate was coming to the West End (they had no stage rights, they'd sold the movie rights for $18,000). "I'd said to Charles, 'It's time to graduate from The Graduate and then there it was.'" They went to visit the cast. All anyone wanted to know was whether it was autobiographical. Was it? "In terms of milieu and character, yes. Charles is Ben, I'm Elaine, the parents were like that . . ." But did he have an affair with Mrs Robinson? "What do you think?" I said I thought probably not. "Well, you're right. I think it was a love story based on our feelings for each other." (They had met at college.) "Pretty much," agreed Webb.

They love being in England which they think is "pre-corruption". Even France has let them down on that front. They took a trip recently to the Naked City, the nudist camp which introduced them to the genre, near Marseille in France. "Now it's just a bunch of obese elderly Germans plodding around in bare feet looking at the girls," said Webb. Here, they feel relaxed. Their last calling point was west Hollywood, a gay town, which "wasn't too bad because people were at odds basically with society". But, even there, people would ask Fred about her hair all the time. "I'll tell you something that happened to me every day and I just dreaded it. I'd be standing in the grocery line and it would be, 'Oh, I'm so sorry you've had chemotherapy', or, 'Gee, I love the way you tie your scarves.' They sound nice, but really they're disapproving, calling attention to it, pointing it out. Here not one person has mentioned it."

"Over here," continued Webb, "people have feelings for each other in a family. Parents. Fathers. Sons. Mothers." Fred picked up the thread. "Sisters. Brothers. Holding hands, talking." "Grandmothers. Grandchildren," said Webb. "They're having fun together," said Fred. "In the States, you don't see children talking to their parents unless it's, 'Can you give me some money to buy some Reeboks?' In the States, there is a mindset that you hate people over 40." Webb: "In a cold, hostile, cynical way." "Oh golly," said Fred.

As for their sons, both in their 30s, they've turned out pretty conventional, the children perhaps their grandparents might have wanted. Both took themselves off to college. Webb said: "They'd had enough of us." The eldest is "very corporate. He's a Russian criminologist. His field is political science and he works for an energy thinktank in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and he tells investors where they should put their money." The youngest is more conventional still. "He is doing a performance art piece," said Fred. "He calls it spending his inheritance." "It's a very long performance," added Webb.

Later, when I was giving them a lift back to their flat, Fred expressed anxiety about the number of girls that seem to come in and out of her boys' lives. "There are just so many. You meet one and you think that's the one and then it's a different girl next time." You can tell that what she'd really like them to do is settle down. So what about them? When will they be moving on? Webb says they have to go back to the US at some point; there's some furniture in storage to be sorted out, for one thing. "They're taking $85 a month out of our account over there to store $50 worth of stuff." "We got the furniture free," said Fred. "I thought we ought to have something." They're in the process of applying for an artist and writer residency visa which will allow them to work here for three years.

Webb was out of earshot when Fred said in a small voice: "I think Charles'll want to move on, but I want to be here for ever." And she shrugged.
fields.bodyText: "Don't look at us. Oh no. She's seen us. Go away. Don't look. Go away." Charles Webb, the author of The Graduate, and his ex-wife Fred, the feminist artist, were standing on the corner of a shopping precinct in a backwater on the south coast, scowling at me. "You can't miss them," the woman in the pet shop downstairs had said. "Couple of oddbods," her assistant had added, giggling. Then hissed: "She wears a scarf." It had been intended that I should pick up the key to their flat from under the mat, let myself in, look around a bit, and then meet them an hour later. But I hadn't been able to find their door and then . . . well, there they were. "Hello!" I called. "What kind of a stalker are you?" growled Webb, a shambling creature in dark glasses and a ponytail. Fred, a dainty figurine in shades of grey, looked like she wanted to cry. "It's ruined," she said. "It's all ruined." They still wanted me to go into their flat. They waited outside while I let myself in. There was a bed in one room, a yoga mat, but no furniture, no television, no food. There were handwritten Post-It notes saying: "Wash back", "Shave", "Put drawings away". The windows were boarded up with corrugated paper. There were animal smells drifting up from downstairs. When I left, Fred said hopefully: "Did you leave anything behind? A sign that you'd been there? Stalkers usually do." They had wanted to know what it felt like to be stalked. They're working on something on the subject. There's a woman in Paris who comes, like Webb, from Pasadena, California, and thinks she knows the real Mrs Robinson. She's got the number of their mobile phone somehow and keeps calling them. She's an osteopath and is coming to an osteopaths convention in Maidstone soon, and wants to meet them there. "Maid Stone? Do you know Maid Stone?" asked Webb, for a disconcerting moment The American Tourist. The moment passed. "We've got very interested in what's behind this mentality," he went on. "It seems sexuality might be the common denominator." It is fair to say that Webb and Fred (no surname) are not conventional people. They've been on the run most of their lives. Ever since The Graduate was published in 1963, in fact. The book became a classic, a movie, a soundtrack, and now a play; Benjamin Braddock, its rebellious protagonist, caught forever as icon of dissent, a "set" text. Its author, though, has just kept on moving, continuing to shun success, conformity, materialism. There's Benjamin Braddock in the West End taking off Kathleen Turner's clothes. There's the man who created him, in his 60s now, living with no furniture in a rented flat smelling of guinea pigs. "Nomads, I suppose," said Fred. They've lived in England for 12 months now. Before that, they lived all over America, in nudist colonies and campsites and, for five years, in one room in a motel. They taught their children, two boys, at home - "unschooling" it's called in the US, even when it was illegal and involved going into hiding. They have few possessions, and give most of their money away. They rejected some inheritances: Webb's father was a wealthy heart surgeon in California; Fred's family used to run Connecticut. Her mother cried when she wouldn't come out at the debutantes ball at the Plaza Hotel in New York. And they got divorced one day, too. "Irreconcilable differences with the institution of marriage," it says on their form. "My mother was gay," said Webb. "She couldn't be married to the kind of person she would have liked to marry, and it was a sort of protest for that reason. Although," he added, "it was sort of lost on her since she didn't know she was gay." Fred, who has also been called Sasha and Anxiety, shaves her head daily. "It's part of a ritual, sort of, to disengage from material things. I just don't like hair. It is such a bore, you know." Their arrival in England a year ago marked the end of their retirement, which they decided to take in the middle of their lives instead of at the end. "It seemed like another way to approach something that was fairly conventional," explained Webb. He was 23 when he wrote The Graduate, and spent the ensuing 38 years trying to escape it. "Everything he wrote was always compared to it," said Fred. So he stopped. Until now. He has just sold his first novel for 25 years, New Cardiff. Illustrated by Fred, who describes herself as a satirical artist, it is about an English painter who takes refuge from a ruined love affair in a small Vermont town. The movie rights are under negotiation. A huge deal is due to be announced. "You know what?" said Fred. "Talk to our agent about that. We've kind of distanced ourselves from the whole selling process." She added that, whatever the figure is, they'll give it all away. "No I don't think so," said Webb. "I don't think we would." "We would," she said. "I would. We have. We always have." Later, when we were talking about something else, she turned to him and said: "I don't know why you say you won't give it all away." "Because we don't plan ahead, that's why," he said softly. "That's true," she said, softer still. We had repaired, for the sake of anonymity, to a Harvester's on the nearby ring road for an early lunch. They don't want the locals to know who they are; and they made me promise not to name their town. They did seem a bit hungry. Fred even ate the orange peel that came with her salad. Hungry for conversation, too. It must be lonely being a nomad. They both talked slowly and wonderingly as if the world was still a surprise to them. Fred took the lead, though usually stopped when Webb spoke, smiled at him when he did so. They couldn't believe, they said, when they saw in the paper shortly after they arrived here that The Graduate was coming to the West End (they had no stage rights, they'd sold the movie rights for $18,000). "I'd said to Charles, 'It's time to graduate from The Graduate and then there it was.'" They went to visit the cast. All anyone wanted to know was whether it was autobiographical. Was it? "In terms of milieu and character, yes. Charles is Ben, I'm Elaine, the parents were like that . . ." But did he have an affair with Mrs Robinson? "What do you think?" I said I thought probably not. "Well, you're right. I think it was a love story based on our feelings for each other." (They had met at college.) "Pretty much," agreed Webb. They love being in England which they think is "pre-corruption". Even France has let them down on that front. They took a trip recently to the Naked City, the nudist camp which introduced them to the genre, near Marseille in France. "Now it's just a bunch of obese elderly Germans plodding around in bare feet looking at the girls," said Webb. Here, they feel relaxed. Their last calling point was west Hollywood, a gay town, which "wasn't too bad because people were at odds basically with society". But, even there, people would ask Fred about her hair all the time. "I'll tell you something that happened to me every day and I just dreaded it. I'd be standing in the grocery line and it would be, 'Oh, I'm so sorry you've had chemotherapy', or, 'Gee, I love the way you tie your scarves.' They sound nice, but really they're disapproving, calling attention to it, pointing it out. Here not one person has mentioned it." "Over here," continued Webb, "people have feelings for each other in a family. Parents. Fathers. Sons. Mothers." Fred picked up the thread. "Sisters. Brothers. Holding hands, talking." "Grandmothers. Grandchildren," said Webb. "They're having fun together," said Fred. "In the States, you don't see children talking to their parents unless it's, 'Can you give me some money to buy some Reeboks?' In the States, there is a mindset that you hate people over 40." Webb: "In a cold, hostile, cynical way." "Oh golly," said Fred. As for their sons, both in their 30s, they've turned out pretty conventional, the children perhaps their grandparents might have wanted. Both took themselves off to college. Webb said: "They'd had enough of us." The eldest is "very corporate. He's a Russian criminologist. His field is political science and he works for an energy thinktank in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and he tells investors where they should put their money." The youngest is more conventional still. "He is doing a performance art piece," said Fred. "He calls it spending his inheritance." "It's a very long performance," added Webb. Later, when I was giving them a lift back to their flat, Fred expressed anxiety about the number of girls that seem to come in and out of her boys' lives. "There are just so many. You meet one and you think that's the one and then it's a different girl next time." You can tell that what she'd really like them to do is settle down. So what about them? When will they be moving on? Webb says they have to go back to the US at some point; there's some furniture in storage to be sorted out, for one thing. "They're taking $85 a month out of our account over there to store $50 worth of stuff." "We got the furniture free," said Fred. "I thought we ought to have something." They're in the process of applying for an artist and writer residency visa which will allow them to work here for three years. Webb was out of earshot when Fred said in a small voice: "I think Charles'll want to move on, but I want to be here for ever." And she shrugged.

webTitle: MP breaks ranks to challenge Blair loyalist for PLP chair

fields.headline: MP breaks ranks to challenge Blair loyalist for PLP chair
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will tomorrow face a fresh challenge to his authority among restless MPs at Westminster, when Andrew   Mackinlay confirms that he plans to challenge the Blairite loyalist, Clive Soley, for the chairmanship of the parliamentary Labour party.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will tomorrow face a fresh challenge to his authority among restless MPs at Westminster, when Andrew Mackinlay confirms that he plans to challenge the Blairite loyalist, Clive Soley, for the chairmanship of the parliamentary Labour party.

With the annual election for the important post as shop steward for the backbenches not due until November, it is far from clear whether other challengers will now join the contest - or whether anyone can beat the well entrenched Mr Soley.

But the decision by the MP for Thurrock to break ranks is a further sign of disquiet in what has been a surprisingly loyal, even docile parliamentary party, in a year which has finally seen the cabinet run into difficulties with both policy and the voters.

Mr Soley, a former probation officer, MP for Acton and Shepherd's Bush, is well liked, but has laid himself open to criticism for sometimes seeming to be the government's messenger to the backbenches, not the other way round. His challenger will demand better accountabilty - and more listening - from ministers.

Mr Mackinlay, 51, a former local government officer, is a product of the old trade union right wing of the Labour party, but one whose passion for the historic rights of parliament has turned him into one of the most outspoken backbench critics of the Blair government's style.

A year after Mr Blair's election, he caught the mood of many MPs when he reminded him how much Labour had loathed what he called "the fawning, obsequious, soft-ball, well rehearsed planted question" that John Major had faced from his own side and how some MPs felt it was their duty to challenge ministers "without fear or favour".

Ian Gibson, the former Trotskyite MP for Norwich North, is his unofficial campaign manager and the 100 MPs - out of 419 with a vote - said to back him so far include Frank Field and Mark Fisher, both sacked ministers.

webTitle: Haider orders Nazi art off parliament's walls

fields.headline: Haider orders Nazi art off parliament's walls
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The far-right Austrain politician Jörg Haider has ordered the removal of Nazi-era frescoes which have for the past 60 years decorated the walls of the parliament chamber in Klagenfurt, capital of Carinthia, the southern Austrian province where he is governor.
fields.body:
The far-right Austrain politician Jörg Haider has ordered the removal of Nazi-era frescoes which have for the past 60 years decorated the walls of the parliament chamber in Klagenfurt, capital of Carinthia, the southern Austrian province where he is governor.

The propaganda art, depicting jubilant scenes of flag-flying Nazis after Germany's annexation of Austria in 1938, are to be restored and transferred to a museum in the province.

The decision has been held up by Mr Haider's allies as proof that the controversial politician, renowned abroad for praising Hitler and hailing SS veterans, has no sympathies with National Socialism.

But his opponents have denounced it as a cheap, populist move aimed at appeasing his critics around the world, and have asked why the paintings were allowed to survive for so long in a building meant to embody democratic values.

The Carinthian-born artist Switbert Lobisser was commissioned by the Nazi party in 1938 to paint the frescoes to decorate the central chamber of the parliament building.

They remained in place when British troops established their base in the building at the end of the war. "They did not cover them up, which I think is grotesque, but then swastikas were everywhere in Austria at that time," the director of the Carinthian Art Gallery in Klagenfurt, Professor Arnulf Rohsmann, said.

The new government which moved back into the building in 1948 cursorily whitewashed the frescoes. They came to light during renovation of the chamber in the 1970s and were restored and left to breathe behind ventilated wooden panels, where they remain today.

Mr Haider, still de facto leader of the Freedom party, even though he has relinquished the formal leadership, and self-appointed chief cultural watchdog of Carinthia, has taken a close interest in the fate of the frescoes.

In removing them, he said, the provincial government hoped to "send out a positive signal to its EU partners", who imposed sanctions on Austria in protest at his party joining the coalition government.

Some say the paintings should be destroyed, others say that would be tantamount to censorship. "If we destroy the pictures we destroy the past," said Wilhelm Wadl, historian at the Carinthian state archives. "That would be to react the same way the Nazis did."

In fact the paintings, regarded as "primitive" and of negligible importance by art critics but of historical value as pieces of propaganda, are subject to a preservation order and cannot be destroyed.

fields.headline: Shop till you pop
fields.standfirst: Can shopaholics be cured with a pill?  Sharon Krum reports on new research
fields.trailText: And now for a bulletin from the Department of the Patently Obvious: psychiatrists have just discovered that women shop too much.
fields.body:
And now for a bulletin from the Department of the Patently Obvious: psychiatrists have just discovered that women shop too much. And a percentage of them, they say, spend so aggressively and shop so passionately that they are in serious danger of hurting themselves, if not ruining their lives. Death by Prada, anyone?

It's easy to make jokes and indeed American women kid themselves about coming down with bouts of "aspendicitis". But psychiatrists at Stanford University in California studying shopaholic women say the kind of spending they are tracking is not your standard case of heading out for some retail therapy after a bad day at work. "These are people who are preoccupied with shopping and buying above everything else," says study leader, psychiatrist Dr Lorrin Koran. "They buy things they don't need, don't use, don't open. Most never take the tags off the clothes. The pleasure for them is in the buying, not the possession."

In some cases, shopaholics "black out" and don't remember their buying binges. When family and friends start to vent about their purchases, they begin hiding the things they buy. Koran says compulsive shoppers, 90% of whom are women, report a release of tension after buying, followed by feelings of guilt, anger and sadness. Many never remove purchases from the packaging; others return them days after a spree. "We have people in our study who are between $5,000 and $100,000 in debt from compulsive shopping. Their spending has led to divorce, bankruptcy, second mortgages."

But why are women and not men so afflicted by a problem Koran views as part of a cluster of obsessive-compulsive disorders? "I believe it is because women are assigned the role of shopper in our culture. The act itself is done to relieve anxiety and shopping is a culturally acceptable way for women to behave. If you look at another impulse control disorder, pulling one's hair out, that is also 90% women and I think this may be because women are socialised to be more attentive to their appearance. So in all these impulse control disorders, there may be a cultural component."

But in studying 19 female and two male compulsive shoppers at the Obsessive Compulsive Disorders Clinic at Stanford, Koran has run smack into controversy. Typically, in cases of compulsions such as alcohol or food, behavioural therapy in conjunction with 12-step programmes is considered the most powerful cure. But Koran is trying a different tack: drugs. He is giving patients the antidepressant SSRI (a selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitor), in the Prozac family, testing the theory that compulsive shopping is a response to low levels of serotonin, which are linked to depression.

"There is a study to suggest cognitive behaviour therapy is helpful," Koran says. "But if you look at the disorder as a symptom of depression - and we know drugs counteract depression - then it is reasonable to try it."

But is compulsive buying a disease of a broken psyche or a robust economy? Shopping today is not what it once was, a humble trip down the high street. The internet, catalogues and home shopping on TV all allow you to shop around the clock and indulge your every whim. You feel like owning a Fendi baguette bag at 3am? No problem.

Compulsive shopping is not listed as a mental disorder in the official diagnostic manual of the American Psychiatric Association and Koran has been questioned about prescribing drugs for a problem some believe is not neurochemical. Worse, there are assertions in the US that drug companies, eager to expand the use of their products, fund research into a "new" disorder for which they, conveniently, have a cure.

Koran says he approached a drug company, not the other way round. "Critics suggest drug companies are creating the disorder to market their drug. But these people are truly suffering. We didn't create the problem - they are compulsive spenders and we are looking to help them."

Despite a 1997 study at the University of Iowa which found little difference between drugs and a placebo in curing shopaholics, Koran says his studies have been promising. "Patients are reporting feeling less anxiety, less depression, less impulsivity. The women in the study are saying: 'I'm not thinking about shopping'."

But can you really cure shopaholics with a drug? Los Angeles clinical psychologist Robert Butterworth says the Stanford study is bunk. "Business is getting bad for drug companies, so they have to create new diseases they can 'cure'. I think the idea that you can cure compulsive spending with a pill is a giant con." He says women shop to reduce feelings of anxiety, isolation and low self-esteem. "Shopping gives them a temporary emotional lift. But it never lasts."

Typically, when women overshop, they buy clothes, jewellery and cosmetics, Koran says. They think if they look better, they might feel better. Conversely men, who constitute 10% of compulsive shoppers, buy items that relate to their idealised selves. In a study of 61 British students between 1994 and 1996, University of Sussex psychologist Helga Dittmar PhD found spendaholic men buy hi-tech toys, electronic and sports equipment - purchases that boost their self-image.

This all sounds very rational, but what about sex? There is a school of psychology, much of it Freudian, that suggests shopping is a substitute for sex. Entering the store is foreplay, finding an item is penetration, buying the item, hearing that ka-ching! of the register, is climax. Maybe women do shop simply to sublimate sexual tension: if they can't find release in the bedroom, are they finding it at Bloomingdale's or Harrods?

Butterworth says this is not as ridiculous as it sounds. "Women shop primarily to relieve feelings of emptiness and shopping makes them feel full. Certainly if a woman is shopping compulsively, I would advise her husband to ask himself what is happening, or not happening, in the bedroom. If women are looking for love, the answer is to go find love, don't look for bargains."

Koran sees the problem predominantly in medical terms. He believes therapy is an important adjunct, but says if low serotonin is driving these women to impulsive behaviour, increasing their serotonin levels could be the answer. And while the study isn't finished, he is confident that, for some women, it will work.

Butterworth, on the other hand, believes talk therapy, giving women insights into their behaviour so they take steps to curtail it, is the only long-term answer. "The problem today is that we are all victims and have no power over ourselves. If you allow women to take a pill, you are creating a dependency and they will never take responsibility for their lives. The only way for women to overcome overspending is to learn to control it themselves by identifying the void in their lives. And cutting up their credit cards wouldn't hurt either."

fields.headline: Tears cannot extinguish town's trauma
fields.standfirst: Survivors pay tribute in emotional memorial service for 15 victims of backpack hostel fire as manhunt grows for suspect
fields.trailText: The traumatised town of Childers in Queensland yesterday marked the deaths of the 15 backpackers killed in a fire at a hostel on Friday with a memorial service.
fields.byline: Matthew Brace in Childers and Paul Kelso
fields.body:
The traumatised town of Childers in Queensland yesterday marked the deaths of the 15 backpackers killed in a fire at a hostel on Friday with a memorial service.

At least 500 people, including the governor general, Sir William Deane, and the Australian prime minister, John Howard, gathered in the Childers cultural centre for a service that left many weeping and in shock.

Outside in the cool evening air another 1,000 clung to each other and wept as they watched the proceedings on a giant television screen. The town has witnessed much courage since the disaster, but this was perhaps its finest hour.

Some inside and out broke down, as the survivors spoke of their ordeal and of the friends they had lost. They did so in the knowledge that Robert Long, 37, the itinerant fruit picker wanted in connection with suspected arson, was still at large, focus of a nationwide manhunt.

The words of Kelly Symonds from Wales, whose friends Sarah Williams, 23, from Aberfan, and Natalie Morris, 28, from Cef Coed, are thought to be among the dead, typified the fortitude that has emerged since the tragedy. Eight backpackers in all, from Britain, the Netherlands and Ireland, spoke of their loss. Joanna Griffin told how she spent Thursday afternoon picking avocados with her new friend Sebastian, who perished in the fire. James Whitehurst, from Bracknell, Berkshire, said he would never forget "the Palace 15".

The two-hour service left dignitaries and guests alike in a state of shock, such was the bravery and companionship of the survivors, who brought the ceremony to an end arm-in-arm on the stage.

Wreaths, one for each victim, were laid and 15 candles were lit in front of the stage. British backpacker Jessica Wiegand read the poem Do Not Stand at My Grave and Weep. Nessa Boyle, from Ireland, grieved for her friend Julie O'Keefe, and Dutch backpacker Minoeska Teeuwen mourned her friend, identified only as Sebastian. "I met my soulmate here - Sebastian - and I know your soul will always surround me," she said.

Meanwhile, Australia's most wanted man has gone to ground. With little money and no transport, Long would have had to make his escape on foot or by hitchhiking on the Bruce highway that runs past the Palace hostel and is the main north-south route through Queensland.

His other option would have been to hide out in the sugar cane fields that stretch for miles around the town. But in this case the weather would be testing his stamina.

Detective Inspector Ken Benjamin warned local people to check outbuild ings in case there was evidence someone had bedded down for the night, and repeated his warning not to approach Long.

A state police spokesman confirmed yesterday that the inquiry was a criminal investigation. "An incident like this would have to be treated as an arson investigation," he said.

Yesterday morning emergency crews retrieved six bodies from the burnt-out shell of the hostel. The remaining nine will be removed today before being transferred to Brisbane for formal identification and postmortem examination. The dead are thought to include six Britons, one Irish national, four Australians, two Dutch, one Japanese and a south Korean. The premier of Queensland, Peter Beattie, apologised for the deaths and said a full-scale investigation was under way. He also declared today a statewide day of mourning during which flags will fly at half-mast. "In some ways I feel we have failed those parents who have entrusted their loved ones into our care," he said at the memorial service.

'No cover-up'

"To those who have lost loved ones and the survivors ... a big apology that this has happened. There will be no cover-up in this. We will get to the bottom of this ... and do as much as we can to ensure that this never happens again."

The operators of the hostel, John Dobe and Christian Atkinson, spoke of their grief in a statement read by Gavin Talbot, the local Anglican priest.

"The people who have been with us at the Palace, some with us for many months, some for a short time, have become our friends and very much part of our lives," he said.

"We want to let you know that we, our families and friends are sharing your grief and are brought together and [are] sharing their prayers."

There was growing anger, however, over the apparent failure of safety procedures that might have prevented such a large loss of life. Some 47 travellers have died in hostel fires in Australia since 1981. One survivor, Neil Griffiths, 24, said that there were no fire alarms or illuminated exit signs and that he had to grope his way along the floor to escape the fire. Another survivor said that smoke alarms had failed to go off.

Mr Griffiths said he had walked into the lounge around 12.30am and saw a rubbish bin on fire. "I thought it was probably started accidentally after someone threw away a cigarette end. I put it out with a cushion," he said.

Wayne Hartley, fire commissioner for the state of Queensland, indicated there would be a crackdown on safety regulations at hostels throughout the state.

The victims of the fire will not be named until they have been formally identified and their relatives informed. The following people, four Britons and an Irish national, are thought to have perished.

Sarah Williams , 23, from Aberfan, Wales.

Ms Williams had been travelling since September. Her parents visited Australia to see her six weeks ago, and she had been due to fly home this weekend to be a bridesmaid at her brother's wedding.

Natalie Morris , 28, from Cef Coed, Wales.

Ms Williams's friend and travelling companion. Kelly Symonds, who survived the fire, contacted the Morrises soon after she escaped to tell them their daughter was dead. Prayers were said for the girls yesterday in Aberfan, a community itself forever marked by the mudslide that killed 144 people in 1966.

Gary Sutton and Michael Lewis , both 25, from Bristol.

Due to fly home next month, they were staying in Childers to earn money from fruit-picking before visiting Ayers Rock.

Julie O'Keefe , 24, from Dublin.

Ms O'Keefe, a former pupil at Laurel Hill convent in Limerick and a marketing graduate, was confirmed as dead by the Irish consulate. Her passport was found in the hostel and she had not contacted her family since the fire.

webTitle: Farming changes reduce song thrush population

fields.headline: Farming changes reduce song thrush population
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The song thrush, the virtuoso of the dawn chorus which inspired Robert Browning to verse, is falling silent over the countryside.
fields.body:
The song thrush, the virtuoso of the dawn chorus which inspired Robert Browning to verse, is falling silent over the countryside.

Farmland numbers have declined by 70% since 1972, according to a report published today by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds. The society blames a shortage of food caused by changing farming practices. Females are often in such poor health that they need six or seven breeding attempts to succeed.

A four year research project estimated there were 990,000 pairs in Britain, and ornithologists fear the population will continue to drop sharply unless there are widespread changes in countryside management.

Mark Avery, the RSPB's director of conservation, said: "The song thrush is an essential part of Britain's heritage and for the population to have fallen so dramatically over the past three decades is nothing short of a national outrage."

An RSPB research biologist, Will Peach, said: "The destruction of hedges, ditches and woodlands, coupled with the drainage of formerly damp, marginal farmland, means these birds are having real difficulty in finding enough food."
