fields.headline: Record number jump the fence
fields.standfirst:
Organisers and fans pronounce weekend 'one of the best' despite security problems
Glastonbury 2000: special report
Quiz: Find yourself at the festival
fields.trailText: Glastonbury host Michael Eavis yesterday pledged to throw a ring of steel around next year's festival after record numbers sneaked in without paying.
fields.body:
Glastonbury host Michael Eavis yesterday pledged to throw a ring of steel around next year's festival after record numbers sneaked in without paying.

As the rock jamboree in Somerset drew to a close, Mr Eavis suggested 10,000-15,000 wormed their way through gaps in the wall or climbed over, but other official sources put the number of fence-jumpers at nearer to 30,000.

Security guards struggled to patrol the 11-mile perimeter fence and chase away the gangs of baseball capped boys levering open sections of corrugated metal and collecting £5 from those wanting to get through the fence.

Police warned at the weekend of thieves stealing bags as fans tried to jump over, but thousands still flooded in to mingle with 80,000 legitimate ticket holders who had paid £87 per head.

Mr Eavis said security guards were partly to blame for the problem of fans sneaking in without paying. "We need better security. They're not brilliant, I must say. We've had lots of problems this year."

He said festival volunteers, rather than paid staff, were more reliable. "Volunteers are the best stewards we can get and are less likely to be corrupted by money."

Mr Eavis said: "There probably were more jumpers this year. We are planning on an invincible fence for 2001. There will be no nuts and bolts. People undo nuts and bolts. The sections are going to slide into each other. It will have prongs going into the soil so it can't be uprooted.

"We will advertise it in all the youth media to say 'this is the new invincible fence, you wont go through, over, or under it'."

Organisers estimate the new fence will cost about £1m - and take four weeks to erect. They will need to increase the numbers of legitimate visitors to pay for it - something which may rise eyebrows among worried locals.

The ugliest incident of the festival came when security guards responding to reports of robberies became involved in a fracas and a man suffered a head injury while a guard suffered an injury to his arm. Neither side pressed charges.

As ever, theft of possessions from tents - and sometimes the entire tent - was the most common crime.

Nearly 900 tent related thefts had been reported by yesterday morning, on course to match last year's figure of over 1,300 for the weekend.

Despite the freeloaders, Mr Eavis voted this year: "The best I've ever had."

He added: "I plan to carry on with it as long as I am fit, and I am feeling exceedingly fit at the moment."

He revealed that this year's festival had cost around £7m and has made £7.5m from ticket sales and vendors' fees.

Festival organisers seek to give £600,000-£700,000 to charities each time it is held. This year those donations will swallow up any profits.

As glorious sunshine broke out over Worthy Farm yesterday, festival goers said it had been superlative.

Macy Gray had asked the crowd on Friday: "Do you like getting muddy?" But no one had to get too dirty this weekend as even Travis - whose hit Why Does It Always Rain On Me? is thought to be jinxed - failed to provoke a downpour.

Travis, this year's Saturday headliners on the main pyramid stage, played a humble afternoon slot on the "Other" stage last year. A clearly awe-struck lead singer Fran Healy could not stop grinning as he walked on stage after sunset.

Before him, as far as the eye could see, was a vast cheering crowd holding up torches here and there and waving flags.

Introducing a track from the band's hugely successful album, The Man Who, Healy declared: "This song is about lowering the guard you put up as you grow old. Once you pull it down someone might slap you or kiss you, but whether they slap you or kiss you, you still feel alive."

Earlier the Pet Shop Boys had proved a surprise hit, pleasing the crowd with a selection of their best known 1980s numbers and bringing on Catatonia singer Cerys Matthews for a duet.

She took the place of Dusty Springfield on What Have I Done To Deserve This?

The crowd lapped it all up, cheerfully waving their arms in unison to group's encore, the camp anthem Go West.

Lounging on the grass in front of the main stage yesterday, Vicki Bateman, 24, from Guildford said: "This is my eighth time and it's one of the best. There are fewer drug pushers around and you are free to do what you want to do."

David Bowie was due to take the main stage last night for the first time since 1971, when he played the free festival. He was promising to put on the show of his life.

Police on the 650-acre site have been working with cus toms and excise officials to crack down on sales of smuggled drink and tobacco.

They have seized 60,000 cigarettes, 60kg of loose tobacco, 12 cases of spirits and 200 crates of beer, lager and cider in and around the festival.

webTitle: British drag off death camp Serb

fields.headline: British drag off death camp Serb
fields.standfirst: War crimes in the former Yugoslavia: special report
fields.trailText: British troops in Bosnia snatched the commander of one of the Serb's most notorious wartime prison camps yesterday, breaking down the door of his home and wrestling him to the ground before flying him to the Hague to face trial.
fields.body:
British troops in Bosnia snatched the commander of one of the Serb's most notorious wartime prison camps yesterday, breaking down the door of his home and wrestling him to the ground before flying him to the Hague to face trial.

Dusko Sikirica was indicted by the war crimes tribunal in July 1995 for genocide and crimes against humanity for presiding over the massacre of Muslims and Croats at the Keraterm camp in Prijedor.

Serb news media reported that British troops, including members of the SAS, drove up to Mr Sikirica's house in Prijedor at 2.45am in four vehicles. They knocked down the door, forced him to the floor, tied him up and dragged him away. Within hours he was on a flight to the Netherlands.

Since 1997, 21 war crimes suspects have been taken to the Hague for trial, eight of them since October, when George Robertson, the former British defence secretary, became Nato secretary general. He promised to make the arrest of war criminals a priority.

Keraterm ranks alongside Omarska, Trnopolje and Srebrenica as one of the most gruesome massacre sites of the Bosnian war. According to the indictment against Mr Sikirica, more than 3,000 prisoners were held in the abandoned ceramics factory, where they were "killed, sexually assaulted, tortured, beaten and otherwise subjected to cruel and inhuman treatment".

"The overcrowded conditions were extreme, to the extent that on many occasions the detainees could not lie down," it added. "Detainees were fed starvation rations once a day, with little time to eat.

"Severe beatings were commonplace; all manner of weapons were used, including wooden batons, metal rods, baseball bats, lengths of thick industrial cable that had metal balls affixed to the end."

The corpses of detainees were piled next to a garbage area.

In one incident in July 1992, the guards herded 140 inmates into a factory warehouse and mowed them down with machine guns. When they discovered that a few prisoners had somehow survived the massacre and escaped, they selected 20 other prisoners and executed them on the spot, the indictment said.

Twelve camp guards and officials were charged with war crimes alongside Mr Sikirica. Three of them are already in custody. He was indicted for genocide because of his role as camp commander.

"This detention shows the international community has not forgotten one of the most gruesome episodes of the war," the defence secretary, Geoffrey Hoon, and foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said yesterday.

Mr Sikirica is one of the most senior Serb officers from the camps to be arrested as Nato troops start to focus on the higher ranks of the Bosnian Serb authorities. Momcilo Krajisnik, the breakaway republic's deputy leader, was arrested in April.

The wartime Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his military commander, Ratko Mladic, remain at large.

webTitle: Measures to combat child poverty questioned

fields.headline: Measures to combat child poverty questioned
fields.trailText: The government's strategy for eradicating child poverty is challenged today in a report from the Family Policy Studies Centre questioning why many poor families have gained less from Gordon Brown's budgets than middle-income earners.
fields.body:
The government's strategy for eradicating child poverty is challenged today in a report from the Family Policy Studies Centre questioning why many poor families have gained less from Gordon Brown's budgets than middle-income earners.

"The measures introduced by the government so far will lift over 1m children out of poverty, but the extent of child poverty will remain high by postwar and by European standards," the independent thinktank warns.

The report says that only Russia and the US in the industrialised world have higher rates of child poverty; the gap between rich and poor has not narrowed under the present government; almost one-fifth of children (2.2m) live in workless households; the number of children in low income households has trebled in the past 30 years.

It takes issue with two of the government's key measures to help parents into work, suggesting that the New Deal helped only a small percentage of lone parents and the working families tax credit may have reduced employment among married women.

webTitle: Captive tells inside story of Zimbabwe's thugs

fields.headline: Captive tells inside story of Zimbabwe's thugs
fields.standfirst:
Villager reveals how ruling party's gangs terrorised opponents
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: When Kudzi Chamunoro went to the polling station here at the weekend his main aim was not to vote. He wanted to find his wife and family, and with several police officers on hand to guard the voting precinct and a long line of people patiently queuing to cast their ballots in Zimbabwe's parliamentary election he hoped he might be safe.
fields.body:
When Kudzi Chamunoro went to the polling station here at the weekend his main aim was not to vote. He wanted to find his wife and family, and with several police officers on hand to guard the voting precinct and a long line of people patiently queuing to cast their ballots in Zimbabwe's parliamentary election he hoped he might be safe.

Mr Chamunoro used to be district chairman of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change in one of the most tense places in this election campaign - Murehwa North, north-east of Harare. He was beaten unconscious and taken captive on April 25 by a gang working for President Robert Mugabe's party, Zanu-PF.

Remarkably, he was not let go, like other prominent MDC supporters once they have been worked over. He was taken to a base camp and forced to sign a Zanu-PF membership card. Then, he says, for a period of several weeks after his captors felt they had broken him, he was taken with the gangs as they terrorised local villagers.

His inside story of how the intimidation works is unique.

"I was forced to take part myself. I was carrying a whip and axe handle. I was afraid for my life and had to go along.

"I was also taken to four rallies attended by Zanu-PF candidates. Our gang and other Zanu-PF youth forced people to take part. We would go into the villages and round people up."

Another tactic, he said, was to put on MDC T-shirts, "and if people responded positively they would be beaten".

"It's the headman and the older men who are pro-Zanu. They also say that Zanu is the party which won our freedom, and the ancestors will be angry if we don't support it. That seems to affect the older men particularly."

His anxiety visibly rising, Mr Chamunoro wanted to drive right into the school grounds, as close to the voters' queue as we could get. We stopped beside a wall. Neighbours waved in astonishment. Most thought he was dead.

But he was too scared to get out of the car. "I can see some of the Zanu-PF people," he whispered. A neighbour found Mr Chamunoro"s wife in the queue and she came over with their nine-month-old baby, the youngest of their five children.

She greeted him with a warm slapping handshake - the Shona culture not being a demonstrative one - and handed him the baby before getting in the car. A few more people came and chatted before we drove off and parked several hundred metres away while he and his wife discussed what to do.

Of those who had come to greet him, Mr Chamunoro said: "One of them was a member of the Zanu gang. He actually asked how I was...But they think you are armed, which is why they will not do anything."

Naomi Chamunoro said the gang had come several times to their house to search for her husband, most recently the night before the voting began on Saturday. Having seen him now, they were bound to come back. It was unsafe for her to stay.

We drove the three miles towards the family's remote village, parked, crossed the fields and waded through a small river. The Chamunoros grow a little cotton, and vegetables, which Kudzi sells in Harare.

Naomi packed a bag, locked the house, and sent word by a neighbour to her mother, who lives 500 metres away, to look after the girls until their parents' return.

"How long do you think that will be?" I asked as we drove the 50 miles back to Harare.

"If we win, and I am sure we will, we'll have to give them time to get over their anger and adjust to the new reality. Perhaps we can go home already next weekend."

fields.headline: Doctors face more criticism
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Doctors will be warned today to brace themselves for a year of mounting public criticism as the General Medical Council gears up to clear a backlog of cases of alleged professional misconduct.
fields.body:
Doctors will be warned today to brace themselves for a year of mounting public criticism as the General Medical Council gears up to clear a backlog of cases of alleged professional misconduct.

The annual representative meeting of the British Medical Association, opening in London today, will hear that the council is planning to treble its throughput of disciplinary hearings from January.

"Instead of one case a month hitting the headlines, we may well have one a week," said Mac Armstrong, the association's secretary.

The flow of adverse publicity for the profession will be attributed to tighter monitoring of doctors' behaviour, rather than a decline in the general level of competence.

But it will coincide with political pressure from ministers for doctors to accept fundamental changes in their working practices in return for a 35% real terms increase in the NHS budget over the next four years.

Mr Armstrong said today's conference would show that doctors were angry, bruised and cynical about the government's promises of extra NHS funding.

The profession felt unjustly criticised after the recent spate of medical scandals, including the serial killer GP Harold Shipman and disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward.

"I have no doubt you will hear doctors who are battered and angry with the government and media. They are anxious to state publicly that we have 120,000 medical practitioners who are highly compe tent, hardworking, compassionate and dedicated," Dr Armstrong said.

"Inevitably, they will feel bruised by the sustained period of criticism. In recent weeks the tide has begun to turn with ministers stating publicly that doctors do a brilliant job. But that vote of confidence will not have sunk in for the majority of doctors.

"You will detect cynicism about the government's modernisation agenda and any announcement about increased spending." Extra money coming into the NHS had so far done little but pay off past debt.

If the government wanted early improvements, it would create jobs for 150 newly qualified obstetricians who could not find posts as consultants. It would also relieve the shortage of intensive care beds that was a main cause of cancelled admissions for surgery.

Dr Armstrong said the conference was unlikely to pass a motion calling for the disbandment of the GMC, but there would be calls for its reform.

The conference will debate a motion from senior hospital medical staff expressing "no confidence in the GMC as currently constituted and functioning".

 The commission for health improvement will today start a programme of hospital inspections to check on quality and involvement of patients in decisions.

 A Tory government would scrap taxes on workers who sign up to free medical insurance in an attempt to expand private healthcare use, Liam Fox, shadow health secretary, said yesterday on BBC1's On the Record.

fields.headline: 'Teach Britain what democracy is about'
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: As expected, thousands of Zimbabweans turned out to cast their votes. Most of them have long made up their minds about the sort of government they would want.
fields.body:
This is an edited extract from the Sunday Mail, the main pro-government weekly newspaper in Zimbabwe:

As expected, thousands of Zimbabweans turned out to cast their votes. Most of them have long made up their minds about the sort of government they would want.

Strictly speaking, there will not be a change of government after this election, whatever the result is. President Mugabe is not due for re-election until 2002, but the outcome of this weekend's poll will have a bearing on the 2002 poll.

It is therefore important for voters to keep the idea of the government they want in mind. Is it one which on paper is supposed to be a labour-backed government, but in reality driven by employers? One which is openly embraced by our former colonial master? Or do they want a true people's government like the one they elected at independence in 1980 and have continued to do so ever since?

Then there is this direct link and interest of Britain in Zimbabwe. Is it one of a genuine desire to maintain peace and stability or driven by other motives such as an attempt to maintain the status quo where the land and other arms of the economy remain under white control?

As President Mugabe pointed out on Friday, this is an opportunity for Zimbabweans to teach the British what democracy is all about.

The reports that people had been intimidated by the ruling party and would not vote were put to rest by yes terday's turnout. The picture of fear painted by the international media has now been exposed for what it is - a figment of their imagination.

Zanu-PF ideology, which has evolved over years, is reflective of the aspirations of the indigenous blacks. It is a way of thinking that guides the party and is independent of individuals. People come and go but a system is hard to change.

The liberation struggle, which sought to change the evil system advocated by the British colonialists, can testify.

That is why a vote for the MDC, which is trying to bring the colonialists back into power, is very dangerous. An unlikely victory for the MDC will mean a return of white control, making it inevitable for another prolonged bloody struggle to regain our independence.

The electorate should not be swayed by the present economic hardships into believing that dollars, jobs, milk and honey will just fall like manna from heaven by voting for a British-shouldered political party.

The unofficial sanctions imposed on our country by the west were meant to turn the electorate against Zanu-PF. After the elections they will disappear. For it is the west more than us who want to do business with Zimbabwe. The difference is that with Zanu-PF it will be on the Zimbabwe government's terms. With puppets in the mould of the MDC, the exploiters will dictate terms to us.

On this the last day of the poll, let's vote wisely and guard our sovereignty jealously.

fields.headline: Austria expects end to isolation
fields.standfirst:
Compromise is in the air as Vienna looks forward to the prospect of EU sanctions being lifted
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Austrian government is convinced it is close to securing a compromise deal that will lead to the suspension of EU sanctions. It says the sanctions, introduced in February after the dominant People's party invited Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party to join a coalition, have failed.
fields.body:
The Austrian government is convinced it is close to securing a compromise deal that will lead to the suspension of EU sanctions. It says the sanctions, introduced in February after the dominant People's party invited Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party to join a coalition, have failed.

Although they have led to the snubbing of Austrian politicians overseas and the cancellation of tourist trips to Austria, they have proved counter-productive, because the public has united behind the People's party, which is enjoying its highest popularity ratings for 30 years.

Opinion polls show that nine out of 10 Austrians are opposed to sanctions, and the turnout at anti-Haider demonstrations in Vienna is dwindling.

The foreign minister, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, said she believed the deal was doing the rounds of European capitals, being modified as it went along. The compromise involves suspending the sanctions while Austria's immigration policies are investigated.

Her government was disappointed that a solution was not put forward at the EU summit in Portugal last week, but it believed there had been a softening of attitudes.

Sanctions have meant diplomatic isolation. On a visit to London this month, Ms Ferrero-Waldner could not find a single British politician prepared to speak to her.

She hinted that if European governments did not act soon, Austria might disrupt the all-important Nice summit at the end of the year, which is intended to pave the way for enlargement of the EU and fundamentally reform the way it does business.

"It is not a threat. It is the reality," she said.

Since sanctions were imposed Mr Haider has stood down as leader of the Freedom party, though there is scepticism that this was any more than a tactical move, and suspicion that he is still pulling the strings from his regional base.

fields.headline: William Papas
fields.standfirst: Political cartoonist who brought a masterful eye for gentle ridicule to the pages of the Guardian
fields.trailText: William Papas, for many years the Guardian's principal political cartoonist, has drowned following a flying accident in British Columbia at the age of 73. Harold Wilson's political secretary once described one of his cartoons as "the worst blow the Guardian struck against the Labour party".
fields.body:
William Papas, for many years the Guardian's principal political cartoonist, has drowned following a flying accident in British Columbia at the age of 73. Harold Wilson's political secretary once described one of his cartoons as "the worst blow the Guardian struck against the Labour party".

Papas was born in Ermolo, South Africa, to a Greek couple who had emigrated there in the early years of the last century. In 1947, at the age of 20, he came to England to complete his art training at St Martin's and Beckenham colleges. He returned home in 1949 to be faced with the most profound political change since the Boer war.

The 1948 elections had brought the avowedly racist Nationalist party government to power. More or less coinciding with Bill's return came the first of its apartheid laws, the Citizenship Act, which forbade marriage between blacks and whites. As the government unrolled its repressive legislative programme, Bill, not instinctively the most political being, was obliged to sort out his attitudes. He opted to work for two of the principal opposition publications, the Cape Times and Drum magazine.

After six years, with the political climate getting ever more difficult for anyone of liberal views (he was eventually banned by the Pretoria government), Bill decided to try his luck in Britain. Within a year, he was taken on by the Guardian, though it was not the easiest time to join the paper as a political cartoonist. David Low's hugely influential work was still appearing regularly on the leader page and Vicky, who had just joined the Evening Standard, was casting almost as long a shadow.

As Papas slowly found his feet, he developed the habit of button-holing me on the newsdesk at around 4pm each day to mull over topics for his nightly cartoon. As we talked, he would sketch out potential offerings at lightning speed. They rarely, if ever, bore the slightest relation to anything we had discussed, but he clearly needed this contact; sometimes, he would even ring me at home on my day off.

Once the session ended, he would take his preliminary drawings to the duty editor for a final decision. Then, in a windowless hovel off the newsroom, he turned the chosen topic into finished artwork with quite astonishing speed and elan - though we had to be equally fast to spot the spelling mistakes before he shot out of the office.

He was best, of course, on South Africa and Rhodesia but, as he hit his stride, he lashed through the British political and social scene with happy assurance. He was also contributing to the Sunday Times, with which the Guardian shared a building, and to the old Punch magazine. But he was never completely happy with abstract debates on public policy.

He loved to get out to such events as party conferences, where he could pen his wonderfully wounding portraits (many of which are now on the walls of their victims, and some in the National Portrait gallery collection).

This need to get out and about evolved into a series of large and detailed impressions of major cities - Amsterdam, Avignon, Jerusalem. He was the author and illustrator of Instant Hebrew (1979) and People Of Old Jerusalem (1980). In the 1980s and 90s, he produced Papas's America and Papas's Portland. Always a classy entrepreneur, he somehow persuaded the paper to fund poster-sized colour reproductions of these works, which he then marketed through Papas Prints.

In 1967, during the six-day war, I had just got back to Tel Aviv from the Golan Heights, when I saw a familiar figure across the hotel lobby. It was Bill, covered in the dust of Sinai, just back from producing an artist's impressions of the conflict. He was uncharacteristically subdued, having been with an Israeli officer when they encountered some Egyptian stragglers near the Suez Canal. One had been slow to discard his weapon and the Israeli had simply shot him dead. The incident cured Bill of any further ambitions as a war artist.

The following year, we dreamed up a splendid scam, charging off to Finland for a couple of weeks for a words-and-pictures feature about the Laplanders' reindeer round-ups. We did not stop to consider that these events take place in December, and failed to realise that culling reindeer is a highly secretive market operation, which Lapps do not reveal to strangers. We therefore covered most of deep-frozen Lapland on various wild goose chases, and could only console ourselves by thawing out in hotel saunas.

In one, we discussed the claim that Finns roll in the snow to cool off, and Bill prompty rushed into the night to try it for himself. He soon reappeared as a sort of transparent, blue wraith, quite unable to speak. It took 20 minutes to get him back to human form. "No", he stuttered out, "I think it's just one of those stories". But he had to establish that for himself.

It was on the Lapland trip that he also showed his effortless grasp of human nature. He had filled the car boot with booze - totally illegal under Finland's spartan alcohol regulations - and, within days of our arrival, the word was out. Suddenly, the Lapps became extraordinarily friendly and informative as they posed for Bill, sipping great mugs of illicit firewater. Within a couple of days we were wallowing in the gore of one of their supposedly secret reindeer culls.

Back in London, I could sense that Bill was getting restless, and was not surprised when he sold up in 1971 and set sail with his wife, Tessa, for the Greek village his father had left 60 years earlier. Their next 12 years were spent cruising the Aegean, assembling a mammoth collection of watercolour portraits and landscapes. I once stumbled on one of Bill's exhibitions in Chicago to find the gallery full of pictures showing all the old sureness of line and lightness of spirit - at prices a long way beyond my pocket.

In 1985, Bill and Tessa moved to Portland, Oregon, where they established their own gallery. Bill concentrated on book illustration and watercolour paintings. He also mounted exhibitions in such varied locations as the military museum in Khabarovsk, the US Senate, and the Old City museum in Jerusalem. By the time of his death, he had established a secure reputation across the United States.

His wife survives him.

Once the session ended, he would take his preliminary drawings to the duty editor for a final decision. Then, in a windowless hovel off the newsroom, he turned the chosen topic into finished artwork with quite astonishing speed and elan - though we had to be equally fast to spot the spelling mistakes before he shot out of the office. He was best, of course, on South Africa and Rhodesia but, as he hit his stride, he lashed through the British political and social scene with happy assurance. He was also contributing to the Sunday Times, with which the Guardian shared a building, and to the old Punch magazine. But he was never completely happy with abstract debates on public policy. He loved to get out to such events as party conferences, where he could pen his wonderfully wounding portraits (many of which are now on the walls of their victims, and some in the National Portrait gallery collection). This need to get out and about evolved into a series of large and detailed impressions of major cities - Amsterdam, Avignon, Jerusalem. He was the author and illustrator of Instant Hebrew (1979) and People Of Old Jerusalem (1980). In the 1980s and 90s, he produced Papas's America and Papas's Portland. Always a classy entrepreneur, he somehow persuaded the paper to fund poster-sized colour reproductions of these works, which he then marketed through Papas Prints. In 1967, during the six-day war, I had just got back to Tel Aviv from the Golan Heights, when I saw a familiar figure across the hotel lobby. It was Bill, covered in the dust of Sinai, just back from producing an artist's impressions of the conflict. He was uncharacteristically subdued, having been with an Israeli officer when they encountered some Egyptian stragglers near the Suez Canal. One had been slow to discard his weapon and the Israeli had simply shot him dead. The incident cured Bill of any further ambitions as a war artist. The following year, we dreamed up a splendid scam, charging off to Finland for a couple of weeks for a words-and-pictures feature about the Laplanders' reindeer round-ups. We did not stop to consider that these events take place in December, and failed to realise that culling reindeer is a highly secretive market operation, which Lapps do not reveal to strangers. We therefore covered most of deep-frozen Lapland on various wild goose chases, and could only console ourselves by thawing out in hotel saunas. In one, we discussed the claim that Finns roll in the snow to cool off, and Bill prompty rushed into the night to try it for himself. He soon reappeared as a sort of transparent, blue wraith, quite unable to speak. It took 20 minutes to get him back to human form. "No", he stuttered out, "I think it's just one of those stories". But he had to establish that for himself. It was on the Lapland trip that he also showed his effortless grasp of human nature. He had filled the car boot with booze - totally illegal under Finland's spartan alcohol regulations - and, within days of our arrival, the word was out. Suddenly, the Lapps became extraordinarily friendly and informative as they posed for Bill, sipping great mugs of illicit firewater. Within a couple of days we were wallowing in the gore of one of their supposedly secret reindeer culls. Back in London, I could sense that Bill was getting restless, and was not surprised when he sold up in 1971 and set sail with his wife, Tessa, for the Greek village his father had left 60 years earlier. Their next 12 years were spent cruising the Aegean, assembling a mammoth collection of watercolour portraits and landscapes. I once stumbled on one of Bill's exhibitions in Chicago to find the gallery full of pictures showing all the old sureness of line and lightness of spirit - at prices a long way beyond my pocket. In 1985, Bill and Tessa moved to Portland, Oregon, where they established their own gallery. Bill concentrated on book illustration and watercolour paintings. He also mounted exhibitions in such varied locations as the military museum in Khabarovsk, the US Senate, and the Old City museum in Jerusalem. By the time of his death, he had established a secure reputation across the United States. His wife survives him.  William 'Bill' Papas, artist, born 1927; died June 19 2000

webTitle: A fine pen for pricking egos

fields.headline: A fine pen for pricking egos
fields.trailText: Bill Papas was too full of the milk of human kindness to be an excoriating political cartoonist; but that, paradoxically, was the secret of his effectiveness.
fields.body:
Bill Papas was too full of the milk of human kindness to be an excoriating political cartoonist; but that, paradoxically, was the secret of his effectiveness.

He couldn't become over-exercised by the normal evasions and corruption of politics, so his gentle ridicule of a seedy Harold Wilson in the dock, facing a charge of general disillusionment, or his Harold Macmillan, carrying a ruined umbrella and clad in shabby tweeds, indiscriminately blasting game birds out of the sky, were drawings that each said just enough and no more.

When he felt strongly, as over the issue of Ian Smith's declaration of unilateral independence for Rhodesia (independence for the whites, that is), the understated humanity of Papas's drawings made them supreme. One cartoon, ambigously captioned "In civilised hands", simply showed Smith, with a whip, sitting on a heavy garden roller pulled by a barefoot African woman.

Although to begin with on the Manchester Guardian, Papas was matched againstthe heavyweight political cartoonist David Low, his true mentors were to be found in the ranks of English illustrators from Tenniel to Ronald Searle and Paul Hogarth. And in providing illustrations for articles about cities of the world - in those days of restricted newsprint and small papers he would often be given a page to fill - he was at his happiest.

When he left newspapers, it was to this kind of work that he turned so successfully, selling them not for publication but as art works, at first in Greece and then, after 1984, in the United States.

fields.headline: Robert Trent Jones Sr
fields.standfirst: He surveyed the world of golf with an architect's vision
fields.trailText: T he golf course architect Robert Trent Jones Sr, who has died aged 93, left more than 400 designs as a lasting monument to his vision, but just as permanent will be the contribution he made to the public perceptions of his profession. His work graces 43 of the United States courses and those of 34 other countries, ranging from Valderrama, in Sotogrande, Spain, to the new course at Ballybunion in Ireland.
fields.body:
T he golf course architect Robert Trent Jones Sr, who has died aged 93, left more than 400 designs as a lasting monument to his vision, but just as permanent will be the contribution he made to the public perceptions of his profession. His work graces 43 of the United States courses and those of 34 other countries, ranging from Valderrama, in Sotogrande, Spain, to the new course at Ballybunion in Ireland.

Almost single-handedly, he made his occupation a high-profile position. While Dr Alister Mackenzie, CB Macdonald, AW Tillinghast and Donald Ross were greater architects, it was Jones who brought attention and respect to the work.

Jones, explained fellow designer Pete Dye, spread golf architecture around the world, and made paramount the name of the person associated with the course. A tireless self-promoter, he created the "signature hole", one of such unique design or stunning beauty that it could be easily used in publicity material for the layout. He was also the first to consistently push layouts past the 7,000-yard barrier and, much to the dismay of golfers and some fellow architects, introduced the widespread use of earth-moving equipment to build artificial bodies of water and create severely penal hazards.

Known as much for his redesigns - the US Open venues at Oakland Hills in Michigan, Baltusrol in New Jersey, and the Olympic Club in California come to mind - as for his original work, Jones most famously expressed his passion for the water hazard by suggesting to Robert Tyre Jones that Augusta National Golf Club, home of the Masters, could be improved by damming Rae's Creek and creating the spectacular beauty of the pond in front of the par-3 16th hole.

Jones was born in Ince, Cheshire, and his family emigrated to Rochester, New York, when he was five. Growing up there, he was fascinated by watching Donald Ross design Oak Hill Country Club - the site of Europe's victory in the 1995 Ryder Cup - and developed a passion for the game. As a teenager, he was a scratch golfer.

While still a student at Cornell University, New York, in the late 1920s, Jones put together the first formal programme of study for golf course architecture, with ele ments of landscape architecture, agronomy, horticulture, hydrolics, surveying, economics and art. It is a standard of study that still exists today.

He began his career as an assistant to the noted Canadian architect Stanley Thompson, and eventually became his partner. He went on his own after a few years and received a major break when he was hired to build a number of courses by the Work Progress Administration, initiated by President Roosevelt during the great depression to create jobs.

His work with Bobby Jones at Augusta National on No 16 gave his career a great boost; it was because of the similarity in their names that Jones added "Trent" to his, taking the title from the English river.

He gained a greater measure of fame - and infamy - when he redesigned Oakland Hills for the 1951 US Open. The remake was, by all accounts, brutal. Only two rounds in the 60s were posted all week, most famously the 67 by the winner, Ben Hogan, in the final round that prompted the man of few words to say: "I'm glad I brought this course, this monster, to its knees."

Concerned by the increasing ability of the modern player, Jones created longer and more devilishly difficult holes, a habit that brought him a fair amount of criticism. At the same time, he devised extremely long teeing grounds with multiple tees so that lesser players could avoid the hazards.

On a 1952 visit to Baltusrol, site of four US Opens, he was subjected to a harsh attack from a member alleging that the redesigned par-3 fourth hole was too difficult. Jones marched the critic and a few bystanders to the tee, plopped down a ball, took a swing and watched as the ball bounced into the cup for a hole-in-one. "Gentlemen," he said, "I think that the hole is eminently fair."

While some may argue that many of the Jones courses were more difficult than they were memorable, and perhaps tested the limits of what was fair, no man did more to raise the stature of his profession.

Jones is survived by two sons, Rees and Robert.

 Robert Trent Jones Sr, golf course architect, born June 20 1906; died June 14 2000

fields.headline: David Tomlinson
fields.standfirst: Determined actor behind portrayal of endearing fools
fields.trailText: What more than one critic called his art of playing "professional idiots" made David Tomlinson, who has died aged 83, an endearing stage actor and one of the best- remembered faces of the great postwar years of British films. But his popularity extended beyond that era. His bewildered and lugubrious features, full mouth drawn down in harmless but permanent perplexity, helped give him a second career in Hollywood, in films such as Mary Poppins, well after many of his contemporaries had fallen away.
fields.body:
What more than one critic called his art of playing "professional idiots" made David Tomlinson, who has died aged 83, an endearing stage actor and one of the best- remembered faces of the great postwar years of British films. But his popularity extended beyond that era. His bewildered and lugubrious features, full mouth drawn down in harmless but permanent perplexity, helped give him a second career in Hollywood, in films such as Mary Poppins, well after many of his contemporaries had fallen away.

This dispenser of quirky benevolence - he scarcely ever appeared in unsympathetic roles - was born into circumstances that others might have found traumatic. His father was a solicitor of uncertain temper, who once burned his baby son's hand with a domestic iron and who, for years, ran a second, secret household in London from Mondays to Fridays, returning to his wife and children in Folkstone at weekends.

The double domestic situation became known to Tomlinson only when he was an established actor and merely, so he said, irritated by his father's pretences.

After Tonbridge school, and much cinema-going by way of emotional release, he scoured London for theatrical jobs, then, unsuccessfully, joined the Grenadier Guards - he bought himself out 16 months later. His sole theatre credit was in a Folkestone amateur production of Outward Bound, in which, the Folkestone Herald said, he was "a constant source of surprise and wonderment . . . his easy confidence, nonchalant cynicism and expressive gestures conveyed everything necessary for the part, and he won a richly deserved triumph."

Precisely the same might have been written about the whole of Tomlinson's subsequent career, which included more than 50 films. But the effects he brought off were not always as easy as they seemed. The principle that guided his acting was that courage was the vital factor; that an actor should always chance his all in grasping the present moment.

A period as dogsbody in Folkstone rep helped equip him for his first professional, but non-speaking, appearance in JM Barrie's Quality Street. By the time war broke out in 1939, he was appearing in popular light plays like George And Margaret and Quiet Wedding.

The film director Anthony Asquith saw him in the latter and asked him to play the part of Margaret Lockwood's brother John, hopelessly in love with Peggy Ashcroft, in the film version. Though he enlisted in the RAF in 1940, Tomlinson's film and stage career continued to prosper, and he was almost always the unruffled survivor when mighty egos clashed, such as in the postwar The Little Hut, when the star, Robert Morley, was hardly on speaking terms with the director, the 25-year-old Peter Brook.

Building up a steady reputation for playing genial upper-class asses - as in William Douglas Home's The Chiltern Hundreds, in which the son of the Lord becomes a Labour candidate - Tomlinson survived even Peter Sellers, whose human relationships normally fell like ninepins to his inordinate ego. He first appeared with Sellers in the 1957 film, Up the Creek. The relationship continued to one of Sellers's last appearances, in the 1980 production of The Fiendish Plot Of Dr Fu Manchu.

Though he appeared in some of the most distinguished and memorable British films of the postwar years - including The Way To The Stars, Fame Is The Spur, Three Men In A Boat and Tom Jones - fashion changed in the 1960s. It seemed as if Tomlinson might have exhausted the possibilities of playing a breed of Englishmen who increasingly appeared more dangerous than endearing.

Walt Disney, who came to see him in Ring Of Truth at the Savoy theatre, saved the day by asking him to appear as Glynis Johns's husband in the film of Mary Poppins, alongside the umbrella-borne Julie Andrews and the chimney-sweeping Dick Van Dyke. Though Tomlinson himself at first thought the film "a sentimental failure", it earned him an Eddy award and a new career in films appealing chiefly to children. This period covered Bedknobs and Broomsticks and The Love Bug.

Tomlinson is survived by Audrey, his wife of 47 years, and four sons.

webTitle: LAPD sued for acting like gangsters

fields.headline: LAPD sued for acting like gangsters
fields.standfirst: A group working for peace on the streets is seeking an injunction to stop a discredited police unit harassing it
fields.trailText: Audaciously turning the tables, an organisation representing current and former gang members in Los Angeles is seeking an injunction to stop the police bothering its members. It claims that the police have been acting like a gang and have to be restricted in the same way as real gangs.
fields.body:
Audaciously turning the tables, an organisation representing current and former gang members in Los Angeles is seeking an injunction to stop the police bothering its members. It claims that the police have been acting like a gang and have to be restricted in the same way as real gangs.

The move comes at a tense time for the Los Angeles police department. The trials of officers implicated in malpractice in the city's Rampart division have just begun, and the force is under fire for having allowed a riot to develop after the LA Lakers' basketball victory in the city last week.

The injunction is sought by a group called Homies Unidos, which was formed in 1998 to try to get gang members out of the spiral of crime that has claimed hundreds of lives in the past 10 years. The group tries to find work for gang members and help them return to the education system.

Alex Sanchez, a former gang member from El Salvador, is one of the most active members of Homies Unidos. He says he has been frequently stopped and questioned after attending its meetings. He has apparently upset the police by claiming to have an alibi for a teenager accused of murder.

In January Mr Sanchez was arrested as an illegal immigrant and jailed pending deportation. His detention has provoked the anger of his supporters, who include the radical state senator Tom Hayden. Last month they placed a full-page advert in the New York Times urging his release.

"If Alex is deported to El Salvador, the police chief of San Salvador says he'll likely be killed by death squads, who make no distinction between current and former gang members," the advert said.

"In recent month three leaders of Homies Unidos San Salvador [where the group originally started] have been gunned down...Alex keeps people out of prison. Isn't he the kind of person Los Angeles needs?"

Five leading LA lawyers have filed a civil rights case claiming that police from the Rampart division assaulted and harassed members of Homies Unidos. This is a deliberate imitation of a current anti-gang initiative by the police, whereby gang members are served with an injunction which puts them under a local curfew.

One of the lawyers, Paul Hoffman, said: "We want the police to stop acting like gangs," he said.

The action seeks damages against the police on behalf of four Homies Unidos members.

The LAPD would not comment on the case yesterday.

Last year a former Rampart division member, Rafael Perez, who had been arrested for reselling seized drugs, gave information against dozens of his former colleagues in exchange for a five-year jail sentence.

Eighty-one convictions of people arrested by Rampart division officers have now been overturned.

The city is facing many claims for wrongful arrest, totalling millions of dollars. Perez's revelations have led to the disbandment of the police anti-gang unit, Community Resources Against Street Hoodlums, (Crash). A replacement unit is being assembled.

"They say Crash was dissolved, but its officers are still working the same neighbourhoods," said the founder of Homies Unidos, Magdaleno Rose-Avila.

"You can call a doberman pinscher a chihuahua, but it's still a doberman pinscher."

Mr Hayden, who has been involved in a number of peace talks between rival gangs in LA, said: "He [Alex] and Homies Unidos were trying to save lives."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Kosovo Serbs back in power
fields.body:
Kosovo Serbs back in power

Moderate Kosovo Serbs are to resume cooperation with ethnic Albanians and UN representatives by returning to the interim UN-controlled government of the province.

The decision depends on the implementation of UN commitments to send anti-terrorist police to Serb areas targeted by ethnic Albanian extremists and to admit more Serbs to the Albanian-dominated Kosovo police force.

"Cooperation is the only way to improve the lot of the Serbian people," a key moderate, Father Sava Janjiche, said. AP, Gracanica

Car bomb injures seven

A car bomb exploded in a wealthy residential area of a small Basque town yesterday, injuring seven people.

An anonymous phone caller said the Basque separatist group ETA claimed responsibility for the blast in Getxo, 12 miles east of Bilbao. The caller told the regional newspaper Gara that the attack was aimed at "the oligarchy". AP, Getxo

Island captors free Malaysian

Muslim guerrillas have freed a Malaysian hostage held with 20 other captives on the Philippine island of Jolo, as a gesture of goodwill. No ransom was paid.

The rebels still hold three Germans, two French, two Finns, two South Africans, a Lebanese, eight Malaysians and two Filipinos they seized on April 23 from the Malaysian diving resort of Sipadan and took to Jolo by boat. AP, Manila

fields.headline: Chirac backs Germany's EU vision
fields.trailText: President Jacques Chirac of France, who arrived on state visit to Germany yesterday, will endorse the substance of recent German proposals for more and faster European integration, officials indicated.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Berlin and Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
President Jacques Chirac of France, who arrived on state visit to Germany yesterday, will endorse the substance of recent German proposals for more and faster European integration, officials indicated.

Mr Chirac's visit revives the possibility of a pact between Paris and Berlin to set up a two-speed Europe in which Britain would be left among the laggards. Such a deal would challenge the claims of Tony Blair's government that Labour has put Britain back at the heart of Europe. It could also add pressure for a British rethink on staying out of the European single currency, the euro.

But diplomats in Paris also made it clear that the call for a big new push on integration made last month by the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, went well beyond what Mr Chirac would like. France simply could not afford to be left behind in initiatives shaping the future, they said.

"France has to be seen to be in there with Germany building a bigger and better Europe," a western diplomat said. "Chirac's speech will have to be a part of that effort."

On Thursday, two days after Mr Chirac leaves Berlin, Mr Blair is due in the capital for a dinner with the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. Its purpose has yet to be explained.

A spokesman for Mr Chirac said his address tomorrow to the lower house of the German parliament, the Bundestag, would be "a big speech, a major political statement on the president's longer-term vision for Europe".

He added: "It is very important that the president contributes to, expresses and underlines the common approach that France and Germany are developing towards the big European issues - issues that go well beyond France's six-month presidency."

Paris takes over the rotating presidency of the European Union at the end of the week. Its main task will be to secure a successful outcome to the current intergovernmental conference (IGC) on reform of the EU to prepare it for the addition of new member states.

The Elysée spokesman's remarks picked up the very words used in recent German initiatives. Last month Mr Fischer urged the EU to look at "the long term, far beyond the current intergovernmental conference".

The union's ultimate aim, he argued, should be a European federation complete with its own government and parliament. The trail would need to be blazed, he said, by a vanguard of states able and willing to push on with political integration.

Last week the Mr Schröder threw his weight behind this proposal, while introducing new elements designed to safeguard the clout of Germany's powerful states.

Through officials, he signalled the need for a new IGC to tackle the "big issues".

This could be launched in 2003 or 2004, once the current round of proposed changes are ratified by the parliaments of member states. The conference, in the Schröder-Fischer vision, would draft a new constitution for the EU and redistribute power between regional, national and EU institutions.

Mr Chirac's spokesman said: "It should be clear to everyone by now that for the past couple of months the Franco-German motor has been turning again at full speed".

Mr Chirac has a record of caution over Europe, but he is under pressure to make a bold move. He and his advisers are already looking ahead to the 2002 presidential election, and one of their difficulties is that his probable opponent, the prime minister Lionel Jospin, has repeatedly encroached on territory traditionally regarded as "presidential". A noteworthy speech to German MPs would enable him to recover some ground.

As a Gaullist, Mr Chirac is hesitant about European integration because of the threat a federation could pose to the survival of France's national identity. But Mr Fischer argued in his speech for a future political union in which the nation states would be the key component. That has given the president some room to manoeuvre.
